    There is hereby created the department of accounts and finances, a principal department of the city. This department shall consist of the commissioner of accounts and finances, city treasurer, director of finance, director of planning and community development, and director of inspections and facilities, their respective offices and departments, all officers and assistants and employees herein, all clerical employees in the city municipal building, and all bookkeepers, accountants and inspectors assigned thereto. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 4187, § 9, 9-16-14; Ord. No. 4276 , § 2, 4-19-16) 
1-4-1.2. - Function. 
    It shall be the function of the department of accounts and finances to: 
(a)  Insure that the various officers and/or departments of the city prepare and maintain proper accounts and records and make periodic reports insofar as the accounts and records of the city are concerned; 
(b)  Make periodic audits at frequent intervals of the accounts and records of the officers and employees of the city who may receive or disburse money, and make provision for the annual audit required by statute; 
(c)  Inspect all accounts or records required to be kept in any of the offices or departments of the city insofar as the accounts and finances of the city are concerned; 
(d)  Examine all bills, accounts, payrolls, demands and claims and prepare reports concerning the same for submission to the council before they are acted upon, unless otherwise provided by statute or ordinance; 
(e)  Provide for the collection of all claims, demands, license fees, inspection fees, franchise taxes, fines, penalties, forfeitures, rentals or money which may be due the city, except as otherwise provided for by statute or ordinance; 
(f)  Report to the council any failure to make a report, or to pay moneys due the city; 
(g)  Insure that every officer or employee having care or custody of the funds of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, give bond to the city, with good and sufficient sureties, and in such amount as may be required by statute or ordinance; 
(h)  Exercise general supervision and control over all matters insofar as the accounts and records of the city are concerned subject to the statutes and ordinances of the state and city and resolutions of the city council; 
(i)  Prepare a proposed budget itemizing expenditures to be met by the city in the coming fiscal year, such proposed budget to be submitted to the council not later than the last regular meeting of the council in May of the current fiscal year; 
(j)  The enforcement of all city ordinances and provisions of this Code relating to the construction, alteration, repair, maintenance or use of buildings, structures and premises within the city, or relating to real property or to the public health within the city; and shall make or cause to be made all inspections necessary for that purpose; 
(k)  The approval and certification of all plans and specifications submitted in connection with any application or request for any permit to build, erect, construct, remodel, alter, install or repair any structure or equipment within the city as provided for in this Code, except where otherwise specified; and 
(l)  Administer programs, projects and activities that focus on improving neighborhoods, regulating land uses for orderly growth and development, increasing economic activity, and fostering new residential, commercial and industrial growth. 
(1970 Code; Ord. 1336, 3-1-77; Ord. No. 4187, § 9, 9-16-14) 
Cross reference- Bonds required; approval; amounts; place of filing, etc., §1-9-6 et seq. 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of council, departments, 65 ILCS 5/4-5-2; audit of accounts, 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq. 
1-4-1.3. - Commissioner. 
    The commissioner of accounts and finances shall have and exercise supervision over and direction of all accounts and finances of the city, and shall have charge of and supervision and direction over all records of the city and all other officers, boards and departments insofar as accounts and records of the city are concerned. He shall be responsible for the carrying out of those functions assigned to the department of accounts and finances and shall report to the council the results of such audits, inspections and examinations which may be required by statute or ordinance, together with such recommendations as he shall see fit to make. He shall have and exercise supervision and direction over all officers and employees assigned to the department of accounts and finances. 
1-4-2. - CITY TREASURER 
1-4-2.1. - Creation of office; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of city treasurer, an executive office of the city. The treasurer shall be appointed by the city council. 
State Law reference- Establishment of certain offices, 65 ILCS 5/4-5-4. 
1-4-2.2. - Duties. 
    The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid to the city, either directly from the person paying it or from the hands of such other officer as may receive it, and he shall pay out only on vouchers or warrants properly signed by the city clerk and the mayor. 
State Law reference- Duties of municipal treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-1; treasurer duties, 65 ILCS 5/4-5-22. 
1-4-2.3. - Deposit of funds; records. 
(a)  The treasurer shall deposit the city funds in such depositories as provided in section 1-8-1.4 of this Code; he shall keep the city money separate and distinct from his own, and shall not intermingle his own money with or make private or personal use of city funds. 
(b)  The treasurer shall keep such records showing all money received by him, the source from which it was received and the purpose for which it was paid out; and he shall keep a record showing at all times the financial status of the city. 
1-4-2.4. - Accounts; reports; register of warrants. 
(a)  The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by the council, and shall keep them in the manner required by law. 
(b)  The treasurer shall make monthly reports to the council showing the state of the finances of the city, and the amounts received and spent during the month, which reports shall be filed. And he shall make an annual report at the close of the fiscal year with the total amount of all receipts and expenditures of the city and his transactions during the preceding year. 
(c)  The treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed with him or paid by him, and all vouchers, as is required by law. 
1-4-2.5. - Appeal to finance committee. 
    See section 1-4-3.9 of this chapter. 
1-4-3. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, adopted Apr. 19, 2016, amended § 1-4-3 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 1-4-3, §§ 1-4-3.1-1-4-3.9 was entitled "City Comptroller", and derived from: Code 1970; and Ord. No. 4187, § 10, adopted Sept. 16, 2014. 
1-4-3.1. - Appointment. 
    A director of finance shall be appointed by the commissioner of accounts and finances with the advice and consent of the council. The director of finance shall be an employee of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.2. - Duties, generally as director of department. 
    The director of finance shall: 
(a)  Establish, organize and keep all accounts of the city government; 
(b)  Prepare, under the direction of the council and city treasurer, the annual budget, which shall constitute his report of estimates required by law to be submitted to the council; 
(c)  Prepare and submit to the council such financial statements and reports as the council may require; 
(d)  Pre-audit all revenues in order to insure the receipt and deposit of all sums due the city; 
(e)  Pre-audit all expenditures in order to prevent expenditures in excess of budget appropriations and in order to prevent illegal and irregular expenditures; 
(f)  Conduct special studies and investigations into the financial affairs of the city departments whenever he deems it advisable; 
(g)  Collect or supervise the collection of all moneys belonging to the city from all sources, except real and personal taxes and from other governmental jurisdictions; and 
(h)  Such additional duties as the council may by ordinance or resolution confer upon him. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.3. - Ex officio collector. 
    The director of finance shall be ex officio city collector, unless such office shall be duly filled by appointment, and he shall, in addition to all duties vested in the city collector by statute, perform the following duties: 
(a)  Collect and receive all money due on special assessments and special taxes that are not paid directly to the city treasurer, and to keep such records pertaining to such collections as may be required by statute or ordinance; 
(b)  Make such reports regarding delinquent special assessments as are required by statute, and shall make a monthly report to the council, showing what money has been received and the source thereof; 
(c)  Preserve all warrants returned to him; 
(d)  Keep such books and accounts as the council may direct; 
(e)  Keep all warrants, books, vouchers and papers pertaining to the office of collector open for the inspection of the mayor, or any member or committee of the council; 
(f)  Once each week, or more often if required by the council the comptroller shall pay over to the treasurer all money collected by him as city collector from any source whatsoever; 
(g)  At the close of the fiscal year the comptroller shall place on file with the council a statement of all money collected by him during the year, the particular warrant or special assessment or account on which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants in his possession, and the balance remaining on all warrants during the preceding fiscal year, and he shall cause such statement to be published by the city clerk as provided by statute; and 
(h)  Make such additional reports to the council of the city's financial status as the council may request or require by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.4. - Supervisory powers. 
    The director of finance shall have supervision over all officers and employees of the city charged in any manner with the receipt, collection or disbursement of the city revenue, or with the collection and return of the city revenue into the treasury. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.5. - Compensation as city collector. 
    The director of finance shall not receive or be entitled to, because of being ex officio city collector, any remuneration other than that fixed by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.6. - Estimate of expenses. 
    On or before May 15 of each year and before the annual appropriation ordinance is prepared, the director of finance shall submit to the council a report of his estimate, as nearly as may be, of the money necessary to defray the expenses of the city during the current fiscal year. For the purpose of making this report he shall require all officers of the city to submit statements of the condition and expenses of their offices or departments, and any proposed improvements and the estimated expense thereof, a statement of all unperformed contracts, and the amount of all unexpended appropriations of the preceding year. 
    His report shall also: 
(a)  Classify the objects and purposes of such estimated expenditures and the amounts required for each; 
(b)  Show the aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year, from all sources; 
(c)  Show the amount of liability on which interest is to be paid; 
(d)  Show the bonds and debts due and payable and the dates when such are due and payable; and 
(e)  Give such other information regarding the financial situation of the city as the council may require. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.7. - Documents. 
    The director of finance shall have custody and control of such city documents, books and papers as the council may require him by ordinance to keep. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-3.8. - Bonds; special assessments. 
(a)  The director of finance shall keep in his office, in books used solely for that purpose, a correct list of all the outstanding bonds of the city, showing the number and amount of each, and for whom and to whom the bonds were issued. He shall also show therein when any city bonds are purchased, paid or cancelled. He shall show in his annual report the bonds sold during the year, the terms of such sale and every item of expense incurred therewith. 
(b)  The director of finance shall keep all money received on any special assessment in a separate fund, to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and the money shall be used for no other purposes, except to reimburse the city for money expended for such improvement. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 3, 4-19-16) 
1-4-4. - DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4187, § 11, adopted Sept. 19, 2014, amended § 1-4-4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former 1-4-4, §§ 1-4-4-1-4-4.15, pertained to the department of planning and zoning, and derived from: 1970 Code; Ord. No. 1336, adopted Mar. 1, 1977; Ord. No. 2549, adopted Dec. 17, 91; Ord. No. 3292, § 3, adopted July 3, 2001; and Ord. No. 3863, § 1, adopted Apr. 14, 2009. 
1-4-4.1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the department of planning and community development, an executive department of the city. This department shall consist of the director of planning and community development, the planning and zoning administrator, and such other inspectors and employees assigned thereto. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 11, 9-16-14) 
1-4-4.2. - Director; office created, appointment, bond. 
    There is hereby created the office of the director of planning and community development, an office of the city. The director shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall hold office for an indefinite term and until a successor is appointed and qualified. 
    The director shall be general superintendent over the department of planning and community development, and shall post bond in the manner prescribed for other city officers. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 11, 9-16-14) 
1-4-4.3. - Director; qualifications. 
    The person appointed to fill the office of director of planning and community development shall be of good moral character and capable of competently carrying out the obligations imposed upon him pursuant to the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 11, 9-16-14) 
1-4-4.4. - Director; duties and powers. 
    The director of planning and community development shall: 
(a)  Encourage existing, expanding, or newly created business enterprises to locate their facilities within the corporate limits of the city; 
(b)  Make suggestions concerning the public improvements which may, if undertaken, serve to attract business enterprises to the city; 
(c)  Recommend changes in policy which, if implemented, might serve to improve the business climate within the city; 
(d)  Coordinate the economic development efforts of the various departments and representatives of the city; 
(e)  Have supervision and control over all employees assigned to the department of planning and community development; 
(f)  Have supervision and control over the Administrator of the East Peoria Housing Authority; 
(g)  Shall hold ex officio each position in the department of planning and community development which is not otherwise filled by appointment of the city council; 
(h)  Cooperate with and assist the city administrator in the implementation of programs and projects undertaken by the city administrator; 
(i)  Serve as zone administrator for the East Peoria Enterprise Zone; 
(j)  Provide professional planning and land use advice to supervisors and other officials; 
(k)  Supervise the evaluation of land use proposals for conformity to established plans and ordinances; 
(l)  Provide staff support to the city's planning commission, zoning board of appeals, designated zone organization, and other boards and commissions related to land use; 
(m)  Serve as the city's zoning administrator. The duties of the zoning administrator shall be: 
(i)  Maintain the city's zoning ordinances, including providing recommendations to the city council for amendments; 
(ii)  Conduct technical reviews and site inspections; 
(iii)  Make staff reports to the planning commission and zoning board of appeals on specific project proposals, including, but not limited to, special use permit applications, text amendments, zoning amendments, variances and subdivisions; 
(iv)  Any other duties as otherwise provided for in the city Code. 
(n)  Serve as the city's flood zone administrator; 
(o)  Manage the subdivision process within the city; 
(p)  Ensure that all subdivisions and annexations meet the requirements of section 8 of title 4, chapter 13; 
(q)  Ensure that all requested variances meet the requirements of section 10 of title 4, chapter 13, and maintain documentation of any variances granted; 
(r)  Notify the Illinois Department of Natural Resources Office of Water Resources and any neighboring communities prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse; 
(s)  Cooperate with state and federal floodplain management agencies to coordinate base flood data and to improve the administration of title 4, chapter 13; and 
(t)  Maintain and make available for public inspection base flood data, floodplain maps, copies of state and federal permits, and documentation of compliance for development activities subject to title 4, chapter 13. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 11, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5. - DEPARTMENT OF BUILDINGS AND INSPECTIONS 
1-4-5.1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the department of buildings and inspections, an executive department of the city. This department shall consist of the director of buildings and inspections, the electrical and plumbing inspectors, the code enforcement officer(s), and such other employees assigned thereto. Any reference elsewhere in this Code to the "department of inspections" shall be deemed to be a reference to the department of buildings and inspections, and any reference to this Code to the "city inspector" shall be deemed to be a reference to the director of buildings and inspections. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14; Ord. No. 4199 , § 1, 2-2-16) 
1-4-5.2. - Director; office created, appointment, bond. 
    There is hereby created the office of the director of buildings and inspections, an office of the city. The director shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council and shall hold office for an indefinite term and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
    The director shall be general superintendent over the department of buildings and inspections. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.3. - Director; qualifications. 
    The person appointed to fill the office of director of buildings and inspections shall be of good moral character and capable of competently carrying out the obligations imposed upon him pursuant to the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.4. - Director; duties and powers. 
    The director of buildings and inspections shall: 
(a)  Enforce all provisions of the building, electrical, plumbing, zoning, minimum housing, and health regulations of the city, and all statutes and other ordinances of the city relating to the same subject matter; he shall make or cause to be made all inspections necessary for this purpose; 
(b)  Have the power to cause any construction, installation or repair work, and electrical, water, heat and fuel flow, or any other activity within the city to be stopped whenever he finds existing a violation of any statute, provision of this Code, or other ordinances of the city; 
(c)  Oversee programs that increase efficiencies of city facilities and coordinate municipal aggregation programs; 
(d)  Keep accurate and permanent records and amounts of all certificates and permits issued, inspections made, and moneys or fees collected under the authority of this Code; and he shall make a monthly report of the activities of his department to the commissioner of accounts and finances; 
(e)  Have supervision and control over all inspectors and employees assigned to the department of buildings and inspections; 
(f)  Be responsible for inspection of existing buildings and structures and those being erected or altered, as frequently as may be necessary, and for the approval of plans and specifications relating thereto, for the purpose of enforcing compliance with structural, fire and related safety regulations and requirements as provided for by statute, this Code or other ordinances of the city; 
(g)  Issue a certificate of inspection to the owner or person in control of any premises which he has inspected, or a certificate of approval to the person submitting any plans or specifications to him only where he finds that the structure, work or plans therein fully complies with state statute, this Code and other ordinances of the city; 
(h)  Enforce the provisions of the building regulations, keep an accurate and permanent record and account of all activities, permits, moneys or fees collected and received thereunder, the name of the person on whose account and for what purpose the same were paid, the date and location of the subject of the permit; 
(i)  Perform such other duties necessary and incidental to the performance of his office, and as may be assigned to him from time to time by the mayor or the council; 
(j)  Other business. It shall be unlawful for the code enforcement administrator, except in the performance of his duties, to engage in the business of construction, alteration or sale of building material or building equipment, either directly or indirectly, and he shall have no financial interest whatsoever in any concern engaged in any such business; 
(k)  Maintain and make available for public inspection base flood data, floodplain maps, copies of state and federal permits, and documentation of compliance for development activities subject to title 4, chapter 13; and 
(l)  Cooperate with and assist the city administrator in the implementation of programs and projects undertaken by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.5. - Electrical inspector; office created, appointment. 
    An electrical inspector shall be appointed by the director of buildings and inspections. He shall hold office for an indefinite term and until his successor is appointed and qualified. The electrical inspector shall be directly responsible to the director of buildings and inspections. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.6. - Electrical inspector; qualifications. 
    The person appointed to fill the office of electrical inspector shall be licensed in the State of Illinois as an electrician. He shall have had at least five (5) years' experience as a journeyman in the practice of his trade or three (3) years' training in a recognized college of electrical engineering and, in addition thereto, at least two (2) years of practical experience in electrical construction, and shall be well versed in approved methods of electrical construction for safety to life and property as adopted by this Code, the Statutes of the State of Illinois relating to electrical work and the rules, the National Electrical Code, and regulations issued by the Fire Marshal of the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.7. - Electrical inspector; duties and powers. 
(a)  The electrical inspector shall enforce all provisions of the electrical regulations of the city, and all statutes and other ordinances of the city relating to electrical construction, installation, repair or maintenance. He shall make or cause to be made all inspections necessary for this purpose. 
(b)  He shall have the power to cause the electrical current in any wire, conduit or circuit to be turned off, whenever this is necessary for the protection of life, limb or property. 
(c)  He shall issue a certificate of approval to the owner or person in control of premises which he has inspected where he finds that the electrical installation and wiring therein fully comply with the provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.8. - Plumbing inspector. 
(a)  A plumbing inspector shall be appointed by the director of buildings and inspections. He shall hold office for an indefinite term or until his successor is appointed. He shall be directly responsible to the director of buildings and inspections. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall enforce all city ordinances and provisions of this Code relating to plumbing installations, alterations, repairs and equipment. He shall make all inspections necessary for this purpose. 
(c)  He shall have the power to cause the flow of water in any pipe, conduit or gutter to be turned off whenever this is necessary for the protection of life, limb or property. 
(d)  He shall issue a certificate of approval to the owner or person in control of the premises which he has inspected where he finds the plumbing installations therein fully comply with the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.9. - Inspection; entry powers. 
    The director of buildings and inspections and any authorized inspector or agent thereunder, shall have the power during reasonable hours, and upon showing of proper identification, to make or cause to be made an entry into any private building or premises within the city for the purpose of making an inspection or test in the discharge of his official duties; provided, however, that no inspection of an occupied dwelling shall occur without the consent of a resident, tenant, or lawful occupant residing therein unless an administrative search warrant is first obtained. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.10. - Stop order; penalty. 
(a)  Whenever the director of buildings and inspections or any authorized inspector or agent thereunder shall find any work, operation, activity or usage being conducted in violation of any statute, provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city, he shall have the power to order such activity stopped until such provision is complied with. 
(b)  Every stop order issued shall be served upon or communicated to any person engaged in or responsible for causing such work to be done; provided, however, that where such stop order is made orally it shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour, signed by the director or any commissioner. 
(c)  Every stop order shall be served by an agent of the department of buildings and inspections or any city police officer, and if any such person to be served is not readily found, then such notice may be served by posting a "STOP NOTICE" upon the premises in some conspicuous place. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to continue any such activity after a stop order has been issued and served, except upon written permission of the council or of the director of buildings and inspections. 
(e)  Any person violating the preceding subsection shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 12, 9-16-14) 
1-4-5.11. - Code enforcement officers. 
(a)  Code enforcement officers shall be appointed by the commissioner of accounts and finance. A code enforcement officer shall be directly responsible to the director of buildings and inspections. 
(b)  Code enforcement officers shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Enforce all provisions of the building, minimum housing, and health regulations of the city, and all statutes and other ordinances of the city relating to the same subject matter; 
(2)  Inspect existing buildings and structures and those being erected or altered for the purpose of enforcing compliance as provided for by statute, this Code or other ordinances of the city; 
(3)  Respond to complaints of potential violations of this Code; 
(4)  Maintain records related to inspection and enforcement activities; 
(5)  Appear as a witness whenever necessary for violation of an ordinance or of any state statute; 
(6)  Such other powers and duties as provided for by ordinance or as assigned by the director of buildings and inspections. 
(c)  In addition to those duties and powers prescribed in section 1-4-5.4, a code enforcement officer shall be a conservator of the peace and shall have the power to make arrests for violations of the Code and to exercise all other powers authorized by state law or as prescribed by ordinance, but only after completing the state-certified basic law enforcement training and firearms training pursuant to or otherwise obtaining a waiver of such training from the Illinois Police Training Act and Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board. Except as otherwise permitted by state law, a code enforcement officer who is qualified as a conservator of the peace shall only be permitted to carry a firearm during the performance of his duties. Further, the director of building and inspections may rescind a code enforcement officer's ability to carry a firearm during the performance of his duties with or without cause. 
(d)  A code enforcement officer shall conduct himself in a proper, law-abiding manner at all times and avoid the use of unnecessary force. A code enforcement officer shall generally abide by the firearms and use of force policies established by the East Peoria Police Department Policy Manual, and such other rules or policies as may be established by the director of buildings and inspections from time to time. However, a code enforcement officer who is qualified as a conservator of the peace shall not be considered to be a member of the police department. 
(e)  A code enforcement officer who is qualified as a conservator of the peace shall, at all times during the course of his duties, carry proper identification indicating he is a conservator of the peace and is certified as a conservator of the peace by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board. 
(Ord. No. 4199 , § 2, 2-2-16) 
CHAPTER 5. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY 
SECTION: 

1-5-1. - IN GENERAL 
1-5-1.1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a department of health and safety, a principal department of the city. This department shall consist of the commissioner of public health and safety, city fire and ambulance departments, and all officers and employees assigned thereto. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 13, 9-16-14) 
1-5-1.2. - Function. 
    The function of the department of public health and safety shall be to: 
(1)  Protect lives and property from the hazards of fire, accidents and natural disasters; 
(2)  Maintain an efficient, highly motivated corps of fire officers and persons trained and equipped to carry out their respective and mutual duties toward the public; and 
(3)  Promote the integration and co-ordination of the city's police and fire functions to the highest degree possible consistent with operational and economic efficiency. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 13, 9-16-14) 
1-5-1.3. - Commissioner. 
    The commissioner over the department of public health and safety shall have charge, supervision and direction over all officers and employees assigned thereto. He shall be generally responsible for carrying out those functions assigned by statute or ordinance to the department of public health and safety and shall report to the city council as to the affairs of said department, making such recommendations as he deems necessary or desirable for the efficient operation thereof. 
1-5-1.4. - Rules of board of fire and police commissioners. 
    The fire department shall be subject to all the lawful rules and regulations promulgated by the board of fire and police commissioners of the city governing employment and disciplining of department members. 
(Ord. 1336, 3-1-77) 
1-5-2. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
1-5-2.1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created an executive department of the city which shall be known as the fire department. This department shall consist of the fire chief, not more than two (2) deputy fire chiefs and such number of assistant fire chiefs and such number of lieutenants, and such number of captains, and such number of firemen as may be determined from time to time by the mayor and the council by resolution. 
(Ord. 1634, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.2. - Function. 
    The fire department, under the supervision of the fire chief, shall: 
(1)  Prevent fires from starting and spreading through inspection or other means; 
(2)  Assure the maintenance of all devices for controlling fires and responding to accidents and natural disasters; 
(3)  Combat fires within the city, and under mutual aid arrangements; 
(4)  Enforce statutes and ordinances relating to fires, fire prevention and medical emergencies; 
(5)  Investigate fires and maintain proper records of fires and matters relating thereto; 
(6)  Attend to matters of rescue as usually conducted by fire and ambulance departments of surrounding communities; and 
(7)  With the consent of the commissioner of public health and safety, carry on the functions of firefighting and rescue outside of the city. 
(Ord. 1336, 3-1-77; Ord. No. 4187, § 14, 9-16-14) 
1-5-2.3. - Fire chief; office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of fire chief, an executive office of the city. The fire chief shall perform the functions and duties delegated in this chapter and elsewhere in this city Code to the fire chief. 
(Ord. 1848, 2-16-82; Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.4. - Duties of the fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall: 
(1)  Be the commanding officer of the fire department and shall have control of the assignment of all members of the department and direction of fire work in the city; 
(2)  Have control and custody and be responsible for the care and maintenance of all apparatus and equipment belonging to the fire department; 
(3)  Keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings of the company and the attendance of the members, a record of all fires, and such other records concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or by the city council; 
(4)  Be responsible generally for the performance of the fire department; 
(5)  The fire chief may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the hours of duty, vacations, uniforms, maintenance of the fire department and conduct of the members thereof as he shall deem advisable; provided, that such rules and regulations shall not be in conflict with any order of the city council or the rules and regulations of the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Ord. 1336, 3-1-77; Ord. 1780, 5-12-81) 
1-5-2.5. - Deputy fire chief, office created. 
    There is hereby created the position of deputy fire chief, an administrative rank in the fire department. Not more than two (2) persons may occupy the rank of deputy fire chief at any one time. Deputy fire chiefs shall be appointed by the city council. Deputy chiefs shall perform such duties as from time to time determined by the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, adopted Sept. 20, 2016 added new provisions designated as § 1-5-2.5 as herein set out above, and further renumbered existing §§ 1-5-2.5-1-5-2.21 accordingly. 
1-5-2.6. - Assistant fire chief; office created. 
    There is hereby created the position of assistant fire chief, an executive office in the city. 
(1)  The position of assistant fire chief is a managerial position. 
(2)  As a condition of acceptance of the position of the assistant fire chief, the candidate shall agree to assume managerial responsibilities and to terminate all activity in the union which represents other fire department personnel. Such union activity shall include the payment of union dues. 
(3)  An Assistant Fire Chief of the East Peoria Fire Department shall not be a member of the bargaining unit within the terms of the contract between the city and the union representing other fire department personnel. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.7. - Duties of assistant fire chief. 
    The duties of an assistant fire chief shall be as defined by the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.8. - Lieutenant; office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of lieutenant. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.9. - Duties of a lieutenant. 
    The duties of a lieutenant shall be as defined by the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. 1634, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.10. - Appointments. 
    Members of the fire department (other than the fire chief and the deputy fire chiefs), after examination, shall be appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners and promotion shall be made in the same manner, as provided by statute and by rules adopted by the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Ord. 1561, 6-12-79; Ord. 1634, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.11. - Bonds. 
    Each fireman hereafter employed or re-employed shall give and execute a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to be approved by the city council, and filed with the clerk, which said bond shall be conditioned to pay any damages resulting from the failure of the appointee to property perform his duty. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
Cross reference- Bonds required; approval; amounts; place of filing, etc., § 1-9-6 et seq. 
1-5-2.12. - Entering firehouse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the fire department house or any place where the equipment and fire apparatus is stored, at any time, except on business pertaining to the fire department or other city business. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.13. - Use of fire alarm system. 
    No person, except a person connected with the management of the same, shall open any signal box of the fire alarm system of the city unless it be for the purpose of giving, in good faith, an alarm of fire; nor shall any person break, cut, injure, deface, derange or in any manner interfere with the fire alarm system or any of its appliances. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.14. - False fire alarms; reward. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make or give any false alarm or false cry of fire. 
    A reward of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be offered by the fire chief for information leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person who turns in such false alarms or request for assistance in the city. The fire chief is hereby authorized for and on behalf of the city council to offer such reward whenever such false alarm or request is turned in. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
State Law reference- False fire alarm as element of disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1. 
1-5-2.15. - False rescue squad alarms; reward. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make or give any false alarm or request for assistance to the rescue squad of the fire department. 
    A reward of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be offered by the fire chief for information leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person who turns in such false alarms or requests for assistance in the city. The fire chief is hereby authorized for and on behalf of the city council to offer such reward whenever such false alarm or request is turned in. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.16. - Vehicles obstructing street in vicinity of fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any motor vehicle or other vehicle to obstruct any street or alley at any point in the vicinity of a fire. When directed by any police officer or member of the fire department, the person in control of such vehicle shall immediately move it to such place as will relieve such obstruction. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.17. - Running vehicles over fire department equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle, locomotive or railroad car on, over or across any ladder, fire hose or other equipment of the fire department without authority from any fireman. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.18. - Interfering with firemen, equipment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully interfere with or offer any hindrance to any fireman in the performance of his duty at a fire. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully interfere with or disturb any equipment or apparatus of the fire department, without authority from any fireman. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.19. - Duties of spectators; authority of firemen. 
(a)  Every person who shall be present at a fire shall be subject to the order of the fire chief or assistant chief or fire captain with respect to extinguishing the fire and the removal and protection of property; provided, that no person not a member of the fire department shall be bound to obey any such officer unless such officer shall bear his respective badge of office, or unless his official status shall be known or made known to such person; and such officer shall have power of arrest for failure to obey the lawful order of such officer as aforesaid. 
(b)  Firemen while on duty at fires shall protect persons and property from damage, loss or injury, and shall have authority to direct spectators away from the scene of danger or where firemen are working, to prevent injury to persons or property. Firemen, while attending any fire or while on fire call, either in response to or returning from a fire, shall be vested with police powers and shall have authority, under the officer in charge, to arrest any person wilfully refusing to obey any lawful order of the department or the officer in charge, or violating any provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.20. - Fire hydrants; authorized use, obstructing. 
(a)  No fire hydrant in the city shall be used by any person other than by a member of the fire department or other authorized city employee, without having first secured permission therefor from the fire chief. 
(b)  The use of any wrenches other than those especially made for the purpose of opening or shutting any fire hydrant is prohibited. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any fire hydrant in the city, or to place or deposit any lumber, rock, sand, debris or other substance within ten (10) feet of any such fire hydrant on any public or private property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.21. - Aid of motor vehicles. 
    It shall be lawful for any member of the fire department to require the aid of any motor vehicle or other source of power in drawing or conveying fire apparatus or equipment to the scene of a fire or other emergency. 
(Ord. 1336, 3-1-77, renumbered by Ord. 1634, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-2.22. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or opposes the enforcement of, any provision of sections 1-5-2.11 through 1-5-2.20 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); and for each subsequent offense such person shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 1634, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 3292, § 4, 7-3-01; Ord. No. 4302 , § 1, 9-20-16) 
1-5-3. - EAST PEORIA MUNICIPAL AMBULANCE SERVICE 
Cross reference- Medical transportation (the regulation and licensing of vehicles and attendants used for emergency and nonemergency medical transportation), title 3, ch. 20. 
1-5-3.1. - Ambulance service created. 
    There is hereby created an ambulance service which shall be known as the "East Peoria Municipal Ambulance Service" (sometimes hereinafter referred to as the "ambulance service"). The ambulance service shall be staffed from time to time with such personnel as are determined by the city council to be necessary to meet the needs of the city for an ambulance service. 
1-5-3.2. - Function. 
    The ambulance service shall respond as quickly as possible to all requests for emergency ambulance service within the geographic area hereinafter described. 
1-5-3.3. - Area attended by ambulance service. 
    The ambulance service shall respond only to emergency calls involving accident or illness occurring within the geographic area served by the East Peoria Fire Department. It is intended that the area to be served by the ambulance service shall include any fire protection district to which fire protection is provided under contract with the city, but shall exclude that portion of the city served by Northern Tazewell Fire Protection District. 
1-5-3.4. - Qualifications of ambulance attendants. 
    All employees making emergency calls for the ambulance service shall be known as "ambulance attendants." All ambulance attendants shall either be certified by the State of Illinois as emergency medical technicians or in training for such certification. 
1-5-3.5. - Supervision of ambulance attendants. 
    Ambulance attendants shall be under the direct supervision of the fire chief and any assistant fire chief to which such supervisory authority has been delegated by the fire chief. The commissioner of public health and safety shall have charge, supervision and direction over the fire chief and all ambulance attendants in connection with services performed for the ambulance service by the fire chief or the ambulance attendants. 
1-5-3.6. - Attendants excused from other municipal service. 
    While on duty, ambulance attendants are excused from the performance of other obligations which they may have to the city in any capacity other than that of ambulance attendant. 
1-5-3.7. - Rules and regulations. 
    The fire chief, with the prior approval of the commissioner of public health and safety, may promulgate such rules and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter as he deems necessary to the efficient operation of the ambulance service. In any event, however, no more than two (2) ambulance attendants may be on duty at any one time. 
(Ord. 1999, 6-12-84) 
1-5-3.8. - Billing and collection. 
(a)  The fire chief, with the prior approval of the commissioner of public health and safety, shall establish from time to time the rates and charges for which each person who is served by the ambulance service shall pay. 
(b)  Bills for ambulance service shall be prepared and mailed to the responsible party promptly after service has been rendered. Bills shall be prepared under the direction of the fire chief by such persons as are from time to time designated by the fire chief. All funds collected shall be immediately delivered to the treasurer of the city for deposit in the general fund. The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute legal action for the collection of charges which remain unpaid ninety (90) days after billing. 
(Ord. 2573, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2634, § 1, 2-16-93) 
1-5-3.9. - Wages; hours of work. 
    Wages, hours of work and benefits payable to ambulance attendants shall be determined from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 1999, 6-12-84) 
CHAPTER 6. - DEPARTMENT OF STREETS AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 
SECTION: 

1-6-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the department of streets and public improvements, a principal department of the city. This department shall consist of the commissioner of streets and public improvements, the director of public works, the city engineer, the superintendent of operations and all employees assigned thereto. 
1-6-2. - Function. 
    The department of streets and public improvements is hereby charged with: 
(a)  The cleaning, operation and maintenance of the city streets, alleys, sidewalks, drains, culverts, viaducts, subways and other improvements; 
(b)  The operation and maintenance of city street lights; 
(c)  The notification to the fire and police departments of any obstruction of any street or alley within the city for which a permit has been issued or of which the department is charged with knowledge; 
(d)  The collection of garbage and refuse; and 
(e)  The performance of engineering functions on behalf of this and all other departments of the city. 
1-6-3. - Commissioner. 
    The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall exercise control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to this department. He shall be generally responsible for the execution of those functions assigned to this department by statute, this Code or other ordinances, and he shall report to the city council as to the affairs of said department, making such recommendations as he deems necessary or desirable for the efficient operation thereof. 
1-6-4. - Director of public works; creation of office, appointment; duties. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of director of public works, an executive office of the city under the joint control of the commissioner of streets and public improvements and the commissioner of public property. The director of public works shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council. 
(b)  Subject to the control of the commissioner of streets and public improvements and the city council, the director of public works is hereby charged with the supervision of day-to-day operations of the department of streets and public improvements. 
(c)  The director of public works shall have direct control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to the department of streets and public improvements, and is hereby authorized to utilize such officers and employees in such manner as he deems necessary or expedient to the efficient operation of the department as a whole, including the assignment of specific officers and employees either permanently or temporarily to any other subordinate positions or departments. 
(d)  The director of public works shall have charge of and be responsible for the condition and maintenance of all motor vehicles and other equipment of the city assigned to the department of streets and public improvements, and of all buildings and places where the same are housed or kept. 
(e)  The director of public works shall assist and coordinate in the execution of special projects such as the Festival of Lights when authorized and directed to do so by the commissioner of streets and public improvements, the commissioner of public property or the city council. 
1-6-5. - City engineer; qualifications; duties. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of city engineer. The city engineer shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council. The city engineer shall report to and be under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(b)  No person shall be appointed as city engineer unless such person is registered under the provisions of The Illinois Professional Engineering Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 111, paragraph 5101, et seq. 
(c)  The city engineer shall advise the director of public works on engineering matters and, in addition, shall perform such duties as from time to time may be assigned by the director. The engineer's duties shall include but are not limited to the preparation of reports and recommendations regarding public improvements, repairs of streets, bridges and sidewalks, design engineering, review of bids for public works projects, and preparation of maintenance plans for property belonging to the city. 
(d)  The engineer shall keep accurate maps, plats and records of all public works, lands or property owned by the city, except where such maps, etc. are required, under the provisions of this Code, to be kept by another officer of the city. 
1-6-6. - Superintendent of operations. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of superintendent of operations. The superintendent of operations shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council. The superintendent of operations shall report to and be under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(b)  The superintendent of operations shall perform such duties and functions as the director of public works may permanently or temporarily assign, shall provide leadership and supervision over all employees permanently or temporarily assigned to his control, and shall advise and inform the director of public works as to the daily operations and needs of the department of streets and public improvements. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the superintendent of operations shall, in particular, supervise employees involved in the operation, maintenance and repair of the city's street system, the collection and disposal of solid waste, and the maintenance of any and all vehicles assigned to or utilized by employees in the department of streets and public improvements. 
(Ord. 2221, 1-19-88) 
CHAPTER 7. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC PROPERTY 
SECTION: 

1-7-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the department of public property, a principal department of the city. This department shall consist of the commissioner of public property, the director of public works, the city engineer and the superintendent of operations and all employees assigned thereto. 
1-7-2. - Function. 
    The department of public property is hereby charged with: 
(a)  The care, operation and maintenance of the city's water distribution system; and 
(a)  The care, operation and maintenance of the city's wastewater collection, treatment and disposal system. 
1-7-3. - Commissioner. 
    The commissioner of public property shall have charge and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to this department. He shall be generally responsible for the execution of those functions assigned to this department by statute, this Code or other ordinances; and he shall report to the council as to the affairs of said department, making such recommendations as he deems necessary or desirable for the efficient operation thereof. 
1-7-4. - Director of public works to supervise. 
(a)  The director of public works appointed pursuant to section 1-6-4 of this Code is also charged with supervision of the day-to-day operations of the department of public property. 
(b)  The director of public works shall have direct control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to the department of public property, and is hereby authorized to utilize such officers and employees in such manner as he deems necessary or expedient to the efficient operation of the department as a whole, including the assignment of specific officers and employees either permanently or temporarily to any other subordinate positions or departments. 
(c)  The director of public works shall have charge of and be responsible for the condition and maintenance of all motor vehicles and other equipment of the city assigned to the department of public property, and of all buildings and places where the same are housed or kept. 
1-7-5. - Superintendent of operations to perform additional duties. 
(a)  The superintendent of operations appointed pursuant to section 1-6-6 shall also perform duties with respect to the department of public property as hereinafter set forth. In the performance of duties for the department of public property, the superintendent of operations shall report to and be under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(b)  The superintendent of operations shall perform such duties and functions as the director of public works may permanently or temporarily assign, shall provide leadership and supervision over all employees permanently or temporarily assigned to his control and shall advise and inform the director of public works as to the daily operations and the needs of the department of public property. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the superintendent of operations shall, in particular, supervise employees involved in the operation, maintenance and repair of the city's water distribution system and in the operation, maintenance and repair of the city's wastewater collection, treatment and disposal system and the maintenance of any and all vehicles assigned to or utilized by employees in the department of public property. 
(Ord. 2221, 1-19-88) 
CHAPTER 8. - FINANCE, PURCHASES AND CONTRACTS 
SECTION: 

1-8-1. - IN GENERAL 
1-8-1.1. - Maintenance of accounts. 
    All accounts of the city shall be kept by the department of accounts and finances. 
1-8-1.2. - Form and execution of city bonds. 
    Whenever the corporate authorities of the city shall provide by ordinance for the issuance of improvement bonds for the purpose of anticipating the collection of special assessments heretofore levied or hereafter to be levied, in pursuance of the provisions of the statutes of the state, such bonds shall be lithographed or steel-engraved on the best quality of heavy bond paper, of a design to be approved by the city council, and shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk. 
1-8-1.3. - Selection of bonds to be paid. 
    The city treasurer is hereby designated as the officer who shall, on or before January 31 of each year, ascertain the amount of surplus funds on hand applicable to the payment of bonds of each series unmatured, and who shall select by lot bonds of series to such amount, to be paid therewith, and who shall give notice in some newspaper published in the city of the number of bonds to be paid, the series thereof, the assessment to which they relate and the particular bonds so selected to be paid, and that the same will be paid, at a place to be specified, on the thirtieth day next following the date of such notice, pursuant to the provisions of the statutes of the state. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 4, 4-19-16) 
1-8-1.4. - Depository banks. 
    The First National Bank in East Peoria, the Community Bank of East Peoria, and the Tazewell Savings and Loan Association, all located in the city, are hereby designated as depository banks in which funds and moneys received by the city treasurer may be deposited. The treasurer shall be discharged from responsibility for all such funds and moneys which he may deposit in such banks or depositories so designated, as provided by law. 
State Law reference- Treasurer; duties, deposit of funds, etc., 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-40 et seq. 
1-8-2. - ACCOUNTING 
1-8-2.1. - Establishment of accounting procedure. 
    The city treasurer shall establish the city's accounting procedure in such manner that the accounts will show all financial transactions of every branch of the city government and all financial transactions relating to all appropriations, funds and sub-funds; all revenues accrued and liabilities incurred; all cash receipts and disbursements; and all transactions affecting the acquisition, custody and disposition of assets. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.2. - Appropriation accounts. 
    Accounts shall be kept by the treasurer for each appropriation made by the council, together with a record of each allotment of the appropriation by the council and every purchase order and contract and every warrant passed for payment shall state specifically against which of such accounts it is drawn. The accounts shall show for each appropriation and allotment made the amount of obligations incurred against the same and the unencumbered balance remaining to the credit thereof. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.3. - Certification of unencumbered balance prerequisite to expenditures. 
    No contract or purchase order involving the expenditure of tax or bond money shall be issued or entered into, nor shall any such be valid, unless the treasurer shall first certify thereon that there is in the treasury to the credit of the appropriation from which it is to be paid an unencumbered balance sufficient to meet the obligation. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.4. - Sources of unencumbered money deemed in treasury. 
    All unencumbered moneys actually in the treasury to the credit of a fund from which they may be drawn, all moneys anticipated to be received from taxes or other sources to the amounts stated in the annual appropriation resolution and all moneys to be derived from bonds, notes and certificates of indebtedness, either then or previously authorized, and either sold or authorized to be sold, shall for the purpose of the treasurer's certification be deemed in the treasury to the credit of the appropriate fund and subject to certification. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.5. - Limitation on certified expenditures. 
    The allotments of appropriations, as approved by the city council and from time to time revised by them, shall limit the amount of expenditures which may be certified and encumbered against any appropriation by the treasurer during any month of the fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.6. - Liability for uncertified obligations. 
    Whenever an official or employee of the city shall authorize or incur an obligation against the city, without first securing the approval of his department head, he and his sureties shall be individually liable for the amount of such obligations. 
1-8-2.7. - Availability of unencumbered balance to close of fiscal year. 
    At the close of each fiscal year, any unencumbered balance of an appropriation, except those relating to bond funds and other appropriations specifically granted for longer than one year by the council, shall automatically lapse and shall cease to be available for expenditure, unless reappropriated by thee council. 
1-8-2.8. - Financial reports. 
    At the close of each month, and at any other time if so ordered, the treasurer or director of finance shall prepare and submit to the city council a statement of the condition of each appropriation and fund or sub-fund and such other reports as may be required of him. At the close of the year, he shall submit to the council a complete report of the financial transactions of the year and the condition of the city's finances, including a balance sheet for each fund, and such other reports as are required by law. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.9. - Payment of claims; liability for unauthorized payments. 
    The treasurer or director of finance shall examine all payrolls, vouchers, bills and other claims and demands against the city, and shall not issue a warrant for payment thereof unless he has found by diligent investigation that the claim is in proper form, correctly computed and duly approved; that it is justly and legally due and payable; and that it is accompanied by the certification of a responsible official of the department concerned that the goods and services listed therein were actually received. If he finds a claim to be fraudulent, erroneous or otherwise invalid, he shall refuse to authorize the payment of the same, and shall make immediate report of the circumstances to the city council. 
    Whenever the director of finance issues a warrant on the treasurer authorizing payment of any item for which no council approval has been given, or which is otherwise contrary to law, he and his sureties shall be individually liable to the city for the full amount thereof. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.10. - Internal audit. 
    The treasurer or director of finance shall conduct a thorough and continuous internal audit of all receipts, payments, assets and liabilities of all funds handled by the city, or by any agency thereof, in order to protect the city from loss through accident, negligence or dishonesty. It shall be his responsibility to see that all amounts legally due the city are correctly computed, collected in full and deposited in the treasury to the credit of the proper fund and account. 
    At least once a year, he shall audit the securities and insurance policies and official bonds of the city and shall determine whether city property is properly and adequately insured and whether city employees are properly and adequately bonded, reporting his findings to the city council. 
    The treasurer shall be present when proposals from banks to be designated as city depositories are opened and shall examine such proposals. In like manner, he shall witness the receipt of securities deposited by the depositories as collateral. He shall maintain an inventory of all real property owned by the city and of all other property of the city having a useful life of one (1) year or more. 
    No money shall be received by any department of the city except by means of a numbered receipt or other controlled stationery prescribed, furnished and controlled by the treasurer or director of finance. A copy of each receipt issued shall be given to the treasurer or director of finance. No money shall be paid out of the treasury except by means of a warrant issued by the treasurer or director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-2.11. - Special audits; independent audit. 
(a)  The treasurer or director of finance shall, when so ordered by the city council and may upon his own initiative, make special audits and investigations into the finances of any department of the city government. 
(b)  At the close of each year and also in case of the death, resignation or removal of the treasurer or director of finance, the council shall at once cause an audit to be made of his accounts by duly qualified public accountants. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 5, 4-19-16) 
1-8-3. - BUDGET 
State Law reference- Authority of city in connection with annual appropriation ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9 et seq. 
1-8-3.1. - Submission of proposed budget to council. 
    On or before the last Tuesday in May of each year, the treasurer shall submit to the council a proposed budget for the current calendar year, based upon a careful consideration of departmental needs and fund resources, as presented to the treasurer or director of finance by department heads. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 6, 4-19-16) 
1-8-3.2. - Information to be shown for each fund. 
    The proposed budget referred to in the preceding section shall set forth for each fund: All proposed expenditures for the administration, operation and maintenance of all departments and agencies for which appropriations are to be made or taxes levied by the council; all expenditures for capital projects to be financed by bonds, tax levies, grants-in-aid or other means during the fiscal year; all interest and debt redemption charges during the fiscal year; and the actual or estimated operating deficits from previous fiscal years. In addition thereto, the proposed budget shall set forth for each fund the anticipated income from all sources, available surpluses and other means of financing such expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year, the total of which shall be not less than the total proposed expenditures from such fund. 
1-8-3.3. - Division into parts; information designated. 
    The proposed budget, as submitted to the council shall consist of three (3) parts, as follows: 
PART 1 shall contain a statement in which the treasurer shall explain the principal items in the budget and the factors affecting the program, discuss the city's financial status in relation to its activities program for the coming year and recommend a financial policy for the coming year. The treasurer shall also include therein a table summarizing the proposed expenditures and anticipated income for the coming year, together with comparisons showing the actual expenditures and income for the last two (2) completed fiscal years and the latest estimated figures for the whole of the current fiscal year, and may include suitable statistical tables to indicate trends. 
PART 2 shall contain the following items: 
(a)  Detailed estimates of all proposed expenditures, showing for each item: 
(1)  Actual expenditures for the last completed fiscal year; 
(2)  The budget allowance for the current fiscal year; 
(3)  Estimated expenditures for the whole of the fiscal year in progress; and 
(4)  Amounts required for the coming fiscal year. 
(b)  Departmental work programs for the ensuing fiscal year and explanations of increases or decreases in budget items recommended. 
(c)  Detailed estimates of the anticipated income for the fiscal year, with revenue data for the current and preceding year properly arranged for comparative purposes. 
(d)  A statement of the bonded and other indebtedness of the city government, showing the debt redemption and interest requirements. 
PART 3 shall contain complete drafts of a proposed appropriation ordinance and such other ordinances as may be required to put into complete effect the budget proposed by the treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 6, 4-19-16) 
1-8-3.4. - Revision, alteration of proposed appropriation ordinance; public hearing. 
    The council may revise, alter, increase or decrease the items of the proposed appropriation ordinance; provided, that when it increases the total proposed expenditures, it shall also make definite provision to increase the sum of the anticipated income so that the total means of financing the budget of such fund shall at least equal the aggregate proposed expenditures of such fund. 
1-8-4. - PURCHASING AND CONTRACTS 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3780, § 1, adopted Nov. 28, 2007, amended § 1-8-4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 1-8-4, §§ 1-8-4.1-1-8-4.14, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the 1970 Code; Ord. No. 1510, adopted Feb. 6, 1979; and Ord. No. 2641, adopted Apr. 6, 1993. 
State Law reference- Authority of city in connection with contracts, 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1 et seq., 65 ILCS 5/4-5-11. 
1-8-4.1. - Purchases costing not more than two thousand five hundred dollars. 
    Each department head is hereby authorized to purchase, at his discretion, on the open market, commodities, supplies, improvements and services which have been included in the annual budget approved by the city council costing not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.2. - Purchases costing not more than five thousand dollars. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized to approve the purchase of and contracts for supplies, materials, equipment, improvements and services which have been included in the annual budget approved by the city council costing not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.3. - Purchases costing not more than ten thousand dollars. 
    Each commissioner is hereby authorized to approve the purchase of and contracts for supplies, materials, equipment, improvements and services for the department under his direction, whether budgeted or unbudgeted, the cost of which does not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.4. - Solicitation of quotations. 
    Except in the case of an emergency or under circumstances where a continuous relationship between the supplier or contractor and the city suggests that the supplier or contractor has offered an appropriate and competitive price, purchases made without the approval of the city council shall be made only after soliciting at least two (2) quotations from reputable suppliers or contractors believed to offer competitive pricing on the purchased item, improvement or service. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.5. - Report of purchase made without prior approval of the city council. 
    Any purchase made or approved by a department head, the city administrator or a commissioner without prior approval of the city council shall be listed as soon as possible on the schedule of bills payable which is approved during meetings of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.6. - Purchases or contracts in excess of ten thousand dollars. 
    Any contract for supplies, materials, equipment, services, public improvements or the maintenance of public property anticipated to cost more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be awarded in the following manner: 
a.  In accordance with any procedure authorized or required by applicable state or federal law; or 
b.  Unless otherwise prohibited by law, pursuant to a solicitation for bids advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Any such solicitation shall include a general description of the supplies, materials, equipment, work or services sought by the city, shall state where specifications and all related documentation may be secured, the time and place for opening bids and such other information as the city council deems appropriate; or 
c.  Unless otherwise prohibited by law, pursuant to written quotations obtained from vendors or contractors capable of providing the supplies, materials, equipment, work or services sought by the city. Except under circumstances where only one (1) or two (2) suppliers are capable of responding to a request for a quotation, quotations shall be obtained from at least three vendors believed to be capable of providing a competitive response to the request. 
    All such contracts shall be awarded by the city council to the lowest responsible bidder whose bid is determined to serve the best interest of the city, taking into consideration the quality of the articles or services to be supplied, or the work to be performed, conformity with specifications, price, delivery terms, the service reputation of the vendor or contractor and such other factors as the city council deems appropriate. Any other provisions of this chapter or this Code to the contrary notwithstanding (and except as otherwise required by state or federal law), the city council may by ordinance or resolution adopted by an affirmative vote of four (4) of its members enter into any contract without any precondition and/or without the solicitation of bids or quotations. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.7. - Failure of vendors to deliver materials. 
    Any vendor who fails to live up to the terms of his contract for the delivery of materials, supplies or equipment may be declared an irresponsible vendor by the city council and upon approval of such a declaration shall not, for a period of one (1) year thereafter, be awarded any further orders for furnishing such supplies, materials or equipment to any department of the city, unless the council shall by vote of four (4) members remove such disqualification. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.8. - Emergency purchases; report required. 
    In the case of the occurrence of any breakage or loss of equipment, or in other circumstances which could not reasonably be anticipated, whereby any necessary regular service of the city is, or is about to be, interrupted, or whereby the city will suffer any great or continuing loss, the department head, upon the approval of the department commissioner or the mayor, may negotiate any emergency purchase or contract to restore or maintain such service as to terminate such loss, without advertising for bids and in such amount as may be necessary in the circumstances. In case of such emergency purchases involving amounts of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), the department head shall render a full report on the case at the next meeting of the council thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.9. - Record of supplies; fiscal year inventory. 
    The department head shall keep an accurate record of all supplies and commodities delivered to his department and on hand in storerooms operated by him. The department head shall at the request of the department commissioner, the mayor or the city administrator supply an inventory of all such materials then on hand in any such storeroom under his direction. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.10. - Purchases or contracts contrary to chapter. 
    Whenever any officer or employee of the city shall purchase or contract for any supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services contrary to the provisions of this chapter or the rules and regulations made thereunder, such order or contract shall be void and of no effect. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.11. - City officers and employees; noninterest. 
    No officer or employee of any department of the city, shall be interested, directly or indirectly, in any contract made and entered into under the provisions of this chapter for any work to be done, or for any materials to be furnished, and all contracts so made in which such officer or employee shall be so interested shall, at the option of the city council, be declared unlawful and void, and of no binding effect whatsoever, and such officer or employee interested in any contract shall to the extent provided by law forfeit his office, and be removed therefrom on proof of such delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 3780, § 1, 11-28-07) 
1-8-4.12. - Responsible bidders on construction projects. 
    With respect to construction projects of more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) involving the construction of new facilities, the renovation of current facilities or road construction, the term "responsible bidder" means a bidder who is capable of meeting all of the specifications for the construction project, who meets the following criteria and who submits evidence satisfactory to the city that the bidder meets such criteria: 
(a)  The bidder is in compliance with all applicable laws prerequisite to doing business in the State of Illinois; 
(b)  The bidder has obtained a federal employer tax identification number or, in the case of an individual contractor, a Social Security number; 
(c)  The bidder is in compliance with the equal opportunity employer provisions of Section 2000(e) of Chapter 21, Title 42 of the United States Code and Federal Executive Order No. 11246 as amended by Federal Executive Order No. 11375; 
(d)  The bidder provides certificates of insurance demonstrating that the bidder has obtained the following forms of insurance coverage in the amounts set forth in bid specifications, contract requirements, or section 1-8-4.13 as applicable, which will be effective during the term of the construction project: 
Comprehensive general liability; 
Workers compensation; 
Completed operations; 
Motor vehicle; 
Hazardous occupation; and 
Where appropriate, products liability. 
(e)  The bidder is in compliance with the hold harmless and indemnification provisions set forth in subsection 1-8-4.13(f); 
(f)  The bidder is in compliance with all provisions of the Illinois Prevailing Wage Act and pays wages, and provides or pays for medical and hospitalization insurance and retirement for those trades covered by the Prevailing Wage Act in the amounts determined in accordance with the Prevailing Wage Act. All such bidders awarded a contract for a construction project and their subcontractors shall provide certified payrolls to the city in accordance with the provisions of the Prevailing Wage Act; and
