(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-3. - Code hearing department personnel and duties. 
    The code hearing department shall consist of, upon appointment by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council and under the direct supervision of the mayor, a hearing officer, a director, and such other positions as may be approved by the city council, with the powers and duties as hereinafter set forth. Other than the hearing officer, one (1) person may serve more than one (1) such position. Compensation for each of the positions shall be as approved by the city council. 
(1)  Hearing officer. 
a.  The hearing officer, prior to appointment, must be an attorney licensed to practice law for at least three (3) years in the State of Illinois. The hearing officer shall preside over all adjudicatory hearings and shall have the following powers and duties: 
i.  To administer oaths; 
ii.  To hear testimony, to accept evidence that is relevant to the existence of the City Code violation and to rule upon motions, objections and the admissibility of evidence; 
iii.  To issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their representatives; 
iv.  To preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
v.  To issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a City Code violation exists; 
vi.  To impose penalties, sanctions or such other relief consistent with applicable City Code provisions and to assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation, except however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to impose a penalty of incarceration; 
vii.  To review final determination of liability for an ordinance violation in accordance with the administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth; and 
viii.  To hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of issues. 
b.  Prior to conducting administrative adjudication proceedings under this chapter, the hearing officer shall have successfully completed a formal training program which includes the following: 
i.  Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings over which the hearing officer shall preside; 
ii.  Orientation to each subject area of the code violations that he/she will adjudicate; 
iii.  Observation of administrative hearings; and 
iv.  Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence and issuing final orders. 
(2)  Director. The director is authorized and directed to: 
a.  Operate and manage the code hearing department; 
b.  Adopt, distribute and process all notices as may be required under this chapter or as may be reasonably required to carry out the purpose of this chapter; 
c.  Collect moneys paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final determination of liability; 
d.  Certify copies of final determinations of an ordinance violation adjudicated pursuant to this chapter, and any factual reports verifying the final determination of any violation liability which was issued in accordance with this chapter; 
e.  Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and maintain the administrative adjudication system hereby created; 
f.  Collect unpaid fines and penalties through private collection agencies and direct the pursuit of all post-judgment remedies available by law; 
g.  Provide input of violation notice information; 
h.  Establish hearing dates and notice dates; 
i.  Record fine and penalty assessment and payments; 
j.  Issue payment receipts; 
k.  Issue succeeding notice of hearing dates and/or final determination of liability; 
l.  Keep accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at administrative hearings, pleas entered, judgments entered, sanctions imposed, if any, fines and penalties assessed and paid; 
m.  Effectuate any other authority as may be reasonably required for the proper administration of this chapter; 
n.  Designate one (1) or more assistant director to assist in fulfilling responsibilities hereunder; and 
o.  The director of planning and zoning shall be the ex officio director under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-4. - Notice. 
    The administrative adjudication of any ordinance violation shall afford a party due process of law. The notice charging a violation of the City Code shall be accompanied by a summons and shall contain, but shall not necessarily be limited to the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the defendant. 
(2)  The date, time and place the violation was observed. 
(3)  A citation to the ordinance violated. 
(4)  A description of the act or omission which violates the ordinance. 
(5)  The names of witnesses to the violation(s). 
(6)  The signature of the person issuing the notice. 
(7)  The address of the structure where the violation is observed, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-5. - Service. 
    Service shall be as provided by state law under the applicable provision of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-6. - Administrative hearings. 
    The administrative adjudication of any ordinance violation shall afford a party due process of law and shall substantially follow the procedure set forth below: 
(1)  Any administrative proceeding conducted by the code hearing department shall afford the parties an opportunity for a hearing before an administrative hearing officer. 
(2)  An attorney who appears on behalf of any person shall file with the hearing officer a written appearance on a form provided by the code hearing department for that purpose. 
(3)  The hearing officer may grant continuances only in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the defendant. Lack of preparation by either party shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this chapter shall not exceed twenty-five (25) days. 
(4)  All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation. 
(5)  The hearing officer may issue subpoenas to secure the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and production of relevant documents. Issuance of subpoenas shall be subject to the restrictions contained in this chapter. 
(6)  The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply to the conduct of the hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of his or her affairs. 
(7)  No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of the evidence; provided, however, that a violation notice, or a copy thereof, issued and signed in accordance with state law shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts contained therein. 
(8)  Upon timely request of any party to a proceeding, any person, who the hearing officer determines may reasonably be expected to provide testimony which is material and which does not constitute a needless presentation of cumulative evidence, shall be made available for cross-examination prior to a final determination of liability. 
(9)  The record of all hearings before a hearing officer shall include: 
a.  All documents presented at the hearing; 
b.  A copy of the notice of the violation or notice of the hearing; and 
c.  A copy of the findings and decisions of the hearing officer. 
(10)  The record of a hearing before a hearing officer may include a record of the testimony presented at the hearing, which may be by means of a tape recording, transcription or other appropriate means. 
a.  The code hearing department shall not be required to provide recording services or equipment. 
b.  Any party desiring to record the testimony presented at the hearing shall provide its own court reporter, transcriber or recorder at that party's own expense regardless of the outcome of the hearing. 
c.  The hearing officer may reasonably limit where the court reporter, transcriber or recorder may be placed in the hearing room. If the party, the court reporter, transcriber or recorder is unwilling to follow reasonable limitations then the hearing officer may remove the court reporter, transcriber or recorder. 
(11)  Upon conclusion of a hearing, the hearing officer shall make a final written determination on the basis of the evidence as to whether or not a code violation exists. Upon issuing a final determination of liability, the hearing officer shall: 
a.  Impose penalties and/or fines that are consistent with applicable provisions of the City Code; 
b.  Issue orders that are consistent with applicable provisions of the City Code, including, but not limited to, orders to cure or abate any continuing violations of the City Code; and 
c.  Assess costs reasonably related to instituting the hearing. 
(12)  In the issuance of a final determination of liability, a hearing officer shall inform the defendant of defendant's right to seek judicial review of the final determination. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-7. - Default. 
(a)  If at the time set for a hearing the recipient of a violation notice or a notice of hearing, or the recipient's attorney of record, fails to appear, the hearing officer may find the recipient in default and proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation and conclude with a finding, decision and order. A copy of the order of default shall be served in any manner permitted under this chapter. 
(b)  Within twenty-one (21) calendar days from the issuance of an order of default, a recipient of a violation notice or a notice of hearing who has been found to be in default may petition the hearing officer to set aside the determination and set a new hearing date on the basis that the failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause. If the petition is granted, the hearing officer shall serve notice of the new hearing date upon the petitioner in any manner permitted by this chapter no less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the hearing date. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-8. - Review of final orders. 
    A final order of a hearing officer shall constitute a final determination and shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-9. - Enforcement of hearing officer's order. 
    Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed by a hearing officer's order and any expenses incurred by the city to enforce the order, including but not limited to; attorney's fees, court costs and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, that remain unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review of a hearing officer's final determination of liability for a code violation shall be a debt due and owing the city and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3817, § 1, adopted June 17, 2008, deleted § 1-11-10, which pertained to violations and orders and derived from Ord. No. 3815, § 1, adopted June 3, 2008. 
1-11-11. - Fines payable to the city treasurer. 
    All fines and other monies paid to the city in accordance with this chapter shall be remitted to the City of East Peoria Treasurer for deposit to the city general fund. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-12. - Post-hearing motions. 
    There shall be no post-hearing motion practice before the code hearing department. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-13. - Ex parte disclosures. 
    The city hereby adopts and incorporates Canon 3(A)(6) of the Code of Conduct for Administrative Law Officers. Therefore, hearing officers and other personnel of the code hearing department are required to refrain from public comment about a pending proceeding before the code hearing department. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-14. - Waiver, suspension or reduction of fines. 
    In instances where the City Code calls for the imposition of a mandatory minimum fine upon a finding of liability by a hearing officer, a hearing officer may not waive, suspend or reduce the imposition of said mandatory minimum fine. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-15. - Schedule of fines/penalties. 
    For an ordinance violation of the City Code, fines and penalties shall be as established from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-16. - Additional rules, regulations and provisions. 
    The director may adopt any other necessary and proper rules, regulations or provisions to carry into effect this chapter and the powers granted and purposes stated in the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-17. - Severability. 
    If any provision of this chapter, or the application thereof, is held to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such ruling shall not affect any other provision of this chapter which is not specifically included in such ruling or which can be given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or application; and to this end, the provisions of this chapter are declared severable. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
1-11-18. - Savings clause. 
    Nothing herein adopted shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court or any rights accrued or liability incurred or any cause or causes of action accrued or existing under any prior resolution or ordinance. Nor shall any right or remedy of any party to a proceeding be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3815, § 1, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 6-17-08) 
CHAPTER 12. - AGGREGATION OF ELECTRIC LOAD 
SECTION: 

1-12-1. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the construction and interpretation of this chapter unless the use or context clearly indicates that another meaning is intened: 
    Act means the Illinois Power Agency Act found at 20 ILCS 3855/1-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
    Aggregation program means a program for the aggregation of residential and small commercial retail electrical loads in accordance with the Act. 
    Plan of operation and governance means the plan of operation and governance for the aggregation program as adopted pursuant to Ordinance No. 4036, as such plan is amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 4036, § 1, 4-17-12) 
1-12-2. - Aggregation of electrical load. 
(a)  The city council may operate an aggregation program in the manner provided by the Act. 
(b)  The aggregation program shall be operated pursuant to an opt-out procedure in accordance with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 4036, § 1, 4-17-12) 
1-12-3. - Adoption and amendment of plan of governance and operation. 
    The aggregation program shall be operated in accordance with the plan of operation and governance. The city council may from time to time amend the plan of operation and governance by resolution approving such amendment. 
(Ord. No. 4036, § 1, 4-17-12) 
1-12-4. - Solicitation and acceptance of proposals. 
    The city shall solicit and accept and/or reject proposals for the supply of electricity in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Act and in accordance with the plan of operation and governance. 
(Ord. No. 4036, § 1, 4-17-12) 
TITLE 2 - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
CHAPTER 1. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS 
SECTION: 

2-1-1. - Creation; appointment; qualification. 
    There is hereby created and established in the city a board of fire and police commissioners. 
    The board shall consist of three (3) members whose terms of office shall be three (3) years, or until their respective successors shall be appointed and qualified; provided, that no appointment shall be made by the city council within thirty (30) days before the expiration of the term of office of the council; and provided further, that not more than two (2) members of the board shall belong to or be members of the same political party; provided further, that the members of such board shall possess the qualifications required of other officers of the city, shall take oath or affirmation of office and give bond in the same manner as other appointive officers of the city, and shall be subject to removal from office as such other officers. 
State Law reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, appointments and discharge, 65 ILCS 5/4-5-7 et seq. 
2-1-2. - Regular meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be held on dates, times, and a location as specified in the Annual Notice of Meetings in January of every year. 
(b)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the board of fire and police commissioners, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the board of fire and police commissioners or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the board of fire and police commissioners or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 3, 9-15-15) 
2-1-3. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall establish rules to carry out the purpose of this chapter, and for the appointments and removals in accordance with its provisions, and the board may, from time to time, make changes in such rules; provided further, that all such rules and changes therein shall be forthwith printed for distribution, and such board shall give notice of the place where such printed rules may be obtained, by publication in a newspaper published in the city. Such publication shall specify the date not less than ten (10) days subsequent to the time of such publication when such rules shall go into operation. 
2-1-4. - Appointment of members of fire and police departments. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the fire and police departments of the city, except the chief of police and the fire chief, provided, that all appointments to such departments other than that of the lowest rank, shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment shall be made. 
2-1-5. - Annual report. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall annually, and at such other times as the city council may provide, make to the Mayor, to be by him transmitted to the city council, a report of its acts and doings, the rules in force and the practical effect thereof, and may in such report make such suggestions as such board believes will result in the greater efficiency of such departments. 
2-1-6. - Secretary. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own members to act as such. Such secretary shall keep the minutes of its proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of such board, shall keep a record of all examinations held; and shall perform such other duties as such board shall prescribe. 
2-1-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4245 , § 4, adopted Sept. 15, 2015, deleted § 2-1-7, entitled "Disqualification for holding other government job". 
2-1-8. - Compensation. 
    The secretary of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be paid a reasonable compensation for his services, to be fixed by the city council. The city council shall also fix the compensation to be paid to the members of such board, but until the city council shall make provisions therefor, the members of such board shall serve without compensation. 
2-1-9. - Bond. 
    The fire and police commissioners of the city shall execute a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with surety to be approved by the city council, payable to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of such commissioners and the payment of all money received by such commissioners according to statute, this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
2-1-10. - Firemen and policemen; examinations for appointments. 
    All applicants for positions in the fire and police departments of the city shall be under thirty-five (35) years of age and shall be subjected to examination which shall be public, competitive and free to all persons possessing the right of suffrage in the city, subject to reasonable limitations as to residence, age, health, habits and moral character, and shall relate to those matters which will fairly test the relative capacity of the persons examined to discharge the positions in which they seek to be appointed, and shall include tests of physical qualification and health, but no such applicant shall be examined concerning his political or religious opinions or affiliations. Such examinations shall be conducted by the board of fire and police commissioners. Notice of the time and place of every examination shall be given by the board by publication for two (2) weeks preceding such examination, in a newspaper published in the city, and such notice shall also be posted in a conspicuous place in the office of such board for two (2) weeks previous to such examination. 
2-1-11. - Firemen and policemen; temporary appointments. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may, in order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary exigencies or to prevent material impairment of either the police or fire department, make temporary appointments to remain in force until regular appointments may be made under the provisions of this chapter, and not in any event to exceed sixty (60) days. 
2-1-12. - Firemen and policemen; register of eligibles. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall prepare and keep a register of persons whose general average standing upon examination is not less than the minimum fixed by the rules of such board and who are otherwise eligible, and such persons shall take rank upon the register as candidates in the order of their relative excellence as determined by examination without reference to priority of time of examination. 
2-1-13. - Firemen and policemen; promotions. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall, by its rules, provide for promotion in the respective departments on the basis of ascertained merit and seniority in service and examination, and shall provide in all cases where it is practicable that vacancies shall be filled by promotion. All examinations for promotion shall be competitive among such members of the next lower rank as desired to submit themselves to such examination, and all promotions shall be made from the three (3) having the highest rating. The method of examination for promotions and the rules governing the same shall be the same as provided for applicants for original appointment. 
2-1-14. - Firemen and policemen; suspensions and removals. 
    No officer or member of the fire and police departments of the city who shall have been such for more than one year prior to the passage of this chapter or who shall have been appointed under the rules and examinations provided for by this chapter shall be removed or discharged except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard in his own defense. The board of fire and police commissioners shall conduct a fair and impartial hearing on the charges, to be commenced within thirty (30) days of the filing thereof, which hearing may be continued from time to time. In case an officer or member is found guilty, the board may discharge him, or may suspend him not exceeding thirty (30) days without pay. The board may suspend any officer or member pending the hearing with or without pay, but not to exceed thirty (30) days. If the board of fire and police commissioners determine that the charges are not sustained, the officer or member shall be reimbursed for all wages withheld, if any. In the conduct of this hearing, each member of the board shall have power to administer oaths and affirmations, and the board shall have power to secure by its subpoena both the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of books and papers relevant to the hearing. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 2. - BOARD OF HEALTH 
SECTION: 

2-2-1. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a board of health for the city, consisting of the commissioner of public health and safety, who shall be ex officio chairman of such board, the city health officer, and a third member who shall be a practicing physician and resident of the city to be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council, for a four (4) year term. 
2-2-2. - Duties, generally. 
    The board of health shall: 
(a)  Have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute, this Code or other ordinances of the city; 
(b)  Enforce all laws of the city which relate to public health and to health nuisances; 
(c)  Make all necessary rules and regulations for the protection of the health of the residents of the city to guard against the spread of contagious diseases, to prevent the induction of diseases, contagious or otherwise, and to make any other rules or regulations which may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of disease. 
2-2-3. - Quarantine; vaccination. 
    The board of health is hereby authorized to make such reasonable rules as may be necessary regarding quarantine and vaccination for the prevention and spread of contagious diseases, and to quarantine premises where such diseases occur for such time as may be necessary to protect public health. 
    The said board shall have the power to prevent persons from entering or leaving premises on which the case of contagious or epidemic disease occurs or is found, and to placard the same with signs indicating the nature of such disease and existence of the quarantine. 
2-2-4. - Rules; review by council. 
    All rules and regulations enacted by the board of health shall be subject to the review of the city council. 
2-2-5. - Violation of orders; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any order of the board of health or to refuse to obey any order or to remove, destroy, mutilate or conceal any notice posted by or under the authority of the board of health. Such person shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 3. - BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 
SECTION: 

2-3-1. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of local improvements for the city, which shall consist of the mayor and the four (4) commissioners. 
State Law reference- Board of local improvements, 65 ILCS 5/9-2-7. 
2-3-2. - Powers and duties. 
    The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute, this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
2-3-3. - Officers. 
    The mayor of the city shall be the president of the board of local improvements, and said board shall select one of its other members as its secretary. 
2-3-4. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the board of local improvements shall be held every Tuesday evening at 6:30 p.m. in the City Council Chambers, Civic Complex Building, 401 West Washington Street, East Peoria, Illinois. 
(b)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the board of local improvements, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the board of local improvements or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the board of local improvements or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the board of local improvements. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 4245 , § 5, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 4. - EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY 
SECTION: 

2-4-1. - Establishment. 
(a)  There is hereby created the East Peoria ESDA to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with The Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Act of 1975. 
(b)  This ESDA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. 
State Law reference- Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq. 
2-4-2. - Coordinator. 
(a)  The coordinator of the city ESDA shall be appointed by the mayor, and the coordinator shall serve until removed by the mayor. 
(b)  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction and control of the mayor as provided by statute. 
(c)  In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the mayor or any person designated by him, shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this chapter. 
2-4-3. - Functions. 
    The city ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the city as shall be prescribed in and by the state ESDA plan and program prepared by the Governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the Governor, and in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by The State ESDA Act of 1975. 
2-4-4. - Service as mobile support team. 
(a)  All or any members of the city organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the state ESDA as provided by law. 
(b)  The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the city ESDA organization. 
(c)  Any member of a mobile support team who is a city employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the Governor, or the state director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the city, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensations as provided by law. 
2-4-5. - Agreements with other political subdivisions. 
    The coordinator of ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipalities, counties or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the city council and by the state director of ESDA. 
2-4-6. - Emergency action. 
    If the Governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the State of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the city ESDA to cooperate fully with the state ESDA and with the Governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
2-4-7. - Compensation. 
    Members of the ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the city, if called for training by the state director of ESDA, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not such city employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by city council. 
2-4-8. - Reimbursement by state. 
    The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the city for expenses incident to training members of the ESDA prescribed by the state director of ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the city in response to a call by the Governor or state director of ESDA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. 
2-4-9. - Purchases and expenditures. 
(a)  The city council may, on recommendation of the city coordinator of ESDA, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the city in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from manmade or natural disaster. 
(b)  In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the city coordinator of ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the city, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to city contracts or obligations, as authorized by The State ESDA Act of 1975, provided that if the city council meets at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. 
2-4-10. - Oath. 
    Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the city ESDA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
    "I, ___________, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the East Peoria ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence." 
2-4-11. - Office. 
    The mayor is authorized to designate space in a city building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the city council, for the city ESDA as its office. 
2-4-12. - Appropriation; levy of taxes. 
    The city council may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by law, and may levy in addition for ESDA purposes only, a tax not to exceed five cents ($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by The State ESDA Act of 1975; however, that amount collectable under such levy shall in no event exceed twenty-five cents ($0.25) per capita. 
(Ord. 1764, 3-10-81) 
CHAPTER 5. - LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-5-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby established a local liquor control commission. 
State Law reference- Designating a local liquor control commissioner and granting of particular powers, 235 ILCS 5/4-1 through 235 ILCS 5/4-7. 
2-5-2. - Commissioner. 
    The mayor of the city shall be the liquor control commissioner, and be charged with the administration of all liquor laws. The mayor, as such liquor control commissioner, may appoint such persons to assist him in the exercise of the powers vested in him and in the performance of his duties as may be deemed advisable. 
2-5-3. - Powers of local liquor control commissioner. 
    The local liquor control commissioner shall also have the following powers: 
(a)  To grant and/or suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke for cause all local licenses issued to persons for premises within the city. 
(b)  To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of this Code or any rules or regulations adopted by him or by the State of Illinois or the State Commission have been or are being violated, and at such time to examine said premises of said licensee in connection therewith. 
(c)  To receive complaint from any citizen that any of the provisions of this code, or the rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto, have been or are being violated and to act upon such complaints. 
(d)  To receive local license fees provided for herein, and to pay the same forthwith to the city treasurer. 
(e)  To hold hearing, take testimony, examine applicants and to do and perform all acts necessary or incidental to such office. 
    Whenever in this Code the local liquor control commissioner is referred to, it shall include any committee or other agency appointed by such local liquor control commissioner, and under his direction to act for him. 
(1970 Code) 
2-5-4. - Meetings. 
(a)  The local liquor control commissioner may call meetings of the local liquor control commission from time to time to address business of the local liquor control commission. 
(b)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the local liquor control commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the local liquor control commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the local liquor control commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the local liquor control commission. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 6, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 6. - PLANNING COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-6-1. - Creation; composition; term of office. 
(a)  A planning commission for the city is hereby created pursuant to the authority of the Illinois Municipal Code, chapter 24, section 11-12-4 et seq. 
(b)  The planning commission shall consist of seven (7) members, all citizens of the United States, who are residents of the city. All members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the city council, on the basis of their particular fitness for their duty on said planning commission. 
(c)  Members shall serve for a period of three (3) years. Should any member fail to complete his term, the vacancy thus created shall be filled by appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. 2070, 6-18-85; Ord. 2544, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 2882, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 4164, § 1, 4-29-14) 
2-6-2. - Regular meetings; records. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the planning commission shall be held on the fourth Monday of each month at a time designated by the chairman in the City of East Peoria Council Chambers, 401 West Washington Street, East Peoria, Illinois, or any other location within the city as may from time to time be convenient. Notice of meetings shall be given in the manner provided by law. 
    Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairman. 
    Notice of meetings shall be given to all members, including ex officio, advisory and other nonvoting members, as provided by law. 
(b)  The planning commission shall keep and maintain written records of its meetings which shall be open to inspection by the city council at all times. 
(c)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the planning commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the planning commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the planning commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the planning commission. 
(Ord. 2070, 6-18-85; Ord. 2544, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 4245 , § 7, 9-15-15) 
2-6-3. - Vacancies in office. 
    Failure to attend three (3) consecutive regular meetings without excuse by the chairman of the planning commission, or failure to attend six (6) consecutive regular meetings for any reason, shall cause a vacancy in such membership. The secretary of the planning commission shall notify the mayor or appointing authority in writing wherever such vacancy by absence shall occur. 
(1970 Code) 
2-6-4. - Ex officio, nonvoting and advisory members. 
    The following city officers shall act as ex officio nonvoting members of and advisors to the planning commission: planning director, city engineer, fire chief, police chief and director of public affairs. 
    Nonvoting advisory or special committee members may be appointed to serve by the mayor upon request of the planning commission. 
(Ord. 2070, 6-18-85) 
2-6-5. - Compensation. 
    No compensation shall be paid to any member or officer of the planning commission unless provided by the city council. 
2-6-6. - Organizational meeting. 
    There shall be an organizational meeting of the planning commission to be held annually. At such meeting, a chairman, vice chairman, secretary and such other officers as shall be deemed necessary by the planning commission shall be elected. 
2-6-7. - Recording secretary; legal advisor. 
(a)  The office of recording secretary of the planning commission is hereby created. The appointment shall be made by the mayor, and the salary for such office shall be approved by the city council. 
(b)  The city attorney shall act as legal advisor to the planning commission. 
2-6-8. - Operational rules. 
    The planning commission shall have the power to make rules governing election of officers, committees and general operation, subject to approval by the city council. 
2-6-9. - Powers and duties, generally. 
    The planning commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the city. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the city. This plan may include reasonable requirements with reference to streets, alleys, public grounds and other improvements hereinafter specified. The plan, as recommended by the planning commission and as thereafter adopted by the city council, may be applicable, by the terms thereof, to land situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of and not included within the city. 
(b)  To recommend changes, from time to time, in the official comprehensive plan. 
(c)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities, from time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(d)  To give aid to the city officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the making of these projects, and, generally, to promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(e)  To exercise such other powers incident to the powers granted by this chapter as may be conferred by the city council, or as may be conferred and authorized by statute. 
(f)  To accept and receive a plat of subdivision of land for preliminary approval, and advise and assist the city council in final approval thereof. The planning commission may by rules designate a subdivision committee to make reports to it in regard to subdivision of land. 
(g)  To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of public information and understanding. 
(h)  To cooperate with city and regional planning commissions and other agencies to further a local planning program and to assume harmonious and integrated planning for the area. 
(i)  To exercise the authority granted to the planning commission pursuant to title 5 of the East Peoria City Code. 
(1970 Code; Ord. 2070, 6-18-85) 
Cross reference- Comprehensive plan, short title, etc., § 5-1-1 et seq. 
2-6-10. - Prior plans, maps, records and actions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not affect the validity of the official comprehensive plan of the city and all amendments thereto in the official map. All official acts of the East Peoria Planning Commission including the adoption of the official comprehensive plan and official map of the city, are hereby validated and declared continuing, and the records of such East Peoria Planning Commission shall be retained in the continuing part of the records and rules of the East Peoria Planning Commission hereby established unless later changed, altered, or amended. 
(Ord. 1220, 11-11-75) 
2-6-11. - Expenditures. 
    The planning commission may, at the direction of the city council employ a paid secretary or staff or both whose salaries, wages and other expenses shall be provided for by the city council from the public funds. Should the planning commission deem it advisable to secure technical advice or services, it may be done by authority of the city council and appropriation duly made by such council therefore. 
2-6-12. - Official comprehensive plan and official map; adoption, filing, copies. 
    An official comprehensive plan, or any amendment thereof or addition thereto, proposed by the planning commission shall be effective in the city in a contiguous area herein prescribed only after its formal adoption by the city council. Such plan shall be advisory and in and of itself shall not be construed to regulate or control the use of private property in any way, except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinance duly enacted by the council. 
    At any time or times before or after the adoption of the official comprehensive plan by the council, the council may designate by ordinance an official map, which map may consist of the whole area included within the official comprehensive plan or one or more separate geographical or functional parts, which map may include all or any part of the contiguous unincorporated area within one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits of the city. Such map or maps shall be made a part of the ordinance, which ordinance shall specifically state standard requirements of the city relating to size of streets, alleys, public ways, parks, playgrounds, school sites and other public grounds and ways for public service facilities; the kind and quantity of materials which shall be used in the construction of streets and alleys; and the kind and quality of materials for public services or service facilities as may be consistent with Illinois Commerce Commission or industry standards; and the standards required for drainage and sanitary sewer and collection and treatment of sewage. The map shall be drawn to scale, shall be reasonably accurate, and shall show north point, section lines and numbers and streams. 
    Such official comprehensive plan and the ordinance or ordinances including the official map, shall be placed on file with the city clerk and shall be available at all times during business hours for public inspection. Copies of said plan and all ordinances implementing the same, including the official map, shall be made available to all interested parties upon payment of such sum as the city council shall determine adequate to reimburse the general fund of the city for the cost of printing and distributing the same. 
2-6-13. - Records and reports. 
    The planning commission shall keep records of its proceedings, which shall be in writing in a permanent book, open to public inspection at all reasonable times. The said commission shall file an annual report with the city council and such additional reports pertaining to their functions and duties as may be expedient, and such reports shall set forth its transactions and recommendations. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 7. - POLICE PENSION BOARD 
SECTION: 

2-7-1. - Creation; appointment; term. 
    There shall be a police pension board consisting of five (5) members. Of these members, two (2) shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the consent of the council, to serve a term of two (2) years each; two (2) shall be elected from the regular police force of the city, and one shall be elected from the beneficiary of the pension. Each member shall serve for two (2) years and elected members shall be selected in the manner provided by law. 
State Law reference- Police pension fund, generally, 40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.; police pension board, 40 ILCS 5/3-128 et seq. 
2-7-2. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duties of the members of the police pension board to manage, invest and control the police pension fund and all moneys pertaining thereto, in the manner provided by statute and to pay beneficiaries as provided by law. 
2-7-3. - Funds. 
    There shall be deposited in the police pension fund those amounts provided for by statute. 
(1970 Code) 
2-7-4. - Rules and regulations; hearings; records. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the police pension board shall make rules and regulations governing the discharge of its duties, and shall hear and decide all applications for relief and pensions under the provisions of this chapter and in accordance with state law. 
(b)  The board shall cause to be kept a record of all its meetings and proceedings. 
(c)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the police pension board, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the police pension board or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the police pension board or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the police pension board. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 8, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 8. - FIREMEN'S PENSION BOARD 
SECTION: 

2-8-1. - Creation; officers. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund, which board shall consist of the following members: The city treasurer, the city clerk, the city fire chief, the mayor, three (3) active firemen and one retired fireman, to be elected at the time and manner provided for by statute. 
(b)  The board shall elect a president and a secretary to be chosen biennially at the regular meeting of the board. 
State Law reference- Firemen's pension board, 40 ILCS 5/4-121. 
2-8-2. - Duties. 
    The board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall have control of the management of all funds belonging to or designated by law as part of the firemen's pension fund and the administration of such funds as provided by statute. 
State Law reference- Financing, contributions, reserves, 40 ILCS 5/4-118 through 40 ILCS 5/4-120. 
2-8-3. - Ex officio treasurer; treasurer's bond. 
    The city treasurer shall be ex officio treasurer of the board of trustees for the firemen's pension fund. He shall give bond to the city in the sum doubled upon all amounts of money to be received by him during the current year, with sureties to be approved by the board, conditioned that he will faithfully perform the duties of his office and will account for such funds as provided for by law. 
2-8-4. - Rules and regulations; hearings; records. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall make rules and regulations for its government in the discharge of its duties, and shall hear and decide all applications for relief and pensions under the provisions of this chapter and in accordance with state law. 
(b)  The board shall cause to be kept a record of all its meetings and proceedings. 
(c)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the firemen's pension board, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the firemen's pension board or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the firemen's pension board or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the firemen's pension board. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 9, 9-15-15) 
2-8-5. - Authority to take and settle assets. 
    The board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall have the power to take, and may settle or dispose of in any way or manner that the board, in its discretion deems proper, any or all assets of any kind which are in its possession or under the control of the board of trustees, and all moneys and funds received from the sale of special assets together with all other money or funds received or taken over shall become part of the firemen's pension fund. The board is hereby empowered to pay out of such fund the necessary expenses of the board. 
2-8-6. - Authority to take by gifts, grants, money. 
    The board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund may take by gift, grant, devise or request any money, request any money, real estate, personal property or other valuable things; and such property, real estate, personal property or right to property or other valuable things so obtained shall in like manner be paid into the pension fund and treated as a part thereof, and be subject to the order of the board. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 9. - HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-9-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the East Peoria Human Relations Commission, which commission shall be composed of seven (7) members, including the chairperson. 
(Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99; Ord. No. 3631, § 1, 8-2-05) 
2-9-2. - Statement of policy. 
    The purpose of the commission shall be to promote, foster, encourage and stimulate understanding, harmonious relationships, a spirit of charity and practical cooperation among all groups and individuals, to the end that the city may grow and advance in wholesome collective achievement and in the field of individual opportunity. 
(Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99) 
2-9-3. - Qualification of members. 
    Each member of the human relations commission shall be a resident of the city. At least one (1) member shall be a member of the city council, one (1) member shall be a member or officer of the East Peoria Housing Authority and one (1) member shall be an officer in the East Peoria Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99) 
2-9-4. - Appointments; term of office. 
    The chairperson and other members of the human relations commission shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by the council. Members shall serve for a term of three (3) years, commencing with the first day of May of the year of appointment. Not more than nine (9) members shall serve on the human relations commission. The terms of office of the members shall be staggered with not more than three (3) members' terms of office expiring each year. The term of office of any existing member not selected for reappointment shall be deemed expired at such time as the council approves a seventh appointee. 
(Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99; Ord. No. 3631, § 2, 8-2-05; Ord. No. 4245 , § 10, 9-15-15) 
2-9-5. - Meetings; secretary. 
(a)  The human relations commission shall conduct such meetings as may be necessary to perform the functions assigned to it by this chapter, by the mayor and council or by ordinance. Meetings of the human relations commission shall be held at the city administration building or in such other suitable place as the commission may determine. A secretary selected by the commission shall be responsible for the recording of minutes and the safeguarding of all commission records. 
(b)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the human relations commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the human relations commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the human relations commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the human relations commission. 
(Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99; Ord. No. 4245 , § 11, 9-15-15) 
2-9-6. - Duties; functions; powers. 
    The commission shall cooperate with the mayor, the city council and other city officials in securing and furnishing equal services to all residents; developing by various publicity and training media improved intergroup relations which, in turn, shall develop respect for equal rights without regard to race, color, creed, religion, disability or handicapped condition, national origin, ancestry or sexual preference; encouraging and fostering fair and equal treatment under the law to all citizens; and maintaining equality of opportunity for employment and advancement in the city government. 
    The commission shall advise and consult with the mayor and city council on matters involving racial, religious, ethnic prejudices or discrimination and recommend such action as it may deem appropriate to effectuate the policy of this chapter. 
    The commission shall coordinate with the East Peoria Housing Authority in assuring compliance with the Fair Housing Regulations of the city as set forth in Title 10, Chapter 3 of this Code. 
    The commission shall exercise those powers delegated to it by ordinance or assigned to it by resolution of the council. 
    The commission may establish such committees as it deems appropriate in order to fulfill its mission and involve concerned citizens in its efforts. Committee members need not be members of the commission. 
    The commission shall determine such officers in addition to the chairperson and secretary as it deems appropriate. 
(Ord. 2337, 5-16-89; Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99) 
2-9-7. - Reports and recommendations. 
    The commission shall submit to the mayor and council annually, no later than February 1st, a report summarizing the activities of the commission during the preceding calendar year. The commission shall in said report and on such other occasions as it deems advisable, make recommendations to the mayor and the council concerning steps to be taken by the city in order to promote tolerance, oppose hate and celebrate diversity. It shall be the responsibility of the commission to communicate to the mayor and city council its recommendations for progressively improving human relations in the entire city. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3168, § 1, 8-3-99) 
CHAPTER 10. - EPIC COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-10-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a commission to be known as EPIC. Said acronym shall stand for "East Peoria Is Concerned." 
2-10-2. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The EPIC Commission created by section 2-10-1 above shall consist of eighteen (18) persons appointed by the mayor to serve without salary for three (3) years, except that of such members first appointed, six (6) shall hold office for one year; six (6) for two (2) years; and six (6) for three (3) years; and until their respective successors are duly appointed and qualified. Commission members shall be broadly representative of the community and shall be individuals who, by background, experience, training, or profession shall have special interest and knowledge in the battle against substance abuse. Further, the mayor shall appoint as an ex officio member of the EPIC commission a member of the city council, which member shall act a liaison between the city council and the commission. 
2-10-3. - Purpose; function. 
    The purpose of the EPIC commission shall be to help coordinate the activities of private and public agencies which are attempting to address the problem of substance abuse in the greater East Peoria community. Further, the EPIC commission shall endeavor to address various aspects of the substance abuse problem, such as educating the general public, including children. 
2-10-4. - Budget. 
    The EPIC commission shall operate under such budget, if any, as may, from time to time, be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city, but any expenditures therefrom shall be made only upon approval of the mayor and in accordance with ordinance and statutory requirements. The EPIC commission shall no less than annually report to the city council on the activities of the commission. 
(Ord. 2378, 10-3-89) 
CHAPTER 11. - SENIOR CITIZENS COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-11-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a commission for senior citizens for the City of East Peoria, Illinois, which shall be known as the Senior Citizens Commission of East Peoria. 
2-11-2. - Composition; appointment of members; salary; terms. 
    The East Peoria Senior Citizens Commission created by section 2-11-1 above shall consist of fifteen (15) persons appointed by the mayor to serve without salary for four (4) year terms, except that of such members first appointed, six (6) shall hold office for one year; three (3) for two (2) years; three (3) for three (3) years; and three (3) for four (4) years; and until their respective successors are duly appointed and qualified. Commission members shall be broadly representative of the community and shall be individuals who, by background, experience, training, profession, and/or age, shall have special interest and knowledge in the affairs and needs of persons sixty-two (62) years of age or older. 
2-11-3. - Purpose; function. 
    The purpose of the Senior Citizens Commission of East Peoria shall be to help coordinate the activities of private and public groups involving the affairs of persons sixty-two (62) years of age or older to the end that there shall be (a) adequate community and individual activities stimulating and maintaining the interests of senior citizens; (b) adequate public and private services maintaining and improving the health and welfare of senior citizens; and (c) adequate dissemination of information concerning the interests, problems and affairs of senior citizens. 
2-11-4. - Budget; salaries. 
    The commission shall operate under such budget, if any, as may from time to time be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city, but any expenditures therefrom, including employee salaries, shall be made only upon approval of the mayor and in accordance with ordinance and statutory requirements. 
2-11-5. - Statement of policy. 
    The twentieth century has witnessed great advances in the prolongation of life, health and ability. A phenomena of the twentieth century has been the shortening of the working and professional life of average citizens, thereby freeing great numbers of citizens over sixty (60) years of age from routine daily tasks. Senior citizens by virtue of their comparative freedom, their experiences and their wisdom in the affairs of life represent a great power for good in our nation, states and cities. Since life is most meaningful and interesting when it is of service to one's fellow man, it is the policy of the city to encourage and promote active participation in government by senior members of the community to assist and advise the city council of the city as to how the city may assist elderly citizens of our community with their problems and how senior citizens may assist the city council in community development and good works. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 12. - AIR POLLUTION CONTROL COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-12-1. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created an air pollution control commission of the city. The commission shall be composed of five (5) members to be appointed by the mayor as follows: One member who shall be actively engaged in the management of a private manufacturing concern having plant facilities within the city; one member who shall be actively engaged in the management of a private or quasi-public utility or transportation concern having plant facilities within the city; one member who is actively engaged in the management of a private commercial concern having plant facilities within the city; one member who shall be representative of labor within the city; and one member who shall be selected at large from the residents of the city. 
2-12-2. - Member's terms of office. 
    The term of office of the members of the commission shall be four (4) years and until their successors are selected and qualified, except that the terms of those first appointed shall expire as follows: 
One at the end of one year after date of appointment; 
One at the end of two (2) years after date of appointment; 
One at the end of three (3) years after date of appointment; 
Two (2) at the end of four (4) years after date of appointment; 
as designated by the mayor at the time of appointment. The terms of all members shall continue until their respective successors have been duly appointed and qualified. If a vacancy occurs in the appointed membership, the mayor may appoint a member for the remaining portion of the unexpired term created by the vacancy. The mayor may remove any appointed member for cause. The members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their services but may be reimbursed for expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties. 
2-12-3. - Meetings. 
    The commission shall hold at least six (6) regular meetings each calendar year at a place and time to be fixed by the commission. The commission shall select at its first meeting one of its members to serve as chairman and another of its members to serve as secretary. At the first regular meeting in each calendar year thereafter, the chairman and secretary for the ensuing year shall be elected. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by two (2) members of the commission upon delivery of written notice to each member of the commission. Three (3) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. 
2-12-4. - Duties and powers. 
    In addition to any other powers which may be vested in it by ordinance, the commission shall have the following powers: 
(a)  To prepare and develop a general comprehensive plan for the prevention, abatement and control of air pollution within the city. 
(b)  To draft and recommend to the city council for enactment into law reasonable rules and regulations and procedures for the enforcement thereof which may be necessary to achieve the objectives of this chapter in a manner consistent with applicable state and federal laws. 
(c)  To request and receive the assistance of any state educational institution, experimental station, board, department and officials and employees thereof, or other state agency when deemed necessary or beneficial by the commission to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(d)  To encourage voluntary cooperation by persons or affected groups in restoring and preserving a reasonable degree of purity of air within the city. 
(e)  To encourage, advise, consult and cooperate with authorized air pollution agencies of the state, other states and the federal government, municipalities, industries and with interested persons or groups to achieve the general purposes and intent of this chapter. 
(f)  To represent the city in any and all matters pertaining to plans, procedures or negotiations for the establishment of inter-city or regional air pollution control agencies for the establishment of uniform laws concerning air pollution. 
2-12-5. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
    The intent and purpose of this chapter is to maintain the purity of the air resources of the city consistent with the protection of the normal health, general welfare and physical property of the people, maximum employment and the full industrial development of the city. The commission shall seek the accomplishments of these objectives through the prevention, abatement and control of air pollution by all practical and economically feasible methods. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 13. - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-13-1. - Creation of commission. 
(a)  There is hereby established an electrical commission for the city, which shall consist of six (6) members, as follows: the director of planning and development shall be a member ex-officio chairman of such commission and of the other six (6) members, one shall be a registered engineer, one shall be an electrical contractor, one a journeyman electrician, one a representative of an electrical supply company and one the fire chief. Such members shall be appointed for a term of one year by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council. In the absence of a resident to fill a required category, any resident may be appointed. 
(b)  The commission shall recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment designed to meet the necessities and conditions that prevail in this city, shall recommend reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits by the director and shall recommend reasonable fees to be paid for inspections to the director of all electrical equipment installed or altered within the city. 
(c)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the electrical commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the electrical commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the electrical commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the electrical commission. 
(Ord. 1820, 11-24-81; Ord. No. 4245 , § 12, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 14. - BUILDING BOARD OF APPEALS 
SECTION: 

2-14-1. - Creation; chairman. 
(a)  There is hereby established in the city a board to be called the building board of appeals, consisting of five (5) members who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon matters pertaining to building construction and who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. 
    The mayor shall designate one of the members to serve as chairman. 
(b)  The zoning board of appeals shall serve as ex officio building board of appeals unless such board is duly filled by appointment; and the zoning board of appeals shall perform the duties of such board in the absence of such appointment. 
2-14-2. - Term of office. 
    The mayor shall appoint one (1) member of the building board of appeals for a term of one (1) year, one (1) member for a term of two (2) years, one (1) member for a term of three (3) years, one (1) member for a term of four (4) years, and one (1) member for a term of five (5) years. Upon expiration of the term of office of a member of the board, his successor shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years. Terms shall run from May 1 through April 30. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which original appointments are required to be made. Continued absence of any member from regular meetings of the board shall, at the discretion of the mayor, render any such member liable to immediate removal from office by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 16, 9-16-14) 
2-14-3. - Meetings, quorum and voting. 
(a)  The board shall meet at least once each month or on call of the chairman or upon written request of at least three (3) members of the board. 
(b)  Four (4) members of the board shall constitute a quorum. All actions of the board must have the concurrence of at least a majority of those present and voting. In varying the application of any provision of this Code or in modifying an order of the director of buildings and inspections affirmative votes of three (3) members shall be required. In the event a quorum is not present, but at least one (1) member is present, action on an appeal brought before the board may be taken by a written vote of a majority of the members upon each voting member certifying that he or she has read and considered the transcript of the hearing proceedings held by the board in his or her absence. No member of the board shall pass upon any question in which he, or any corporation in which he is a shareholder, is interested. 
(c)  Any member of the board who fails to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the board, whether for the conduct of administrative matters or hearings of appeals, without prior consent of the chairman, shall be deemed to have resigned from the board. Thereupon, the chairman of the board shall notify the Mayor of the City of East Peoria so that the mayor may make an appointment to fill the vacancy for the remainder of the term. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 16, 9-16-14) 
2-14-4. - Meetings and records; procedure. 
(a)  All hearings before the board shall be open to the public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon every question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such facts, and shall also keep records of its examinations and other official action. Such minutes and such records shall be public records. 
(b)  The board shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the building board of appeals, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the building board of appeals or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the building board of appeals or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the building board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 16, 9-16-14; Ord. No. 4245 , § 13, 9-15-15) 
2-14-5-2-14-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4187, § 16, adopted Sept. 16, 2014, deleted §§ 2-14-5-2-14-8, which pertained to appeals, modifications and variations by board, decision by board and appeals from decision of board, and derived from the 1970 Code. 
CHAPTER 15. - BOARD OF MINIMUM HOUSING APPEALS 
SECTION: 

2-15-1. - Board of appeals; establishment, appointment. 
    There is hereby established a board of minimum housing appeals consisting of seven (7) members who are qualified by experience and training, and who shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. 
    The zoning board of appeals shall serve as ex officio minimum housing board of appeals unless such board is duly filled by appointment; and the zoning board of appeals shall perform the duties of such board in the absence of such appointment. 
2-15-2. - Terms of members; vacancies; chairman. 
    The mayor shall appoint one member of the board of appeals for a term of one year, one member for a term of two (2) years, one member for a term of three (3) years, one member for a term of four (4) years, one member for a term of five (5) years, one member for a term of six (6) years and one member for a term of seven (7) years. Upon the expiration of the term of office of a member of the board, his successor shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which original appointments are required to be made. The mayor shall designate one of the members to serve as chairman. The director of city inspections shall be an ex officio member of the board and shall act as secretary of the board. 
2-15-3. - Function of board.
