    The board of minimum housing appeals shall perform those duties and functions as are set forth in section 4-8-8 of this Code. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 16. - EAST PEORIA YOUTH COUNCIL 
SECTION: 

2-16-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the East Peoria Youth Council consisting of twenty (20) board members who over the years have shown a special, vital and public-spirited interest in youth leadership and youth problems in the city. 
(Ord. 2112, 2-18-86) 
2-16-2. - Purpose. 
    The overall purpose of the youth council shall be to encourage the continuing betterment of opportunities for the wholesome development of the youth in the city. 
2-16-3. - Appointment and vacancies. 
    The board members of the youth council shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by the city council. In making appointments to fill vacancies, the mayor shall first consider recommendations made by the East Peoria Youth Council Board. In the month of December the Board of the East Peoria Youth Council shall make its recommendations for appointments to fill any vacancies, and all appointments so made shall become effective on January 1 next following such appointments. Vacancies which may occur by reason of death or resignation may be filled by appointment of the mayor after recommendation by the Board of the East Peoria Youth Council. 
(1970 Code) 
2-16-4. - Term and selection of officers. 
    The terms of the members of the Board of the East Peoria Youth Council shall be for three (3) years, except for the terms of initial appointees or newly created positions on the board. The terms of board members shall be assigned so that the terms of six (6) board members shall end on December 31, 1986, the terms of seven (7) board members shall end on December 31, 1987 and the term of the remaining seven (7) board members shall end on December 31, 1988. 
    The Board of the East Peoria Youth Council shall select its own chairman and officers in accordance with the procedures which said council may adopt. 
(Ord. 2112, 2-18-86) 
2-16-5. - Duties. 
    The Board of the East Peoria Youth Council shall: 
(a)  Assist in coordinating and integrating governmental and private plans and services affecting the welfare of children and youth in the city. 
(b)  Assist in coordinating and integrating all plans and services for protecting children from exposure to harmful influences and conditions conducive to delinquency. 
(c)  Make or cause to be made studies and surveys related to juvenile behavior or in the interest of youth guidance. 
(d)  Request and obtain such cooperation, assistance and data from city departments and agencies as may be reasonably necessary to carry out its work. 
(e)  Recommend plans and methods for the improvement of opportunities for the wholesome development of youth in the city. 
(f)  Create subcommittees, composed of members or nonmembers of said council, to aid and assist in the work of the council. 
(g)  Create a special subcommittee consisting of persons qualified by experience and training to provide guidance and counsel to children referred to it by the police department, the courts, the schools, any social agency or member of the community. 
(h)  Meet at least once a month. 
2-16-6. - Service contract. 
    The youth council may enter into a purchase of service contract or agreement with public and/or private agencies provided that such contract or agreement is first approved by a majority vote of the city council. 
2-16-7. - Ex officio members. 
    The mayor, chief of police, dean of boys and dean of girls at the high school and counselor of boys and counselor of girls at the junior high school, in the city, shall be ex officio members of the Board of the East Peoria Youth Council. 
(1970 Code) 
2-16-8. - Summary report. 
    In December of each year, the East Peoria Youth Council shall prepare and submit to the mayor and city council of the city a summary report of its activities, operations, studies and meetings held and attendance at said meetings during the preceding fiscal year, along with a statement of projected plans for the subsequent fiscal year. The council shall keep a written record of its proceedings which shall be kept by the East Peoria City Clerk and which shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. 1220, 11-11-75) 
2-16-9. - Meetings. 
    All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period, from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Youth Council, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Youth Council or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the East Peoria Youth Council or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the East Peoria Youth Council. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 14, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 18. - MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
SECTION: 

2-18-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a Board of Trustees for the East Peoria Mass Transit District, which shall be composed of three (3) members. 
2-18-2. - Composition; appointment of members; terms. 
    The members of the board of trustees shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the city council. The three (3) members first appointed after the passage of this chapter shall serve the following terms: 
One trustee shall serve for four (4) years; 
One trustee shall serve for three (3) years; and 
One trustee shall serve for two (2) years. 
    A trustee having been duly appointed shall continue to serve after the expiration of his term until his successor has been appointed. All terms shall expire on April 30 in their final year. 
2-18-3. - Creation of mass transit district. 
    There is hereby created and established a local mass transit district to be known as the East Peoria Mass Transit District in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 111 2/3 , Section 353, Illinois Revised Statutes. 
2-18-4. - Powers, rights, duties. 
    The East Peoria Mass Transit District Board of Trustees shall have all the powers, rights and duties enumerated and granted pursuant to the provisions of the Local Mass Transit District Act, being Chapter 111 2/3 , Sections 351 through 359, Illinois Revised Statutes and such others as are provided by law. 
(1970 Code) 
2-18-5. - Meetings. 
    All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the mass transit district board of trustees, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the mass transit district board of trustees or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the mass transit district board of trustees or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the mass transit district board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 15, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 19. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD 
SECTION: 

2-19-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a five-member foreign fire insurance board for the city, comprised of one (1) appointed trustee and four (4) elected trustees as set forth below, whose purpose is to establish rules and regulations with respect to the management of money to be received by the city as foreign fire insurance tax receipts as provided by Section 11-10-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-2. - Definitions. 
    Board means the foreign fire insurance board. 
    Department means the East Peoria Fire Department. 
    Fund means the foreign fire insurance tax fund. 
    Members of the department means any person currently employed full-time in the East Peoria Fire Department in the position of firefighter, paramedic, lieutenant, assistant chief or chief. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-3. - Board members. 
    The foreign fire insurance board shall consist of five (5) members. 
(a)  The city administrator shall appoint one (1) member of the department as trustee of the board. Such trustee shall continue to serve until either replaced at the sole discretion of the city administrator or until no longer employed with the city. 
(b)  The members of the department belonging to the bargaining unit shall elect four (4) trustees of the board by secret ballot in an election held on the first Monday in November of odd numbered years. The trustees so elected shall serve two (2) year terms beginning January 1 following the election. Two (2) of these members so elected to serve as trustees shall be elected by the board to the offices of chairman and treasurer and shall serve a two-year term beginning January 1 following the election. Upon passage of this chapter, the members of the department belonging to the bargaining unit shall hold an election for these trustees and offices for a term to begin immediately and end on December 31, 1999. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-4. - Duties and powers. 
(a)  Chairman. The chairman shall: 
(1)  Coordinate with the treasurer to establish any needful rules and regulations as provided in section 5 of this chapter. 
(2)  Preside at all meetings of the foreign fire insurance board. 
(3)  Coordinate with the treasurer to develop and maintain a list of items the board determines to be appropriate expenditures as provided in section 2-19-7 of this chapter. 
(4)  In general, perform all duties incidental to the office of chairman. 
(b)  Treasurer. The treasurer shall: 
(1)  Coordinate with the chairman to establish any needful rules and regulations as provided in section 2-19-5 of this chapter. 
(2)  Have charge and custody of and be responsible for all funds collected by the city from the foreign fire insurance tax revenues as described in section 11-10-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code; 
(3)  Coordinate with the chairman to develop and maintain a list of items the board determines to be appropriate expenditures as provided in section 2-19-7 of this chapter. 
(4)  Deposit all such monies in the name of the City of East Peoria Fire Department in interest-bearing savings accounts, interest-bearing certificates of deposit or interest-bearing time deposits, or any other investments constituting direct obligations of any bank as defined by the Illinois Banking Act, or in any other investment as allowed under the Public Funds Investment Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 30, Sections 235 and following. 
(5)  Maintain financial books and records of the board; 
(6)  Give a sufficient bond to the city. This bond shall be approved by the mayor and conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his or her duties under the city ordinances and the rules and regulations provided for in the Illinois Municipal Code; 
(7)  Receive the foreign fire insurance company fees so paid and shall pay out the money upon order of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department; 
(8)  Keep and distribute minutes of the board to all board trustees and the city clerk; 
(9)  In general, perform all duties incidental to the office of treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-5. - Rules and regulations. 
    The officers of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to department Foreign Fire Insurance Board and the management of money appropriated to the board. All such rules and regulations promulgated by the officers of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board must be consistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-6. - Transfer of tax receipts. 
    The city treasurer shall pay the sums received as a result of foreign fire insurance tax revenues as specified in section 11-10-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code to the treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-7. - Budget. 
(a)  The foreign fire insurance board shall approve a yearly budget for the expenditure of foreign fire insurance tax revenues upon an affirmative vote of at least three (3) trustees by March of each year. Said budget shall prescribe a detailed description of prioritized items for which foreign fire insurance tax revenues will be expended in the upcoming fiscal year (May 1-April 30). The items appropriated in the budget shall be purchased in the order of their priority. After the budget is approved, the chairman and treasurer shall develop and maintain a list of the items in the order of their board-determined priority, together with their estimated cost and procurement date which shall be posted in a prominent place within the department. Under no circumstances shall any funds be expended for an item which does not have top priority in the budget. All funds shall be expended for the maintenance, use and benefit of the East Peoria Fire Department. 
(b)  Budget amendments. The foreign fire insurance board budget referred to in subsection (a) may be amended at any time upon an affirmative vote of at least three (3) trustees of the foreign fire insurance board. 
(c)  Accumulation of funds. The board shall not accumulate funds in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) unless the accumulation is for a specific capital expenditure appropriated in the budget. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-8. - Annual audit. 
    The foreign fire insurance board shall provide to the city council an annual audit of the financial affairs of the foreign fire insurance board to be made by the city treasurer or his or her appointee at the end of each fiscal year in accordance with generally accepted auditing principles. In the event the treasurer shall select an outside accounting firm or agency to perform the annual audit, any expense shall be paid from the foreign fire insurance tax revenues. 
(Ord. No. 2959, § 1, 4-27-99) 
2-19-9. - Meetings. 
    All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the foreign fire insurance board, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the foreign fire insurance board or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the foreign fire insurance board or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the foreign fire insurance board. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 16, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 20. - COMMISSION ON POLICE-COMMUNITY RELATIONS 
SECTION: 

2-20-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a commission for the betterment of police-community relations for the City of East Peoria, Illinois, which shall be known as the Commission on Police-Community Relations of East Peoria. 
2-20-2. - Composition; appointment of members; salary; terms. 
    The Commission of Police-Community Relations of East Peoria created by section 2-20-1 above shall consist of nine (9) persons appointed by the mayor to serve without salary for four (4) year terms, except that of such members first appointed, two (2) shall hold office for one year; two (2) for two (2) years; two (2) for three (3) years; and three (3) for four (4) years; and until their respective successors are duly appointed and qualified. 
    The mayor shall appoint as members of the commission, one member of the city council, one member of the high school board, one member of the East Peoria Fire and Police Commission, one member as representative of the East Peoria business community, two (2) members from the young persons of the city under twenty-one (21) years of age, and three (3) members of the East Peoria Police Department. 
    The chairman of the commission shall be elected from and by the commission members for a term of one calendar year. The commission shall have the power to establish bylaws and rules in conformity with the authority to elect or appoint such other officers as the commission deems necessary; but the chairman of the commission or any such officer appointed or elected by the commission, may be removed at any time by a majority of votes of the duly appointed members of the commission. 
2-20-3. - Purpose; function. 
    The purpose of the Commission on Police-Community Relations of East Peoria shall be to promote and foster a better understanding of the respective obligations and responsibilities of police officers and citizens of the city; to promote and foster respect for law, individual rights and fundamental principles of civil government; with a view towards creating a climate of better understanding and communication between the citizens of this community, especially the young, and East Peoria police personnel. 
2-20-4. - Budget; salaries. 
    The commission shall operate under such budgets, if any, as may from time to time be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city, but any expenditures therefrom, including employees' salaries, shall be made only upon approval of the mayor and in accordance with ordinance and statutory requirements. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 21. - CRIME PREVENTION AND CONTROL COUNCIL 
SECTION: 

2-21-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a council on crime prevention and control for the city, which shall be known as the East Peoria Council on Crime Prevention and Control. 
2-21-2. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The council created in section 2-21-1 shall consist of fifteen (15) members to be appointed by the mayor. 
    The mayor shall appoint the following persons to serve on the council for an indefinite term: 
(a)  The East Peoria Chief of Police; 
(b)  The East Peoria City Attorney; 
(c)  The Chairman of the East Peoria Commission on Police-Community Relations; 
(d)  A member of the East Peoria Fire and Police Commission; 
(e)  One member of the East Peoria City council; 
The mayor shall further invite the following persons to serve as regular members of said council, and upon their acceptance, appoint such person or a representative selected by him to serve for an indefinite term: 
(f)  The State's Attorney of Tazewell County; 
(g)  The Sheriff of Tazewell County; 
(h)  The officer in charge of State Police District 8; 
(i)  The Tazewell County Probation Officer; 
(j)  A Circuit Judge, Associate Circuit Judge or Magistrate of the Tenth Judicial Circuit, Tazewell County, Illinois; 
(k)  The Tazewell County Coroner; and the mayor shall further appoint to serve for two (2) year terms; 
(l)  One representative of the Clergy of East Peoria; 
(m)  One representative of industry; 
(n)  One representative of labor; 
(o)  One representative from the field of education. 
    Terms of members selected by reference to particular office shall expire upon the termination of such term of office; all members shall serve without pay, unless otherwise determined by action of the city council. 
    The chairman of the council shall be elected from and by the council members for a term of one calendar year. The council shall have the power to establish such by-laws and rules in conformity with the authority to elect or appoint such other officers as the council deems necessary; but the chairman of the council or any such officer appointed or elected by the council, may be removed from office at any time by a majority of votes of the duly appointed members of the council. 
2-21-3. - Purpose; function. 
    The purposes and function of the East Peoria Council on Crime Prevention and Control shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(a)  To determine and evaluate the status of law and order in the greater East Peoria community. 
(b)  To select and develop new techniques and approaches-short, intermediate and long-range-for dealing with the problems of crime prevention and control. 
(c)  To establish and recommend priorities for solving specific problems of crime prevention and control together with the means of translating such priorities into action. 
(d)  To determine and recommend ways and means of raising the professional standards of personnel entering the criminal justice area. 
(e)  To determine and recommend ways and means of improving communications and working relationships between all criminal justice agencies and personnel. 
(f)  To determine and recommend ways and means of improving through inter-agency cooperation the in-service, continuing professional education of law enforcement personnel. 
(g)  To establish and maintain contacts with such other agencies, councils or organizations throughout the State of Illinois and the United States for purposes of learning and evaluating new approaches or techniques in the criminal justice area which are or which soon will be in current use. 
2-21-4. - Budget; salaries. 
    The council shall operate under such budget, if any, as may from time to time be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city; expenditures for secretarial services, transcript of proceedings, postage, travel and subscriptions shall be made only upon prior approval by resolution of the city council. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 22. - WATER POLLUTION CONTROL COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-22-1. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a water pollution control commission of the city, which shall be known as the East Peoria Water Pollution Control Commission. The commission shall be composed of five (5) members to be appointed by the mayor. 
2-22-2. - Members' terms of office. 
    The term of office of the members of the commission shall be four (4) years and until their successors are selected and qualified, except that the terms of those first appointed shall expire as follows: 
One at the end of one year after date of appointment; 
One at the end of two (2) years after date of appointment; 
One at the end of three (3) years after date of appointment; 
Two (2) at the end of four (4) years after date of appointment; 
as designated by the mayor at the time of appointment. The terms of all members shall continue until their respective successors have been duly appointed and qualified. If a vacancy occurs in the appointed membership, the mayor may appoint a member for the remaining portion of the unexpired term created by the vacancy. The mayor may remove any appointed member for cause. The members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their services, but may be reimbursed for expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties. 
2-22-3. - Meetings. 
    The commission shall hold at least six (6) regular meetings each calendar year at a place and time to be fixed by the commission. The commission shall select at its first meeting one of its members to serve as chairman and another of its members to serve as secretary. At the first regular meeting in each calendar year thereafter, the chairman and secretary for the ensuing year shall be elected. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by two (2) members of the commission upon delivery of written notice to each member of the commission. Three (3) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. 
2-22-4. - Duties and powers. 
    In addition to any other powers which may be vested in it by ordinance, the commission shall have the following powers: 
(a)  To study the progress and problems of the City of East Peoria, and the greater East Peoria environment, in regard to water pollution and water resources. 
(b)  To study the inter-relationship between the various units of government, federal, state, county and local in the administration of their respective programs and projects concerning water pollution and the role of the city in such programs and projects so as to more effectively deal with the problem of water pollution in the city. 
(c)  To prepare and develop a general comprehensive plan for the prevention, abatement and control of water pollution within the city. 
(d)  To draft and recommend to the city council for enactment into law reasonable rules and regulations and procedures for the enforcement thereof which may be necessary to achieve the objectives of this chapter in a manner consistent with applicable state and federal laws and regulations. 
(e)  To request and receive the assistance of any state educational institution, experimental station, board, department or officials and employees thereof, or other state agency when deemed necessary or beneficial by the commission to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(f)  To encourage voluntary cooperation by persons or effective groups in restoring and preserving a reasonable degree of purity of water within the city. 
(g)  To encourage, advise, consult and cooperate with authorized water pollution agencies of the state, or other states and the Federal government, municipalities, industries and with interested persons or groups to achieve the general purposes and intent of this chapter. 
(h)  To represent the city in any and all matters pertaining to plans, procedures or negotiations for the establishment of inter-city or regional water pollution control agencies for the establishment of uniform laws concerning water pollution. 
2-22-5. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
    The intent and purpose of this chapter is to maintain the purity of the water resources of the city consistent with the protection of the normal health, general welfare and physical property of the people, maximum employment and the full industrial development of the city. The commission shall seek the accomplishment of these objectives through the prevention, abatement and control of water pollution by all practical and economically feasible methods, taking into consideration both the needs of the present and future generations. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 23. - EAST PEORIA BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-23-1. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established, in and for the city, a commission to be known as the City of East Peoria Beautification Commission. The commission shall be charged with the responsibility of recommending to the city council improvements which will enhance the appearance of the city and its environs. The commission shall, in addition, assist in the implementation of such recommendations as are adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. 1953, 9-27-83) 
2-23-2. - Reserved. 
2-23-3. - Reserved. 
2-23-4. - Composition. 
    The commission shall be comprised of both voting members and associate members subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  Voting members shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council in the manner hereinafter set forth in this chapter. There shall be twenty-five (25) voting members. The powers and duties hereinafter set forth in this chapter may be exercised only by voting members. Associate members are prohibited from participating in the selection of officers, voting on matters before the commission, or exercising any other right, power or authority conferred upon the members of the commission by this chapter. 
(b)  Associate members shall be selected from time to time by the commission in such number as the commission deems appropriate. Associate members shall be selected from among those individuals willing to occasionally volunteer their services to the commission. Associate members are not required to attend meetings of the commission and have no authority to exercise any right, power or duty hereinafter set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 2057, 3-5-85) 
2-23-5. - Appointment and compensation of members. 
    The members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council and shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 1242, 2-3-76, eff. 2-13-76) 
2-23-6. - Terms of office. 
    The members of the commission shall be appointed for the term of three (3) years beginning with January 1 of the year of appointment. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the council, shall have the authority to reappoint members. 
(Ord. 1560, 5-29-79) 
2-23-7. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring in the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the mayor. 
2-23-8. - Removal of members. 
    The council, by a majority vote, shall have the authority to remove any member of the commission from office, whenever, in its discretion, the best interest of the city shall be served thereby. 
(Ord. 1242, 2-3-76, eff. 2-13-76) 
2-23-9. - Officers. 
    During the first regular meeting of each calendar year, the commission shall elect from among its voting members a chairman and a vice-chairman and such other officers as the commission deems necessary. Such officers shall serve for the balance of the calendar year in which they are selected and until their successors are elected and qualified. Officers shall be eligible to succeed themselves. 
2-23-10. - Duties of officers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chairman to preside over all meetings of the commission. It shall be the duty of the vice-chairman to preside over all meetings in the absence of the chairman. In the absence of both the chairman and the vice-chairman, the voting members shall select a chairman pro tempore who shall preside until the return of either the chairman or the vice-chairman. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the secretary to keep a record of all of the proceedings of the commission, transmit the recommendations of the commission to the mayor and council and perform such other duties as are usually performed by the secretary of a deliberative body. 
(Ord. 2057, 3-5-85) 
2-23-11. - Commission staff. 
    The commission shall have the authority to employ planning consultants and/or such other professional personnel as it shall be deemed necessary within the means provided by any funds made available to the city for such purposes. In the event that it is deemed necessary to employ planning consultants, the mayor and council or their representatives shall solicit funds from individuals or organizations interested in environmental beautification and/or real estate development to pay for such consultants. The compensation of such planning consultants and such other employees of said commission as they are from time to time designated and provided for, shall be fixed by the council. 
2-23-12. - Rules and procedures. 
    The commission shall adopt a set of rules to govern its own meetings and procedures. The rules may be amended from time to time, but only upon notice of all members that said proposed amendment shall be acted upon at a specified meeting. A majority vote of the commission shall be required for the approval of the proposed amendment. 
2-23-13. - Meetings. 
(a)  The commission shall meet from time to time as may be necessary to fulfill its duties as herein established at a time and place designated by the chairman or his designee. 
(b)  The council, the chairman or any three (3) members of the commission shall have the authority to call special meetings of the commission. Written notice of special meetings shall be given to all members. 
(c)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Beautification Commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Beautification Commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the East Peoria Beautification Commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the East Peoria Beautification Commission. 
(Ord. 1242, 2-3-76, eff. 2-13-76; Ord. No. 4245 , § 17, 9-15-15) 
2-23-14. - Effect of absence of members. 
    Absence of a voting member from four (4) consecutive regular meetings without justification shall constitute the retirement of that member. The commission shall notify the city council of any such retirement and the vacancy thus created shall be filled by appointment of the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council for the duration of the unexpired term of the retired member. 
2-23-15. - Powers and duties. 
    The beautification commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  To confer with and advise the council and mayor on special projects. 
(b)  To confer with and advise the council and mayor on all matters concerning the development and beautification of the East Peoria Riverfront. 
(c)  To collect data and information as to the type and uses best suited for the beautification and development of the city and the East Peoria Riverfront. 
(d)  To encourage the proper zoning and orderly development of areas along the East Peoria Riverfront and to promote the concept of beautification of such areas of the city. 
(e)  To cooperate with all private individuals and community groups which are dedicated to the beautification and/or development of the city and to furnish them with such aid and advice as is deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. 2057, 3-5-85) 
2-23-16. - Advisory capacity. 
    Except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance, the powers and duties of the East Peoria Beautification Commission are of an advisory nature only, and the commission shall not have any powers and duties which conflict with or supersede the powers and duties of other city commissions or boards. 
2-23-17. - City officials to cooperate. 
    All officers and division heads of the city shall cooperate with the commission and render all reasonable assistance. 
2-23-18. - Commission limited in power to incur liability. 
    Neither the commission nor any member thereof shall incur any financial liability in the name of the city. 
2-23-19. - Annual report. 
    The commission shall render annually, a full report of its work to the mayor. 
(Ord. 1242, 2-3-76, eff. 2-13-76) 
CHAPTER 24. - ACCIDENT REVIEW BOARD 
SECTION: 

2-24-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be known and may be cited as the East Peoria Accident Review Board Ordinance. 
2-24-2. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their variations, shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, the words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular number include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directive. 
    Board is the East Peoria Accident Review Board, as created by this chapter. 
    Chairman is the Chairman of the East Peoria Accident Review Board as provided for hereunder. 
    City is the City of East Peoria, Illinois. 
    Council is the city council of the City of East Peoria, Illinois. 
    Fire and police commission is the Fire and Police Commission of the City of East Peoria, Illinois. 
2-24-3. - Establishment. 
    An East Peoria Accident Review Board is hereby established in and for the city. 
2-24-4. - Composition. 
    This board shall consist of three (3) members. 
2-24-5. - Appointment and compensation of members. 
    The members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council and shall serve without compensation. 
2-24-6. - Term of office. 
    The members of the board shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the council, shall have the authority to reappoint members. 
2-24-7. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring in the board shall be filled for the unexpired term by an appointment by the mayor. 
2-24-8. - Removal of members. 
    The council, by a majority vote, shall have the authority to remove any member of the board from office whenever in its discretion, the best interest of the city shall be served thereby. 
2-24-9. - Chairman. 
    Within thirty (30) days after their appointment, the members of the board shall meet in regular session and elect from their members a chairman. The board shall have the authority to appoint or elect other officers as it may deem necessary. 
2-24-10. - Duties of chairman. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chairman to preside over all of the meetings of the board. In his absence, a chairman pro-tem may be elected to preside. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the chairman to appoint one other member of the board to keep a record of all the proceedings of the board and transmit its recommendations to the city council, fire and police commission or any other appropriate body. 
2-24-11. - Board staff. 
    The board shall have the authority to employ a court reporter or such other secretarial help as may be needed by the board or given permission so to do by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council. 
2-24-12. - Rules and procedures. 
    The board shall adopt a set of rules to govern its own meetings and procedures. The rules may be amended from time to time, but only upon notice to all members that said proposed amendment shall be acted upon at a specified meeting. A majority vote of the board shall be required before the approval for the proposed amendment. 
2-24-13. - Meetings. 
(a)  The board may meet in regular session at least once a month at a time and place selected by a vote of its members, but may meet more often for special meetings if so ordered by the chairman. 
(b)  The board shall meet as soon as possible after receipt of notification from the mayor or any commissioner or director of any department or superintendent or chief of any department of the city of an accident involving any vehicle owned by the city. 
2-24-14. - Powers and duties. 
    The accident review board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  To investigate the circumstances surrounding all accidents involving vehicles owned by the city. 
(b)  To request any employee of the city to personally appear before the board to answer questions and give information regarding any accident involving a vehicle owned by the city. 
(c)  To make determinations as to whether a given accident involving a vehicle owned by the city was a preventable or unpreventable accident. 
(d)  To make recommendations to the fire and police commission or to the city council regarding any penalties or obligations which should be imposed upon employees of the city who have caused a preventable accident with a city owned vehicle. 
(e)  To make such other and further reports or recommendations to the city council or fire and police commission as it deems appropriate. 
2-24-15. - Advisory capacity. 
    Except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance, the powers and duties of the East Peoria Accident Review Board are of an advisory nature only, and the commission shall not have any powers or duties which conflict with or supersede the powers and duties of any other city commissions or boards. 
2-24-16. - City officials to cooperate. 
    All officers and department heads of the city shall cooperate with the board and render all reasonable assistance. 
2-24-17. - Board limited in power to incur liability. 
    Neither the commission nor any member thereof shall incur any financial liability in the name of the city unless so directed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council. 
2-24-18. - Annual report. 
    The board shall render annually, a full report of its work to the mayor. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 25. - RIVERFRONT DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-25-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission. 
2-25-2. - Composition and appointment of commission. 
    The East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission shall consist of twenty-six (26) persons having an interest in promoting development along the Illinois River. Members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council. The term of persons initially appointed to the commission shall end on April 30, 1993. Subsequent terms shall expire every fourth April 30 thereafter. Should any member of the commission fail to complete his term, the vacancy thus created shall be filled by appointment of the mayor for the remainder of the unexpired term. The commission shall select its own chairman and other officers in accordance with procedures which said commission may adopt. 
2-25-3. - Purpose. 
    The East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission is created for the purpose of encouraging both recreational and utilitarian uses of property along the Illinois River while at the same time maintaining its aesthetic value. 
2-25-4. - Duties. 
    The East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission shall: 
(a)  By August 1, 1990, prepare and submit to the city council for the council's review and consideration a comprehensive plan for development along that portion of the Illinois River located in and near the city. The plan submitted by the commission shall incorporate at least the following components: 
(1)  An inventory of all parcels of real property located along the east bank of the Illinois River which are either undeveloped, under developed or under utilized. 
(2)  Suggest general and, where possible, specific uses for inventoried property, which uses are consistent with the purpose identified for the commission. 
(3)  Suggest a plan under which the commission and/or the city may when appropriate offer assistance to the owners of the inventoried property in marketing the property on both a local and regional level. 
(4)  Suggest methods of involving other units of local government as well as the state and federal governments in a coordinated effort to develop the riverfront. 
(5)  Suggest potential methods for financing any improvements which might be advocated by the commission. 
(6)  Suggest means by which the development of the east bank of the Illinois River might be coordinated with potential development on the west bank of the Illinois River. 
(7)  Review the zoning codes of the city to determine what changes, if any, should be made in order to encourage and accommodate development along the riverfront. 
(b)  Upon submission of the development plan and its acceptance by the city council, the commission shall regularly monitor its implementation and shall, from time to time, make such suggestions as it deems necessary to aid in the implementation of the plan or modification of the plan. 
2-25-5. - Use of subcommittees and city staff. 
    The East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission is authorized and encouraged to form subcommittees which will work on various components of the plan. In the preparation of the plan, the commission is authorized and encouraged to seek input and assistance from members of the city's staff. 
2-25-6. - Meetings. 
(a)  The East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission and/or any subcommittees thereof shall hold such meetings as may be necessary to fulfill its duties as herein established. 
(b)  All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the East Peoria Riverfront Development Commission. 
(Ord. 2388, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4245 , § 18, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 26. - EAST PEORIA REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

2-26-1. - Short title. 
    There is hereby created a commission for the study of the redevelopment of commercial blight areas as defined in the Commercial Renewal and Redevelopment Areas Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 24, Section 11-74.2 and for the redevelopment of blighted areas and conservation areas as defined in the Real Property Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 11-74.4. The commission hereby created shall be known as the East Peoria Redevelopment Commission. 
2-26-2. - Definitions. 
    The following terms whenever used or referred to in this chapter 26 shall have the following respective meanings unless in any case a different meaning clearly appears from the context. 
    Commission means or refers to the East Peoria Redevelopment Commission. 
    Commercial Blight Act means the Commercial Renewal and Redevelopment Areas Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 24, Section 11-74.2 as it now exists or may be hereafter amended. 
    Tax Increment Act means the Real Property Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 24, Section 11-74.4 as it now exists or may be hereafter amended. 
2-26-3. - Composition; appointment of members; salaries; term. 
    The East Peoria Redevelopment Commission shall consist of nine (9) persons all to be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the majority of the city council to serve without salary. The mayor shall appoint committee members from among local merchants, owners of commercial real estate, the advertising media, residential property owners, associations, human relations commissions, labor organizations and civic organizations. 
    With the exception of six (6) of the initial nine (9) persons appointed, the commission members shall serve staggered four (4) year terms. Of the initial nine (9) commission members appointed, three (3) shall serve two (2) year terms beginning on May 8, 1979 and ending on May 7, 1981; three (3) shall serve three (3) year terms beginning on May 8, 1979 and ending on May 7, 1982, and three (3) shall serve four (4) year terms beginning of May 8, 1979 and ending on May 7, 1983. Upon the expiration of the terms of office of the original nine (9) commission members, all terms of commission members shall commence on May 8 in the year of expiration and terminate on May 7 four (4) years later. Vacancies created by death or resignation of commission members shall be filled by appointment as herein provided for the remainder of the term to be served by the departing commission member. 
    The chairman of the commission shall be elected from and by the nine (9) commission members for a term of one calendar year. The commission shall have the power to establish by-laws and rules and to appoint or elect such other officers as the commission deems necessary. The chairman of the commission or any other officer appointed or elected by the commission may be removed at any time by majority vote of the duly appointed members of the commission. 
2-26-4. - Powers and function under the commercial blight act. 
    The commission shall exercise the following powers and functions permitted or required under the provisions of the Commercial Blight Act: 
(a)  The commission shall, if requested by the city council, hold and conduct all public hearings required to be conducted under the provisions of the Commercial Blight Act in the manner and upon such notice as therein provided and make a report of the proceedings and recommendations to the city council. 
(b)  The commission shall, from time to time, vote on whether or not to approve any final Commercial Redevelopment Plan as defined in the Commercial Blight Act as such Commercial Redevelopment Plans are from time to time submitted, and further, shall report such approval or disapproval to the city council. 
(c)  The commission shall, if requested by the city council, make recommendations to the city council concerning any action which the city council may take under the terms of the Commercial Blight Act, including but not limited to property acquisition; clearing and demolition of structures; renovation or rehabilitation of structures; installation, repair or relocation of street, utilities and site improvements; appropriate charges, fees or rents for the use of buildings or properties; the application for or acceptance of loans, grants, guarantees, and donations of property, labor, or other things of value; the acquisition or construction of facilities; the designation of a redevelopment area; recommendations concerning redevelopment plans and redevelopment projects; and such other duties as the city council may from time to time authorize. 
2-26-5. - Powers and functions under the tax increment act. 
    The commission shall exercise the following powers and functions permitted or required under the provisions of the Tax Increment Act: 
(a)  The commission shall, if requested by the city council, hold and conduct all public hearings to be conducted under the provisions of the Tax Increment Act in the manner and upon such notice as therein provided and make a report of the proceedings and recommendations to the city council. 
(b)  The commission shall, if requested by the city council, make recommendations to the city council concerning any action which the city council may take under the terms of the Tax Increment Act, including but not limited to property acquisition; clearing and demolition of structures; renovation or rehabilitation of structures; installation, repair, or relocation of streets, utilities and site improvements; appropriate charges, fees or rents for the use of buildings or properties; the application for or acceptance of loans, grants, guarantees, and donations of property, labor or other things of value; the acquisition or construction of facilities; the designation of a redevelopment area; recommendations concerning redevelopment plans and redevelopment projects, and such other duties as the city council may, from time to time authorize. 
2-26-6. - Budget; salary. 
    The commission will operate under such budget if any, as may from time to time be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city but any expenditure therefrom including employee's salaries shall be made only upon approval of the mayor with the consent of the majority of the city council. 
(Ord. 1543, 5-8-79) 
2-26-7. - Meetings. 
    All open meetings shall allow for a public comment period. Each person speaking during any public comment period from the audience shall state his or her name. Each speaker shall confine comments to five (5) minutes or less, restrict remarks to matters relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Redevelopment Commission, and avoid repetitious statements. If the chair, or his designee, concludes that a speaker has unnecessarily exceeded the five (5) minute limitation, is addressing areas not relevant to the governance of the East Peoria Redevelopment Commission or has been needlessly repetitious, the speaker shall immediately conclude his or her comments. The chair may grant additional time to a speaker upon the request of any member of the East Peoria Redevelopment Commission or the speaker. No person shall speak more than once during any public comment period, except by permission of the East Peoria Redevelopment Commission. 
(Ord. No. 4245 , § 19, 9-15-15) 
CHAPTER 27. - DESIGN REVIEW COMMITTEE[2] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2544, § 5, adopted Oct. 29, 1991, repealed former Title 2, Chapter 27, pertaining to the beltline highway commission. Provisions of former Title 2, Chapter 27 derived from Ord. No. 1328, adopted Jan. 4, 1977. 

2-27-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a committee which shall be known as the "East Peoria Design Review Committee." 
(Ord. No. 3966, § 1, 3-20-12) 
2-27-2. - Composition of committee. 
    The East Peoria Design Review Committee shall consist of the mayor, the commissioner of accounts and finances, the city administrator, the director of planning and zoning, the director of public works and the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 3966, § 1, 3-20-12) 
2-27-3. - Purpose and duties of committee. 
    The East Peoria Design Review Committee shall, subject to the limitations established by this chapter, comment on, make recommendations concerning or act regarding the acquisition, improvement and development of property within or adjacent to the city. In so doing, the committee shall address aesthetic considerations related to such property, the compatibility of proposed structures and uses with structures and uses on nearby parcels, the suitability of such property for its intended use or other matters deemed by the committee to serve the interests of the city. In particular, the committee shall: 
(1)  At the request of any member of the city council or of the city administrator, review and make recommendations regarding the design, appearance and use of public buildings and land owned or to be developed by the city. 
(2)  At the request of any member of the city council or of the city administrator, review and make recommendations regarding the design, appearance and use of privately owned buildings and land purchased or to be developed with financial assistance from the city. 
(3)  Exercise authority granted specifically to the committee or generally to the city under the terms and conditions of any restrictive covenants which vest the city with the power to enforce the terms and conditions of such covenants. 
(Ord. No. 3966, § 1, 3-20-12) 
2-27-4. - Use of city staff. 
    The East Peoria Design Review Committee is authorized to use the staff and other resources of the city in order to achieve the purposes of the committee and to fulfill the duties assigned to the committee under the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3966, § 1, 3-20-12) 
2-27-5. - Meetings. 
    The East Peoria Design Review Committee shall hold such meetings as may be necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to it under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3966, § 1, 3-20-12) 
CHAPTER 28. - SUBPOENAS AND ORDERS BY BOARDS, COMMISSIONS OR AGENCIES OF THE CITY 
SECTION: 

2-28-1. - Appearances and response to subpoenas. 
    No person, who shall be served with a subpoena to appear before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas, shall refuse or neglect to appear or to testify before such board, commission or agency in response to such subpoena and as directed by such subpoena. 
2-28-2. - Production of records and responses to subpoenas. 
    No person, who shall be served with a subpoena duces tecum to produce books, papers or other material before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas, relevant to any hearing before or investigation by such board, commission or agency, shall refuse or neglect to produce such books, papers or other material at the date, time and place specified in such subpoena duces tecum. 
2-28-3. - Subsequent appearances pursuant to subpoenas. 
    No person, who shall be served with a subpoena to appear before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas, shall refuse or neglect to appear or to testify at a hearing to be held subsequent to the date and time for which such person was subpoenaed if directed or ordered so to appear by such board, commission or agency at such subsequent hearing and if such subsequent hearing pertains to the matter for which such person has initially subpoenaed. 
2-28-4. - Avoidance of service. 
    No person shall wilfully avoid service of a subpoena to appear before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas. No person shall wilfully avoid service of a subpoena duces tecum to produce books, papers or other material before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas. 
2-28-5. - Objection to subpoenas. 
    No person who shall be served with a subpoena to appear or testify before, or who shall be served with a subpoena duces tecum to produce books, papers or other material before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas, shall refuse or neglect to obey the command of any such subpoena on the contention or basis that such subpoena or the service thereof was invalid or illegal unless, within a reasonable time before the date and time specified in such subpoena for appearance or production, such person has made a written request of such board, commission or agency that such subpoena be quashed specifying in such request the reasons why the same should be quashed and unless such subpoena or the service thereof shall be, in fact, invalid or illegal. 
2-28-6. - Interference with witnesses. 
    No person shall encourage or suggest that any person not obey the command of any valid subpoena or valid subpoena duces tecum of any board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas, or attempt so to do, or conspire with any other so to do. No person shall endeavor, in any way, to prevent any person from obeying the command of any valid subpoena or valid subpoena duces tecum of any board, commission or agency of this municipality, having the power or authority to issue subpoenas, or attempt so to do, or conspire with any other so to do. No person shall encourage or suggest that any person not obey the lawful order of a board, commission or agency of this municipality directing the appearance of a person before such board, commission or agency, or directing the production of books, papers or material before such board, commission or agency, or attempt so to do, or conspire with any other so to do. No person shall endeavor, in any way, to prevent any person from obeying the lawful order of a board, commission or agency of this municipality directing the appearance of a person before such board, commission or agency or directing the production of books, papers or material before such board, commission or agency, or attempt so to do, or conspire with any other so to do. 
2-28-7. - Payment of fees and mileage. 
    The party who requests a subpoena or subpoena duces tecum for a witness to appear before a board, commission or agency of this municipality, shall pay witness fees plus mileage to that witness in the same amount as that provided for witnesses in civil cases before courts of record in this state. 
2-28-8. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of the foregoing sections of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of no less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 7, 7-3-01) 
2-28-9. - Severability clause. 
    If any provisions of this chapter or the application thereof is held to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such ruling shall not affect any other provisions of this Code not specifically included in such ruling or which can be given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or application; and to this end, the provisions of this Code are declared severable. 
(Ord. 1759, 2-10-81) 
CHAPTER 29. - TREE COMMISSION 
SECTION: 

Sec. 2-29-1. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the City of East Peoria Tree Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-2. - Composition. 
    Because Chapter 23 of the Code of the City of East Peoria establishes the City of East Peoria Beautification Commission and prescribes the composition and method of appointment of members and officers and because the goals and objectives of the beautification commission are consistent with and parallel to the goals and objectives of this Ordinance No. 2670, the city of East Peoria Beautification Commission shall function as this city's tree commission and shall have all the powers and duties set forth in this Ordinance No. 2670. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-3. - Purpose. 
    The City of East Peoria Tree Commission is created for the purpose of promoting and protecting the public health, safety and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants within East Peoria, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-4. - City-owned property. 
    Property within the city limits of East Peoria, Illinois and (1) owned by the city in fee simple absolute, or (2) implied or expressly dedicated to the public for present or further use for the purposes of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or for public easements. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-5. - Duties. 
    The East Peoria Tree Commission shall advise and consult the City Arborist of East Peoria (hereinafter "arborist") on the following matters: 
(a)  Amendments to this Ordinance No. 2670, and alterations or revisions to the Arboricultural Specifications Manual, and alterations or revisions of the Urban Forestry Plan. 
(b)  Policy concerning selection, planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants within the city. 
(c)  Allocation and expenditure of funds for the purposes set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-6. - City arborist; creation, duties. 
(a)  Creation. The position of arborist is hereby created. 
(b)  Duties. The arborist shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  The arborist, with the assistance of the tree commission, shall develop and update the Urban Forestry Plan. This plan shall describe the urban forestry activities to be undertaken by the city, the reasons for those activities and possible funding source(s), the means of accomplishing the activities, the alternatives available to the city to fund or accomplish the activity, the projected date of completion, and the consequences if the activity is not completed. 
(2)  The arborist, with the assistance of the tree commission, shall develop and periodically review and revise, as necessary, the Arboricultural Specifications Manual. This manual shall contain regulations and standards for the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants upon city-owned property. 
(3)  The arborist shall perform whatever acts are necessary, including the planting and maintenance of trees, the removal of undesirable trees, shrubs and other plants located on city-owned property to conform with the Urban Forestry Plan, the Arboricultural Specifications Manual and this chapter. 
(4)  The arborist shall establish a program of public information and education that will encourage the planting, maintenance or removal of trees, shrubs and other plants on private property in furtherance of the goals of the Urban Forestry Plan. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-7. - Public nuisance. 
    The arborist shall have the right to cause the treatment of any tree within the city that has become a public nuisance. A public nuisance includes any dead or diseased tree, any tree that constitutes a hazard to life or property, any tree that harbors insects, any tree which by location or condition constitutes an imminent danger to the health, safety or welfare of the general public. 
(a)  Public property. Any such tree located on public property shall be removed, pruned or otherwise treated by the arborist. 
(b)  Private property. If such tree is located on private property, the arborist shall send written notice to the property owner advising treatment for the tree. If the tree is not treated within thirty (30) days of the written notice, the arborist is authorized to cause the proper treatment to occur. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-8. - Permits. 
(a)  Scope of requirements. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the arborist, to engage in the following activities without a permit: 
(1)  Plant on city-owned property, or treat, prune, remove or otherwise disturb any tree, shrub or other plant located on city-owned property, except that this provision shall not be construed to prohibit owners of property adjacent to city-owned property from watering, fertilizing, trimming or otherwise treating without a permit any tree, shrub or other plant located on such city-owned property as may be required by Title 7, Chapter 3 of the East Peoria City Code; or 
(2)  Trim, prune or remove any tree or portions thereof if such tree or portion thereof reasonably may be expected to fall on city-owned property and thereby to cause damage to persons or property. 
(b)  Insurance. The arborist shall issue such permit at no charge to the applicant within seven (7) days of receipt of written request for any of the acts described in section (a) provided, however, that if the work for which a permit is issued entails the felling of any tree or part thereof, located on private property, which, as a result of such felling reasonably may be expected to fall upon city-owned property, and if such felling is done by one other than the owner of the property on which such felling is done, then the applicant shall agree to indemnify and to hold the City of East Peoria harmless for all damages resulting from work conducted pursuant to the permit and shall deposit with the arborist a liability insurance policy in the amount of $100,000.00 per person/$300,000.00 per accident for bodily injury liability and $50,000.00 aggregate for property damage liability, which policy shall name the City of East Peoria as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-9. - Interference with arborist. 
    No person shall unreasonably hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the arborist or his/her agents while engaged in the execution of enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-10. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or who fails to comply with any notice issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, upon being found guilty of violation, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
Sec. 2-29-11. - Appeal. 
    Any party who elects to dispute any action or decision by the city arborist or tree commission shall be entitled to appeal to the city council for a final determination. 
(Ord. No. 2670, § 1, 11-30-93) 
TITLE 3 - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
CHAPTER 1. - TAXES[1] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Retailers Occupation Tax, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.6. 

3-1-1 - Non-home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax. 
(a)  Tax imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than on an item of tangible personal property that is titled and registered by an agency of the State of Illinois, at retail in the city at the rate of one and three-fourths percent (1.75%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-1.6 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.6) as amended from time to time. This tax shall not be imposed on the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics. 
(b)  Returns to be filed: Each such person engaged in such business in the city shall file the report to the state department of revenue required by Section 3 of the Retailers' Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.). 
(c)  Payment of tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the reporting period. 
(Ord. No. 4353 , § 5, 3-20-18) 
Editor's note- Sections 5 and 6 of Ord. No. 4353 deleted §§ 3-1-1 and 3-1-1.1 and replaced as herein set out above. Former §§ 3-1-1 and 3-1-1.1 pertained to similar subject matter derived from: 1970 Code; Ord. 1531, adopted Jan. 16, 1979; Ord. 1717, adopted Sept. 9, 1980; Ord. No. 2674, § 5, adopted Sept. 28, 1993; and Ord. No. 2800, § 2, adopted Aug. 29, 1995. 
State Law reference- Home Rule Municipal Retailer's Occupation Tax Act, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1; Retailer's Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
3-1-2 - Non-home rule municipal service occupation tax. 
(a)  Tax imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the city in the business of making sales of service at the rate of one and three-fourths percent (1.75%) of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-1.7 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.6) as amended from time to time. This tax shall not be imposed on the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics. 
(b)  Returns to be filed: Every serviceman required to account for non-home rule municipal service occupation tax for the benefit of the city shall file the report to the state department of revenue required by Section 9 of the Service Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 1150/1 et seq.). 
(c)  Payment of tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from transfers of tangible personal property or real estate incident to a sale of service during the reporting period. 
(Ord. No. 4353 , § 7, 3-20-18) 
Editor's note- Sections 7 and 8 of Ord. No. 4353 deleted §§ 3-1-2 and 3-1-2.1 and replaced as herein set out above. Former §§ 3-1-2 and 3-1-2.1 pertained to similar subject matter derived from: 1970 Code; Ord. 1531, adopted Jan. 16, 1979; Ord. 1717, adopted Sept. 9, 1980; Ord. No. 2674, § 6, adopted Sept. 28, 1993; and Ord. No. 2800, § 3, adopted Aug. 29, 1995. 
3-1-3. - Municipal automobile renting taxes. 
(a)  Municipal automobile renting use tax: 
(1)  Tax imposed. A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in this city an automobile which is rented from a renter outside the state and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government in this city at the rate of one percent of the rental price of such automobile while this subsection is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(2)  Collection. The tax provided for in this subsection shall be collected from the persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in this city. 
(3)  Payment. The tax imposed by this subsection shall be paid to the Illinois Department of Revenue. 
(b)  Municipal automobile renting occupation tax: 
(1)  Tax imposed. A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in this city at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such rentals made in the course of such business while this subsection is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(2)  File report. Every such person engaged in such business in the city shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue required by sections two and three of An Act in Relation to a Tax Upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption approved June 29, 1933, as amended. 
(3)  Payment. At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. 1831, 1-19-82; Ord. 1834, 1-19-82) 
3-1-4. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE MAINTENANCE FEE. 
3-1-4.1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  Gross charges means the amount paid to a telecommunications retailer for the act or privilege of originating or receiving telecommunications within the city, and for all services rendered in connection therewith, valued in money whether paid in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services, and property of every kind or nature, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of such telecommunications, the cost of the materials used, labor or service costs, or any other expense whatsoever. In case credit is extended, the amount thereof shall be included only as and when paid. Gross charges for private line service shall include charges imposed at each channel point within the city, charges for the channel mileage between each channel point within the city, and charges for that portion of the interstate inter-office channel provided within the city. However, gross charges shall not include: 
(1)  Any amounts added to a purchaser's bill because of a charge made under: (i) the fee imposed by this section, (ii) additional charges added to a purchaser's bill under Section 9-221 or 9-222 of the Public Utilities Act, (iii) amounts collected under Section 8-11-17 of the Illinois Municipal Code, (iv) the tax imposed by the Telecommunications Excise Tax Act, (v) 911 surcharges, or (vi) the tax imposed by Section 4251 of the Internal Revenue Code; 
(2)  Charges for a sent collect telecommunication received outside the city; 
(3)  Charges for leased time on equipment or charges for the storage of data or information or subsequent retrieval or the processing of data or information intended to change its form or content. Such equipment includes, but is not limited to, the use of calculators, computers, data processing equipment, tabulating equipment, or accounting equipment and also includes the usage of computers under a time-sharing agreement; 
(4)  Charges for customer equipment, including such equipment that is leased or rented by the customer from any source, wherein such charges are disaggregated and separately identified from other charges; 
(5)  Charges to business enterprises certified under Section 9-222.1 of the Public Utilities Act to the extent of such exemption and during the period of time specified by the city; 
(6)  Charges for telecommunications and all services and equipment provided in connection therewith between a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries, and only to the extent that the charges between the parent corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries represent expense allocation between the corporations and not the generation of profit other than a regulatory required profit for the corporation rendering such services; 
(7)  Bad debts (bad debt means any portion of a debt that is related to a sale at retail for which gross charges are not otherwise deductible or excludable that has become worthless or uncollectible, as determined under applicable federal income tax standards; if the portion of the debt deemed to be bad is subsequently paid, the retailer shall report and pay the tax on that portion during the reporting period in which the payment is made); 
(8)  Charges paid by inserting coins in coin-operated telecommunications devices; or 
(9)  Charges for telecommunications and all services and equipment provided to the city. 
(b)  Public right-of-way means any municipal street, alley, water or public right-of-way dedicated or commonly used for utility purposes, including utility easements wherein the city has acquired the right and authority to locate or permit the location of utilities consistent with telecommunications facilities. "Public right-of-way" shall not include any real or personal city property that is not specifically described in the previous sentence and shall not include city buildings and other structures or improvements, regardless of whether they are situated in the public right-of-way. 
(c)  Retailer maintaining a place of business in this state , or any like term, means and includes any retailer having or maintaining within the state, directly or by a subsidiary, an office, distribution facilities, transmission facilities, sales office, warehouse, or other place of business, or any agent or other representative operating within this state under the authority of the retailer or its subsidiary, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or other representative is located here permanently or temporarily, or whether such retailer or subsidiary is licensed to do business in this state. 
(d)  Sale of telecommunications at retail means the transmitting, supplying, or furnishing of telecommunications and all services rendered in connection therewith for a consideration, other than between a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries, when the gross charge made by one such corporation to another such corporation is not greater than the gross charge paid to the retailer for their use or consumption and not for sale.
