    It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver or cause to be delivered off-premises any alcoholic liquor sold at retail except by a nationally recognized shipping and delivery carrier, which includes the United States Postal Service (USPS), FedEx, UPS, DHL, or other similar service provider. 
(Ord. No. 4379 , § 2, 3-20-18) 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate hours for sale of alcoholic liquor, 235 ILCS 5/6-14. 
3-3-4.16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4379 , § 3, adopted Mar. 20, 2018, deleted § 3-3-4.16 entitled "Marking of delivery vehicles required." 
3-3-4.17. - Transportation of distillery mash. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transport or carry any distillery mash over, upon or along the streets of the city, or to place the same for transportation in any container that is not watertight. 
3-3-4.18. - Restrictions on use of certain premises. 
(a)  No person operating or conducting a class A tavern or restaurant shall serve or permit to be served any alcoholic liquors of any kind in a private apartment or booth, the interior of which is shut off from the general pubic view by doors, curtains, screenings, partitions or other devices of any kind; and no such private apartment or booth may be maintained as part of or adjacent to any class A tavern or restaurant. These restrictions shall not apply to room service at duly licensed hotels and motels, nor to banquet rooms operated as a part of the ordinary business of any class A tavern or restaurant. 
(b)  Except as provided in section 3-3-3.2 relating to special outdoor sales and consumption permits, in section 3-3-3.5 relating to permanent outdoor sales and consumption permits, and in subsection 3-3-1.4(b)6 relating to class F licenses, a person holding a license for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor shall not allow the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises on the exterior of a totally enclosed permanent structure located on the licensed premises. For the purposes of this section, patios, open porches, roof tops, balconies, stoops, sidewalks, yards, driveways, parking lots and similar outside areas are deemed to be on the exterior of a totally enclosed permanent structure. 
(c)  Except as provided in section 3-3-3.2 relating to special outdoor sales and consumption permits, in section 3-3-3.5 relating to permanent outdoor sales and consumption permits, and in subsection 3-3-1.4(b)(6) relating to class F licenses, it shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic liquor on any licensed premises on the exterior of a totally enclosed permanent structure located on the licensed premises. 
3-3-4.19. - Condition of premises. 
    All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage of such liquor for retail sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with all provisions of this Code and other ordinances of this city regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption; city police officers and city building and health inspectors are authorized to conduct inspections of such premises at all times during business hours to assure compliance with this provision. 
3-3-4.20. - Off-street parking required. 
    All premises, except those for which a class F license has been authorized, used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor shall comply with the off-street parking and loading requirements of title 5, chapter 7 of the East Peoria City Code. 
3-3-4.21. - Books and records. 
    It shall be the duty of every licensee to make books and records available upon reasonable notice for the purpose of investigation by the local liquor control commission having jurisdiction over the licensee. Such books and records need not be maintained on the licensed premises, but must be maintained in the state. 
3-3-4.22. - Certain sexually oriented activities prohibited. 
    The following kinds of conduct are prohibited on premises in this city used for the sale of alcoholic liquor: 
(1)  The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
(2)  The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
(3)  The actual or simulated displaying of the breasts, buttocks, pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. 
(4)  The permitting by a licensee or agent of a licensee of any person to remain in or upon the premises who exposes to public view any portion of his or her genitals, vulva, anus, breasts, buttocks or pubic hair or engages in any of the conduct prohibited by subsections (1), (2) or (3) immediately above. 
(Ord. 2484, 2-26-91) 
3-3-4.23. - Distance measurement. 
    Whenever in this chapter 3, a licensed premises is required to be located a specific distance from a church or a building or structure designed for or devoted to, or being used for, any residential use, the distance shall be measured from the nearest point of a licensed building in which alcoholic liquor may be sold or served to the nearest point of the adjacent building, not including accessory buildings. For purposes of this section, any area located outside of a building on which alcoholic liquor may be sold, served or consumed (e.g., beer garden), shall be considered as a part of the licensed building when making the distance measurement. Whenever in this chapter 3, a licensed premises is required to be located a specific distance from a school, hospital, home for the aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children, or any military or naval station, the distance shall be measured from the lot line or property line of the licensed premises to the lot line or property line of the other specific use identified in this sentence. 
(Ord. No. 3472, § 11, 9-16-03) 
3-3-5-3-3-5.8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3050, § 3, adopted Feb. 17, 1998, repealed §§ 3-3-5-3-3-5.8, which pertained to licensing of bartenders, and derived from the original title 3, ch. 3, and Ord. No. 2131, adopted July 29, 1986. 
CHAPTER 4. - AMUSEMENTS 
SECTION: 

3-4-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Entertainment or amusement means and includes any theatrical exhibition, show or similar amusement or entertainment offered, operated, presented or exhibited for gain or for admission to which the public is required to pay a fee. 
    Place means the theater, opera house, auditorium, hall, park grounds, gardens, premises, tent or other enclosure within which it is intended to produce, offer or present any amusement or entertainment. 
3-4-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent or in any other capacity, to give, conduct, produce or offer for gain or profit any of the entertainments, exhibitions, performances or amusements specified and defined in this chapter without first having obtained a license therefor. 
State Law reference- City to license, tax, regulate and prohibit amusements generally, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq. 
3-4-3. - Application. 
    Application for the license required by the preceding section shall be made in writing to the city clerk, stating the full name of the applicant, if an individual, and if a corporation, the full names and residences of its principal officers; the location and description of the building, enclosure or place for which a license is desired or where it is desired to present any public amusement; the class of entertainment it is desired to produce, offer or present at such place; the seating capacity and the price of admission intended to be charged; provided, however, that if the named location or premises is not a fit and proper place, or is not conducted or maintained in accordance with the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city governing or controlling such places, or if the entertainment desired to be produced or offered is of an immoral or dangerous character, or if the person making application for a license is not of good character, the mayor may refuse to approve such application. No license shall be issued by the city clerk, except upon the approval of the application therefor by the mayor. 
3-4-4. - Bond required. 
    Whenever any application for a license shall include the use or occupancy of a public street or other public grounds, every applicant shall file with such application a certificate of bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), payable to the City of East Peoria, with sureties to be approved by the commissioner of accounts and finances, conditioned that the applicant, his heirs, executors and assignees will indemnify, save and keep harmless the city from any and all loss from damage and claims for damages arising from or out of the use of such public street or public grounds; and further conditioned that such person will keep the city harmless from all litigation and for the faithful performance and observance of all the terms and conditions of this chapter. 
3-4-5. - Classification, generally. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, all amusements are divided into the following classes: 
(a)  Class I. All entertainment of the theatrical, dramatic or operatic character. All musical entertainment consisting solely of vocal or instrumental music, or both, or in the nature of an opera, but being what is commonly styled or known as a "concert." 
(b)  Class II. Any park, garden or other premises of the kind commonly known and described as summer gardens, in which musical entertainment only, whether instrumental or vocal, or both, is furnished. 
(c)  Class III. All exhibitions of motion pictures, moving pictures or cinema. 
(d)  Class IV. All baseball, basketball, football or similar games or sports, including all athletic exhibitions or performances presented, given or conducted in any building, under canvas or other covering or within any enclosure. 
(e)  Class V. All lectures, readings or recitations, exhibitions of paintings or statuary, or other exhibitions of art. 
(f)  Class VI. Dances, bazaars and other entertainment of like character conducted, carried on or engaged in any hall, structure or building. 
(g)  Class VII. Exhibitions of fireworks. 
(h)  Class VIII. All poultry shows, horse shows, stock shows, flower shows, dog shows, cat shows, automobile shows and any other show or exhibition of like character, intended to represent any sport, art, science, technology or the progress or development of the same. 
(i)  Class IX. Any collection of animals, commonly known as a zoo, kept for public exhibitions. 
(j)  Class X. All circuses, menageries, rodeos, wild west shows or entertainment of like character, caravans, side shows, exhibitions of monsters or freaks of nature, and street fairs. 
(k)  Class XI. Each merry-go-round, revolving wheel carrying passengers, slide roller skating rink and all similar amusement devices, exhibitions, performances or entertainments not included in or carried on as a part of class XII as hereinafter described. 
(l)  Class XII. When several amusement enterprises such as shooting-the-chutes, revolving wheels, merry-go-rounds, shooting galleries, giant swings, panoramas, musical or theatrical entertainment and various other devices or entertainments are carried on, engaged in or conducted in any garden, park or other premises, whether carried on, engaged in or conducted as one enterprise or by several concessionaires and whether one admission or a separate fee is charged to each amusement enterprise, the various entertainments offered shall, for the purpose of this chapter be considered as one enterprise and shall belong to and be known as entertainments of class XII. 
(m)  Class XIII. All exhibitions, performances, entertainments or amusement devices not included in classes I through XII shall belong to and be known as entertainments of class XIII. 
3-4-6. - License fees. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specified, the annual fee for a license to present a single class of entertainment only, and no other, at a single place, shall be: 
Class I. Two hundred dollars ($200.00); provided, that if the highest price of admission shall not exceed fifty cents ($.50), then the license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
Class II. Fifty dollars ($50.00). A license may be issued to present any entertainment of classes I or II for a period not to exceed six (6) months, for which the fee shall be one-half the fees hereinabove specified. 
Class III. 
100 to 500 seats ..... $100.00 
501 to 1000 seats ..... 200.00 
1001 to 1500 seats ..... 300.00 
Over 1500 seats ..... 400.00 
Class IV. Twenty five dollars ($25.00); but for a period not to exceed six (6) months, fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
Class V. Fifty dollars ($50.00); but for a period not to exceed six (6) months, twenty five dollars ($25.00). 
Class VI. When the hall or building shall have a capacity of: 
Less than 300 persons ..... $25.00 
301 to 600 persons ..... 40.00 
Over 600 persons ..... 60.00 
Class VII. Thirty dollars ($30.00) per day. 
Class VIII. Ten dollars ($10.00) per day. 
Class IX. Fifty dollars ($50.00) per day. 
Class X. Sixty dollars ($60.00) per day. 
Class XI. One hundred dollars ($100.00); or ten dollars ($10.00) per week, or fraction thereof. 
Class XII. Five hundred dollars ($500.00); or fifty dollars ($50.00) per week, or fraction thereof. 
Class XIII. Two dollars ($2.00) per day. 
(b)  In no event shall any license hereunder be issued for any part of a license year unless otherwise specified; provided, however, that where lesser license periods are specifically provided for, no license shall be issued for any part of the shortest period so specified. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to require the payment of a fee by any person seeking to conduct an amusement for a bona fide charitable or non-profit purpose, as determined by the mayor. 
3-4-7. - Information to be shown. 
    Every license for entertainment under the provisions of this chapter shall contain a proviso that no gaming, raffle, lottery or chance gift distribution of money or articles of value shall be connected therewith or permitted by the person named in the license or in any way permitted or held out as an inducement to visitors. Such license shall also state the number of persons for which the named premises provides accommodation, and no more than that number shall be allowed to occupy such theater, hall, building or place at any one time. 
3-4-8. - Subject to provisions of Code. 
    Every license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall at all times be subject to all provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city in effect when the same shall be issued, or which shall thereafter be passed, so far as the same shall apply. 
3-4-9. - Street shows. 
    No license shall be issued for any carnival, exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such place that the main accommodation for visitors will be in a public place, except by written order of the city council. 
3-4-10. - Hours of operation. 
    The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall specify in writing upon every license issued hereunder the hours during which such amusement or entertainment must be closed to the public. 
3-4-11. - Indecent shows. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit, conduct or take part in any indecent show, theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of public amusement or show. 
3-4-12. - Crowding, riots, police protection. 
(a)  The audience of any amusement, show or theater must be orderly and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such amusement, show or theater to create an unwarranted disturbance in the audience. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any such amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risks. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to present or offer any public amusement or show of any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or disturbance. 
(d)  Sufficient members of the police department shall be admitted free of charge to all amusements for the purposes of preserving and maintaining order. 
3-4-13. - Smoking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe on or beneath the stage or in a dressing room of any building used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred (100) persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other entertainments are offered, presented, operated or exhibited. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owner or the person in control of such premises to provide and place printed signs on which the words "No smoking" shall appear in letters at least five (5) inches high in conspicuous places, at least two (2) signs being on the stage or in the wings thereof and one in each dressing room. 
3-4-14. - Exit lights. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or person in control of any building or hall in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other entertainment is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a sign on which the word "Exit" shall appear in letters at least five (5) inches high, over every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom, and a light provided with a red globe shall be placed at or over such sign, which light shall be kept burning during the entire period that the hall is open to the public and until the audience has left the hall. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 5. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
SECTION: 

3-5-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter: 
    Coin-operated amusement device means any machine, which, upon the insertion of a coin, token, slug or upon the payment of any fee, operates or may be operated by the public generally as a game or contest of skill or amusement of any kind or description, and which does not provide for any tangible payoff, reward or return of token or fee to the player; the term shall mean and include any pin ball, ball table, or marble machine or any other similar type of game, machine or table in which any ball, sphere, missile, arm, vehicle, crane, rod or plunger is struck, released, controlled or manipulated for the purpose of amusement or skill, or any electrical machine or game controlled or manipulated for the purpose of amusement or skill and in which a test of skill is involved; the term also means and includes any machine vending recorded music or a period of radio or television entertainment in return for the insertion or deposit therein of a coin, token or slug; provided, however, that this does not include coin-operated radios or televisions within private quarters. 
    Proprietor means any person acting in the capacity of owner, lessee or any other person in control, either directly or through an agent, of the premises or place wherein any coin-operated amusement device is located for the purpose of being operated. 
    Public peace means any tavern, drugstore, eating place, club room or other place open to the public generally, or to a group of selected members or patrons, wherein a coin-operated amusement device is maintained for the purpose of being operated by and for the enjoyment or benefit of the patrons, members or other persons who may be upon the premises. 
3-5-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any proprietor to use and operate or keep for use and operation any coin-operated amusement device in any public place within the city, unless a license therefor shall have first been obtained, as hereinafter provided. 
State Law reference- City to regulate and license coin-operated amusement devices, 65 ILCS 5/11-55-1. 
3-5-3. - Application. 
    Application for licenses required by the preceding section shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and shall include the following information: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation, club or partnership, the names of all principal officers thereof, and their addresses; 
(b)  All prior criminal convictions of applicant, if any; 
(c)  Place where the device is to be displayed or operated, and the business conducted at that place; 
(d)  Description of the device to be covered by the license, including mechanical features, name of manufacturer, serial number, and amount of money required for the operation thereof; 
(e)  The number and general description of all devices intended to be kept for use on the premises for which a license is required by the preceding section. 
(f)  A schedule of the hours during which such place is open for use by the members, patrons or public. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sign or present any application for a license required by this chapter, knowing it to contain any false statement. 
3-5-4. - Fee. 
    The fee for the license required under this chapter shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year, or any fraction thereof, per coin-operated amusement device; said year to correspond with the fiscal year of the city. 
3-5-5. - Issuance; contents; display; replacement. 
(a)  Upon approval by the mayor, or his representative, of the application and receipt by the city clerk of the required fee, the clerk shall issue to the applicant a license certificate or emblem, capable of being securely and permanently fixed upon a wooden or metallic surface, which emblem shall bear the name of the city, license number, year for which issued, and date of expiration. 
(b)  Such license certificate or emblem shall be displayed in a conspicuous place upon each coin-operated amusement device for which issued, and shall be securely fastened upon the same. 
(c)  In the event such certificate or emblem shall be lost or destroyed, the city clerk shall, upon application and payment of a fee of one dollar ($1.00) issue a replacement certificate or emblem expressly marked as such. 
3-5-6. - Assignment; transfer. 
    The license certificate issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid only for the person, premises and device named in the application therefor, and shall not be assignable or transferable to any other person, premises or device. 
    Written application for transfer or assignment, based upon a reasonable transfer of ownership or location, must be made to and approved by the city clerk, or else such license shall be deemed invalid. 
3-5-7. - Chapter not applicable to gambling devices. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device. 
3-5-8. - Regulations, generally. 
    No coin-operated amusement device shall be operated or kept for operation in any public place: 
(a)  Valid license not displayed. Where a valid license is not in full force and effect for the operation by the proprietor of the particular coin-operated amusement device and the same is not conspicuously affixed thereto; or 
(b)  Nuisance. At any time when, because of the condition of the premises or of the coin-operated amusement device, the operation of such device would constitute a nuisance or a fire hazard, or would in any other way endanger the safety of patrons, members of the club or other persons who may be legally upon such premises. 
3-5-9. - Possession of gambling devices prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or use in any place within the city any coin-operated mechanical device for which there has been purchased a coin-operated gambling device special tax stamp, issued by the internal revenue authorities of the United States government. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 6. - BOWLING ALLEYS AND POOLROOMS 
SECTION: 

3-6-1. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or conduct for profit within the city any billiard or pool table or bowling alley or lane without having first obtained a license therefor, as provided in this chapter. 
    Any billiard or pool table kept, used or maintained in any tavern, public place or any other premises, which table is available for the use of patrons or customers therein, shall be licensed under the provisions of this chapter, whether a fee is charged for the use of such table or not. 
State Law reference- Power of city to license, tax, regulate or prohibit bowling alleys, billiards and pools, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2. 
3-6-2. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to have, keep or maintain any billiard or pool table or bowling alley within the city for which a license is required by the preceding section, shall make written application to the city clerk therefor, setting forth in such application the full name of the applicant; the address or nature of the place at or in which such billiard or pool table or bowling alley is to be kept, used or maintained; the name and address of the owner of such premises; a description, including manufacturer's serial number, of the table or other mechanical apparatus involved; and the number of such tables or alleys which the applicant proposes to maintain at such location. 
3-6-3. - Fee. 
    Upon the written approval of the mayor with respect to such application, and upon the payment by the applicant to the city clerk of an annual license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each billiard or pool table and one dollar ($1.00) for each bowling alley which such applicant desires to use, keep or maintain, the clerk shall issue to the applicant a license authorizing the keeping, conducting or operating of such billiard or pool table or such bowling alley, as the case may be at the location described in such application, for and during the current fiscal year of the city; provided, however, that no such licensee shall be required to pay more than twenty five dollars ($25.00) fee per year with respect to bowling alleys at any one place of business, nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) fee per year with respect to billiard or pool tables at any one place of business. 
3-6-4. - Limitation. 
    No license shall be issued pursuant to this chapter for any premises where such use would be contrary to any provisions of the building or zoning regulations of the city, as set forth in Titles 4 and 5, respectively, of this Code. 
3-6-5. - Posting. 
    License certificates or emblems shall be of the type and shall be affixed as provided in section 3-5-5 of this Code. 
3-6-6. - Assignment; transfer. 
    The license certificate issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid only for the person, premises and device named in the application therefor, and shall not be assignable or transferable to any other person, premises or device. 
    Written application for transfer or assignment, based upon a reasonable transfer of ownership or location, must be made to and approved by the city clerk, or else such license shall be deemed invalid. 
3-6-7. - Minors in billiard and poolrooms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed or required to be licensed under the provisions of this chapter with respect to any billiard or pool tables to permit or allow any minor person under the age of sixteen (16) years to play thereon or to use any such table, or to be or remain in or frequent any such premises, unless accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 7. - FOOD AND BEVERAGE DEALERS 
SECTION: 

3-7-1. - LICENSES 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate the sale of foods and beverages, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 
3-7-1.1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Drink includes any liquid used or intended to be used as a beverage for human consumption, irrespective of any nourishing quality thereof. 
    Employee means any person working in a food dealer or wholesale food establishment, including the proprietor, who handles food or drink during the preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensil, or who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served, or is engaged in the plant or establishment of a wholesale food establishment, exclusive of traveling salesmen and drivers or operators of vehicles. 
    Food means any article used or intended to be used for human consumption, whether simple, mixed or compound, liquid or solid, or any article used or intended to be used as an ingredient in the composition or preparation thereof; except unprocessed fruits and vegetables of any kind. 
    Food dealer means any hotel, restaurant, cafe, club, lunchroom, grillroom, diner, buffet, cabaret, tavern, soda fountain, lunchstand, cafeteria, caterer or industrial food server dispensing food or drinks to office personnel or employees of an industrial plant, boardinghouse or transient guest house, having eating or drinking facilities for five (5) or more people, institutions, school lunch rooms, private and semi-private clubs, or any other place preparing, storing, serving, offering for sale or selling food or drink; except wholesale food establishments and retail food establishments as defined in this section. 
    Food dispenser means any proprietor, cook, chef, baker, waiter, waitress, bartender or any other person engaged in preparing or handling any food or drink intended for sale for human consumption. 
    Proprietor means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association conducting, operating or maintaining or intending to conduct, operate or maintain a food dealer as defined in this section. 
    Retail food establishment means any establishment used for the sale at retail of groceries, meats, delicatessen, poultry, candy, bakery goods and soft drinks; provided, however, that a retail food establishment shall not include any food dispenser or other person selling or serving only drink as defined in this section at retail in hermetically sealed containers, when such person does not manufacture and seal such drink himself. 
    Seat means the seating place where one patron or customer to be served can be seated; provided, that for the purpose of computing the number of seats at a counter where no fixed seats or stools are provided, two (2) lineal feet of counter space which may be used or occupied by one patron or customer to be served while standing shall be considered as a seating place. The term "seat" shall not include extra seating provided in case of special occasions. 
    Utensils means all pots, pans, dishes, plates, bowls, cups, saucers and glasses used in the preparation, service and sale of food or drink, and all knives, forks, spoons and other articles, instruments or containers used in such preparation, service and sale, or in actual eating or drinking. 
    Wholesale food establishment means any establishment used for the preparation, manufacture, canning, bottling, packing, distribution, selling or offering or keeping for sale at wholesale any article of food, confection or drink; provided, however, that wholesale milk dealers, producers and distributors, as defined and licensed in section 3-7-4 of this chapter are not included in this definition. 
State Law reference- Illinois Refrigerated Warehouses Act, definitions, 240 ILCS 35/1. 
3-7-1.2. - Conformity with chapter. 
    All food dealers, wholesale food establishments, retail food establishments, proprietors and food dispensers shall conform to the regulations of this chapter, and all such persons and places shall be subject to inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city. Unless otherwise specifically or necessarily limited, all the regulations of this chapter shall apply not only to the rooms to which the public is invited, but also to all kitchens, rooms, compartments, basements, outhouses and other places used as appurtenances to or in connection with food dealers, wholesale food establishments and retail food establishments. 
3-7-1.3. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any proprietor or other person to conduct, operate or maintain any food dealer, wholesale food establishment or retail food establishment in the city without first obtaining a license therefor in the manner provided in this chapter. 
3-7-1.4. - Operation of more than one establishment; sale of milk. 
(a)  In the case of any single proprietor operating more than one food dealer, wholesale food establishment or retail food establishment, a separate license shall be obtained for each separate establishment. 
(b)  Whenever a proprietor conducts or operates upon the same premises more than one of the various classes of food businesses established hereunder, he shall be required to procure but one license and such license shall be of the class that requires the payment of the highest license fee under this section. Whenever a proprietor has obtained a license under this section and also sells milk and milk products at retail, he shall not be required to pay the additional license fee provided for under section 3-7-4 of this chapter. 
Cross reference- License required (milk dealers), § 3-7-4.2. 
3-7-1.5. - Application. 
    Any proprietor seeking a license under the provisions of this section shall make written application for same to the city clerk, which application shall contain the name and address of the applicant. If the applicant be a firm, partnership or association, the application shall contain the names and addresses of the members thereof, and if a corporation, the names and addresses of the officers thereof. Such application shall contain such further information as may be required by the board of health to reasonably inform the board of the size and nature of the contemplated food dealer, wholesale food establishment or retail food establishment; the conditions, equipment and facilities for conducting the business; the health of persons to be employed and the regulations and facilities provided for such employees. 
3-7-1.6. - Inspection of premises to be licensed. 
    Before any license required by this section shall be issued the board of health, through its proper agents, shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises to be occupied by the applicant as a food dealer, wholesale food establishment or retail food establishment, the equipment contained therein, the persons to be employed therein and the sanitary and hygienic features and conditions thereof. If from such inspection it appears that the proposed premises are in a sanitary condition and is a fit and proper place for such business from the standpoint of public health, and that all the provisions of this chapter relating to the conduct of such business have been observed, the application shall be approved by the health officer and, upon the payment to the city clerk of the license fee provided in the following section, the clerk shall issue a license authorizing such proprietor to operate a food dealer, wholesale food establishment or retail food establishment at such place during the balance of the current fiscal year. 
3-7-1.7. - Fees; exceptions. 
    The annual license fee payable in advance for any food business is hereby fixed as follows: 
(a)  Food dealers: 
1 to 5 seats ..... $15.00 
5 to 25 seats ..... 25.00 
(b)  Retail food establishments: 
1 to 3 employees ..... 15.00 
Over 3 employees ..... 25.00 
(c)  Wholesale food establishments ..... 25.00 
    The above inspection fees shall not be required of those food dealers operated not for profit by educational, religious or charitable institutions or governmental agencies; however, such establishments shall in any case require a license as provided in this section. 
3-7-1.8. - Certificate to be posted. 
    Every licensee under this section shall be furnished with a license certificate, which shall be prominently displayed upon the named premises at all times. 
3-7-1.9. - Revocation. 
    Whenever it shall appear to the satisfaction of the board of health from the recommendation of the health officer, or otherwise, that any licensee under the provisions of this section has violated the provisions of any statute or ordinance of the city relating to the operation or maintenance of a food dealer, wholesale food establishment or retail food establishment, then the board shall cause a written notice to be served upon such licensee, either by having it served upon him personally or by having it delivered to one of his employees at the licensed premises or by having it mailed to him addressed to the licensed premises, notifying him that he will be given a hearing within ten (10) days thereof before the public health board at such time and place as it may designate, at which time he may appear in person or by an attorney to show cause why such license should not be revoked. At or within a reasonable time after such hearing the board shall make available to such proprietor its decision on such appeal, and if the license is revoked, the board shall inform the proprietor of the lawful conditions on which the license may be reinstated or a new license obtained. However, nothing in this section shall be construed as abrogating the right of the health officer to summarily abate any condition deleterious or hazardous to public health. 
3-7-1.10. - Sanitation required, generally. 
    The premises of all food businesses shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
State Law reference- Health and sanitation of food dealers, generally, 410 ILCS 650/1 et seq. 
3-7-1.11. - Inspections; right of entry, confiscation of unwholesome food. 
(a)  The board of health shall cause periodic inspections to be made of all food businesses and personnel employed therein for the purpose of determining whether all the requirements of this chapter and the health and sanitation laws of the state are being carried out. 
(b)  The health officer, or his authorized agent, is empowered to enter any place where food or drink is manufactured, processed, served, offered for sale or sold, and to make inspections and examinations as may be necessary for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of food inspectors or other duly authorized representatives of the board to enter any and all food businesses in the city at any time to make such inspections as they deem necessary, and to forthwith seize, condemn and destroy any putrid, decayed, poisoned or infected food which any such inspector or other employee of the board may find in and upon the premises, and such employees of the board are hereby empowered to so do. 
State Law reference- Power of city to inspect all food for human consumption, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-3. 
3-7-1.12. - Inspection of premises, generally. 
(a)  Not less frequently than semi-annually, the health officer shall inspect the premises of every handler of food or food products located within the city and required to be licensed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. Whenever the health officer discovers the violation of any provision of this chapter, he shall give notice to the licensee thereof, and make a second inspection after the lapse of such time as he deems necessary for the condition to be remedied, and the second inspection shall serve to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter. Any violation of the same provision of this chapter on such second inspection shall call for immediate revocation of such license. 
(b)  One copy of the inspection report shall be posted by the health officer upon an inside wall of the licensed premises, and said inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person except the health officer. Another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the records of the health board. 
(c)  The person operating the food business shall, upon request of the health officer, permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall permit copying any or all records of food purchased or sold. 
3-7-2. - DELIVERY VEHICLES 
3-7-2.1. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of any vehicle, including wagons, carts, motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by human power, for the storage or carrying of any meat, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, bread or bakery products, or other articles of any kind intended for human consumption including beverages, within the city for the purpose of delivering any such foodstuffs to any place within the city for use of consumption at such place, wholesale or retail, unless a license for such vehicle shall have been first obtained, and the provisions of this section shall be fully complied with. 
3-7-2.2. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Application for the license required by the preceding section shall be made to the city clerk, and shall state the name and address of the owner of the vehicle, the name or names of the persons from whom such deliveries are made, the nature of the goods carried, and the name or names of persons within the city to whom such deliveries are made. 
(b)  The annual fee for such licenses shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each vehicle. Such fees shall be paid to the city clerk who shall turn them over to the treasurer, forthwith. 
3-7-2.3. - Sanitary regulations, generally. 
    All licensed vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used. It shall be unlawful to permit stale food, decaying matter or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle while it is so used. 
    Whenever unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicle, such goods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. 
3-7-2.4. - Temperature control. 
    Readily perishable foods or beverages, while in transit, shall be maintained at a temperature of not less than thirty five (35) degrees Fahrenheit and not more than fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit. The temperature for hot liquid foods or beverages shall be maintained at not less than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit; and for frozen foods, not more than thirty two (32) degrees Fahrenheit. The compartments in vehicles used for carrying such foods shall be so constructed, equipped and maintained as to preserve the temperature as above indicated for the respective types of food. 
3-7-2.5. - Inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this section; but such inspection shall occur not less frequently than once in every two (2) months. 
3-7-3. - FOOD LOCKER PLANTS 
3-7-3.1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this section: 
    Food locker plant means any premises in which space or individual locker compartments are rented for the storage of food at or below a temperature of zero degrees Fahrenheit, and which may contain any of the following facilities: chill room, locker room, sharp freezing facilities, equipment for cutting, preparing, wrapping and packaging of meat and meat products, or food and food products. 
3-7-3.2. - License required; application; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a food locker plant within the city without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  Application for such license shall be made to the city clerk. In addition to all other information required of applications generally, it shall state the number of units maintained on the premises, the size of each unit and whether a unit is maintained in which will be stored food belonging to more than one customer or patron. 
(c)  The annual fee for such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00), which fee shall be payable to the city clerk. 
3-7-3.3. - Regulations, generally. 
    No food locker plant shall be operated or conducted in a building which is not constructed in full compliance with the building regulations of the city; and no such plant shall be operated in a frame building, nor in any building other than one where the floors are so constructed as to bear a live load of one hundred (100) pounds per square foot. 
    No food shall be stored in any such plant unless such food has been frozen to a temperature of zero degrees Fahrenheit or below before being so stored; and the lockers or compartments used for the refrigerated storage of food must be kept at all times at a temperature below fifteen degrees Fahrenheit. 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Title 4. 
3-7-3.4. - Wiring. 
    The wiring within the refrigeration plant shall conform to the provisions of this Code relating to electrical and heating and refrigeration installations. 
Cross reference- Smoke detectors required for all residential structures, § 4-1-7. 
3-7-3.5. - Sanitation. 
    All premises used for the operation of a food locker plant shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned of all refuse, dust and debris at least once in every twenty four (24) hours. It shall be unlawful to store or keep in such plant unwholesome, spoiled, contaminated or adulterated food. 
    No license shall be issued for any food locker plant which does not comply with the laws of the state pertaining thereto. 
State Law reference- Licenses, application, examination, issuance, 240 ILCS 35/2 et seq. 
3-7-4. - MILK DEALERS 
3-7-4.1. - Standards, generally. 
(a)  "Milk," for the purposes of this section, shall mean the whole fresh clean lacteal secretion obtained by the complete milking of one or more healthy cows, properly fed and kept clean, excluding that obtained within fifteen (15) days before and five (5) days after calving, or such longer period as may be required to render the milk practically colostrum free, and shall contain not less than three and one-half (31/2) percent of milk fat; and not less than eight (8) percent of milk solids not fat. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any milk not conforming to the requirements of this section to be sold or offered for sale within the city. 
(c)  All skim milk, buttermilk and cream shall conform to the standards fixed by state law, and the sale or offering for sale of any milk products or milk not in conformity with this law is prohibited. 
3-7-4.2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the sale or distribution of milk or cream within the city without having first obtained a license therefor. 
Cross reference- Operation of more than one establishment; sale of milk (licenses), § 3-7-1.4. 
3-7-4.3. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Application for the license required by the preceding section shall comply with the general regulations governing such applications, and shall state, in addition to the other information required, the source of supply of the milk to be sold and the ownership of the cattle from which the milk is produced. 
(b)  The annual fee for such license shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) payable to the city clerk. 
3-7-4.4. - Cream; percentage of butterfat; milk and cows from which obtained. 
    No cream shall be sold, offered for sale, exchanged or delivered or kept for the purpose of sale which contains less than eighteen (18) percent of butterfat, or that is obtained from any impure, diseased, adulterated or unwholesome milk, or from milk to which any foreign substance has been added, or from milk containing less than three (3) percent of butterfat, or from cows fed on refuse, slop, mash, food which has been subject to fermentation, or any food which is in any way unwholesome. 
3-7-4.5. - Containers. 
    No milk, except skimmed milk, buttermilk or sour milk shall be peddled or sold at retail in quantities of less than one gallon, except in containers bearing the true name of the article, the name and address of the producer, dealer or distributor, and the net volume of the contents in accordance with the state law, and no person shall sell milk or cream in any bottle or container other than those bearing the seller's name or to which he has acquired title as required by law. 
3-7-4.6. - Artificial coloring prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell any milk or cream containing any artificial coloring or preservation, or to which water or any foreign substance has been added, or which has been handled or transported in unclean or insanitary containers or vessels. 
3-7-4.7. - Milk-producing animals; bacterial rating; persons handling milk. 
    All milk offered for sale or sold must come from animals under state and Federal supervision and proven free from all contagious and infectious disease, and shall contain not more than fifty thousand (50,000) bacteria per cubic centimeter and no pathogenic bacteria, and shall be produced under the following conditions: 
(a)  All persons living upon farms, employed thereon of coming in contact with milk in dairies or other places shall be free from contagious or infectious diseases and shall not have been exposed to anyone having such a disease within a period of one week prior to the exercise of such duties. 
(b)  No person who is a paratyphoid, typhoid, diphtheria or septic sore throat carrier shall be employed in the production or handling of such milk. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every person with a knowledge of the facts to notify the health officer or other legally constituted authority at once of the occurrence of any of the above afflictions in persons living or employed in or about a place where milk is produced, handled or sold, milk and milk derivatives that have been exposed shall not be shipped into or sold or offered for sale within the city. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to employ for work upon such premises any person so afflicted. 
3-7-4.8. - Dairies. 
    Every building, room, basement enclosure or premises occupied or used as a dairy or milk depot shall be properly and adequately lighted, drained and ventilated, and shall have adequate plumbing facilities. 
3-7-4.9. - Grade-A milk. 
    It shall be unlawful to offer for sale any milk labeled "Grade-A Milk" unless the same has been produced and transported in compliance with the statutes of the state relating thereto. 
3-7-4.10. - Pasteurization required. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale for human consumption any milk or milk products which has not been produced and pasteurized in the manner required by statute. 
3-7-4.11. - Delivery to quarantined premises. 
    Milk may be delivered to quarantined premises, provided that there is no contact of any kind between the persons therein or any contents of the quarantined premises and the delivery agent. 
    No milk receptacles shall be taken from such premises during the period of quarantine; and before taken away for use such receptacles shall be thoroughly scalded and sterilized. 
3-7-4.12. - Vehicles. 
    Every vehicle used for the delivery of milk or cream to consumers shall have marked plainly thereon the name and address of the vendor of such milk. All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary manner and condition. 
3-7-4.13. - Inspection. 
    The health officer shall conduct periodic inspections of all milk distribution plants, dairies, vehicles and equipment used in the sale or distribution of milk, as well as of the milk itself. Such inspections shall be made every two (2) months or more frequently, as the said health officer deems necessary. The officer may in his discretion, in lieu of inspection, accept the certificate of inspection of any other city or village having equal or more rigid requirements than provided by this chapter. The licensee shall be liable to the city for the cost of all bacteriological inspections and tests ordered performed by the health officer. 
3-7-5. - FOOD VENDING MACHINES 
3-7-5.1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this section: 
    Adulterated: Food is adulterated: 
(a)  If it bears or contains any poisonous or deleterious substance which may be injurious to health; or 
(b)  If it bears or contains any added poisonous or deleterious substance for which no safe tolerance has been established by regulation, or in excess of such tolerance if one has been established; or 
(c)  If it consists in whole or in part of it any filthy, putrid, decomposed substance, or if it is otherwise unfit for human consumption; or 
(d)  If it has been prepared, packed or stored under insanitary conditions whereby it may have become contaminated with filth or rendered injurious to health; or 
(e)  If the container is composed in whole or part of a poisonous or deleterious substance which may render the contents injurious to health. 
    Employee means any operator or any person employed by him who handles any food, beverage or ingredient to be dispensed through vending machines, or who comes into contact with food contact surfaces of containers, equipment, utensils or packaging materials used in connection with vending machine operation, or who otherwise services or maintains one or more such machines. 
    Food vending machine means any self-service device offered for public use which, upon insertion of coin or token, or by any other means, dispenses unit servings of food or beverage, either in bulk or in package, without the necessity of replenishing the device between each vending operation. 
    Health authority means the city health officer, or an authorized representative thereof. 
    Machine location means the room, enclosure, space or area where one or more vending machines are installed and operated. 
    Operator means any person who by contract, agreement or ownership takes responsibility for furnishing, installing, servicing, operating or maintaining one or more vending machines. 
    Product contact surface means any surface of the vending machine, appurtenances or containers which comes into direct contact with any food, beverage or ingredient. 
3-7-5.2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain within the city any food vending machine without first having obtained a license for each such machine. 
3-7-5.3. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to operate or maintain any food vending machine shall make application therefor to the city clerk, which application shall set forth the full name of the applicant, if an individual; the full name of a partner, officer or agent, if a business, firm or corporation; the local business address and telephone number of the applicant; the number of machines for which the applicant desires licenses; the location of such machines and their nature (candy, peanuts, soft drinks, milk, milk beverages, ice cream, dairy products, popcorn or gum, etc.). Such application shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant, if an individual, or the officer or agent, if a firm or corporation, is or are responsible persons of good character and reputation having a residence or business address within the city; and if the clerk shall be satisfied as to the application, he shall cause a license or licenses to be issued upon payment of the fees hereinafter set forth. 
3-7-5.4. - Fee. 
    The annual license fee for the operation of food vending machines shall be as follows: 
(a)  One-cent machines:       $ 2.00 for each such machine 
(b)  Ten-cent (or less) machines:       5.00 for each such machine 
(c)  All other machines:       10.00 for each such machine 
3-7-5.5. - Issuance; posting. 
    Upon receipt of the appropriate license fee, the city clerk shall issue to the applicant a license certificate or emblem, which certificate shall be affixed in a prominent place upon such machine and in a manner so as not to be easily removable. 
3-7-5.6. - Duration; transferability. 
    Licenses under the provisions of this section shall be valid for an annual period corresponding to the fiscal year of the city; and shall be non-transferable or assignable as to the owner of the machines for which issued. 
3-7-5.7. - Sanitation requirements, generally. 
(a)  Foods, beverages, ingredients, consumer containers, equipment maintenance and operations. Foods, beverages and ingredients intended for sale through vending machines shall be obtained from sources complying with the regulations of this chapter, and with other applicable state and Federal laws and regulations. Such products shall be clean and wholesome, free from spoilage, and shall be processed, prepared, handled and stored in such a manner as to be protected against contamination and adulteration. All product contact surfaces of containers and equipment shall be protected from contamination. 
(b)  Machine location, cleanliness. The machine location shall be such as to minimize the potential for contamination of the product; and shall be easily cleanable, and shall be maintained in a clean condition. 
(c)  Exterior construction and maintenance. The exterior construction of the vending machine shall be such as to facilitate cleaning and to minimize the entrance of insects and rodents, and the exterior of the machine shall be kept clean. Service connections shall be such as to protect against unintentional or accidental interruption of service to the machine. 
(d)  Interior construction and maintenance. All interior surface and component parts of the vending machine shall be so designed and constructed as to permit easy cleaning, and shall be kept clean. All product contact surfaces of the machine shall be of smooth, nontoxic, corrosion resistant and relatively nonabsorbent material, and shall be capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and bactericidal treatment by normal procedures. Such surfaces shall be protected against contamination. 
(e)  Water supply. Water used in vending machines shall be from an approved source, and shall be of a safe and sanitary quality. 
(f)  Waste disposal. All wastes shall be properly disposed of and pending disposition shall be kept in suitable containers so as to prevent the creation of a nuisance. 
(g)  Delivery of foods, ingredients, equipment and supplies to machine location. Foods, beverages and ingredients and product contact surfaces of containers, equipment and supplies shall be protected from contamination while in transit to the machine location. 
(h)  Personnel cleanliness. Employees shall keep their hands clean and shall wear clean outer garments while engaged in handling foods or beverages or product contact surfaces of utensils or equipment. Employees shall wash their hands immediately prior to engaging in any vending machine servicing operation which may bring them into contact with foods, beverages or ingredients, or with product contact surfaces of utensils, containers or equipment. While engaged in such servicing operations employees shall wear clean outer garments. 
3-7-5.8. - Inspection and analysis of products. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the health officer, and he is authorized and empowered therefor, to inspect and examine all food or drink being offered for sale by means of vending machines within the city for the purpose of ascertaining whether the laws of the state and of the city in relation thereto are being complied with, and that the food and drink so offered for sale has been kept fresh, clean and wholesome; and it shall be the duty of all persons operating such food vending machines upon the demand of the health officer to furnish to said officer for his inspection samples of all such food and drink, which samples may be analyzed by or under order of the health officer, and a record of such analysis shall be made and kept in his office. 
    The health officer shall also inspect all locations where such machines are placed in order to ascertain that the same shall be free from contamination and in a sanitary condition. The owner or operator of such machines shall, on the request of the health officer, furnish keys to said machines so that contents of the same may be inspected, in the company of an agent of such owner or operator, if so desired. 
(b)  Whenever the health officer discovers a violation of any provision of this section or the state laws, he shall notify the operator concerned. Such notice shall (1) describe the condition found and state which subsection of this section or state law is violated by such condition; (2) provide a specific and reasonable period of time for correction of the condition; and (3) state that an opportunity for a hearing as to inspection findings shall be provided if a written request for such hearing is filed with the health board within ten (10) days of receipt of the said notice. 
    The health officer shall advise the operator in writing that, unless the said violations are corrected within the specified period of time, any license issued under the provisions of this section shall be suspended or revoked, in accordance with provisions of section 3-2-17 of this Code. 
3-7-5.9. - Identification to be posted on machine. 
    Each machine licensed hereunder and operated within the city shall be identified in a permanent and conspicuous manner with the name, local business addresses and local telephone numbers of the licensee and his service representative, if any. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 8. - REAL ESTATE BROKERS 
SECTION: 

3-8-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Real estate broker means any person who for another or others, in consideration of the commission or brokerage, or on the basis of compensation in proportion to the amount of the transaction, shall make it his vocation or business in full or in part, to sell, buy, exchange, lease or solicit or negotiate a sale, purchase, exchange or lease of any real property or interest therein; or who, for another or others, in consideration of the commission or brokerage, or on the basis of compensation in proportion to the amount of money involved, engages in the renting or management of real property; or who acts through the medium of another licensed broker for any of the purposes aforesaid. 
    Real estate salesman means any person who, for compensation or valuable consideration, is employed either directly or indirectly by a real estate broker, as defined in the preceding paragraph. 
Provided, however, that nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to apply to any attorney at law, court officer or banking institution, licensed as such, in the performance of their powers and authority. 
3-8-2. - Zoning classification; failure to disclose prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any real estate broker or real estate salesman to negotiate the sale, purchase or exchange of any real property, whether by proposal to purchase, offer, option, agreement for deed or any other agreement, without reciting in said document a statement as to the zoning classification of the real estate involved in the transaction as set forth in Title 5 of this Code. The classification shown on the current zoning map shall be deemed sufficient compliance with the provisions hereof. 
3-8-3. - Zoning classification; misrepresentation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any real estate broker or real estate salesman to make any substantial misrepresentation with respect to the zoning classification of any real estate in connection with the sale, purchase or exchange of said real estate. 
3-8-4. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 9. - PEDDLERS, BROKERS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS 
SECTION: 

3-9-1. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter: 
    Broker. Any person, whether or not the person is an employee of another person, who takes orders or subscriptions, while traveling house to house or from place to place in, along or upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places within the city, for future delivery of tangible personal property or services by a seller, at retail, whether to regular customers or not, regardless of whether or not such person collects payment therefor at the time of such transaction, but who does not make delivery of such property or perform such service at that time. 
    Itinerant merchant. Any person, whether or not the person is an employee of another person, who on real property in which he does not hold a fee simple interest establishes a display, exhibition or sales facility for the purpose of selling, offering or displaying for sale and immediate delivery, or taking orders or subscriptions for the future delivery of tangible personal property at retail shall be considered an itinerant merchant for purposes of this chapter if: 
(a)  The display, exhibition or sales facility is established with the intent that such display, exhibition or sales facility will remain in operation for a period of less than six (6) months; or 
(b)  The display, exhibition or sales facility is established with the intent that its operation will be interrupted for a period of more than ninety (90) days in any calendar year. 
    Nonprofit organization. Any bona fide charitable, educational, fraternal, labor, religious or veterans' organization that operates without profit to its members and which has been in existence continuously for a period of five (5) years or more immediately before making application for a license and which has had during the entire five (5) year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out its objectives. 
    Peddler. Any person, whether or not the person is an employee of another person, who directly or indirectly sells or offers for sale, barter or exchange any farm produce, vegetables, dairy products, meat, fish, foods of any kind or other goods, wares or merchandise of any kind, at retail, making delivery of said goods at the time of sale regardless of whether or not such person collects payment at the time of sale, all while traveling from place to place in, along and upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places within the city, or while operating from one or more locations outside of a totally enclosed permanent structure. 
(Ord. 2171, 3-3-87) 
3-9-2. - License and bond required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any peddler, itinerant merchant or broker to transact any business within the city without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any peddler, itinerant merchant or broker as herein defined, to transact any business within the city without having first filed with the city clerk a bond running to the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), in cash or executed by a surety company, conditioned that the applicant shall comply with all the provisions of this Code, the city ordinances and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and will pay all judgments rendered against such applicant for any violation of this Code, or the ordinances or statutes or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with the applicant, whether such representation or deception was made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought by any person. 
(c)  No license required in subparagraph (a) shall be issued until the applicant therefor shall have filed the bond required in subparagraph (b). 
3-9-3. - Application. 
    Applications for licenses required by the preceding section shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall state thereon the name and permanent address of the applicant; the kind of merchandise or nature of service to be sold or contracted for; the proposed area or place where the business is sought to be conducted; the proposed hours during which business will be conducted; the state sales tax number of the operator; and, in case of a corporation or firm, the name, permanent business address and names of the principal officers of the same. If the applicant desires to operate from property owned or maintained by the city in accordance with the provisions of section 3-9-12 of this chapter, the applicant shall describe the location from which the applicant desires to operate. 
3-9-4. - Fee. 
    No license hereunder shall be issued until a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) has been paid to the city clerk. Each license issued hereunder shall be for a period of time not to exceed one year. An additional fee may be required of certain licensees under the provisions of section 3-9-12. 
(Ord. 1991, 6-12-84) 
3-9-5. - Exemption from application, license and bond requirements. 
    The following shall be exempt from the application, license and bond requirements of this chapter: 
(a)  Prior invitation. Any person who, for the purpose of selling or taking orders for the sale of merchandise or services, has been previously invited by the occupant of a residence to call thereon. 
(b)  Nonprofit organization. Any person selling, peddling, soliciting or taking orders for any goods or services not prohibited by law on behalf of a nonprofit organization sponsored by or participated in by a local chapter of such organization; or by a national nonprofit organization not represented locally but which has filed a statement of registration with the city clerk specifying the name of the nonprofit organization, its permanent address, the names of its principal officers and names of those persons who are authorized to sell, peddle or solicit or take orders for goods and services within the city. 
(c)  Celebration. Any person selling, peddling, soliciting or taking orders for any goods or services not prohibited by law while invited to participate in the East Peoria Centennial Celebration by the City of East Peoria Centennial Commission or while invited to participate in any celebration, fair, festival or similar activity sponsored by a nonprofit organization. 
(d)  Farmers or gardeners. Any person who sells the produce of his own farm, vineyard, orchard or garden, provided he does not obstruct streets, sidewalks or other public places within the city; provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed to authorize the sale of alcoholic, spirituous, malt or other intoxicating liquors or peddling of any kind whatsoever in any public park. 
(e)  Newspaper vendors. Any person who, on behalf of the publisher of any newspaper of general circulation within the city, peddles the same within the city. 
(f)  Holders of special outdoor sales and consumption permits. Any holder of a liquor license under the provisions of title 3, chapter 3, of the East Peoria City Code or the employees or agents of such license holder but only with respect to any event for which a special outdoor sales and consumption permit has been granted in the manner provided by title 3, chapter 3, section 3.2, of the East Peoria City Code. 
(g)  Certain peddlers and brokers operating in residential areas and who are registered under chapter 4, title 10, of the East Peoria City Code. Any peddler or broker as defined in this chapter who operates only on a door-to-door basis and only in residential areas of the city and whose sole means of attracting potential customers is by knocking on doors or ringing doorbells rather than the use of bells, buzzers, microphones, horns, whistles or other similar devices; provided, however, that such a peddler is exempted from the application, license and bond requirements of this chapter only if he has registered as a residential solicitor under the provisions of title 10, chapter 4, of the East Peoria City Code. 
(h)  Certain arts and crafts displays. Any itinerant merchant who sells goods or merchandise at retail which goods or merchandise were made or constructed by the seller but only if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The display is erected on private property at the invitation of the owner thereof; and 
(2)  The zoning regulations applicable to the parcel where the display is located permit the sale of goods at retail; and 
(3)  The display is removed within forty-eight (48) hours of being erected; and 
(4)  The person erecting the display has not erected the same or a similar display within the city more than twice during the same calendar year. 
(Ord. 2017, 10-2-84; Ord. 2171, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 3937, § 1, 9-7-10) 
3-9-6. - Possession required. 
    Any person licensed pursuant to this chapter shall, at all times while engaged in the activities defined in section 3-9-1, keep said license in his possession and shall display the same upon the demand of any police officer or upon the request of any person whose premises he seeks to enter. 
3-9-7. - Vehicles to be marked. 
    Every vehicle or conveyance used by a person licensed hereunder shall be conspicuously and permanently marked, as may be prescribed by the chief of police, with the name of such person or his employer and the number of his license. 
3-9-8. - Peddling on nonmotorized vehicles after sunset prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle any goods, wares or other merchandise by means of a bicycle or other nonmotorized vehicle after sunset and before sunrise. 
3-9-9. - When peddling, etc., a nuisance. 
    It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and welfare and a nuisance for any peddler, itinerant merchant, or broker to enter upon private premises in disregard of the express wish of the owner or occupant or enter into a private residence without the express consent of the owner or occupant for the purpose of selling, peddling or soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise. 
3-9-10. - Sign prohibiting peddlers and brokers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, itinerant merchant or broker to enter upon any premises or to in any way disturb or attempt to gain the attention of the owner or occupant of any premises if a sign having dimensions of not less than three (3) inches by five (5) inches which states "No Peddlers Invited" or other words of similar substance has been posted at a conspicuous location near any front entrance to the premises. 
3-9-11. - Limitation on hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, itinerant merchant or broker to transact the business of a peddler, itinerant merchant or broker as defined in section 3-9-1 of this chapter before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after sunset. 
3-9-12. - Public streets, etc.; restrictions. 
(a)  Except as permitted in subsection (b) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person, for the purpose of dispensing or displaying any goods, wares, foodstuff or other mer-chandise or tangible personal property of any nature whatsoever, to erect or place any temporary or permanent stand, cart, wagon or other structure or vehicle upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other location owned or maintained by the city; or to go about the city or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other place owned or maintained by the city while making any noise, blowing any horn or using any like device to call attention to his goods, wares, foodstuff or other merchandise or tangible personal property of any nature whatsoever. 
(b)  Any person licensed hereunder may, if so indicated on the face of such license, conduct licensed operations from a single specific fixed location identified on the face of the license, which location is on property owned or maintained by the city. Conduct of licensed operations from more than one location shall require a separate license and payment of an additional license fee for each such location. No such location shall be within fifty (50) feet of any entrance or exit to any building. All such locations shall be within areas of the city which are zoned B-1, B-2 or B-3 under the East Peoria Zoning Code (East Peoria City Code, Title 5, chapters 2-14). No licensee may conduct licensed operations from any location where such operations would unreasonably interfere with the intended or primary use of the public place in question. No license shall be issued for any location on property owned or maintained by the city which is within three hundred (300) feet of any location for which a current valid license has been issued. 
(Ord. 1991, 6-12-84) 
3-9-13. - Location of sales facilities on private property. 
    No peddler, itinerant merchant or broker licensed under the provisions of this chapter may erect or place any display, exhibition or sales facility of any nature whatsoever upon any parcel of privately-owned real property except under the following conditions: 
(a)  Such activity is permitted under all applicable zoning regulations. 
(b)  The display, exhibition or sales facility is housed within and operated from a totally enclosed permanent structure which in all respects complies with the provisions of the East Peoria Building Code. 
(c)  The structure from which the display, exhibition or sales facility is operated is provided with sewer and water service in the manner required by the East Peoria City Code. 
(d)  The electrical system for such display, exhibition or sales facility is installed in accordance with the provisions of the East Peoria Electrical Code. 
(e)  Parking and loading facilities available on the parcel meet the requirements established under the provisions of the East Peoria Zoning Code. 
(Ord. 2171, 3-3-87) 
3-9-14. - Location of sales facilities on school or park property. 
    A licensed peddler, itinerant merchant or broker may erect and operate a temporary display or sales facility upon property under the control of any school or park district, provided the written consent of an authorized official of the school or park district in question is first obtained. 
3-9-15. - Compliance with setback requirements. 
    Except as otherwise permitted in this chapter, no peddler, itinerant merchant or broker shall establish a display or offer for sale any goods, merchandise or other tangible personal property from any location which is closer to any public right-of-way than the front yard setback established under the zoning regulations set forth in this City Code which are applicable to the parcel from which he is operating. 
3-9-16. - Compliance with sign requirements. 
    Except as otherwise permitted in this chapter, no peddler, itinerant merchant or broker shall establish or display a sign without first complying with the City Code regulations applicable to signs. 
3-9-17. - Fraud. 
    Any licensed peddler, broker or itinerant merchant who shall be guilty of any fraud, cheating, misrepresentation or imposition, whether himself or through an employee, while engaged in his trade within the city or who shall broker, sell or peddle any goods other than those specified in his application for a license shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
3-9-18. - Penalty.
