    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue. 
(Ord. 1991, 6-12-84; Ord. No. 3292, § 10, 7-3-01) 
3-9-19. - Compliance with other applicable licensing or registration provisions required. 
    Compliance with the provisions of this chapter 9 of the City Code shall not excuse compliance with any other applicable provision of the East Peoria City Code including, but not limited to, the provisions requiring the licensing of peddlers as set forth in Title 10, chapter 4, of the City Code. Furthermore, should any provision of this chapter conflict with any provision of Title 10, chapter 4, of this Code, then the more restrictive provision shall govern. 
(Ord. 2017, 10-2-84) 
CHAPTER 10. - CIGARETTE VENDING MACHINES 
SECTION: 

3-10-1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Cigarette vending machine means and includes any machine dispensing cigarettes, cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco or other products containing tobacco, which is operated by the insertion of a coin or other lawful money in exchange for some unit quantity of the contents of said machine. 
3-10-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or permit to be kept upon any property owned or controlled by him within the city any cigarette vending machine without first having obtained a license therefor as hereinafter provided. 
3-10-3. - Application. 
    Application for the license required by the preceding section shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall specify: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation, club or association, the names and addresses of the principal officers thereof; 
(b)  The place where such machine is to be located, and a description of all cigarette vending machines intended to be kept for use at such place, including model, serial number and name of manufacturer for each machine; and 
(c)  The nature of the business or other activity carried on at the place wherein the machine will be located. 
3-10-4. - Fee; duration. 
    An annual license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each cigarette vending machine licensed pursuant to this chapter shall be paid on or before the first day of the fiscal year of the city. No license shall be issued for less than one year; provided, however, any license issued during the then current fiscal year shall not extend beyond the last day thereof. In no case shall a license be issued for less than the annual fee or shall any portion of such annual fee be repaid to any licensee. 
3-10-5. - Posting required. 
    Every license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be in the form of a certificate or emblem, capable of being permanently affixed in a prominent location upon such cigarette vending machine, and imprinted with the name of the city, the license number, license year and date of expiration. 
    The licensee shall be permitted to maintain and keep as many such machines as the number of licenses applied for and issued. 
3-10-6. - License not transferable. 
    No license certificate issued pursuant to this chapter shall be assignable or transferable to any person other than the named licensee, nor to any machine other than that specified in the application, unless application, upon good cause shown, shall be made to and approved by the city clerk. 
3-10-7. - Operation by minors prohibited. 
(a)  Each cigarette vending machine shall have affixed thereto, in a conspicuous place visible to any person attempting to operate said machine, a warning to the effect that operation by a minor person under the age of eighteen (18) is unlawful and punishable by fine. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly permit any minor person under the age of eighteen (18) to operate any machine licensed pursuant to this chapter. 
(c)  It is hereby declared unlawful for any minor person under the age of eighteen (18) to misrepresent his age for the purpose of operating any cigarette vending machine within the city. 
State Law reference- Sale of tobacco to minors, 720 ILCS 675/1. 
3-10-8. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3292, § 11, 7-3-01) 
CHAPTER 11. - AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS 
SECTION: 

3-11-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Auctioneer means any person who conducts a sale at auction or, at public outcry, offers for sale to the highest bidder any property, either his own or that of any other person; except any person who acts by virtue of legal process. 
    Legal process means any writ, process or order of any kind issued out of any court. 
    Property means personal property of every kind, including any goods, wares, merchandise or other effects whatsoever; but not real property, unless specifically included. 
    Sale at auction means any sale of property within the city, by public outcry to the highest bidder or offer of property at a price beyond its value followed by a lowering of price or an increasing of the number of articles until someone accepts the property offered as a purchase. 
3-11-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to act as an auctioneer, or to sell or offer for sale within the city by way of public sale, auction or outcry any property without first having obtained a license therefor. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license, tax and regulate auctioneers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 
3-11-3. - Bond required. 
    No person shall be issued a license to act as auctioneer within the city until he shall first execute and deliver to the city his certificate of bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with satisfactory sureties thereupon, conditioned for strict observance of the laws of the state, the provisions of this Code, and all other ordinances of the city relating to auctions and auctioneers, and for the indemnification of any purchaser, at a sale at auction conducted by the applicant, who suffers any loss by reason of misrepresentation at such auction. 
    Such bond and sureties thereon shall be approved by the commissioner of accounts and finances as to the sufficiency of the surety and as to the form and manner of the execution thereof. The bond shall be kept in full force and effect until during the period during which the license is to be granted, and shall in addition thereto be kept in full force and effect for a period of thirty (30) days after expiration of such license. 
3-11-4. - Application. 
    Applications for the license to act as an auctioneer shall be verified, stating the name of the applicant, his residence address, the street and number of the proposed place of auction and whether the applicant has been previously so licensed or engaged in the same or similar activity. 
(1970 Code) 
3-11-5. - Fee; duration. 
    Before any license to act as an auctioneer shall be issued, the applicant therefor shall pay to the city clerk a license fee pursuant to the following schedule: 
(a)  A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to conduct a one-day auction. 
(b)  A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a one-year license. 
(Ord. 1252, 3-16-76) 
3-11-6. - Transferability. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be transferable, or be held to authorize any person other than the one named therein to sell or offer for sale property at public outcry. In no case shall any license be held to authorize more than one person to sell under it, or to cover more than one regular place of business except that a single license may be taken in the name of partners, naming them therein. 
3-11-7. - Restrictions, generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensed auctioneer to conduct a sale of any property at public auction for any person, whether the same shall belong to such person or whether he sells the same as agent or employee of another; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to sales by legal process or to sales by executors or administrators, by trustee or assignees under deed of assignment, by lienors or by public officers in the manner prescribed by law; provided further, that this section shall not apply to auction sales in the place named in the license of the auctioneer, nor to the sale at public auction of the stock on hand of any person that shall, for the period of one year next preceding such sale, have been continuously in business within the city as a retail or wholesale merchant. 
(1970 Code) 
3-11-8. - Records required. 
    Every licensed auctioneer in the city shall keep a record book in which shall be legibly written at the time of each transaction an accurate description of the articles involved (including, if any, the serial number or other identification number of the article), the name and residence of the person offering each article for sale, and the name and residence of the person purchasing each article. Provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to a sale of merchants' stock under section 3-11-12 of this chapter. 
3-11-9. - Inspection of records. 
    The record book required to be kept under section 3-11-8 of this chapter shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the mayor, his authorized agent, or any city police officer. 
3-11-10. - Report to police. 
    It shall be the duty of every auctioneer licensed hereunder to deliver to the police department before twelve o'clock (12:00) p.m. on Monday of each week a legible and complete copy of the record book required by section 3-11-8 of this chapter regarding all property received for sale during the preceding week. 
3-11-11. - Restriction on time of sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensed auctioneer to sell any property at public auction for any person, until at least twenty four (24) hours have elapsed since the record book required under section 3-11-8 of this chapter containing the description, etc., of said property shall have been delivered to the police department as required by section 3-11-9 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1993, 10-2-84) 
3-11-12. - Sale of merchants' stock. 
    Sales at public auction of the stock on hand of any person that has been continuously in business within the city as a retail or wholesale merchant for a period of one year next preceding such sales shall be held only subject to the following conditions: 
(a)  When sale is to be held; continuance. Such sales shall be held on successive days, Sundays and legal holidays except, and shall not continue for more than thirty (30) days in all, and a period of at least three hundred sixty five (365) days must have lapsed after the conclusion of any such auction sale conducted before another auction sale shall be commenced for the benefit of the same merchant. 
(b)  Place of sale. Such auction sales must be held either at a place at which the merchant so selling his goods at auction conducts or has conducted his business for a period of at least six (6) months immediately prior to the commencement of such auction sales or at the regular and usual place of business of a duly licensed auctioneer, and at no other place; provided, however, that should such merchant's place of business be rendered untenantable by fire or other casualty, such auction may be conducted at a temporary location. 
(c)  Hours of sale. Such sales may be held only between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) a.m. and ten o'clock (10:00) p.m., and at no other time. 
(d)  Statement by merchant. Not more than fifteen (15) nor less than ten (10) days before commencing any such sale, the auctioneer must file with the city clerk a statement setting forth the name and address of the merchant so intending to sell his property, the place at which for the year next preceding the sale such merchant has conducted his business, the location and purpose of proposed sale, the probable duration thereof, the name and address of the auctioneer who will conduct such sale and an inventory showing in detail the quantity, kind or grade of the property intended to be sold at such sale; stating therein that no items or articles belonging to any person other than the merchant are included in the inventory. Such statement must be subscribed to by the merchant, or an officer thereof, if the merchant is a corporation, and verified by oath before a notary public by the person so subscribing. 
(e)  Affidavit of auctioneer. At least two (2) days before the commencement of such sale, the auctioneer named in the statement provided for in this section shall file with the city clerk an affidavit, subscribed and sworn to by him, referring to the statement and setting forth that he has been employed to conduct such sale, and that he will keep a true record of any and all lots or items sold at such sale, and the prices obtained therefor. 
(f)  Report to city clerk. Within ten (10) days after the conclusion of such sale, the auctioneer shall file with the city clerk a report showing all properties sold at auction and the price obtained, and certifying that no articles were sold which were not included in the inventory statement provided for in this section. Such report shall be subscribed and sworn to by the auctioneer before a notary public. 
(g)  Only inventory property sold. No property not set forth in the statement of inventory as filed by the merchant in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be sold or offered for sale at such auction by the auctioneer, and all properties sold thereat must be sold as the property of and under the name of said merchant; and during the course of such sale, a sign must be maintained at the place of sale, plainly visible to the persons attending, showing the name of the auctioneer and the name and address of the merchant whose property is being sold at auction. 
(h)  Conducting of other business at place of sale. Except in the case of auction sales conducted at the regular place of auction of a duly licensed auctioneer, during the course of such auction sales no business other than the business which has been conducted for the period of six (6) months immediately prior to the commencement of the auction sale shall be conducted or engaged in at or in the place so designated in the statement provided for in this section and filed with the city clerk. 
3-11-13. - Inspection of inventory and sale. 
    All provisions of this Code relating to inspection of businesses licensed by the city shall likewise apply to sales at auction within the city. In addition, the commissioner of public affairs may appoint inspectors whose duty it shall be to inspect and investigate inventory statements submitted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the stock of property offered for sale thereunder and, if so directed, to attend the auction sales held thereunder for the purpose of ascertaining the fact that any property being offered for sale was not included in such inventory. For the purposes of such inspection, such inspectors shall have access to the place of auction at any reasonable hour and time prior to the commencement of any such sale. 
3-11-14. - Sale of property not included in inventory. 
    Any auctioneer who offers for sale any property not included in an inventory statement required under the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to: 
(a)  A penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for every article of property so offered; and 
(b)  Forfeiture of the license under which he acts as auctioneer, after which no further sales may be held thereunder. 
    No refund shall be made to any licensee as a result of any license fee paid in advance upon such forfeiture of license. No appeal taken from any conviction thereunder shall stay any such forfeiture pending the final determination of such appeal. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 12, 7-13-01) 
3-11-15. - Only licensed auctioneers to conduct auctions. 
    No person shall dispose of any property at public auction within the city except through the medium of an auctioneer duly licensed to conduct such auction within the city; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to sales by legal process, by executors or administrators, by trustees or assignees under deed of assignment, by lienors or by public officers in the manner prescribed by law. 
3-11-16. - Compliance with fire, safety, health and licensing provisions generally. 
    All provisions of this Code relating to fire prevention, safety and health in connection with the conduct of businesses within the city shall also apply to sales at auction conducted within the city. Any sale at auction not conducted by a licensed auctioneer or at a place not authorized by this chapter shall subject the person conducting such sale to a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day of violation shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 13, 7-13-01) 
3-11-17. - Acts prohibited to auctioneer. 
    No auctioneer duly licensed to conduct sales at auction within the city shall do any of the following acts within the city: 
(a)  Make any false representation as to the character, quality, condition, value or ownership of any property offered for sale; 
(b)  Substitute afterwards any other articles in lieu of that offered to and purchased by a bidder; 
(c)  Bid for any property offered by him for sale, and no person shall act as an accomplice, capper, booster or shiller or make any false or mock bid or offer to purchase any article offered for sale or sold at such auction; 
(d)  Employ music or noise of any kind, either mechanical, vocal or otherwise, or any means of attracting the public other than a sign or flag in connection with any auction sale. 
3-11-18. - Sale of watches, plate or jewelry. 
    It shall be the duty of every auctioneer who shall offer for sale any watch, plate or jewelry of any kind to announce to the persons present in a loud voice whether the same be gold, gold plate, silver, silver plate or base metal before proceeding to sell the same. Any auctioneer who fails to comply shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 14, 7-13-01) 
3-11-19. - Cancellation for violation of state or Federal statutes. 
    Whenever any duly licensed auctioneer shall violate a state or Federal statute, then and in that event the license shall be cancelled by the city. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 12. - PAWNBROKERS 
SECTION: 

3-12-1. - Definition. 
    Pawnbroker means any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property, or who deals in the purchase of personal property on condition of selling the same back at a stipulated price, or who makes a public display at his place of business of the sign generally used by pawnbrokers to denote their business, to-wit: three (3), or more or less, gilt or yellow balls, or who publicly exhibits a sign "Money to loan on personal property or deposit or pledge." 
3-12-2. - License required. 
    The city council may, from time to time, grant licenses to such persons as shall produce to them satisfactory evidence of their good character to exercise or carry on the business of pawnbroker within the city. No person shall exercise or carry on the business of pawn broker within the city without being duly licensed therefor. 
State Law reference- Power of city to license, tax, regulate or prohibit pawnbrokers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 
3-12-3. - Fee; transferability. 
    Every applicant for a license to act as a pawnbroker within the city shall pay to the city clerk an annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Such license shall be valid only during the fiscal year of the city; and no license shall be issued for an amount less than the annual fee. Such license shall not be transferable, to any person or persons, except upon written consent of the city council. 
3-12-4. - Bond. 
    Every person so licensed shall at the time of receiving such license file a certificate of bond with two (2) or more sureties to be approved by the city council, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), payable to the city, conditioned for due observance of all provisions of this chapter or other ordinances that may be passed during the term for which the license is granted. 
(1970 Code) 
3-12-5. - Records required. 
    Every pawnbroker licensed under this chapter shall keep a record book in which shall be legibly written, at the time of each pledge or purchase of personal property, the following: 
(a)  The name and address of the pledgor or seller; 
(b)  The pledgor or seller's drivers license number or military identification number, if available; 
(c)  A general description of the pledgor or seller; 
(d)  An identification and complete description of the pledged or purchased property, including serial numbers if available; 
(e)  The amount of money loaned on the pledged goods, or the purchase price of purchased goods; 
(f)  The rate of interest to be paid on each loan; and 
(g)  The date and time of each pledge or purchase of personal property. 
    Each pawnbroker licensed under this chapter shall preserve the records required by this section for one year from the date of the pledge or purchase or until the item is sold, whichever occurs later. 
(Ord. 1998, 10-2-84) 
State Law reference- State law regulations with respect to pawnbrokers, 205 ILCS 510/5. 
3-12-6. - Inspection of records. 
    The record book provided for in the preceding section, as well as every article or thing of value pawned or pledged, shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the mayor or any member of the police department. 
3-12-7. - Memorandum to pledger. 
    Every pawnbroker shall at the time of each loan deliver to the person pawning or pledging any goods, articles or thing, a memorandum or note signed by him, containing the substance of the entry to be made in his book, which is provided for in section 3-12-5; and no charge shall be made or received by any pawnbroker for any such entry, memorandum or note. 
(1970 Code) 
3-12-8. - Prohibited transactions. 
    No pawnbroker shall, under any pretense whatsoever, purchase or buy any secondhand furniture, metals, clothes or any other article or thing whatsoever offered to him as a pawn or pledge. No pawnbroker shall conduct the business of a secondhand dealer without having first obtained the license required by this Code for such dealer, in addition to his license as a pawnbroker. No pawnbroker licensed under this chapter shall sell or permit to be redeemed any item of personal property for which the records required by section 3-12-5 of this chapter have not been made. 
(Ord. 1998, 10-2-84) 
Cross reference- License required (secondhand and junk dealers), § 3-13-2. 
3-12-9. - Report to police. 
    It shall be the duty of every person licensed hereunder to make out and deliver to the police department before the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) p.m. on Monday of each week a legible and correct copy of the record book required in section 3-12-5 of this chapter regarding all personal property and other valuable things received on deposit during the preceding week, together with the time, meaning the hour, when received or purchased and a description of the person or persons by whom left in pledge or from whom the same was received. 
3-12-10. - Redemption or removal of pledged property. 
    No personal property received on deposit or pledged by any such licensed person shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed from the place of business of such licensed person for the space of twenty-four (24) hours after the copy and statement required to be delivered to the police department shall have been delivered as required by the preceding section. 
3-12-11. - Hours of business. 
    No person licensed under this chapter shall receive on deposit or pledge any personal property or other valuable thing before the hour of six o'clock (6:00) a.m. nor after the hour of nine o'clock (9:00) p.m. 
3-12-12. - Pledges from minors prohibited. 
    No person licensed under this chapter shall take or receive any property, bonds, notes, securities, articles or other valuable things as a pawn or pledge, for money loaned, which may be in the possession or control of any person under eighteen (18) years of age, regardless of any claim by any such person under eighteen (18) years of age with respect to ownership. 
(Ord. No. 3757, § 1, 8-21-07) 
3-12-13. - Exclusive business as to licensed place. 
    No person licensed under this chapter shall carry on any other business or vocation, directly or indirectly, in the same building or in any building adjoining the place or building in which he may be licensed to carry on the business of pawnbroker. 
3-12-14. - Employment of minors prohibited. 
    No person licensed under this chapter shall employ any person under eighteen (18) years of age to take or receive pledges or pawns. 
(Ord. No. 3757, § 2, 8-21-07) 
3-12-15. - Prohibited pledges. 
    No person licensed hereunder shall take any article or pawn from any person appearing to be intoxicated, nor from any person known to be a notorious thief or to have been convicted of larceny or burglary. 
    It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police department any article pledged with him, or which is sought to be pledged with him, if he has reason to believe that the article was stolen or lost and found by the person, not its owner, attempting to pledge the same. 
State Law reference- Property from intoxicated person or thief, return of stolen property, 205 ILCS 510/9. 
3-12-16. - Display of certain weapons. 
    No pawnbroker shall show, display or exhibit any pistol, revolver, derringer, bowie knife, dirk or other weapon of like character which can be concealed on the person, in any show window or in or on any premises immediately abutting upon any public way in the city in such a way that the same may be seen from such public way. 
3-12-17. - Police report; revocation of license. 
    It shall be the duty of all members of the police department to report to the mayor any failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter, and the city council may revoke the license of the person offending against any of these provisions. And the city council shall revoke the license of any person who shall be convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter, whether such judgment or conviction shall have been appealed from or not. 
3-12-18. - Penalty. 
    Every pawnbroker who shall violate or neglect or refuse to comply with any or either of the provisions of this chapter, where no other penalty is imposed, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense, and in addition to such penalty the license of any person convicted as aforesaid shall be revoked. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3292, § 17, 7-3-01) 
CHAPTER 13. - SECONDHAND AND JUNK DEALERS[2] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4223, § 1, adopted July 7, 2015, amended ch. 13 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 13, §§ 3-13-1-3-13-19, pertained to simialr subject matter, and derived from: 1970 Code; Ord. 1465, adopted Aug. 29, 1978; Ord. 1994, adopted Oct. 2, 1984; Ord. 2219, adopted Sept. 22, 1987; Ord. No. 3292, §§ 16, 17, adopted July 13, 2001; and Ord. No. 3757, § 3, adopted Aug. 21, 2007. 

3-13-1. - Definitions. 
    Firearm: As used in this chapter, the term "firearm" means: (a) any weapon (including a starter gun) which will or is designed to or may readily be converted to expel a projectile by the action of an explosive; (b) the frame or receiver of any such weapon; (c) any firearm muffler or firearm silencer; or (d) any destructive device as that term is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 921(a)(4). The term "firearm" does not include an antique firearm as that term is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 921(a)(16). 
    Junk dealer: As used in this chapter, the term "junk dealer" means any person who shall keep a junk shop or store or junk yard or place for the purchase, sale or exchange of junk, wire or sheet material; old iron, brass, copper, tin, or lead; junk motor vehicles or parts thereof; ranges, old rope, paper or bags; bones, glass or empty bottles; or any articles or things composed of or consisting of any combination of any one (1) or more of the materials or articles mentioned in this section. 
    Junk motor vehicle: As used in this chapter, the term "junk motor vehicle" includes any wrecked, damaged, disabled or inoperable automobile, bus, truck or other motor vehicle, or any used part thereof. 
    Precious metals: As used in this chapter, the term "precious metals" means any item containing gold, silver, platinum, palladium, or rhodium or any combination of gold, silver, platinum, palladium or rhodium. "Precious metals" do not include items containing any chemical or any automotive, photographic, electrical, medical or dental materials, or electronic parts, except for those containing precious metals. 
    Secondhand dealer: As used in this chapter, a "secondhand dealer" is any person which operates a business for profit which buys, sells, possesses on consignment for sale or trades jewelry, stamps, electronic equipment, or any precious metals or stones which have been previously owned by a consumer; or which derives more than thirty-five (35) percent of its gross receipts from the sale, consignment for sale, pledge or trade of any goods, wares or merchandise which have previously been owned by a consumer, including but not limited to, cellular phones, appliances, televisions, automobile parts and accessories, metals, whether in bulk or manufactured state, computers, computer parts or equipment, video/camera/stereo parts or equipment, electronic video consoles and games, videos, music, musical instruments, collectibles and memorabilia, sporting goods, bicycles, motorized tools/vehicles, tools, collectible artwork, firearms including their accessories and ammunition. The term "secondhand dealer" shall include "junk dealer" as defined in this section. The term "secondhand dealer" shall include businesses commonly known as swapshop operators, cash for gold operators, stamp dealers, and jewelers who purchase and resell items from persons other than dealers and suppliers that possess a federal employee identification number and engage in disassembling for purposes other than appraisals, melting or otherwise altering jewelry. The term "secondhand dealer" shall not include pawnbrokers, coin dealers, providers of commercial mobile services as defined in 47 U.S.C. 332(d), or retail merchants that do not purchase previously owned items directly from the public at the retail location. The fact that any business does any of the following acts shall be prima facie proof that such business is a secondhand dealership: 
(a)  Advertises in any fashion that it buys or sells secondhand or used items. Such advertisements shall include, but not be limited to, media advertisements, telephone listings, and signs whether on the exterior or interior of the business. 
(b)  Devotes a significant segment or section of the business premises to the purchase or sale of secondhand or used items. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 4247 , § 1, 7-21-15) 
3-13-2. - License required. 
    No person, either as owner, manager, lessee, officer or agent, or in any other capacity, within the city, shall operate or permit to be operated a secondhand dealership without first having obtained a license from the city to do so. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
Cross reference- Prohibited transactions (pawnbrokers), § 3-12-8. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license, tax, locate and regulate all places of business in dealers of junk, rags and secondhand articles whatsoever, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 
3-13-3. - Exemptions. 
    The following are exempt from the requirements of this chapter: 
(a)  Garage sales: As used in this chapter, a "garage sale" is defined as the sale at retail of used personal property by the lawful residents of residentially zone property which garage sale is not conducted on a periodic or ongoing basis. A garage sale shall be deemed to be periodic or ongoing if a garage sale is held by the lawful resident of residentially zoned property more than five (5) days in any consecutive ninety-day period; 
(b)  Sales conducted by governmental, civic, patriotic, fraternal, educational, religious, or benevolent organizations which have been in active and continuous existence for at least one (1) year prior to holding of the sale, or which are incorporated as a not for profit corporation by the state; 
(c)  Sales or purchases which are regulated by the licensing laws of the state, including automobile dealers, used parts dealers, and automotive parts recyclers; however, notwithstanding this exemption, such automobile dealers, used part dealers and automotive parts dealers must comply with the restrictions set forth in section 3-13-23 with regard to the premises from which these dealers operate their business; 
(d)  Antique dealers: As used in this section, an "antique dealer" is defined as one who derives seventy-five (75) percent of his gross sales each year from the sale of antiques and/or primitives. As used in this section, an "antique or primitive" is defined as an old and valuable art object or article no longer in production which is at least fifty (50) years old. As used in this section, the term "sale" does not include an exchange, trade or swap of items; 
(e)  Sales of furniture, clothing, home-made crafts and books/magazines; 
(f)  Consumer shows or exhibitions of collectibles other than a show or convention that offers to buy secondhand jewelry from attendees; 
(g)  Auctioneers; 
(h)  Pawnbrokers; 
(i)  Coin dealers: As used in this section, a "coin dealer" is defined as one who is primarily engaged in the business of buying and selling coins because of its numismatic value; and 
(j)  Providers of commercial mobile services as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 332(d) or their authorized dealers. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 4247 , § 2, 7-21-15) 
3-13-4. - Application. 
    An application for license required by section 3-13-2 shall be made in writing to the East Peoria City Clerk which shall minimally set forth the following: 
(1)  The name of the individual, partnership, corporation or association applying for a license. 
(2)  The residence, phone number, date of birth and driver's license number of the applicant or partners; or, if a corporation or association, the residence, phone number and driver's license number of the officers and all shareholders owning more than five (5) percent of the outstanding shares of stock. 
(3)  The location for which the license is requested. 
(4)  Whether the applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have been convicted of any criminal offense or ordinance violation (other than traffic or parking offenses) in any jurisdiction and, if so, a list of such convictions with date and prosecuting jurisdiction. 
(5)  Whether the applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have held a license or had an interest in a license issued by the city or any other jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of secondhand property revoked for cause, and, if so, list the date of revocation and jurisdiction. 
(6)  Whether the applicant desires to deal in, or buy or sell, or display firearms, derringers, Bowie knifes, dirks or other deadly weapons. 
a.  If so, whether the applicant possesses a valid and current license or permit pursuant to federal or state law pertaining to the buying or selling of such firearms, derringers, Bowie knives, dirks or other deadly weapons. The applicant shall also furnish a copy of the applicable license or permit. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-5. - Fees. 
    The applicant shall pay the city clerk prior to filing an application a nonrefundable license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per city fiscal year or part thereof. The license shall be renewed each year; the annual renewal fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-6. - Investigation. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license under this chapter, the city clerk shall cause a copy thereof to be sent to the police department, planning and community development department, and building and inspections department which shall report back to the city clerk in twenty-one (21) days whether the applicant is in accordance with applicable city codes. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-7. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the report from the police department referred to in section 3-13-6, the city clerk shall issue the license requested unless the city clerk shall find that: 
(a)  The applicant is under the age of eighteen (18); 
(b)  The location requested is not in a permanent structure; 
(c)  The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have been convicted of or had plead guilty to any offense related to theft, burglary, or purchasing or receiving stolen items under the laws of this state, city or any other jurisdiction within the past ten (10) years, or have forfeited a bond to appear in court to answer for charges for such offenses during such time; 
(d)  The location requested and structure to be used would not comply with all applicable laws including the zoning code of the city; 
(e)  The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have held a license or had an interest in a license issued by the city or any other jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of secondhand property which was revoked for cause; 
(f)  The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders has knowingly furnished false or misleading information or withheld relevant information on any application for a license required by this chapter or any investigation into any application; or 
(g)  In the case of an applicant who desires to deal in, or buy or sell, or display firearms, derringers, Bowie knives, dirks or other deadly weapons; the applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have been convicted of or had plead guilty to any offense related to the unlawful possession, sale or delivery of firearms or other deadly weapons. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 4247 , § 3, 7-21-15) 
3-13-8. - Posting. 
    Every license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall, at all times during the period for which it is effective, be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the principal entrance to the premises for which the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-9. - Revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued for a secondhand dealer under this chapter may be revoked or suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the mayor if he shall find after hearing: 
(1)  That the licensee, its officers, agents or employees have violated any of the provisions of this chapter, the laws of the state, or ordinances of the city in the operation of the business; 
(2)  That the licensee, its partners, officers or shareholders have been convicted of any offense set forth in section 3-13-7 of this chapter; or 
(3)  That the licensee, partners, officers or shareholders have knowingly furnished false or misleading information or withheld relevant information on any application for a license required by this chapter or any investigation into any application. 
(b)  The licensee shall be responsible for the acts of its agents, servants and employees in the operation of the business. Prior to holding a hearing concerning the question of whether a license shall be revoked or suspended, the mayor shall give at least ten (10) days' written notice to the licensee setting forth the alleged violation specifically. The licensee may present evidence and cross-examine witnesses at such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-10. - Bond. 
    Every applicant for a license under this chapter shall file with the city a license and permit bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), approved by the corporation counsel, with the city as obligee, conditioned for the faithful and due performance of the provisions of this chapter and the laws of the state concerning the operation of the licensed business, and the payment of all fines and penalties by reason of the violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-11. - Transfer. 
(a)  No license issued under this chapter may be transferred to any other person. 
(b)  No corporate licensee shall permit any transfer of its stock which would vest in aggregate more than five (5) percent of the stock outstanding in such corporation in any shareholder unless such shareholder has been certified by the city manager as meeting the requirements of section 3-13-7 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-12. - Change of location. 
    No licensee shall carry on any business required to be licensed under this chapter except at the location designated on the license. Should the licensee wish to change the location, application shall be made to the city clerk for such change in writing. The city clerk shall approve the change of location unless the new location would be contrary to the provisions of this chapter or any of the ordinances of the city. There shall be no fee for filing any application for change of location. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-13. - Hours of operation. 
    No licensee shall purchase any goods, wares, articles or things whatsoever from any person between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the next day. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-14. - Prohibited purchases. 
    No licensee under this chapter shall purchase or accept any goods, wares, articles, or things under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where the seller is less than the age of eighteen (18). 
(2)  Where the seller is intoxicated. Intoxicated is defined as a seller whose mental or physical functioning is substantially impaired as a result of the use of alcohol or drugs. 
(3)  Where the seller fails to present a valid and current identification government issued I.D. containing the seller's full legal name, date of birth, address, photograph, and an identification number. 
(4)  Where the article to be purchased had an original manufacturer's serial number at the time it was new, but no longer legibly exhibits such number. 
(5)  Where the licensee or its employee or agent knows or reasonably should have known that the items are stolen or otherwise illegal to possess. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-15. - Purchasing, selling, etc., weapons prohibited. 
    No licensee shall deal in, or buy or sell, or display in his shop, any firearm, derringer, Bowie knife, dirk or other deadly weapon of like character, capable of being secreted upon the person unless such licensee shall also possess valid and current licenses or permits as required by applicable federal, state, or local laws, ordinances, rules or regulations. 
    No licensee shall deal in, or buy or sell, or display in his shop, any firearm, derringer, Bowie knife, dirk or other deadly weapon of like character, capable of being secreted upon the person, unless such weapons are displayed for sale in a locked cabinet, employees are present during customer business hours, and security cameras are recording all activity surrounding the weapon display areas. After customer business hours, the weapons shall be locked in a secure area inaccessible to intruders such as a secure gun vault or locker or behind locked bars on windows and doors to the business. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-16. - Removal of identifying marks prohibited. 
    No licensee shall remove, alter or obliterate any manufacturer's make model or serial number, personal identification number or other identifying marks engraved or etched upon an item of personal property that was purchased or received by the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-17. - Recycling kiosks. 
    The recycling of electronic devices through a kiosk must be approved by the chief of police prior to receiving a license as a secondhand dealer. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-18. - Record of purchases. 
(a)  Every licensee shall keep at the licensed location a standard record book that has been approved by the chief of police in which shall be entered all of the following information accurately: 
(1)  A succinct and accurate description of all the goods, articles or other property (excluding junk/scrap), purchased or received in the course of the business licensed under this chapter including: 
a.  Type of good or article. 
b.  Brand name/make/manufacturer. 
c.  Model number. 
d.  Serial number. 
e.  Color/finish. 
f.  Any other identifying marks, writings, engraving, etc. 
(2)  The time of sale. 
(3)  Clear photograph of the goods, articles or other property using Leads Online cameras. 
(4)  Seller's full legal name, date of birth and address. Also required is a color copy or photograph of a valid and current government issued photo I.D. containing the aforementioned information. 
(5)  The amount of money or value given, or thing loaned to such person and the terms thereof. 
(6)  The signature of the employees who received the property. 
(7)  A signed statement of the person from whom the property was obtained affirming that he is over eighteen (18) years of age, lawful owner of the property which is clear of all attachments. 
(8)  In the case of firearms, all information and forms required by federal law. 
(b)  Entries made in the record book shall be printed or typed and shall be legible. All entries shall be made immediately upon receipt or purchase of any item. The record book shall be open to inspection by the chief of police or his designee during the performance of their duties during normal hours of operation. All licensees shall maintain such records for a period of three (3) years. 
(c)  Effective August 1, 2015, all licensees are required to use the Leads Online system for keeping records under this section. The chief of police shall provide information on obtaining the software and hardware necessary for this purpose. 
(d)  All licensees shall subscribe to and participate in "leadsonline.com" , the current software based tracking system approved by the chief of police. Any item received or purchased shall be entered into leadsonline.com and downloaded into the database within twelve (12) hours of receipt of the article. Leads Online may be substituted in the future at the discretion of the chief, however substitution shall be made with ample notice to licensees to allow for compliance. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-19. - Reports to chief of police. 
    It shall be the duty of every licensee under this chapter to deliver to the chief of police or his designee, each day before the hour of 12:00 noon, a legible, correct, and complete copy of the record book. Such daily report shall be delivered by any means authorized by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-20. - Inspection of records and premises; seizures. 
    Every licensee under this chapter and every person employed by him in the conduct of business shall admit to any and every part of the premises designated in the license, during normal business hours, the chief of police or his designee to examine any goods, articles, things, or books or other records on the premises dealing with purchase or sale of used property and to search for and to take into possession any article known or for which he has reasonable grounds to believe to have been stolen. Such law enforcement officer may make any such search or seizure as is provided for in this section, and property so seized shall be receipted for by such officer, who shall adequately describe the seized property and sign the receipt. Should the officer determine the property not to be stolen, he shall promptly return same to licensee. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-21. - Waiting period. 
    Every licensee, except auction houses, shall keep all property purchased or received from an individual in its original condition at the time of acquisition for inspection for the period of time as designated below, before it can be sold, traded, discarded or otherwise changed from its original condition. 
(1)  Fourteen-day waiting period for any individually identifiable item, including but not limited to: 
a.  Appliances. 
b.  Memorabilia/collectibles (i.e., autographed items, sports cards, collectible stamps, figurines, etc.). 
c.  Collectible artwork (numbered prints, sculptures, etc.). 
d.  Jewelry (precious metals, gemstones, etc., excluding costume jewelry). 
e.  Currency/coins. 
f.  Musical instruments. 
g.  Automobile wheels/rims. 
h.  Tools. 
i.  All other items bearing a manufacturer's make, model or serial number; personal identification number; or other identifying mark engraved or etched upon an item. 
(2)  Seven-day waiting period for any non-identifiable item, including but not limited to: 
a.  Video games. 
b.  Music (CDs, cassettes, records, etc.) 
c.  Sporting goods. 
d.  All other items not specified in subsection 3-13-21(1) above. 
    During the holding period, all items purchased or received shall be stored at the location in which they were purchased or received. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-22. - Hold order. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a written hold order from a law enforcement officer of the city indicating that property in the possession of the licensee is needed for the purpose of a criminal investigation and prosecution, the licensee shall release the property to the custody of the law enforcement officer. Such officer shall provide a written acknowledgement that the property has been released to the officer. The release of the property to the custody of a law enforcement officer shall not be considered a waiver or release of the licensee's property rights or interest in the property. Upon completion of the criminal investigation, the property shall be returned to the licensee; except that, if the law enforcement officer has not completed the criminal investigation within one hundred twenty (120) days after the property's release, the officer shall immediately return the property to the licensee or obtain and furnish to the licensee a warrant for the continued custody of the property. 
(b)  The licensee shall not release or dispose of the property except pursuant to a court order or the expiration of the holding period of the hold order, including all extensions. 
(c)  In cases where criminal charges have been filed and the property may be needed as evidence, the prosecuting attorney shall notify the licensee in writing. The notice shall contain the case number, the style of the case, and a description of the property. The licensee shall hold such property until receiving notice of the disposition of the case from the prosecuting attorney. The prosecuting attorney shall notify the licensee and claimant in writing within fifteen (15) days after the disposition of the case. When such other disposition is ordered, the court shall additionally order the person from whom the licensee acquired the property to pay restitution to the licensee in the amount that the licensee paid for the property together with reasonable attorney's fees and costs. 
(d)  When any person is found to be the owner of stolen property that has been sold to a licensee, the property shall be returned to the owner without the payment of the money paid by the licensee or any costs or charges of any kind that the licensee may have placed on the property. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
3-13-23. - Restriction; premises. 
    Any premises, area, lot or parcel of land within the city kept as a secondhand or junk yard by a duly licensed dealer shall be enclosed with either a solid non-transparent wall or fence or lin-weave steel wire privacy fence, or combination thereof, with a minimum height of nine (9) feet from the ground level. No secondhand or junk articles shall be allowed to remain outside such enclosure, unless such secondhand items are fully restored and in operating condition for the purpose of displaying the item for resale. No entrance or exit shall exceed fifteen (15) feet in width; and all such entrances and exits shall be closed and locked after regular business hours. The fence or wall shall not contain any poster or advertising of any kind except one (1) sign, not exceeding thirty-two (32) square feet in area. Said enclosures shall be erected within six (6) months of the date of the passage of this section. 
(Ord. No. 4247 , § 4, 7-21-15) 
3-13-24. - False or misleading application. 
    In addition to being subject to penalty as hereinafter set forth, any person which obtains a license, as herein provided by furnishing the city with a false and misleading application shall, upon the discovery thereof, suffer an immediate revocation of such license and forfeiture of all fees paid. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 4247 , § 4, 7-21-15) 
Editor's note- Formerly codified as § 3-13-23. Renumbered by the addition of new provisions codified as § 3-13-23 by Ord. No. 4247 . 
3-13-25. - Penalty. 
    Whosoever shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, where no other penalty is provided, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day of violation shall be deemed a separate offense. The licensee shall be fully responsible for any violation of this chapter occasioned by or with the condonation of the licensee's partners, officers, shareholders, agents or employees; any such violation shall be imputed to the licensee. The city retains the right to revoke the license in the event of noncompliance of the Code. Such revocation may be appealed per the Administrative Adjudication Act. 
(Ord. No. 4223 , § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 4247 , § 4, 7-21-15) 
Editor's note- Formerly codified as § 3-13-24. See editor's note above. 
CHAPTER 14. - USED CAR DEALERS 
SECTION: 

3-14-1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Used car dealer means any person buying, selling or exchanging or otherwise disposing of or receiving into possession, any used or secondhand motor vehicles for the purpose of earning a profit therefrom. 
3-14-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a used car dealer within the city without having first obtained a license therefor, as hereinafter provided. 
3-14-3. - Application. 
    Application to engage in the business of a used car dealer shall be made to the city clerk, upon such forms as may be provided, and shall state thereon: 
(a)  The name and residence of the applicant, and if a corporation, the names and residences of the principal officers thereof, including one or more persons whom the corporation shall designate as manager or person in charge; 
(b)  The location of the place or premises at or on which it is desired to carry on such business; 
(c)  The length of time which the applicant has resided at his residence or, if a corporation, the length of time which the manager or person in charge has resided at his residence; 
(d)  What type of shop the applicant maintains or intends to maintain in connection with his business and what equipment it contains for the purpose of servicing, repairing and reconditioning the vehicles which the applicant intends to offer for sale; and 
(e)  Such other reasonable and pertinent information as the city council shall from time to time require. 
3-14-4. - Fee. 
    No license shall be issued hereinunder until an annual license fee of one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00) shall have been paid for every place or premises operated as a used car lot. 
3-14-5. - Investigation; approval; renewal. 
    Such application when filed shall be referred to the chief of police for such investigation as he deems necessary. No license shall be issued hereunder until a satisfactory report shall be filed by the chief of police with the mayor. 
    Whenever it shall appear to the mayor that all provisions of this chapter relating to the applicant and to the premises have been conformed with, the mayor shall approve the application hereunder. Provided, however, that the city clerk may thereafter grant renewal of any license issued hereunder upon a finding of conformance with all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4229 , § 1, 5-19-15) 
3-14-6. - Expiration; transferability. 
    All licenses granted hereunder shall be valid only during the fiscal year of the city. 
    No license issued hereunder shall be transferable or assignable with respect to the named licensee, or with respect to the named premises without written consent of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 4229 , § 2, 5-19-15) 
3-14-7. - Restriction; location. 
    A separate license shall be required for each location, place or premises upon which such business or occupation is proposed to be conducted. 
3-14-8. - Records required. 
    Every licensee hereunder or his manager shall keep a written book in which shall be recorded in ink every sale of a motor vehicle, which records shall accurately show: 
(a)  Date of transaction; 
(b)  Parties to the transaction; 
(c)  Make of car and name of manufacturer; 
(d)  Model number, type, body style and year of manufacture; 
(e)  Motor number; 
(f)  Chassis number; 
(g)  Consideration transferred in the course of the transaction, if any; and 
(h)  Finance charge, if any. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, obliterate or remove any entry made in such books. 
3-14-9. - Inspection. 
    Such record books and every used or secondhand motor vehicle and parts thereof in the possession of any licensee hereunder shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the mayor or of any member of the police department of the city. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made inspections for the purpose of seeing that the records required hereunder are being kept, which inspections shall occur of a frequency of not less than four (4) times per year. 
3-14-10. - Transactions with minors prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to purchase or receive through trade or barter any used or secondhand motor vehicle, or any used or secondhand parts of any motor vehicle, from any minor person without the written consent of such person's parent or guardian. 
3-14-11. - Receiving stolen vehicles; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed hereunder to buy or receive or conceal any used or secondhand motor vehicle, or any used or secondhand parts of any motor vehicle, knowing the same to have been stolen, with the intent to defraud the owner. 
    Violations of this section shall be punishable, upon conviction thereof, by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 18, 7-3-01) 
3-14-12. - Exception to chapter. 
    Any individual making an isolated sale of his own motor vehicle or parts thereof shall not be deemed to be engaged in the business of dealing in used or secondhand motor vehicles. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 15. - HOTELS AND MOTOR COURTS 
SECTION: 

3-15-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Hotel means a building or structure kept, used or maintained as, or advertised or held out to the public to be an inn, family hotel, apartment hotel, lodging house, dormitory or place where sleeping or rooming accommodations are furnished for hire or rent, whether with or without meals, for twenty (20) or more persons, for a period of one day or more. 
    Motel or Motor court means any parking lot or garage for the accommodation of motor vehicles where permanent sleeping accommodations for transients are afforded or provided on the same premises for the public or the occupants of such vehicles; provided, however, that a hotel which furnishes parking space or has a garage in connection with such hotel will not be construed as a motel or motor court. 
(1970 Code) 
3-15-2. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, operated or maintained, upon any property owned or controlled by him a hotel or motor court within the city without having obtained a license therefor from the city clerk or without complying with all provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  No license shall be issued or annually renewed for a hotel or motel court delinquent in payment of the hotel/motel room renting tax to the city as provided by this Title. 
3-15-3. - Fee; duration. 
    The annual fee for such license for a hotel or a motor court shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The license shall be valid for one year. 
(Ord. 2324, 4-11-89) 
3-15-4. - Application; plans. 
    Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain a hotel or motor court within the city shall file a written application with the city clerk and shall state thereon the name and address of the applicant, name and address of the owner, name and address of the manager or managers thereof, location of the hotel or motor court, and the maximum number of persons or vehicles to be accommodated. This application shall be accompanied by plans of the toilet, bath and wash basin facilities, slop sinks, water faucets, sewer connections, driveway and other improvements, unless such plans shall be already on file in the office of the director of city inspections. 
3-15-5. - Sanitary facilities. 
(a)  Hotels. Water closets, lavatories and bathing facilities shall be available to all guests on each floor; and there shall be at least one bathroom equipped with water closet, shower or tub, and lavatory facilities for each ten (10) residents on the premises. 
(b)  Motor courts. No such premises shall be operated as a motor court unless equipped with adequate water closet, lavatory and bathing facilities to serve the total number of persons accommodated in each room or suite or rooms. 
(c)  General. All such sanitary facilities shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewer system of the city if the premises are located on a street served by such a sewer. 
3-15-6. - Heating. 
    All such premises shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1 to a temperature of not less than sixty eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) a.m. and ten o'clock (10:00) p.m. and to a temperature of not less than fifty five (55) degrees Fahrenheit at all other times. 
3-15-7. - Exits, hotels. 
    No building shall be used for a hotel unless it is furnished with the number of fire escapes and exits required by the Building and Fire Prevention Codes of the city relating to the construction of a new hotel. It shall be unlawful to block or permit the blocking of any exit from any premises used as a hotel. 
3-15-8. - Fire walls, motor court. 
    No parking space shall be provided for motor vehicles within ten (10) feet of any building or structure used for housing accommodations in a motor court unless the wall facing such parking space is constructed of fire proof materials and unless any windows in such wall are equipped with reinforced fire-resistant glass. 
3-15-9. - Inspections. 
    The director of city inspections and the chiefs of the fire and police departments are hereby vested with full power and authority to inspect and supervise all places within the city now used or hereafter to be used for hotel or motor court purposes; and it shall be the duty of such officials to cause such inspections of not less frequency than once in every four (4) months. Such officials and all duly authorized inspectors and agents thereunder shall be permitted access to any hotel or motor court and all parts thereof at all times for the purpose of seeing that such hotel or motor court is kept and maintained in a clean, sanitary and safe manner, and for the purpose of determining whether or not all provisions of this Code are being complied with. 
3-15-10. - Regulations, generally. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any statute or any provision of this Code on or in any hotel or motor court. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any hotel or motor court or any portion thereof for immoral purposes. 
3-15-11. - Cleanliness. 
    The premises of any hotel or motor court must be kept clean and sanitary at all times, and all waste material must be removed therefrom at least once every twenty four (24) hours; the owner or operator of such hotel or motor court shall provide proper waste receptacles and shall make all necessary arrangements with the city for disposal of the same. 
3-15-12. - Manager or agent required. 
    Each hotel or motor court shall have a manager or agent residing on the premises either in a room or suite of rooms within the building or buildings, or in a separate building constructed for such purpose; and there shall at all times be present a person or persons in charge of such hotel or motor court who shall be responsible for its proper maintenance and operation. 
3-15-13. - Register required. 
    The operator of such hotel or motor court shall keep a register which shall contain the names and addresses of all persons occupying any room or suite of rooms within the hotel or motor court, and the hour and date of arrival and departure of such occupants, and the state automobile license number and license year of the vehicle or vehicles of such occupants. Said register shall be available for examination at all times by members of the city council, officers of the city police department or of state or Federal law enforcement or investigative agencies. 
3-15-14. - Registering under false name prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to register as a guest in any hotel or motor court within the city under an assumed, fictitious or false name. 
3-15-15. - Falsely registering as owner of car prohibited. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department of the city from time to time to check the register provided for in this chapter. If after such investigation it is determined that the owner of any vehicle is different than the person who has signed the register as the owner, then such person signing the register shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
3-15-16. - Fugitives prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any fugitive from justice to remain in any hotel or motor court without notice to the police department. 
3-15-17. - Lights required. 
    Any area or premises of a hotel or motor court open to use by the public or by persons occupying or being accommodated therein shall be kept adequately lighted after dark; provided, that such lights must be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any adjacent premises. 
3-15-18. - Signs; approval. 
    No sign advertising such hotel or motor court shall be attached to the building or erected on the grounds unless and until a permit to do so has been approved by the zoning board. Before any such sign is erected or attached, an application to erect or attach shall be made to the zoning administrator and the plans and specifications for such sign shall be submitted therewith, subject to approval by the building inspector. 
3-15-19. - Trailers in motor courts. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any motor court for the accommodation of any travel trailer or mobile home unless all requirements of this Code relating to mobile home parks or camp grounds are complied with; provided, however, that where a license fee for a mobile home park has been paid, it shall not be necessary to pay an additional fee for the operation of a motor court on the same premises. 
(1970 Code) 
Cross reference- Mobile home parks, § 3-16-1 et seq.; campgrounds, § 3-17-1 et seq. 
3-15-20. - Hotel or motel room renting tax. 
    No licensee shall wilfully fail to file tax returns with the city showing tax receipts received with respect to each hotel and motel room or make such payments as are required pursuant to Chapter 28 of this Title of the East Peoria City Code. 
(Ord. 2324, 4-11-89) 
CHAPTER 16. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 
SECTION: 
DIVISION I. - IN GENERAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Trailers in motor courts, § 3-15-19. 

3-16-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Dependant mobile home. Any mobile home which does not contain toilet and bath or shower facilities. 
    Independent mobile home. Any mobile home with self-contained toilet and bath or shower facilities. 
    Mobile commercial facility. Any vehicle or similar portable structure which is so constructed as to permit it being used as a conveyance upon public streets or highways, which lacks a permanent foundation and which is designed for use as an office, retail facility, sleeping quarters, manufacturing facility, warehouse facility or for any other non residential use allowed in commercial or manufacturing districts established pursuant to Title 5, Chapter 9 and Chapter 10 of the East Peoria City Code. 
    Mobile home. Any vehicle or similar portable structure of any floor area under nine hundred (900) square feet, so constructed as to permit its being used as a conveyance upon public streets or highways and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling place of one or more persons for year-round living without a permanent foundation; excepting, however, those structures considered to be travel trailers as hereinafter defined. 
    Mobile home park. Any premises upon which two (2) or more occupied mobile homes are harbored either free of charge or for revenue and shall include any buildings, structures, tent, vehicle or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park. 
    Mobile home site. Any portion of a mobile home park designated for the use or occupancy of one mobile home. 
    School district. Any district created or operated under the provisions of the School Code of 1961. 
State Law reference- Schools, 105 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
    Travel trailer. Any vehicular portable structure built on a chassis designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation and vacation uses and having a body width not exceeding eight (8) feet, being of any length, provided its gross weight does not exceed four thousand five hundred (4,500) pounds, or being of any weight provided its body length does not exceed twenty nine (29) feet. 
    Travel trailer site. Any portion of a mobile home park designed for the use or occupancy of one travel trailer. 
(1970 Code; Ord. 2535, 10-15-91) 
3-16-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate within the city any mobile home park unless such person shall have first obtained a license therefor, as hereinafter provided. 
3-16-3. - License application. 
(a)  License application; general. General application for mobile home park licenses shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and shall state therein the name and address of the owner or lessee of the premises; the maximum number of mobile homes the park will accommodate; and the name and address of the manager who will be directly responsible for the maintenance and operation of the mobile home park and upon whom all notices and demands may be served. 
(b)  License application; renewal. In addition to subsection (a) above the owner or owners of mobile home parks established within the City of East Peoria prior to the effective date of this chapter, shall, prior to June 30, 1970, file with the city clerk a plat showing the location of the park and all buildings, hydrants, sewer connections and driveways, together with available mobile home sites and vehicle parking areas designated and numbered. 
    No license shall be renewed subsequent to June 30, 1970, unless the licensee shall have the abovementioned plat on file. 
    It is also desirable that a plat be drawn to scale showing toilets, baths, washing facilities, slop sinks and water faucets. 
(c)  License application; initial. In addition to subsection (a) above, the initial application shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  A copy of the special use permit granted by the city pursuant to section 5-8-6(a)4f of this Code permitting the operation of a mobile home park upon the premises to be licensed. The initial license for a mobile home park established after the effective date of this chapter shall not be issued until a special use permit granted by the planning commission of the city has been filed. 
(2)  A plat approved by the planning commission of the city, showing all buildings, toilets, baths, washing facilities, slop sinks, water faucets, hydrants, sewer connections, roadways, together with available mobile home sites and projected mobile home sites and vehicle parking areas designed and numbered. Such plats shall be drawn to scale. 
3-16-4. - State permit required. 
    No license shall be issued hereunder unless the applicant shall file with the city clerk a certified copy of the permit issued by the State Department of Public Health pursuant to the Mobile Home Park Law. 
State Law reference- Mobile Home Park Act, 210 ILCS 115/1 et seq. 
3-16-5. - Fee. 
    The fee for the license required hereunder shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per mobile home park per calendar year. 
3-16-6. - Limitation of number. 
    No license shall issue to any mobile home park established after the effective date of this chapter unless said mobile home park shall be of sufficient size to accommodate one hundred (100) mobile home sites with off-street parking and shall have underground utilities furnished. 
3-16-7. - Revocation; suspension. 
    Any license issued hereunder shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the city council as provided in section 3-2-17 of this Code. 
    This section shall particularly apply to the provisions of section 3-16-25 of this chapter, regarding certificates of title. 
3-16-8. - Resident manager required. 
    Every mobile home park shall have a responsible attendant or manager residing on the premises whose duty it shall be to maintain the park, its facilities, and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition, and, who shall be answerable with the licensee hereunder for any violation of the provisions of this Code. 
3-16-9. - Drainage requirements. 
    No mobile home park shall be so located that the drainage of the park area will endanger any water supply. All such parks shall be well drained and shall be located in areas free from ponds, swamps and similar places in which mosquitoes may breed. No waste water from mobile homes shall be deposited on the surface of the ground. 
3-16-10. - Size and numbering of mobile home sites. 
(a)  Each mobile home space or site on which a mobile home is accommodated shall have a minimum area of six thousand (6,000) square feet, provided that the mobile home spaces or sites, existing in the park and approved by the city for construction prior to the effective date of this chapter, shall contain an area not less than one thousand (1,000) square feet and provided further that the mobile home spaces or sites, existing in the park and approved by the city for construction prior to March 31, 1998, shall contain an area not less than two thousand eight hundred (2,800) square feet. 
(b)  Travel trailer spaces must be kept in a separate area from the mobile home spaces and shall have a minimum area of seven hundred fifty (750) square feet. 
(c)  Travel trailer spaces may not be used for the parking of mobile homes. 
(d)  Each of the above-mentioned sites or spaces shall have prominently displayed upon it a sign indicating the number given that site or space in accordance with section 3-16-3 of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 3064, § 1, 7-21-98) 
3-16-10.5. - Mobile home stands. 
(a)  No mobile home shall remain in a mobile home park for a period greater than seventy-two (72) hours unless such mobile home is placed upon and anchored to a mobile home stand in compliance with this Section 10.5. 
(b)  The mobile home stand shall be constructed of concrete at least five (5) inches deep with adequate footings which extend to a depth not less than the frost line. 
(c)  Stands shall be constructed so that properly placed and blocked mobile homes are supported at each longitudinal frame member entirely by slabs of concrete not less than two (2) feet long and two (2) feet wide. 
(d)  Stands shall be equipped with devices for anchoring the mobile home to prevent overturning or unintended uplift. Anchors or tie-downs shall be provided by eyelets imbedded in the concrete with adequate anchor plates or hooks, or other suitable means. Tie-downs shall, at a minimum, comply with the rules and regulation promulgated by the Illinois Department of Public Health under the Mobile Home Tie-down Act. 
(Ord. No. 3064, § 2, 7-21-98) 
3-16-11. - Distance requirements. 
(a)  No mobile home shall be parked closer than five (5) feet to the side lot lines of the mobile home park or closer than ten (10) feet to a public street, alley or building. 
(b)  Each individual mobile home site shall abut or face on a roadway, which roadway shall have unobstructed access to a public highway or alley; all roadways shall have concrete or bituminous, combination curbs and gutters or wedge-type gutters and the road shall be constructed with an asphalt treated surface. 
(c)  There shall be an open space of at least ten (10) feet adjacent to the sides of every mobile home and at least five (5) feet adjacent to the ends of every mobile home. 
3-16-12. - Water supply. 
    An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality shall be furnished in each mobile home park. At least one cold water supply outlet shall be provided within three hundred (300) feet of every dependent mobile home site. Each independent mobile home site shall be provided with a cold water tap at least four (4) inches above the ground level. 
3-16-12.5. - Sidewalks. 
    Mobile home parks shall provide and maintain sidewalks in compliance with the city subdivision code. 
(Ord. No. 3064, § 3, 7-21-98) 
3-16-13. - Community service building required.
