    Adequate toilet, lavatory and bathing facilities for occupants of dependent mobile homes shall be provided within a community service building or buildings. Such building or buildings shall be conveniently located, well constructed, having good natural and artificial lighting, adequate ventilation and floors of concrete or similar impervious materials. Concrete curbings, extending at least six (6) inches above the floor, shall be provided and the floor sloped to adequate drains. Walls and partitions shall be constructed of impervious material where subject to splash. Such building shall be maintained at a temperature of at least sixty eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit during the period from October 1 to May 1. 
3-16-14. - Community service building; toilets. 
(a)  The community service building shall be provided with toilet rooms for each sex, plainly marked by appropriate signs, in which shall be installed water closets and lavatories adequate in number to serve the reasonable needs of occupants of dependent mobile homes. Each water closet shall be placed in a separate compartment, properly separated from other water closets and shall be not less than three (3) feet wide and shall be enclosed with proper partitions. The community service building shall also be provided with a tub or shower bath compartments, for both sexes, adequate in number to accommodate the reasonable needs of occupants of dependent mobile homes. In combination with each bath or shower stall, there shall be provided an individual dressing compartment not less than two and one-half feet by three feet (21/2' × 3') in plan so arranged as to insure privacy. The floor of such compartment shall be waterproof and elevated three (3) inches above the floor of the shower stall or a six (6) inch curbing provided separating shower compartment from dressing room. Mats, grids and walkways made of wood, cloth or other absorbent materials will not be approved for use in bath sections of community service buildings. 
(b)  No laundry trays shall be located in toilet or bathrooms. 
(c)  An adequate water supply shall be provided at all times for the operation of all water closets in service buildings, and an adequate supply of hot and cold water shall be provided at all times in the service buildings for all bathing, washing, cleaning and laundry facilities. 
(d)  Every mobile home park shall be so arranged that the walking distance from any dependent mobile home unit parking site to the water, toilet and shower accommodations will not exceed three hundred (300) feet. 
3-16-15. - Disposal of sewage and other water-carried wastes. 
(a)  All sewage and other water-carried wastes shall be disposed of into the city sewerage system whenever available. In mobile home parks in which such connections are not available, disposal shall be into a private system which shall include a sanitary means of disposal, the operation of which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to health. 
(b)  When a water carriage system of sewage is used, each mobile home site shall be provided with a sewer connection for the combined liquid waste outlet or outlets of each mobile home. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of said mobile home park to provide an approved type of water and odor tight connection from the mobile home water drainage to the sewer connection, and it shall be the duty of said owner or operator to make such connection to said sewer while located in such mobile home park. 
(d)  Sewer connections in unoccupied mobile home sites shall be so closed that they will emit no odors or cause a breeding place for flies. 
(e)  No water or waste from any mobile home shall be allowed to fall on the ground. 
3-16-16. - Garbage and rubbish; storage, disposal. 
(a)  A sufficient number of adequate fly-proof and water-tight containers shall be supplied for the storage of garbage and rubbish. 
(b)  Garbage and rubbish containers shall be emptied at least every three (3) days and shall not be filled to overflowing or allowed to become foul smelling or a breeding place for flies. 
(c)  The burning of garbage and rubbish in mobile home parks is hereby prohibited. 
(d)  Garbage containers shall be kept at all times upon cement pads in accordance with the statutes, rules and regulations of the State of Illinois. 
(e)  Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to health. 
3-16-17. - Insect and rodent control. 
(a)  Adequate insect and rodent control measures shall be employed. All buildings shall be fly and rodent proof and rodent harborages shall not be permitted to exist in the mobile home park. 
(b)  Skirting shall be placed around each mobile home by the owner thereof, reaching from the bottom edge of each side of said mobile home to the ground directly below, and running completely around said mobile home on all sides. 
(c)  Said skirting may be constructed of any material sufficient to keep the area under each mobile home from the public view, and to prevent the passage of rodents, provided that said material shall not prevent adequate ventilation of the area under any mobile home, and shall be erected within sixty (60) days of the date upon which each mobile home is placed upon a mobile home site. 
3-16-18. - Electrical outlets, connections. 
(a)  Electrical outlets for each individual mobile home site shall be provided and the installation shall be in compliance with city building and electrical regulations. 
(b)  No connected electric extension cords shall lie on the ground or be suspended less than seven (7) feet from the ground above sidewalks or pathways; except that electric cords buried in the ground are permissible. 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Title 4. 
3-16-19. - Fire protection. 
    Mobile home parks shall provide fire hydrants in compliance with city construction standards and in locations approved by the department of planning and zoning. 
(Ord. No. 3064, § 4, 7-21-98) 
3-16-19.5. - Mobile home roofs. 
    Mobile homes in mobile home parks shall have a pitched roof with a slope having a rise of three-twelfths (3/12) of span or greater. 
(Ord. No. 3064, § 5, 7-21-98) 
3-16-20. - Temporary porches, rooms. 
    Temporary porches, canvas-roofed canopies and skirts shall be permitted for mobile homes and auxiliary rooms may also be authorized if constructed of fire resistant materials of such specifications as shall be required by city building regulations. 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Title 4. 
3-16-21. - Lighting. 
    There shall be a minimum of one and five-tenths (1.5) foot-candle power of light in all residential areas of a mobile home park. 
3-16-22. - City regulations to be posted. 
    The city clerk shall supply all licensees hereunder with any and all rules and regulations pertaining thereto established by the city, and any changes that may be made from time to time, which shall be kept posted at all times by said licensee or his manager in a protected, conspicuous place within the mobile home park. 
3-16-23. - Special duties of licensee. 
    The following provisions shall be applicable to all mobile home parks licensed under the provisions of this chapter: 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each licensee on the first days of February and September of each year to file with the school board or boards of the school district or districts wherein the mobile home park is located a report giving the name, age and address within the park of all children of school age living in such mobile home park. 
(b)  All streets and driveways in every mobile home park must be maintained in a passable and reasonably dust-proof condition at all times; and all streets and driveways in every mobile home park established after January 1, 1954, shall have a minimum width of twenty (20) feet. All streets and driveways in parks constructed after the effective date of this chapter shall have a minimum width of twenty five (25) feet. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every licensee hereunder or his manager to report to the city board of health the full name, age and address within the park of every person therein who is affected or suspected of being affected with a reportable or communicable disease. 
(d)  The management of every mobile home park shall assume full responsibility for maintaining in good repair and condition all sanitary and safety appliances in the park, and shall promptly bring such action as is necessary to prosecute or eject from the park any person or persons who wilfully or maliciously damage such appliances or any person or persons who fail to comply with the regulations of this chapter. 
Cross reference- Disease controls, Title 9, ch. 3. 
3-16-24. - Registration of mobile homes required. 
    Each mobile home entering such mobile home park shall be assigned a site, a location, given a copy of the mobile home park rules and registered as hereinafter provided. 
    Said registration shall include the name and address of every occupant of said mobile home, the license number of all units thereof, the state issuing such licenses, and a statement indicating the exact location at which such mobile home was last parked, including the state, city, town or village where such parking occurred. The licensee shall keep a registry of all children of school age occupying mobile homes in the mobile home park. The above mentioned registration entry shall be signed by an occupant of the mobile home. It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish false information for purposes of registration, either deliberately or negligently. The registration records shall be neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records shall be destroyed until six (6) years have elapsed following the date of registration. The register shall be available at all times for inspection by city, state and Federal law enforcement officers. 
3-16-25. - Display certificate of title required. 
(a)  In the event that any mobile home in such mobile home park shall not have displayed, in accordance with a display certificate of title, the mobile home park licensee or the manager thereof shall, within forty eight (48) hours after said mobile home enters said mobile home park, notify the State Department of Revenue of that fact. 
(b)  For the purpose of determining when any such notification was sent to the department of revenue by a mobile home park with respect to any particular mobile home, it shall be a presumption that the notification was not sent more than four (4) days prior to the time when it was received by the department of revenue. 
(c)  The owner of any mobile home park which fails to give timely notification to the department of revenue as required herein is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each such mobile home which is located in such mobile home park after the expiration of the forty eight (48) hours hereinabove referred to and prior to the time when the notification by the mobile home park is made to the department of revenue. 
(d)  Representatives of the department of revenue and all other law enforcement officers may enter any mobile home park at any time for the purpose of determining which, if any, mobile homes located therein do not have displayed the display certificate of title referred to hereinabove. 
3-16-26. - School authorities' powers. 
    The governing body of the school district in which any mobile home park is located, by and through its officers, attendance officers and proper employees, may inspect and visit such mobile home park for the purpose of examining the register with reference to children of school age, for the purpose of enforcing school attendance of such children housed therein. When a mobile home park is located in two (2) or more school districts, the school district boards of such districts, acting jointly, are hereby authorized to proceed under the provisions of this section. 
DIVISION II. - TRAVEL TRAILERS 

3-16-27. - Location of travel trailer; outside of mobile home park prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any travel trailer upon any street, alley or highway or other public place, or upon any private premises, whether occupied or unoccupied, within the city, outside of a licensed mobile home park, except as provided in this chapter. 
3-16-28. - Emergency or temporary parking. 
    Emergency or temporary stopping or parking of a travel trailer is permitted on any street, alley or highway for not longer than two (2) hours subject to any other and further prohibitions, regulations or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking regulations or ordinances. 
3-16-29. - Permitted parking; restrictions. 
    Travel trailers may be parked upon private lots or tracts of land subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  No travel trailer shall be parked on any private lot or tract of land for a period exceeding thirty (30) days. 
(b)  Such travel trailer shall be used for sleeping purposes only. 
(c)  No cooking of any kind shall be permitted in such travel trailer at any time. 
(d)  Electrical outlets for such travel trailer may be provided, but the installation shall be in compliance with city electrical regulations. No connected electrical extension cords shall lie on the ground or be suspended less than seven (7) feet from the ground. Electrical cords buried in the ground are permissible. 
3-16-30. - Location upon owner's premises; restrictions. 
    Travel trailer owners may store their own travel trailers upon their own premises, subject to the limitations imposed in the preceding section 3-16-29; provided, however, that thirty (30) day maximum shall not apply thereto. 
DIVISION III. - ENFORCEMENT 

3-16-31. - Inspection and reporting. 
(a)  The city fire prevention bureau and the city inspections department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto affecting fire hazards, sanitation, health, water supply sewage, garbage and waste disposal. Said agencies shall inspect, at least four (4) times each year, each mobile home park and all the accommodations and facilities therewith. Said agencies are hereby granted the power and authority to enter upon the premises of such mobile home parks at any time for the purposes herein set forth. 
(b)  The owner of each mobile home park shall fill out or cause to be filled out, on the first day of each month a Mobile Home Park Inspection Report, a copy of which is made a part hereof by reference, and shall file said report or cause said report to be filed in a readily available and designated location in each park. 
(c)  Said reports shall be retained for at least one year, except that they shall be surrendered upon demand to the inspecting agencies designated in subsection (a), in which case copies need not be retained. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to falsify to cause to be falsified, any of the reports required by this chapter. 
(1970 Code) 
3-16-32. - Restrictions as to location of mobile homes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain a mobile home in the city outside of a mobile home park which is duly licensed hereunder, except as herein specifically permitted. 
(b)  A mobile home placed upon a mobile home site in accordance with this chapter shall be connected to the city sanitary sewer whenever the same is available or, when said sewer is not accessible, then the same shall be connected with the proper septic tank or cesspool; and said mobile homes shall be connected with electricity and shall have a fuse box concealed from the weather. 
(c)  A vehicle having over nine hundred (900) square feet of floor space shall not be considered a mobile home for the purpose of this chapter, but must comply with the building, electrical, plumbing and housing ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 2535, 10-15-91) 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Title 4. 
3-16-33. - Restrictions as to location of mobile commercial facilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain a mobile commercial facility in the city except as herein specifically permitted. 
(b)  Mobile commercial facilities may be used as a temporary office or storage area of a construction company actually engaged in construction work within the city but only under the following circumstances: 
(1)  A building permit has been issued by the city to the-construction company which is utilizing the mobile commercial facility. 
(2)  The mobile commercial facility is located on the site where the company is engaged in construction. 
(3)  The city council has by resolution authorized the placement of the commercial mobile facility on the site. 
(c)  Mobile commercial facilities may be used as a temporary office, retail facility or other non residential use allowed under Title 5, Chapters 9 and 10 of the East Peoria City Code but only under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where permanent facilities previously occupied by the occupants of the commercial mobile facility have been damaged by fire, storm or other casualty or where new construction of permanent facilities is underway; and 
(2)  A building permit has been issued by the city for repair or construction of the improvements on the site; and 
(3)  The mobile commercial facility shall be located on the site of construction, which site shall be located within a B-1, B-2, B-3, M-1, M-2 or M-3 zoning classification. 
(4)  The city council has by resolution authorized the placement of the commercial mobile facility on the site. 
(d)  Any permit issued by the city council pursuant to this section may not be issued for a period of longer than six (6) months. Such a permit may be extended by resolution of the city council of additional periods of time not to exceed six (6) months. The previous issuance of such a permit shall not give rise to a presumption in favor of the renewal of the permit. Application for permits shall be submitted to the department of public affairs. 
(e)  Any mobile commercial facility located pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be removed from the site within ten (10) days after the city's building inspector determines that construction at the site has been substantially completed or determines that construction at the site has ceased for a period of time in excess of fifteen (15) days. 
(Ord. 2535, 10-15-91) 
3-16-34. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates or refuses to comply with any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense; and each and every day during or on which said violation continues after such conviction shall be deemed to be a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2535, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 3292, § 19, 7-3-01) 
CHAPTER 17. - CAMPGROUNDS[4] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Trailers in motor courts, § 3-15-19. 

3-17-1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Campgrounds means any camping or meeting ground, area or other like place kept, used or maintained, or advertised or held out to the public to be, for the accommodation or convenience of tourists, transients, campers or travelers, space therein being for hire or rent, whether with or without means, for five (5) or more persons, for a period of one day or more; provided, however, that this definition shall not be construed to include regularly licensed hotels, motor courts, rooming houses and mobile home parks. 
3-17-2. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, conduct, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, conducted, operated or maintained, upon any property owned or controlled by him a campground within the city without having first obtained a license therefor from the city clerk or without complying with all provisions of this chapter. 
3-17-3. - Fee; duration. 
    The annual fee for the license required by the preceding section shall be five dollars ($5.00) for every place or premises to be operated as a campground. 
    The license year shall be the same as that provided in this Code for licenses in general. 
3-17-4. - Application. 
    Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain a campground shall file a written application with the city clerk and shall state therein the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the owner, name and address of the manager or managers thereof, location of the campground, and the maximum number of persons, tents and vehicles to be accommodated. 
    This application shall be accompanied by the plans of the toilet, bath and wash basin facilities; slop sinks, water faucets, sewer connections, garbage and vehicle parking areas, and other improvements. 
3-17-5. - Not transferable. 
    No license issued hereunder shall be transferable or assignable with respect to any person other than the named licensee, or with respect to any premises other than that named in the license without the express consent of the city council. 
3-17-6. - Sanitary facilities. 
    Every campground licensed under the provisions of this chapter, and the surrounding premises, shall at all times be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition; and suitable and adequate toilet facilities for the use of all tourists, transients, campers, guests and other persons staying at said campground shall be provided. 
    All such sanitary facilities shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewer system of the city if the premises are located on a street served by such a sewer. 
3-17-7. - Regulations, generally. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of state law or provisions of this Code upon or within any campground. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any campground or any portion thereof for immoral purposes. 
3-17-8. - Cleanliness. 
    The premises of any campground must be kept clean and sanitary at all times; and all waste material must be removed therefrom at least once every twenty four (24) hours. The owner or operator of such campground shall provide proper waste receptacles and shall make necessary arrangements with the city for disposal of same. 
3-17-9. - Manager or agent required. 
    Every campground shall have a manager or agent residing on the premises; and there shall at all times be such a person or persons in charge of such campground who shall be responsible for its proper maintenance and operation. 
3-17-10. - Register required. 
    The operator of such campground shall keep a register which shall contain the names and addresses of all persons or guests accommodated or resting therein, and the hour and date of arrival and departure of such persons or guests, and the state automobile license number and license year of any vehicle or vehicles of such persons or guests. Said register shall be available for examination at all times by members of the city council, officers of the city police department, or of state or Federal law enforcement or investigative agencies. 
3-17-11. - Registering under false name prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to register as a guest in any campground within the city under an assumed, fictitious or false name. 
3-17-12. - Falsely registering as owner of car prohibited. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department of the city from time to time to check the register provided for in this chapter, If after such investigation, it is determined that the owner of any car is different than the person who signed the register as the owner, then such person signing the register shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
3-17-13. - Certain guests prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any campground hereunder to permit any known fugitive to stop or remain at any such campground without notice to the police department. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any campground hereunder to permit any known vagrant, tramp or other undesirable or disreputable person to stop or remain at any such campground. 
3-17-14. - Camping upon streets, etc. prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp at any time upon any street, highway, sidewalk or any other public place within the city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any transient, traveler, camper, tourist or any other such person to camp at any place within the city, except at a duly licensed campground or mobile home park. 
3-17-15. - Inspections. 
    The director of city inspections and the chiefs of the fire and police departments are hereby vested with full power and authority to inspect and supervise all places within the city now used and hereafter to be used for campground purposes; and it shall be the duty of such officers to cause such inspections of not less frequency than once in every three (3) months. 
    Such officers and all duly authorized inspectors and agents thereunder shall be permitted access to any campground or any part thereof at all times for the purpose of seeing that such campground is being kept and maintained in a clean, sanitary and safe manner, and for the purpose of determining whether or not all provisions of this Code are being complied with. 
3-17-16. - License revocation. 
    Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked at any time by the mayor or the city council if he shall be satisfied that the person holding such license has violated or permitted the violation of any provision of this Code. 
3-17-17. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense; and each and every day any person operates or conducts a campground without a license, or that any transient, tourist, camper or traveler shall camp at any place within the city other than a duly licensed campground or mobile home park, shall be considered a distinct and separate offense. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3292, § 20, 7-3-01) 
CHAPTER 18. - ROOMING HOUSES 
SECTION: 

3-18-1. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this chapter: 
    Rooming house means every dwelling, furnished room, house, tourist home, lodging house, boarding house and any other similarly occupied building, structure or portion thereof kept, held or used where sleeping or lodging is provided, or which is equipped to provide lodging, by pre-arrangement for a definite period, for compensation, for three (3) or more persons, in contradistinction to hotels and motor courts open to transients. 
3-18-2. - License required; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, keep, manage or operate, or permit to be conducted, kept, managed or operated, upon any property owned or controlled by him a rooming house within the city without having first obtained a license therefor from the city clerk or without complying with all provisions of this Code. 
    The annual fee for such license shall be five dollars ($5.00) and the license year shall be the same as that provided for business licenses in the city in general. 
3-18-3. - Transferability. 
    Licenses to operate or maintain a rooming house shall be issued only to persons of good moral character and shall not be transferable with respect to any person other than the named licensee. 
3-18-4. - Application. 
    A written application shall be filed with the city clerk before such license shall be issued and shall accurately state the full name and address of the applicant, the full name and address of the owner of the building and premises where such rooms in the building which are to be occupied as sleeping rooms, and the number of persons proposed to be accommodated or allowed in each room. Such application shall be verified and sworn to by the applicant before a notary public. 
3-18-5. - Approval. 
    Upon receipt of such application it shall be the duty of the city clerk to submit copies thereof to the director of city inspections and chiefs of the city fire and police departments, who shall each authorize the proper inspection or investigation; and no license shall be issued by the clerk until and unless he shall receive the written approval of each official. 
3-18-6. - Compliance with building regulations. 
    No house or building hereafter constructed or erected within the city shall be used as a rooming house, and no house or building heretofore erected and not now used for such purposes, or any building, house or portion thereof, which is now used or intended to be used or occupied for rooming house purposes shall be converted into, used as or leased as a rooming house, unless such building and every part thereof shall conform to the requirements of this chapter and to such other requirements of the building, plumbing, electrical, health and zoning provisions of this Code. 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Title 4; minimum housing regulations, Title 4, ch. 8; zoning regulations, Title 5. 
3-18-7. - Exits; stairways. 
(a)  No premises within the city shall be used as a rooming house unless there are at least two (2) exits to the outdoors from such premises. It shall be unlawful to block or permit the blocking of any exit from any premises used as a rooming house. 
(b)  Every rooming house, housing persons on the third floor, shall be provided with at least two (2) stairways leading from the ground to each floor providing habitable rooms; provided, further, every rooming house where less than three (3) stories are occupied shall be provided with two (2) stairways in all cases when occupied by more than five (5) persons on the second floor (including members of the family of the owner or operator), or in all cases where the total number of persons housed in the building exceeds eight (8) (including members of the family of the owner or operator). 
3-18-8. - Sanitary facilities. 
    Every rooming house shall be provided with a water closet, lavatory and bathing facilities on each floor on which habitable rooms are located, and such facilities shall be accessible for all persons on that floor without passage through another sleeping room; provided further, that water closets shall be provided in a ration of at least one water closet to every eight (8) occupants, or fraction thereof. 
3-18-9. - Sleeping room; minimum space required. 
    No chamber in any such rooming house shall be occupied as a sleeping room unless there is at least eighty (80) square feet of floor space per single occupant and not less than seven (7) feet in height from the floor to the ceiling; provided, however, in no case shall there be less than fifty (50) square feet of floor space per occupant. 
3-18-10. - Ventilation; sanitary requirements. 
(a)  Each sleeping room in any rooming house shall be adequately ventilated and shall have adequate window space opening onto street, yard or court. 
(b)  The bedding used therein shall be clean. 
(c)  Every room shall be free from filth and vermin. 
(d)  The walls, floors and ceilings in each sleeping room and the hallways, stairways and toilet rooms or other parts thereof shall be cleaned and properly repaired as frequently as may be required by the health inspector. 
3-18-11. - Heating. 
    All such premises shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1 to a temperature of not less than sixty eight degrees (680) Fahrenheit between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) a.m. and ten o'clock (10:00) p.m., and to a temperature of not less than sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit at all other times. 
3-18-12. - Light housekeeping prohibited. 
    No person shall keep, conduct, operate or maintain such rooming house shall permit in any living or sleeping room the cooking or preparation of food or meals or the storage of foodstuffs; and light housekeeping, so called, shall not be permitted in any living or sleeping room. 
3-18-13. - Register required. 
    The operator of any rooming house shall keep a register which shall contain the names and former addresses of all persons occupying any sleeping room therein, and the hour and date of arrival and departure of such occupants, and the state automobile license number and the license year of any vehicle kept by such occupant on or about the premises of the rooming house. 
    Said register shall be available for examination at all times by members of the city council, officers of the city police department or of state or Federal law enforcement or investigative agencies. 
3-18-14. - Fugitives prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any rooming house in the city to knowingly permit any fugitive from justice to reside therein without notice to the police department. 
3-18-15. - Inspection. 
    The director of city inspections and the chiefs of the fire and police departments are hereby vested with full power and authority to inspect and supervise all places within the city now used or hereafter to be used for rooming house purposes; and it shall be the duty of such officials to cause such inspection of not less frequency of once in every three (3) months. Such officials and all duly authorized inspectors or agents thereunder shall be permitted access to the rooming house and all parts thereof at all times for the purpose of seeing that said rooming house is kept and maintained in a clean, sanitary and safe manner, and for the purpose of determining whether or not all provisions of this Code are being complied with. 
3-18-16. - Nuisance; when; abatement. 
    The maintenance or use of any rooming house hereunder in violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be and shall constitute a nuisance and may be abated accordingly by the director of city inspections or the fire chief as provided in this Code, with written consent of the city council. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 19. - TAXICABS AND PUBLIC CARTS 
SECTION: 
DIVISION I. - DEFINITIONS 

3-19-1. - Taxicab. 
    The term "taxicab" as used in this chapter shall mean any motor vehicles, used or kept for use of transportation of passengers or their baggage, for hire indiscriminately accept or such persons that may offer themselves for transportation. 
(1)  Provided, however, that this term shall not include motor vehicles rented by special contract to be operated by the customer, or any vehicle operating under authority by special ordinance or franchise or, licensed under an ordinance licensing motor vehicles for the transportation of passengers or freight over a specific route, or railroad cars and motorbuses operating under the authority and jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission. 
(2)  Vehicles operated from points outside the city limits entering such limits for the purpose of discharging a passenger or picking up a passenger and transporting beyond such limits shall be held to be a taxicab hereunder except as expressly excluded by subsection (1) of this section. 
(3)  A certificate of compliance as required by section 3-19-5 of this chapter, is not required by motor vehicles defined in subsection (1) of this section. 
3-19-2. - Taximeter. 
    The term taximeter shall mean and include any meter instrument or device which is designed to measure distance driven and the waiting time and which indicates in dollars and cents the fare to be charged. 
3-19-3. - Waiting time. 
    The term waiting time shall be defined as the time consumed while standing at the direction of a passenger. 
3-19-4. - Person. 
    The term person includes an individual, corporation, partnership, unincorporated association, joint venture or other legal entity. 
DIVISION II. - CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE 

3-19-5. - Required. 
(a)  [Certificate required.] No person shall operate or cause to be operated, a taxicab that has been hired or is for hire in the city without a certificate of compliance as hereinafter described and carried in the taxicab at all times while the same is for hire. 
(b)  Application; contents. No person, whether acting as owner, principal, agent, employees, lessee or licensee, shall operate a taxicab or motor vehicle as defined in section 3-19-1 of this Code, for the carriage of persons, for hire in the city, without first making application, in writing, for a license so to do to the city clerk. Applications for licenses for taxicabs shall be made by the owner upon blank forms provided for by the chief of police, and such applications shall contain the full name and address of the owner, the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the number of persons it is capable of carrying, a description thereof, including the motor power, model, motor and chassis number, the state license number, the principal place of business and office address of and the names of the officers of the person, firm or corporation owing and operating the same, and, if a partnership, the names and addresses of each partner, and such other information as the chief of police may require. 
(Ord. No. 4276 , § 9, 4-19-16) 
3-19-6. - Issuance. 
(a)  A certificate of compliance shall be issued by the city to any taxicab passing an inspection by an authorized employee company approved by the Chief of Police of East Peoria. Such compliance shall take place at such place or places as may be designated by said department. The certificate of compliance shall be issued upon a determination by the chief of police that the taxicab and the taximeter therein, meet all the requirements of this chapter, and said certificate shall be valid until January of the next year following the date of issuance. At the end of that period and annually thereafter on or prior to January 1, a new certificate can be issued upon satisfactory reinspection. 
(b)  No taxicab license issued under this division may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred, without the consent of the city. 
3-19-7. - Fee. 
    A licensing fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per taxi vehicle is required annually with a maximum amount of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per taxi company if the company is based in the City of East Peoria, and if not based in the City of East Peoria, then a maximum amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per company is required for issuance of a certificate under this chapter. 
(Ord. 1515, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 3824, § 1, 9-29-09) 
3-19-8. - Insurance policy required. 
(a)  Before any certificate of compliance for a taxicab shall be issued, the owner shall file with the chief of police a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, providing insurance coverage for each and every taxicab owned, operated or leased by the applicant with a minimum liability providing against public liability in the amount of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for the injury or death of any person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury or death per accident, and a minimum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage, growing out of any accident regardless of whether such taxicab was being driven by the owner, his agent, employee, licensee or lessee. Such policy shall further provide that insolvency or bankruptcy of the insured shall not release the insurance company from any payment due under such policy, and if by reason of such insolvency or bankruptcy, an execution or a judgment against the insured is returned unsatisfied, the judgment creditor shall have a right of action against the insurance company to recover the amount of such judgment to the same extent that the insured could have had to recover against the company had the insured paid the judgment such policy shall further provide that it cannot be cancelled until thirty (30) days' notice of such cancellation shall have been given to the chief of police. 
(b)  Unless the owner of any taxicab shall provide another policy of insurance complying with this section within thirty (30) days after receipt by the chief of police of notice of cancellation, the certificate of compliance shall automatically become null and void. 
(Ord. 1869, 7-13-82; Ord. No. 3824, § 2, 9-29-09; Ord. No. 4156, § 1, 1-21-14) 
3-19-9. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby given authority to suspend or revoke the certificate of compliance issued under this chapter for a driver's failure or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, or other ordinances of the city, or laws of the state. However, a certificate of compliance may not be revoked or suspended without notice to the owner and an opportunity to present evidence on his behalf. 
(b)  Operation of taxicabs while license suspended or revoked. No person or entity owning or operating taxicabs not licensed and equipped in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, or a taxicab, the license of which has been revoked, or whose license is at the time suspended, shall operate a taxicab within the city during any such period of revocation or suspension. 
(c)  Any aggrieved person or entity may appeal any decision of the chief of police made pursuant to the provisions under this chapter. An appeal may be taken to the chief of police within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed from, by filing with the chief of police and the city clerk a notice of appeal specifying the grounds on which the appeal is based. The city council shall hold a hearing on the appeal within thirty (30) days of its filing. At the hearing the person or entity appealing the decision, may present witnesses and relevant proof in support of its position. Every decision of the city council pursuant to this section shall be entered and filed in the records of the office of the city clerk. If a decision of the city council reverses or modifies the decision of the chief of police, the chief shall take immediate action in accordance with the council's decision. 
3-19-10. - Financial responsibility; failure to discharge. 
    Any certificate of compliance issued hereunder may be cancelled by the chief of police at any time when for a period of forty (40) days there has not been full satisfaction of a final judgment of any court against any persons for damages sustained by third parties and arising out of the operation of the taxicab; provided, however, that such person against whom judgment is taken is the owner or his agent, employee, licensee or lessee. 
DIVISION III. - VEHICLES 

3-19-11. - Inspection by the police department. 
    In addition to any other inspections that may be required it shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect taxicabs so often as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, and such inspections may be conducted by the police department at reasonable times and places and without notice when, in the opinion of the police department, public safety would be benefited by such an inspection. 
3-19-12. - Standards. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate or cause to be operated, a taxicab for hire in this city unless such taxicab: 
(1)  Bears a duly issued state license; 
(2)  Is in safe operating condition; 
(3)  Is equipped with properly operating brakes, lights, tires, rear vision mirror, horn, muffler, turn signals, and windshield wipers in good condition; 
(4)  Has a clean interior of good appearance; 
(5)  Has no protruding parts which could create a hazard to any person, vehicle or thing; 
(6)  Is in compliance with all laws and regulations of the state pertaining to such vehicles and with all provisions of this chapter; 
(7)  Every taxicab licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall have plainly the name of the owner or the operating company and the number of the cab painted or affixed in the center of the main panel of each door of each taxicab. 
DIVISION IV. - TAXIMETER 

3-19-13. - Required. 
    No taxicab shall be operated for hire unless the same is equipped with a taximeter in compliance with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, mutilate or break any taximeter, or the seal thereof, or to transfer a taximeter from one taxicab to another for use in the transportation of passengers for hire, before delivery of the taxicab with a transferred taximeter for inspection, testing and certification by the chief of police as provided in section 3-19-6 of this Code. 
(2)  Immediately on arrival at the passenger's destination, it shall be the duty of the driver of a taxicab to throw the taximeter lever to the "off" position and to call the passenger's attention to the fare registered. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver to operate his taxicab with a passenger aboard with his taximeter not in operation, so that it will not accurately register distance travelled and amount of fare earned and to be charged. Any taxicab driver who violates this provision, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 3-19-35 of this Code, and in addition thereto have his license revoked. 
3-19-14. - Flag. 
    Each taximeter shall be equipped with a flag which is plainly visible from the street and which shall be kept up when the taxicab is for hire and down when the taxicab is engaged or otherwise not for hire. 
3-19-15. - Seal. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a taxicab for hire within the city unless the taximeter is sealed. 
3-19-16. - Visibility. 
    The figures indicating distance driven, waiting time and the fare to be charged, shall be in plain view of the passenger while riding, and shall be lighted between sundown and sunrise to enable the passenger to read the same. 
3-19-17. - Complaint. 
    Upon complains by any person that a taximeter is out of working order or does not accurately register the lawful rates of charge, it shall again be inspected and tested as herein before provided; and if found to be in improper working condition or inaccurate, it shall be unlawful to operate the taxicab to which it is attached until such taxicab is equipped with a taximeter which had been inspected by an authorized company approved by the chief of police and found to be in proper working condition and accurate and a new certificate of compliance for the taxicab is issued. 
(Ord. 1515, 12-16-78) 
DIVISION V. - RATES 

3-19-18. - Charges. 
    The charges for taxicab service shall not exceed the rates as set forth below in this division. 
3-19-19. - Rates for mileage and waiting time. 
    For the first one-tenth of a mile, or fraction thereof the rate shall not exceed two dollars and eighty cents ($2.80); for each additional one-seventh of a mile, or fraction thereof an additional forty cents ($0.40) may be charged. Waiting time shall be charged at a rate not to exceed twenty-five cents ($0.25) for each one-half minute of waiting time or fraction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 3, 9-29-09) 
3-19-20. - Premium for extra territorial service. 
    A premium of one dollar ($1.00) over and above the total charge shown on the taxi meter may be charged for any trip originating within the corporate limits of the city and terminating outside the corporate limits of the city, or for any trip which begins outside the corporate limits of the city and terminates within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 1869, 7-13-82) 
3-19-21. - Daily rate. 
    The rate for the use of a taxicab for the day may be in any amount agreed to beforehand by the parties. 
3-19-22. - Hand baggage. 
    There shall be no extra charge for hand baggage which usually is carried in the passenger compartment of the taxicab. 
3-19-23. - Trunks. 
    A charge of fifty cents ($0.50) per trunk may be made. 
3-19-24. - Additional passengers. 
(a)  Generally. No additional passengers shall be admitted to a taxicab without the consent of the passenger who first engages the taxicab. 
(b)  Charges. No extra charge shall be made for additional passengers except for only that distance traveled beyond the previous passenger's destination, except that each passenger in addition to two (2) may be charged twenty cents ($0.20), and except that children under the age of twelve (12) and accompanied by an adult, shall not be considered as additional passengers. An additional charge of one dollar ($1.00) may be made for motor-driven wheelchairs. 
(c)  Overcharge. No person shall charge or attempt to charge any passenger a fare greater than that which is allowed under the provisions of this chapter. 
3-19-25. - Rate card required. 
    Every taxicab operated under this chapter shall have a rate card setting forth the rates of fare and displayed in such a place as to be within the plain view of all passengers. 
3-19-26. - Refusal of passenger to pay legal fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any of the vehicles mentioned in this chapter after having hired the same, and it shall be unlawful for any person to hire any vehicle with the intent to defraud the person from whom it is hired of the value of such services. 
DIVISION VI. - DRIVERS 

3-19-27. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate for hire a taxicab in this city unless such person is properly licensed to drive as may be required by the state and has such a license in his possession. 
3-19-28. - Payment in advance; refusal to carry orderly passengers. 
    Every driver of a taxicab shall have the right to demand payment of the fare in advance and may refuse to carry a passenger or passengers unless so prepaid; provided, however, that no driver shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person or persons, upon request, unless previously engaged, unable, or forbidden by the provisions of this chapter to do so. 
3-19-29. - Receipts. 
    The driver of any taxicab shall upon request by any passenger render to such passenger a receipt in writing showing the amount charged, the amount of the meter reading, the name of the taxicab owner, and the date of the transaction. 
3-19-30. - Cruising and soliciting generally. 
    No taxicab driver shall park his vehicle upon any public street or repeatedly or persistently drive his vehicle up and down the streets of the city in a manner that interferes with the flow of traffic or with the proper access to or egress from any theater, hall, public building, railway station, bus depot or other place of public gathering; nor shall any one solicit passengers for a taxicab except the driver thereof when sitting in the driver's seat of the taxicab or when standing on the curb adjacent to a properly parked taxicab. 
3-19-31. - Solicitation of other common carrier passengers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver, owner or other person to solicit passengers at the terminal of any other common carrier, nor at any intermediate points along any established route of any other common carrier. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a taxicab driver to solicit patronage in a loud, boisterous or annoying tone of voice. 
3-19-32. - Soliciting; misrepresentation. 
    No person shall induce or attempt to induce any other person by way of any false statement or representation to employ any taxicab. 
3-19-33. - Prohibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver while on duty: 
(1)  To drink any alcoholic beverages; 
(2)  To solicit any business for any hotel, motel or restaurants; 
(3)  To allow any passenger to ride anywhere in, on, or about the taxicab other than in the passenger area with all doors fully closed; 
(4)  To solicit any business for any house of ill repute; 
(5)  To disobey any traffic rule or rules established by state statute or by this Code; 
(6)  To knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in the perpetration of crime or misdemeanor; 
(7)  To have in his possession or in or about the passenger compartment of the taxicab any firearm, blackjack or other dangerous weapon; or 
(8)  To use any profane or obscene language or disturb the peace in any way. 
3-19-34. - Direct route. 
    The driver of a taxicab shall take his passenger to his destination by the most direct, available route from the place where the passenger enters the taxicab unless otherwise directed by such passenger. 
DIVISION VII. - PENALTY 

3-19-35. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day a violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 4, 9-29-09) 
DIVISION VIII. - SEVERABILITY 

3-19-36. - Severability. 
    Each day of the provisions of this chapter are severable, and if any provisions shall be declared to be invalid, the remaining provisions shall not be affected but shall remain in full force and effect. 
DIVISION IX. - REPEALING PROVISION 

3-19-37. - Repealing provisions. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. 1515, 12-26-78) 
CHAPTER 20. - MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION[5] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- East Peoria municipal ambulance service, § 1-5-3. 

3-20-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Ambulance. Any motor vehicle that is specifically designed, equipped and intended for use as provided for in this chapter as a Class II licensed vehicle, in providing medical, emergency transportation for patients. 
    Attendant-driver. An individual trained or qualified pursuant to this chapter, responsible for the operation and driving of a vehicle and the care of the passengers or patients. 
    Emergency medical services officer (EMS officer). The Fire Chief of the City of East Peoria, including proper employees and inspectors acting under the authority of the fire chief. 
    Medicar. Any motor vehicle that is specifically designed, equipped and intended for use as provided for in this chapter as a class III licensed vehicle in providing medical, nonemergency transportation for nonambulatory passengers. 
    Mobile intensive care personnel (MICP). An individual certified by the Illinois Department of Public Health as an advanced emergency medical technician (mobile intensive care personnel) pursuant to the provisions of Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 1111/2, section 86.3. 
    Mobile intensive care unit vehicle (MICU). A motor vehicle that is specifically designed and equipped in compliance with Federal, state and local standards for providing pre-hospital, emergency medical service and transportation as may be from time to time adopted by the city council pursuant to this chapter. It is intended for use as provided in this chapter as a Class I license vehicle. 
    Passenger. A nonambulatory, invalid, or convalescent person utilizing the services of a medicare, class III license, as provided under this chapter. 
    Patient. An individual who is sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless to an extent that he requires emergency medical transportation. 
    Project medical director. The physician appointed by the State of Illinois who has the authority and responsibility for the total management of the Advanced Life Support/Mobile Intensive Care System for the region including the City of East Peoria. 
3-20-2. - Purpose and class of license. 
    This chapter is intended to regulate and license any and all types of the service of supplying medical transportation, emergency and nonemergency, for the health, safety, welfare, convenience and necessity of the public in the city. 
    Licenses to supply medical transportation are divided into three (3) classes: 
(a)  Class I. Mobile intensive care unit. This license shall authorize the emergency medical transportation of patients on a call response basis. Each licensee hereunder must have at least one such MICU fully manned, on duty, and in operation twenty four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. The decision to respond to an emergency call with a class I or class II vehicle shall be made by the licensee based on the information received concerning the nature of the emergency and on the availability of vehicles. 
(b)  Class II. Ambulance. This license shall authorize the emergency medical transportation of patients on a call response basis. Each licensee hereunder must have such service reasonably available and in operation twenty four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
(c)  Class III. Medicar. This license shall authorize the transportation of nonemergency, nonambulatory, invalid and convalescent passengers from their places of residence or other points, to and from hospitals, doctors' offices and other locales for medical care. The provisions of this license apply only to, and permit only, the transportation of medically stable persons who are handicapped, wheelchair confined or otherwise unable to utilize normal transportation and yet do not require ambulance or other emergency service. Class III license shall be on a nonemergency basis, by arranging for the transportation directly with the licensee, and shall not be in response to emergency requests. The availability for any vehicle shall be not less than forty (40) hours per week. 
3-20-3. - Operator's license; required; fee. 
(a)  No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall furnish, operate, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in or profess to be engaged in the commercial or noncommercial business or service of the medical transportation of passengers or patients in the city unless he holds a current valid license for such a vehicle, issued by the city clerk, pursuant to this chapter. 
    No class I or class II license shall be issued under this chapter for so long as the city operates its ambulance service under authority of this Code. The city shall not be required to apply for a license under this chapter in order to operate its ambulance service within the city. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be operated, and no individual shall drive, attend or permit it to be operated on the streets, alleys, or any public way or place of the city unless it shall be under the immediate supervision of a person who is holding a currently valid or probationary license as an attendant-driver as provided in this chapter, except that a probationary license holder may not operate a class licensed vehicle, and may operate a class II licensed vehicle only under the direct supervision of a licensed attendant-driver. 
(c)  Provided, however, that no such licenses shall be required for a vehicle, or for the attendant-driver of a vehicle, which: 
(1)  Is rendering assistance to licensed ambulances, or MICU vehicles in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency in which the licensed ambulances and MICU vehicles of the city are insufficient or unable to cope; or 
(2)  Is summoned from outside the city by the East Peoria Police or Fire Department upon the determination that no city-licensed vehicle is able to respond to an emergency. 
(d)  An annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged for the operation of each commercial vehicle licensed hereunder, which fees along with attendant-driver's fees shall be retained by the city clerk to be used for the administration of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1821, 1-19-82; Ord. 1928, 4-5-83; Ord. No. 3169, § 1, 8-17-99) 
3-20-4. - Operator's license; application. 
    Applications for vehicle licenses hereunder shall be made upon such forms and may be prepared or prescribed by the city clerk and shall contain: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant and the owner of the vehicle. 
(b)  The trade or other fictitious name, if any, under which the applicant does business and proposes to do business. 
(c)  The training and experience of the applicant in the transportation and care of patients or passengers. 
(d)  A description of each vehicle, including the make, model, year of manufacture, motor and chassis number; current state license number; the length of time the vehicle has been in use; and the color scheme, insignia, name, monogram, or other distinguishing characteristics to be used to designate applicant's vehicle. 
(e)  The location and descriptions of the place or places from which it is intended to operate. 
(f)  Such other information as the city clerk and EMS officer shall deem reasonably necessary to a fair determination of compliance with this chapter. 
(g)  An accompanying license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per vehicle. 
(h)  A financial statement and balance sheet containing sufficient information to determine the financial responsibility of the applicant. 
(i)  At any time a change in the officers of the corporation which is a licensee hereunder shall be made, such change of officers shall be reported to the city clerk within five (5) days after such change. 
3-20-5. - Operator's license; prerequisites to issuance. 
(a)  The city council shall direct the city clerk to issue a license hereunder for a specified vehicle, to be valid for a period of one year unless earlier suspended, revoked or terminated, when they find that: 
(1)  Each such vehicle, its required equipment and the premises designated in the application, comply with the standards prescribed in this chapter and with the regulations promulgated hereunder, as determined by inspection by the EMS officer. 
(2)  The applicant is a responsible and proper person to conduct or work in the proposed business. 
(3)  Only duly licensed attendant-drivers or probationary attendant-drivers are employed in such capacities. 
(4)  All the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable laws and ordinances have been met. 
(5)  The public convenience and necessity require such additional services. 
(b)  prior to the issuance of any vehicle license hereunder, the applicant for such license must present to the city clerk evidence that the said vehicle has passed a safety inspection for second division vehicles as set forth in the Illinois Vehicle Code, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 951/2, section 13-101 and following. This requirement must be met notwithstanding any definitions or exemptions from such safety tests provided in the applicable statutes. The method of ascertaining such compliance shall be left to rules promulgated by the EMS officer. Such safety inspections shall be made not less than once a year. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of any vehicle license hereunder, the applicant must equip the vehicle with such radio equipment as will permit two-way communications with the dispatch center for the city police and fire departments. 
3-20-6. - Determination of public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a license hereunder for a specified class I, class II or class III vehicle by a person not now licensed and engaged in the operation of such a vehicle, or by a person now licensed and engaged in the operation of such vehicles for additional licenses, the city council shall establish a date in the future for the purpose of determining the question of whether the license(s) applied for should be issued. Notice of the filing of the application and the date and time the matter is scheduled for action by the city council shall be sent to all others holding licenses issued by the city. Said notice shall state that the application for a medical transportation license has been made, the name of the applicant, the class of license applied for, and that a decision on the application will be made on the application designating the place, date and hour. 
(b)  On the date set for the city council action as provided for in subsection (a) above, the holders of existing medical transportation licenses or any other person affected by the issuance of additional medical transportation licenses may protest either orally or in writing the issuance of such additional licenses. 
    Any person or licensee desiring to so protest may protest on or prior to the date for action on the application by the city council and shall be entitled to offer proof upon the question of public necessity and convenience for additional medical transportation licenses. 
(c)  The city council shall not direct the city clerk to issue a class I, class II or class III license unless they shall find that there is need for such service within the city which cannot be met by the current license holders and which the applicant can meet. 
(d)  The holder of at least one of the class I or class II licenses shall maintain a base of operation at a central location within the city limits. 
(e)  Renewal of any license hereunder, upon expiration or after revocation for any reason, shall require conformance with all requirements of this chapter relating to original licensing. 
3-20-7. - Display of license. 
    Once a license for a vehicle has been issued, the licensee shall cause said license to be kept in plain view in a conspicuous place within the vehicle. 
3-20-8. - Attendant-driver license; required; fee; transferability. 
    No person shall drive or serve as an attendant-driver of a vehicle licensed hereunder without first procuring a license for the class of vehicle driven or served as provided below. The annual charge for such licenses shall be five dollars ($5.00). Such licenses shall not be assignable or transferable. 
3-20-9. - Attendant-driver license; standards for issuance. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license to an attendant-driver hereunder, valid for a period of one year, unless earlier suspended, revoked or terminated, when he finds that: 
(a)  The applicant is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or narcotics. 
(b)  The applicant is able to speak, read, and write the English language. 
(c)  The applicant has been found by a duly licensed physician, upon examination attested to on a form provided by the EMS officer, to be of sound physique, possessing eyesight corrected to at least 20/40 in the better eye, and free of physical defects or diseases which might impair the ability to drive or attend a vehicle. 
(d)  For a class II license that such applicant has a currently valid certificate evidencing successful completion of a course of training, the minimum requirements of which shall be eighty two (82) hours of instruction and examination for emergency medical technician and certification by the State and National Emergency Medical Technician Registry. After the initial certification, applicants shall complete an emergency medical technician refresher course of not less than twenty (20) hours of instruction at least once every two (2) years, as determined by the EMS officer and Illinois Department of Public Health. 
(e)  For a class III license that such applicant has a currently valid certificate issued by the American Red Cross evidencing successful completion of its advanced life saving course. 
(f)  The applicant for a license as an attendant-driver holds a currently valid class A driver's license from the state. 
(g)  The applicant must be at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(h)  Provided, however, the city clerk may issue a probationary license for a period of six (6) months during which period of time the applicant must successfully complete a training course as set forth above. If the applicant does not successfully complete such course within such period of six (6) months, he shall not be considered to be the holder of a currently valid license upon the expiration of such six-month period. 
(i)  For a class I or class II license, the applicant must have successfully completed a defensive driving course as required by the EMS officer and shall complete a refresher course at intervals specified by the EMS officer. 
3-20-10. - Attendant-driver license; application. 
    Applications for attendant-drivers' licenses hereunder shall be made upon such forms as may be prepared or purchased by the city clerk and shall contain: 
(a)  The applicant's full name, current residence, places of residence for five (5) years previous to moving to his present address, and length of time he has resided in the city. 
(b)  The applicant's age, marital status, color of eyes and hair and height. 
(c)  Whether he has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, and if so, when and where and for what cause. 
(d)  The applicant's training and experience in the transportation and care of patients or passengers and whether he has previously been licensed as a driver, chauffeur, attendant-driver, or similar such occupation, and if so, when and where, and whether his license has ever been revoked or suspended in any jurisdiction and for what cause. 
Applicants for probationary licenses shall complete and furnish a short history form supplied by the city clerk and furnish satisfactory evidence of age. 
(e)  Two (2) recent photographs of the applicant of a size designated by the city clerk, one of which shall be attached by the city clerk to the license. 
(f)  Such other information as the city clerk and EMS officer shall deem reasonably necessary to fair determination of compliance with this chapter. 
(g)  An accompanying license fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
3-20-11. - Mobile intensive care personnel license; required; fee; transferability. 
    No person shall drive or serve as an MICU attendant-driver of a vehicle licensed hereunder without first procuring a license as provided below. The annual charge for such licenses shall be five dollars ($5.00). Such licenses shall not be assignable or transferable. 
3-20-12. - Mobile intensive care personnel license; standards for issuance. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license to an attendant-driver hereunder, valid for a period of one year, unless earlier suspended, revoked or terminated, when he finds that: 
(a)  The applicant is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or narcotics. 
(b)  The applicant is able to speak, read and write the English language. 
(c)  The applicant has been found by a duly licensed physician, upon examination attested to on a form provided by the city clerk, to be of sound physique, possessing eyesight corrected to at least 20/40 in the better eye, and free of physical defects or diseases which might impair the ability to drive or attend a vehicle. 
(d)  Such applicant has a currently valid certificate evidencing successful completion of a course of training and examination for advanced emergency medical technician (mobile intensive care personnel). This certificate must be issued by the Illinois Department of Public Health. After initial application, applicants shall complete continuing education and biennial recertification as determined by the Illinois Department of Public Health. 
(e)  The applicant for a license holds a currently valid class B driver's license from the state. 
(f)  The applicant must have successfully completed a defensive driving course as required by the EMS officer and shall complete a refresher course at intervals specified by the EMS officer. 
3-20-13. - Mobile intensive care personnel license; application. 
    Applications for attendant-driver's licenses hereunder shall be made upon such forms as may be prepared or purchased by the city clerk and shall contain: 
(a)  The applicant's full name, current residence, places of residence for five (5) years previous to moving to his present address, and length of time he has resided in the city. 
(b)  The applicant's age, marital status, color of eyes and hair, and height. 
(c)  Whether he has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, and if so, when and where and for what cause. 
(d)  The applicant's training and experience in the transportation and care of patients or passengers, and whether he has previously been licensed as a driver, chauffeur, or similar such occupation, and if so, when and where, and whether his license has ever been revoked or suspended in any jurisdiction and for what cause. 
Applicants for probationary licenses shall complete and furnish a short history form supplied by the city clerk and furnish satisfactory evidence of age. 
(e)  Two (2) recent photographs of the applicant of a size designated by the city clerk, one of which shall be attached by the city clerk to the license. 
(f)  Such other information as the city clerk and EMS officer shall deem reasonably necessary to a fair determination of compliance with this chapter. 
(g)  An accompanying fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
3-20-14. - Transfer of license to new vehicle. 
    Licenses issued for any vehicle may be transferred to another vehicle belonging to the same licensee upon filing with the city clerk an application therefor, duly verified and showing that the vehicle previously licensed has become obsolete or has been destroyed, sold or traded, and that such vehicle is no longer to be used for the purpose herein contemplated. The vehicle to which the license is transferred shall conform with all the requirements of this chapter as upon original licensing. If satisfied that the transfer is in good faith and not for the purpose of evasion, the city clerk shall require a surrender of the former certificate and issue a new one, charging therefor a transfer fee of one dollar ($1.00). 
3-20-15. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
(a)  Whenever it shall appear to the city clerk or EMS officer that any licensee under the provisions of this chapter has failed to comply and maintain compliance with, or has violated any applicable provisions or requirements of this chapter or of regulations promulgated hereunder, then the city clerk shall cause a written notice to be served upon the licensee in person or by certified mail. Such notice shall inform the licensee that he will be given a hearing before the city council within thirty (30) days thereof, but not earlier than ten (10) days thereof, at such time and place as it may designate, at which the licensee may appear in person or by attorney to participate in a hearing concerning the alleged violation and possible penalties therefor. The city council shall have the power and authority to suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke such license issued under this chapter, upon evidence of a violation presented at a public hearing as set forth in this section. Within three (3) days after such hearing, the city council shall issue a written decision, which shall be promptly transmitted in writing to the licensee to whom it refers. 
(b)  Upon suspension, revocation or termination of a vehicle licensed hereunder, operations as such shall cease with such vehicle, and no person shall permit continued operation of such vehicle. Upon suspension, revocation or termination of an attendant-driver's license hereunder, such attendant or driver shall cease to drive or attend a vehicle and no person shall employ or permit such individual to drive or attend a vehicle. Any violation of this or any other provision of this licensing ordinance shall be punishable upon conviction as provided in accordance with the general penalty provisions of the Code of the city. 
3-20-16. - Standards for licensed vehicles. 
    Each vehicle shall, at all times when in use as such: 
(a)  Conform with the standards, requirements and regulations provided for in this chapter for the transportation of passengers and the nature of the premises from the standpoint of health, sanitation, and safety. 
(b)  Contain equipment conforming with the standards, requirements, and regulations provided for herein; which equipment shall be in proper and good condition before such use. The EMS officer shall have the authority to promulgate, and from time to time revise according to current medical standards, the standards, requirements, and regulations for vehicles licensed under this chapter. The EMS officer shall duly notify in writing any current license holders or applicants for new licenses under this chapter, of any such promulgated or revised equipment requirements, and the effective date thereof. 
(c)  Currently comply with all applicable laws and local ordinances relating to health, sanitation, and safety, including obedience to all traffic regulations as is required of any normal vehicle traveling on the highways, streets, or roadways of the state. However, the driver of an ambulance or MICU vehicle when responding to an emergency call or while transporting a patient, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section but subject to the conditions herein stated; and only when such driver has reasonable grounds to believe that an emergency in fact exists requiring the exercise of such privileges. 
The driver of an ambulance or MICU vehicle may, irrespective of the otherwise applicable provisions of law, ordinance or regulation, proceed past a red or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; disregard laws, ordinances or regulations governing direction or movement or turning in specified directions; provided, however, that no vehicle shall exceed the lawful speed limit unless so directed by a licensed physician. 
Whenever an ambulance or MICU vehicle is operated at a speed in excess of forty (40) miles per hour, the ambulance or MICU vehicle shall be operated in complete conformance with every other motor vehicle law and regulation of the state or of the city, relating to the operation of motor vehicles in general, except laws and regulations pertaining to compliance with official traffic-control devices or to vehicular operation upon the right half of the roadway. 
The exemptions herein granted shall apply only when the driver of such vehicle, while in motion, sounds audible signal by siren as may be reasonably necessary and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying an oscillating, rotating or flashing red beam visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the front of such vehicle. 
The foregoing provisions shall not relieve the driver of any vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(d)  Be marked with any special markings designating it as a medical transfer vehicle as may be prescribed in reasonable regulations promulgated by the EMS officer, but not contrary to state law. 
(e)  Be driven by a licensed attendant-driver pursuant to the requirements of this chapter. Only one such attendant-driver per vehicle for a class III license is required; additional attendant-drivers may be used per class III vehicle according to individual circumstances. Class I and class II vehicles require at least two (2) licensed attendant-drivers. 
A probationary attendant-driver under this chapter must be accompanied at all times by a holder of a currently valid license as an attendant-driver, except that this requirement does not apply for class III licensed vehicles. 
3-20-17. - Insurance policy required.
