(c)  If a timely written notice and petition for hearing is filed, the local tax administrator shall fix the time and place for hearing and shall given written notice to the taxpayer. The taxpayer may request an alternative date convenient to all parties. 
(d)  If a written protest and petition for hearing is not filed within the forty-five-day period, the tax determination, audit or assessment shall become a final bill due and owing without further notice. 
(e)  Upon the showing of reasonable cause by the taxpayer and the full payment of the contested tax liability along with interest accrued as of the due date of the tax, the local tax administrator may reopen or extend the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing. In no event shall the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing be reopened or extended for more than sixty (60) days after the expiration of the original forty-five-day period. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-10. - Hearing. 
(a)  Whenever a taxpayer or a tax collector has filed a timely written protest and petition for hearing under section 3-32-9, above, the local tax administrator shall conduct a hearing regarding any appeal. 
(b)  No continuances shall be granted except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the taxpayer. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. 
(c)  At the hearing the local tax administrator shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the tax determination, audit or assessment. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the local tax administrator shall make a written determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing. The taxpayer or tax collector shall be provided with a copy of the written decision. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-11. - Interest and penalties. 
    In the event a determination has been made that a tax is due and owing, through audit, assessment or other bill sent, the tax must be paid within the time frame otherwise indicated. 
(a)  Interest. The interest to be assessed on a late payment, underpayment, or nonpayment of the tax, shall be twelve (12) percent per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty-five (365) days and the number of days elapsed. 
(b)  Late filing and payment penalties. If a tax return is not filed within the time and manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance, a late filing penalty, of five (5) percent of the amount of tax required to be shown as due on a return shall be imposed; and a late payment penalty of five (5) percent of the tax due shall be imposed. If no return is filed within the time or manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance and prior to the city issuing a notice of tax delinquency or notice of tax liability, then a failure to file penalty shall be assessed equal to twenty-five (25) percent of the total tax due for the applicable reporting period for which the return was required to be filed. A late filing or payment penalty shall not apply if a failure to file penalty is imposed by the controlling ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-12. - Abatement. 
    The local tax administrator shall have the authority to waive or abate any late filing penalty, late payment penalty or failure to file penalty if the local tax administrator shall determine reasonable cause exists for delay or failure to make a filing. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-13. - Installment contracts. 
    The city may enter into an installment contract with the taxpayer for the payment of taxes, interest and/or penalties under the controlling tax ordinance. The local tax administrator may not cancel any installment contract so entered unless the taxpayer fails to pay any amount due and owing. Upon written notice by the local tax administrator that the payment is thirty (30) days delinquent, the taxpayer shall have fourteen (14) working days to cure any delinquency. If the taxpayer fails to cure the delinquency within the fourteen-day period or fails to demonstrate good faith in restructuring the installment contract with the local administrator, the installment contract shall be canceled without further notice to the taxpayer. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-14. - Statute of limitations. 
    The city, through the local tax administrator, shall review all tax returns in a prompt and timely manner and inform taxpayers of any amounts due and owing. The taxpayer shall have forty-five (45) days after receiving notice of the reviewed tax returns to make any request for refund or provide any tax still due and owing. 
(a)  No determination of tax due and owing may be issued more than four (4) years after the end of the calendar year for which the return for the applicable period was filed or for the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was due, whichever occurs later. 
(b)  If any tax return is not filed or if during any four-year period for which a notice of tax determination or assessment may be issued by the city, the tax paid was less than seventy-five (75) percent of the tax due, the statute of limitations shall be six (6) years after the end of the calendar year in which return for the applicable period was due or end of the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was filed. 
(c)  No statute of limitations shall apply if a fraudulent tax return was filed by the taxpayer. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-15. - Voluntary disclosure. 
    For any locally imposed and administered tax for which a taxpayer has not received a written notice of an audit, investigation, or assessment from the local tax administrator, a taxpayer is entitled to file an application with the local tax administrator for a voluntary disclosure of the tax due. A taxpayer filing a voluntary disclosure application must agree to pay the amount of tax due, along with interest of one (1) percent per month, for all periods prior to the filing of the application but not more than four (4) years before the date of filing the application. A taxpayer filing a valid voluntary disclosure application may not be liable for any additional tax, interest, or penalty for any period before the date the application was filed. However, if the taxpayer incorrectly determined and underpaid the amount of tax due, the taxpayer is liable for the underpaid tax along with applicable interest on the underpaid tax, unless the underpayment was the result of fraud on the part of the taxpayer, in which case the application shall be deemed invalid and void. The payment of tax and interest must be made by no later than ninety (90) days after the filing of the voluntary disclosure application or the date agreed to by the local tax administrator. However, any additional amounts owed as a result of an underpayment of tax and interest previously paid under this section must be paid within ninety (90) days after a final determination and the exhaustion of all appeals of the additional amount owed or the date agreed to by the local tax administrator, whichever is longer. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-16. - Review of liens. 
    The local tax administrator may review any liens filed against any taxpayers for unpaid taxes. Upon a determination by the local tax administrator that the lien is valid, the lien shall remain in full force and effect. If the lien is determined to be improper, the local tax administrator shall: 
(a)  Timely remove the lien at the city's expense. 
(b)  Correct any public disclosure of the improperly imposed lien. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-17. - Application. 
    This chapter shall be liberally construed and administered to supplement all of the city's tax ordinances. To the extent that any tax ordinance is in conflict with or inconsistent with this chapter, this chapter shall be controlling. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
3-32-18. - Severability. 
    If any section, paragraph or provision of this chapter shall be held to be invalid or unenforceable for any reason, the invalidity or unenforceability of such section, paragraph or provision shall not affect any of the remaining provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3267, § 1, 1-9-01) 
CHAPTER 33. - BOTTLE CLUBS 
SECTION: 

3-33-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    Adult uses shall mean each of those uses enumerated as adult uses in section 3-27-2 of the East Peoria City Code and shall be defined as defined in section 3-27-1 of the East Peoria City Code. 
    Bottle club shall mean businesses operating as a public accommodation that permit the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the business premises and that are not licensed or required to be licensed under the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-1). For purposes of this chapter, "public accommodation" means a refreshment, entertainment, or recreation facility of any kind, whether licensed or not, whose goods, services, facilities, privileges, or advantages are extended, offered, sold, or otherwise made available to the public. This shall include, but not be limited to an entity, business or enterprise that is open to the general public with or without the payment of an entry fee or an entity, business or enterprise that is only open to members of the public on a membership or subscription basis, whether or not a fee is charged for becoming a member or subscriber. Bottle club shall include but not be limited to entities, businesses or enterprises known as "BYOB" establishments, "brown-bag" establishments or similar businesses. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-2. - License required. 
    No person, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent, or in any other capacity shall operate or permit to be operated a bottle club without having first obtained a license to do so. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-3. - Application. 
    An application for a bottle club license required by this chapter shall be made in writing to the city clerk which shall set forth the following: 
(a)  The name of the individual, partnership, corporation or association applying for the license. 
(b)  The residence, phone number and driver's license number of the applicant or partners; or, if a corporation or association, the residence, phone number and driver's license number of the officers, and directors, and the principal shareholders and parties in interest. 
(c)  The address and legal description of the location for which the license is requested, including a scale drawing of the premises clearly indicating all areas within or adjoining the building or structure which are to be used in connection with the bottle club activities or are accessible from it, including off-street parking. 
(d)  The type of license requested. 
(e)  The seating capacity and price of admission intended to be charged or the cost of membership. 
(f)  Whether the applicant, officers, partners, directors or the principal shareholders or parties in interest of the corporation or association or the corporation or association itself have been convicted of a criminal offense or ordinance violation (other than minor traffic or parking offenses) in any jurisdiction and, if so, a list of such convictions with date and prosecuting jurisdiction. 
(g)  Location. A statement that the proposed location is not located in any zoning district classified as C, R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or B-1 pursuant to the Zoning Code of the City of East Peoria and is not within three hundred (300) feet of any residential use; church; hospital; undertaking establishment; mortuary; home for aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their wives or children; or any military or naval station; provided, further, that the proposed location is not within one hundred (100) feet of any school or any place of business where the majority of customers are minors or where the principal business transacted consists of school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for minors. The distances shall be measured as provided in section 3-3-4.23 of the East Peoria City Code. 
(h)  In addition, the application shall show: 
(1)  The method by which age identification shall be established to prevent entry by persons under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(2)  The method by which security shall be provided both inside and outside of the bottle club. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-4. - Fees. 
    The applicant shall pay the city treasurer prior to filing an application, a fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) per year or part thereof. Should the application be denied, the license fee shall be refunded to the applicant. Renewal license fees are payable on or before January 1 of each succeeding year. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-5. - Investigation. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license, the city administrator shall cause a copy of the application to be sent to the fire department, police department and planning and zoning department which shall report back to the city administrator or his designee within fifteen (15) days whether the location for which the license is sought meets applicable City Codes and whether the applicant meets the requirement for issuance of the license requested. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-6. - Limitation on location. 
    It shall be within the power of the city administrator to determine what parts of the city constitute residential uses herein referred to. 
(a)  The city administrator shall not issue any bottle club license for any premises located within a zoning district designated as C, R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or B-1 pursuant to the Zoning Code of the City of East Peoria or within three hundred (300) feet of any residential use; church; hospital; undertaking establishment; mortuary; home for aged for indigent persons or for veterans, their wives or children; or any military or naval station. 
(b)  No license shall be issued to any person for the operation of a bottle club within one hundred (100) feet of any school or any place of business where the majority of customers are minors or where the principal business transacted consists of school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for minors. 
(c)  Provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not affect premises for which a valid license for the operation of a bottle club is now in existence, and which is now being operated as a bottle club by virtue of such license. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-7. - Outdoor consumption prohibited. 
    The licensee shall not permit any patron, member or other person to consume alcoholic liquor in an area that is not located within a fully enclosed building or structure on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-8. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the report from the departments referred to in section 3-33-5, the city administrator shall direct the city clerk to issue the license requested unless he shall find: 
(a)  That the applicant is under the age of twenty-one (21); 
(b)  That the applicant, officers, partners, directors or the principal shareholders or parties in interest therein has been convicted of any obscenity offense relating to an amusement-type activity, any gambling-related offense or an offense relating to the violation of the laws or ordinances controlling the sale of alcoholic liquor; 
(c)  That the operation of the bottle club as proposed would not comply with all applicable laws, including but not limited to, building, health, zoning and fire codes of the city; 
(d)  That the applicant, officers, partners, directors or the principal shareholders or parties in interest therein has held a license or had an interest in a license issued pursuant to this chapter that was revoked for cause; 
(e)  The premises for which a bottle club license is requested, including required off-street parking, is within three hundred (300) feet of any C, R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or B-1 zoning district as defined in the zoning code of the city or in any area designated in section 3-33-6; or 
(f)  The methods proposed for age identification, security and supervision pursuant to section 3-33-3(h) are insufficient. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-9. - Posting. 
    Every license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall, at all times during the period for which it is effective, be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the principal entrance to the premises for which the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-10. - Revocation and suspension. 
(a)  Any bottle club license may be revoked or suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the city administrator if the city administrator shall find after a hearing: 
(1)  That the licensee, its employees, officers, agents or representatives have violated any of the provisions of this article, the laws of the state or ordinances of the city at the licensed location; 
(2)  That the licensee, its officers, directors or principal shareholders have been convicted of any offense set forth in section 3-33-8(b); or 
(3)  The licensee has knowingly furnished false or misleading information or withheld relevant information on any application for a license required by section 3-33-3 or any investigation into any such application. 
(b)  The licensee shall be responsible for the acts of his agents, servants and employees in the operation of any licensed establishment. Prior to holding a hearing concerning the question of whether a license issued pursuant to this division shall be revoked or suspended, the city administrator shall give at least ten (10) days' written notice to the licensee setting forth the alleged violations specifically. The licensee may present evidence at such hearing and cross-examine witnesses. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-11. - Restrictions on persons under 21. 
    It shall be unlawful for a bottle club licensee to permit persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years on the premises of a bottle club. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-12. - Reporting incidents to police; telephone required; mandatory closing. 
(a)  Each licensee and each of his agents and employees shall promptly report to the police department of the city any incident occurring on or about the licensed premises and in his knowledge or view relating to the commission or suspected commission of any crime, including, but not limited to, any violation of this chapter, any violation of ordinances or laws concerning the sale, possession, or consumption of alcoholic liquor, any violation of ordinances or laws concerning the sale of controlled substances or cannabis, any violation of laws concerning the abduction or the physical or sexual abuse of children, or any fights, assaults or batteries, and shall truthfully and fully answer all questions and investigations of any identified police officer who makes inquiry concerning any persons in or about the licensed premises, and cooperate fully in any such investigation, including the giving of any oral or written statements at such reasonable times and in such reasonable locations to any police officer engaged in such investigation. 
(b)  Each licensee shall maintain on the licensed premises not less than one (1) telephone in operating order, which phone must be easily accessible to the responsible person in charge of the premises and to other employees on the premises at all times for the purpose of conveniently reporting to the police department incidents occurring on or about the licensed premises. 
(c)  If a disturbance occurs on or about the licensed premises during the hours of operation which in the judgment of the chief of police or the ranking command officer of the police department on duty creates an imminent danger to lives or property, the chief or ranking command officer may, if in his professional judgment it is reasonably necessary in order to restore order and protect lives and property, order the licensed establishment to close its business for such period of time as is reasonably necessary, but not later than the next business day, and may order all patrons to leave the licensed premises immediately. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-13. - Illegal activities on premises. 
    No licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee shall engage in any activity or conduct or suffer or permit any other person to engage in any activity or conduct in or about the licensed premises which is prohibited by an ordinance of the city or law of the state or the United States. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-14. - Certain sexually oriented activities prohibited. 
    The following kinds of conduct are prohibited on premises or in any building structure in this city, that is used or is licensed to be used as a bottle club: 
(a)  The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
(b)  The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
(c)  The actual or simulated displaying of the breasts, buttocks, pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. 
(d)  The permitting by a licensee or agent of a licensee of any person to remain in or upon the premises who exposes to public view any portion of his or her genitals, vulva, anus, breasts, buttocks or public hair or engages in any of the conduct prohibited by subsections (a), (b) or (c) immediately above. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-15. - Adult uses prohibited. 
    A bottle club shall not be located in a building structure which contains another business or establishment providing for or permitting any adult use. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-16. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a bottle club to open for business between the following hours and it shall be unlawful for patrons to be on the premises of a bottle club during these hours: 
(1)  One o'clock (1:00) a.m. Monday and six o'clock (6:00) a.m. Monday; 
(2)  One o'clock (1:00) a.m. Tuesday and six o'clock (6:00) a.m. Tuesday; 
(3)  One o'clock (1:00) a.m. Wednesday and six o'clock (6:00) a.m. Wednesday; 
(4)  One o'clock (1:00) a.m. Thursday and six o'clock (6:00) a.m. Thursday; 
(5)  Two o'clock (2:00) a.m. Friday and six o'clock (6:00) a.m. Friday; 
(6)  Two o'clock (2:00) a.m. Saturday and six o'clock (6:00) a.m. Saturday; 
(7)  Two o'clock (2:00) a.m. Sunday and twelve o'clock (12:00) noon Sunday. 
(b)  On the last Sunday of October, or on any other date specified by the state as a return to United States Standard Central Time it shall be unlawful for a bottle club to open during the hours of one o'clock (1:00) a.m. Central Standard Time and twelve o'clock (12:00) noon Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
3-33-17. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Title 1 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 3466, § 1, 9-9-03) 
CHAPTER 34. - FARM CREEK AREA BUSINESS DISTRICT RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX AND BUSINESS DISTRICT SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX 
SECTION: 

3-34-1. - Business District Retailers' Occupation Tax. 
    A Business District Retailers' Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail within the Farm Creek Area Business District (as described and designated by Ordinance No. 3998) at the rate of one (1.00) percent of the gross receipts from the sales made in the course of such business. This tax is not imposed on food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption), prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances, modifications to a motor vehicle for the purpose of rendering it usable by a disabled person, and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics, for human use. This tax shall be in effect for so long as the Farm Creek Area Business District shall continue in existence and shall terminate upon termination of the Farm Creek Area Business District. The tax imposed by this section and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue and paid over to the city as provided by the Business District Development and Redevelopment Act found at 65 ILCS 5/11-74.3-1 et. seq., as amended from time to time (the "Act"). 
(Ord. No. 3999, § 2, 9-20-11) 
3-34-2. - Business District Service Occupation Tax. 
    A Business District Service Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged, within the Farm Creek Area Business District, in the business of making sales of service, who, as an incident to making those sales of service, transfer tangible personal property within the Farm Creek Area Business District, either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service. The tax shall be imposed at the rate of one (1.00) percent of the selling price of tangible personal property so transferred within the Farm Creek Area Business District. This tax is not imposed on food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption), prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances, modifications to a motor vehicle for the purpose of rendering it usable by a disabled person, and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics, for human use. This tax shall be in effect for so long as the Farm Creek Area Business District shall continue in existence and shall terminate upon termination of the Farm Creek Area Business District. The tax imposed by this section and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue and paid over to the city as provided by the Act. 
(Ord. No. 3999, § 2, 9-20-11) 
3-34-3. - Farm Creek Area Business District Tax Allocation Fund. 
    The proceeds of the taxes imposed herein shall be deposited into a special fund held by the treasurer of the city called the "Farm Creek Area Business District Tax Allocation Fund". Money deposited in such fund shall be expended in accordance with the provisions of the Act and in accordance with the business district development and redevelopment plan approved by Ordinance No. 3998. 
(Ord. No. 3999, § 2, 9-20-11) 
CHAPTER 35. - TARGET AREA BUSINESS DISTRICT RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX AND BUSINESS DISTRICT SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX 
SECTION: 

3-35-1. - Business District Retailers' Occupation Tax. 
    A Business District Retailers' Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail within the Target Area Business District (as described and designated by Ordinance No. 4022) at the rate of one (1.00) percent of the gross receipts from the sales made in the course of such business. This tax is not imposed on food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption), prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances, modifications to a motor vehicle for the purpose of rendering it usable by a disabled person, and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics, for human use. This tax shall be in effect for so long as the Target Area Business District shall continue in existence and shall terminate upon termination of the Target Area Business District. The tax imposed by this section and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue and paid over to the city as provided by the Business District Development and Redevelopment Act found at 65 ILCS 5/11-74.3-1 et. seq., as amended from time to time (the "Act"). 
(Ord. No. 4023, § 2, 2-7-12) 
3-35-2. - Business District Service Occupation Tax. 
    A Business District Service Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged, within the Target Area Business District, in the business of making sales of service, who, as an incident to making those sales of service, transfer tangible personal property within the Target Area Business District, either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service. The tax shall be imposed at the rate of one (1.00) percent of the selling price of tangible personal property so transferred within the Target Area Business District. This tax is not imposed on food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption), prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances, modifications to a motor vehicle for the purpose of rendering it usable by a disabled person, and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics, for human use. This tax shall be in effect for so long as the Target Area Business District shall continue in existence and shall terminate upon termination of the Target Area Business District. The tax imposed by this section and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue and paid over to the city as provided by the Act. 
(Ord. No. 4023, § 2, 2-7-12) 
3-35-3. - Target Area Business District Tax Allocation Fund. 
    The proceeds of the taxes imposed herein shall be deposited into a special fund held by the treasurer of the city called the "Target Area Business District Tax Allocation Fund". Money deposited in such fund shall be expended in accordance with the provisions of the Act and in accordance with the business district development and redevelopment plan approved by Ordinance No. 4022. 
(Ord. No. 4023, § 2, 2-7-12) 
CHAPTER 36. - COSTCO AREA BUSINESS DISTRICT RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX AND BUSINESS DISTRICT SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX 
SECTION: 

3-36-1. - Business District Retailers' Occupation Tax. 
    A Business District Retailers' Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail within the Costco Area Business District (as described and designated by Ordinance No. 4024) at the rate of one-half (0.5) percent of the gross receipts from the sales made in the course of such business. This tax is not imposed on food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption), prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances, modifications to a motor vehicle for the purpose of rendering it usable by a disabled person, and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics, for human use. This tax shall be in effect for so long as the Costco Area Business District shall continue in existence and shall terminate upon termination of the Costco Area Business District. The tax imposed by this section and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue and paid over to the city as provided by the Business District Development and Redevelopment Act found at 65 ILCS 5/11-74.3-1 et. seq., as amended from time to time (the "Act"). 
(Ord. No. 4025, § 2, 2-7-12) 
3-36-2. - Business District Service Occupation Tax. 
    A Business District Service Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged, within the Costco Area Business District, in the business of making sales of service, who, as an incident to making those sales of service, transfer tangible personal property within the Costco Area Business District, either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service. The tax shall be imposed at the rate of one-half (0.5) percent of the selling price of tangible personal property so transferred within the Costco Area Business District. This tax is not imposed on food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption), prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances, modifications to a motor vehicle for the purpose of rendering it usable by a disabled person, and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics, for human use. This tax shall be in effect for so long as the Costco Area Business District shall continue in existence and shall terminate upon termination of the Costco Area Business District. The tax imposed by this section and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue and paid over to the city as provided by the Act. 
(Ord. No. 4025, § 2, 2-7-12) 
3-36-3. - Costco Area Business District Tax Allocation Fund. 
    The proceeds of the taxes imposed herein shall be deposited into a special fund held by the treasurer of the city called the "Costco Area Business District Tax Allocation Fund". Money deposited in such fund shall be expended in accordance with the provisions of the Act and in accordance with the business district development and redevelopment plan approved by Ordinance No. 4024. 
(Ord. No. 4025, § 2, 2-7-12) 
TITLE 4 - BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and premises (licenses and premises, § 3-2-10, change of location (licenses and permits), § 3-2-11; regulations generally (food locker plants), § 3-7-3.3; electrical outlets, connections, § 3-16-18, buildings regulations (mobile home parks), § 3-16-32; compliance with building regulations (mobile home parks), § 3-18-6. 

CHAPTER 1. - EAST PEORIA BUILDING CODE 
SECTION: 

4-1-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the East Peoria Building Code. 
(1975, 5-22-84) 
4-1-2. - Definitions. 
    In the construction of this chapter, including the IBC, the IRC, the IMC, the IPMC and the IECC, the words and terms set forth in this section shall have the following meanings unless the context or use clearly indicates another or different meaning or intent: 
(a)  Code council means the International Code Council, Inc. 
(b)  IBC means the "International Building Code, 2012 Edition" published by the code council. 
(c)  IRC means the "International Residential Code, 2012 Edition" published by the code council. 
(d)  Building official as used in the IBC, the ICR, the IMC, the IPMC or the IECC shall be considered to be a reference to the director of the department of buildings and inspections of the city or his authorized agent. 
(e)  Director means the director of the department of buildings and inspections of the city or his authorized agent. 
(f)  IMC means the "International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition" published by the code council. 
(g)  Prefabricated assembly means a building or portion of a building which is constructed at a location other than the site at which the building or portion thereof is to be permanently affixed to real estate. 
(h)  Third party inspector means a person certified as an independent testing and inspection agency for prefabricated assemblies by either the International Code Council, Inc. or the International Conference of Building Officials. 
(i)  IECC means the "International Energy Conservation Code, 2012 Edition" published by the code council. 
(j)  IPMC means the "International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 Edition" published by the code council. 
(Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 4-5-94; Ord. No. 2762, § 1, 10-18-94; Ord. No. 3048, § 1, 2-17-98; Ord. No. 3288, § 1, 5-15-01; Ord. No. 3487, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 3503, § 1, 1-4-05; Ord. No. 3758, § 1, 10-16-07; Ord. No. 3955, § 1, 1-4-11; Ord. No. 4161, § 1, 6-17-14; Ord. No. 4187, § 17, 9-16-14) 
4-1-3. - IBC, IRC and Mechanical Code adopted; applicability. 
    The IBC, the IRC, the Energy Conservation Code, the Property Maintenance Code and the Mechanical Code are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter by reference thereto. The substantive provisions of the IRC shall be applicable only to structures designed and constructed for residential use by not more than two families as defined in said IRC. The IBC shall be applicable to all other structures. The Energy Conservation Code, the Property Maintenance Code and the Mechanical Code shall be applicable in accordance with their provisions. 
(Ord. No. 2724, § 2, 4-5-94; Ord. No. 3503, § 2, 1-4-05; Ord. No. 3955, § 2, 1-4-11)

4-1-5. - Powers and duties of director. 
    The director is authorized and directed to enforce all provisions of this chapter, including specifically, those portions of the IBC and the IRC adopted by reference. In carrying out these responsibilities, the director shall, as he deems necessary, consult with and consider the suggestions of other departments and officers of the city including but not limited to the fire department, public works department, city engineer and city attorney. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the director shall immediately notify the fire department of any application for a building permit which is received for a structure regulated by the IBC. The fire department may, in its discretion, review and comment upon such plans; provided, however, that comments shall be forwarded immediately in writing to the director. In the event a dispute arises between the director and the fire department as to the propriety of issuing a permit for the proposed structure, the director shall not issue the permit until the director has notified both the commissioner of finance and the commissioner of public safety of the director's intent to issue the permit despite the objections of the fire department. The director shall also collect and account for all fees. 
(Ord. 2332, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 3487, § 4, 1-27-04) 
4-1-6. - Additional requirements. 
    Any less restrictive provisions of either the IBC or the IRC to the contrary notwithstanding, the following requirements where applicable shall also be met: 
(a)  Elevators and stairways. 
(1)  Elevators are required in buildings having a height of more than three (3) stories. All elevators in such buildings shall have a capacity of not less than four thousand five hundred (4,500) pounds and interior dimensions of not less than eight (8) feet in length and five (5) feet ten (10) inches in width. The sides of the car which lie perpendicular to the side which contains the doorway to the car shall have an interior length of not less than eight (8) feet. Any such elevator shall be capable of accessing each floor in the building in which it is located. 
(2)  Buildings having a height of two (2) or three (3) stories (except one- or two-family dwellings) shall include at least one (1) of the following: 
a.  An elevator with a capacity of not less than two thousand five hundred (2,500) pounds and interior dimensions of not less than six (6) feet ten (10) inches in length by four (4) feet three (3) inches in width. The sides of the car which lie perpendicular to the side which contains the doorway to the car shall have an interior length of not less than six (6) feet ten (10) inches. Any such elevator shall be capable of accessing each floor in the building in which it is located; or 
b.  A stairway which meets applicable requirements of the IBC or the standards set forth in this subsection, whichever are more restrictive. All landings in any such stairway shall have a clear width (measured by any angle that the standard ambulance cart in use by the East Peoria Fire Department Ambulance Service may rotate to change direction) of four (4) feet six (6) inches by nine (9) feet in length. Doorways entering and/or exiting stairways shall comply with the IBC. Emergency personnel shall not be required to re-enter the building or exit the stair enclosure at any floor level to complete a rotation by an ambulance cart to further ascend or descend the stairway. Doors shall be located to allow exit from the stair enclosure with the ambulance cart remaining in the horizontal or rolling configuration. Under no circumstance shall the stairway be designed in such a manner as to require the ambulance cart to be elevated in order to negotiate a corner or pass through a door. No point in any such building shall be located more than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the nearest stairway which complies with this subsection. 
(b)  Fire suppression. With respect to: any new building intended to be used for commercial, industrial or multifamily residential purposes or with respect to any existing building used for commercial, industrial or multifamily residential purposes which is undergoing remodeling or improvement where the cost of construction exceeds fifty (50) percent of the fair cash market value as determined by reference to the most recent assessed value of the building, the property must include facilities which in the judgment of the fire chief are sufficient to permit the fire department to promptly suppress any fire which may occur in the structure. In the absence of an analysis by the fire chief which demonstrates that either more or less substantial facilities are required, any property or building subject to the requirements of this subsection must include a pumper-type hydrant on the city's side of the sprinkler system check valve not more than one hundred (100) feet, nor less than fifty (50) feet from the Siamese connection. Hydrants on mains having a minimum diameter of six (6) inches shall also be provided so that hydrant spacing around the perimeter of the building does not exceed three hundred (300) feet. The site plan for the building shall show all existing and new underground piping, pipe sizes, fire hydrant and a location suitable for testing water flows. 
(c)  Fire alarm system. Every new building intended to be used for commercial, mercantile, business, industrial or multifamily residential purposes shall be equipped with a complete automatic/manual/notification fire alarm system monitored by a reputable UL listed central station. Such fire alarm system shall be capable of detecting fire and smoke and shall be installed in accordance with the standards prescribed by the IBC. 
(Ord. 2332, 10-5-91; Ord. No. 3082, § 1, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 3264, § 1, 12-5-00; Ord. No. 3487, § 5, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 4099, § 1, 10-29-13) 
4-1-7. - Smoke detectors required for all residential structures. 
(a)  Smoke detectors required. This section shall require the installation of smoke detectors in a building of the class described in this section only if neither the IBC or the IRC require the installation of a smoke detector. If the IBC or the IRC require the installation of a smoke detector in a building of the class described in this section, then the provisions of such code pertaining to smoke detectors shall apply and the provisions of this section shall be inapplicable. 
(b)  Definitions in IBC to apply. Unless otherwise specifically set forth in this section, the definitions contained in the IBC shall apply in the interpretation of this section. 
(c)  Smoke detector defined. For the purposes of this section, a smoke detector is defined as a device which: 
(1)  Is designed for the purpose of sensing the presence of visible or invisible particles or products of combustion; and 
(2)  Which emits a loud, audible alarm when visible or invisible products or particles of combustion are sensed; and 
(3)  Is powered either by battery or by the electrical service which supplies electrical power to the building where the smoke detector is located; and 
(4)  Is listed by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., 333 Pfingsten Road, Northbrook, Illinois as complying with Underwriters Laboratories Standard No. 217 and bears the mark "UL" or in the alternative is approved in writing by the Fire Chief of the City of East Peoria. 
(d)  Tenant defined. Every person who has a possessory interest in but is not an owner of a dwelling unit of a multifamily apartment house, a dwelling unit of a two-family dwelling or a one-family dwelling. 
(e)  Buildings where smoke detectors required. Except as otherwise provided in this section 4-1-7, a smoke detector shall be installed and located in every dwelling unit in the city and specifically or additionally in each of the following locations within the City of East Peoria: 
(1)  In each sleeping room of every boarding house. 
(2)  In each sleeping room of every dormitory. 
(3)  In each guest or sleeping room of every hotel. 
(4)  In each dwelling unit of every multifamily apartment house. 
(5)  In each one-family dwelling. 
(6)  In each dwelling unit of every two-family dwelling. 
(f)  Location of required smoke detector within building. Detectors required under provisions of this section shall be mounted either on a ceiling or on a wall within twelve (12) inches of but no closer than six (6) inches to the ceiling. Within the dwelling units of multifamily apartment houses, one-family dwellings or two-family dwellings, smoke detectors shall be located in hall areas giving access to rooms used for sleeping but remote from any cooking area. 
(g)  Responsibility for installation and maintenance. The owner of the building where smoke detector(s) are required by this section to be installed shall install each and every smoke detector required by this section and, in addition, shall continuously maintain every required smoke detector in an operable condition. When a tenant occupies either a dwelling unit of a multifamily apartment house, a one-family dwelling or a dwelling unit of a two-family dwelling, the tenant is responsible for notifying the owner in writing within forty-eight (48) hours in the event any smoke detector installed within the dwelling unit which he occupies becomes inoperable or appears to be inoperable. 
(h)  Exception for areas protected by automatic sprinklers. The fire chief may waive the requirement for the installation of a smoke detector pursuant to this section 4-1-7 if he first determines that the area where a smoke detector would be required by this section is adequately protected by an automatic sprinkler system. 
(i)  Moratorium on imposition of fines authorized. The city council may, in its discretion, authorize by resolution a moratorium on the imposition of fines for violation of the requirements imposed by this section 4-1-7. The enactment of a moratorium on the imposition of fines for violation of this section shall not be construed to eliminate or diminish the responsibility imposed upon owners and tenants pursuant to this section. The existence of such a moratorium is an affirmative defense which must be pleaded and proved by the alleged violator in order to avoid the imposition of a fine. 
(Ord. 2038, 1-8-85; Ord. No. 3487, § 6, 1-27-04) 
Cross reference- Wiring (food locker plants), § 3-7-3.4. 
4-1-8. - Placement and inspection of prefabricated assemblies. 
(a)  The East Peoria Building Code shall govern the construction of prefabricated assemblies affixed or intended to be affixed or intended to be affixed at any site within the city in the same manner and to the same extent as if the prefabricated assembly had been constructed entirely on the site to which it is or will be affixed. 
(b)  No prefabricated assembly may be affixed at any site within the corporate limits of the city unless a permit for the construction of the prefabricated assembly has been issued by the director prior to the commencement of its construction. In addition to any other information required of applicants for building permits, the applicant for a permit to construct any building or structure which includes a prefabricated assembly requiring a third party inspection shall provide the following: 
(1)  A signed agreement between the applicant and an approved third party inspector providing for inspection of the proposed prefabricated assembly in accordance with the applicable provisions of the East Peoria Building Code. Such agreement shall be in a form approved by the director; and 
(2)  Written permission from the manufacturer of the prefabricated assembly authorizing the third party inspector to enter upon the premises of the manufacturer for the purpose of conducting all necessary inspections in accordance with the provisions of the East Peoria Building Code. 
(c)  A third party inspector must perform all inspections of any element of any prefabricated assembly which is not readily accessible to inspection at the site within the corporate limits of the city at which the prefabricated assembly will be affixed to the real estate. 
(d)  Third party inspectors shall be selected in the following manner: 
(1)  The director shall maintain a list of approved third party inspectors. 
(2)  The applicant for a permit to construct any building or structure which is intended to contain any prefabricated assembly which must be inspected by a third party inspector shall select an inspector from the list of approved inspectors. 
(3)  If no inspector on the approved list is available to perform the inspection requested by the applicant, then the applicant may propose one (1) or more qualified third party inspectors for consideration by the director who may then add such qualified third party inspectors to the approved list. 
(e)  All third party inspections required by the East Peoria Building Code shall be performed in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  The third party inspector must perform all required inspections of a prefabricated assembly at the location of its construction at times when the inspected elements of the prefabricated assembly are readily accessible to inspection by the third party inspector. 
(2)  The third party inspector must prepare and submit directly to the director a written report which includes each of the following elements: 
a.  A description of each inspection performed. 
b.  The date of each inspection. 
c.  A room by room description of the components inspected. 
d.  A description of the observants made during each inspection. 
e.  A certification that the inspector has carefully reviewed the plans and specifications for the prefabricated assembly. 
f.  A certification that the prefabricated assembly has been built in accordance with the plans and specifications for that assembly. 
g.  In the case of a prefabricated assembly which is incorporated into a one- or two-family dwelling, a certification that the prefabricated assembly complies with all applicable provisions of the IRC or in the case of all other structures, a certification that it complies with all applicable provisions of the IBC. 
h.  A certification that the prefabricated assembly complies with all applicable provisions of the National Electrical Code. 
i.  A certification that the prefabricated assembly complies with all applicable provisions of the Illinois Plumbing Code. 
j.  A certification by the signatory to the report that the report is based on the personal observations of the signatory. 
k.  The signature of the third party inspector and the date of that signature. 
l.  A notary certificate evidencing that the signature of the third party inspector has been acknowledged before a notary public. 
(f)  Once a prefabricated assembly has been delivered to the site at which it is intended to be affixed to a foundation, the prefabricated assembly shall not be placed upon the foundation until all of the following have first occurred: 
(1)  The director has received a written report on the inspection of the prefabricated assembly from a third party inspector which report complies in all respects with applicable provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  An on-site inspection of the prefabricated assembly has been completed by the director. The director shall endeavor to complete any such on-site inspection within two (2) business days after the date on which the prefabricated assembly arrives at the site where it is intended to be affixed to a foundation; and 
(3)  The director has given written consent for the placement of the prefabricated assembly on the foundation. 
(g)  The director may in his discretion prescribe inspection forms which must be completed by the third party inspector. If prescribed by the director, such inspection forms shall be utilized by the third party inspector in completing the inspection of the prefabricated assembly. An inspection report which fails to utilize prescribed forms shall be unacceptable, provided that the director has first provided the prescribed forms to the third party inspector within fourteen (14) days after the building permit for the prefabricated assembly has been approved. 
(h)  The applicant shall bear any and all costs associated with any third party inspection performed on behalf of the applicant. 
(i)  Prefabricated assemblies remain subject to inspection on the site at which they will be affixed and upon completion of construction must conform to the East Peoria Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 2762, § 2, 10-18-94; Ord. No. 2785, § 1, 1-17-95; Ord. No. 3487, § 7, 1-27-04) 
4-1-9. - Director to deny applications for building permits under certain circumstances. 
    The director shall deny an application for a building permit under circumstances where the site of the proposed structure fails to comply in all respects with applicable provisions of the City Code or any applicable state or federal statute or regulation or where the site of the proposed structure has inadequate access to a public water supply, a public sanitary sewer system or electrical service. Circumstances where the director shall deny the issuance of a building permit under this section include, but are not limited to the following: 
(a)  Failure to provide adequate fire protection facilities as required by this chapter. 
(b)  With respect to any parcel which has been created in violation of the city's subdivision code or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 3264, § 2, 12-5-00) 
4-1-10. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Each applicant for a building permit shall pay a filing fee of six dollars and fifty cents ($6.50). In addition thereto, the applicant shall pay the sum of three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or fraction thereof of value of improvements up to one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) of value. For improvements valued in excess of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), the applicant shall, in addition, pay the sum of two dollars ($2.00) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or fraction thereof of value in excess of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). 
(b)  The value of all new construction, except for one- and two-family residences, will be based on the contract cost. The code official shall determine the value of new one- and two-family residences by using the data published periodically by the code council. The value of remodeling or repair work shall be determined on the basis of contracts entered into by the applicant. In the event no contract is available, the code official shall estimate the value of remodeling or repair work for one- and two-family residences by using the "Home-Tech Remodeling and Renovation Cost Estimator" published by Home-Tech Publications, or such other similar publication deemed appropriate by the director. 
(c)  In the event that the work specified in the application was started prior to the issuance of a building permit for such work, then the permit fees herein established shall be doubled. 
(Ord. No. 3487, § 8, 1-27-04) 
4-1-11. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of this chapter or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair a building or structure in violation of an approved plan or directive of the code official or a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this Code shall be guilty of a violation of the East Peoria Building Code punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3487, § 9, 1-27-04) 
4-1-12. - Inconsistencies between IBC, IRC and other codes adopted by the city. 
    In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of the IBC or the IRC and any other code adopted or incorporated by reference by the City Code, the terms of the more stringent code as determined by the director shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 3487, § 10, 1-27-04) 
4-1-13. - Approval of alternate construction techniques and procedures. 
    The director may in his or her discretion approve alternate construction techniques and procedures not addressed or approved by the IRC or the IBC provided that a licensed professional with demonstrated expertise in the evaluation of the alternate technique or procedure has to the satisfaction of the director certified the safety and durability of the alternate technique or procedure. 
(Ord. No. 4317 , § 1, 2-7-17) 
CHAPTER 2. - MOVING BUILDINGS 
SECTION: 

4-2-1. - Permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to move, or to cause or permit to be moved, any building or structure, on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place within the city without having first obtained a permit therefor. 
4-2-2. - Application. 
    Application for a permit to move any building or structure shall be made in writing by the owner, owner's agent or contractor thereof upon such forms as may be provided, to the city clerk, with copies to the director of city inspections, the director of public works, any utility company serving the premises, and the owners or agents of adjoining or neighboring premises. 
Such application shall state the location and description of the building or structure, the date when moving is to commence, the proposed route and the number of days that such building or structure shall occupy any portion of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. 
4-2-3. - Fee. 
    No permit to move any building or structure shall be issued unless and until a fee shall have been paid to the city clerk in the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day or fraction thereof that it is intended that the same shall occupy any portion of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place; and an additional sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day or fraction thereof over and above the time stated in such application, during or on which any such building or structure shall occupy said public place, shall be paid to the clerk. 
4-2-4. - Bond required. 
    Before any permit to move any building or structure shall be issued, the person engaged in the work of moving the same shall file with the city clerk his certificate bond, in an amount and conditioned as required under section 4-4-4 of this Code. 
4-2-5. - Deposit required. 
    Before any permit to move any building or structure shall be issued, the person in the work of moving the same shall deposit with the city clerk a sum of money as provided in paragraph (a) of section 4-4-4 of this Code, conditioned upon the safe condition of the premises after removal of such building or structure, as further provided in paragraphs (a) and (b) of section 4-2-11. 
4-2-6. - Issuance of permit. 
    If the directors of public works and city inspections both are satisfied that all provisions of this chapter will be complied with, and that all possible precautions will be taken by the applicant to prevent injury to persons, vehicles or property, public or private, they shall approve the application, and the city clerk shall issue a permit for such moving. 
4-2-7. - Supervision. 
    Upon issuance of the permit required by section 4-2-6, such building or structure may be moved upon the public ways; provided, that all work done thereunder shall be subject to the supervision of the director. 
The director shall inspect or cause to be inspected such operation at least once every two (2) hours during the period when such moving is in progress. 
4-2-8. - Warning lights, signs required. 
    Whenever any street, alley or sidewalk is obstructed by any building or structure being moved thereon, written warnings to that effect shall be placed thereon by the persons engaged in the moving, adequate to warn vehicles and persons entering that portion of the public way so obstructed. 
Such persons engaged in the moving shall keep warning lanterns or lights upon the building structure after dusk and before dawn so as to warn any person or vehicle against collision with the same. 
4-2-9. - Cutting of wires. 
    Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with any wires or cables of a public utility in the moving of any building or structure, the terms of any special or franchise ordinance governing shall apply and the bond therein specified shall be given. If no such terms apply, then the director shall estimate the expense of cutting and repairing the wires and the bond to be given to cover such expense. 
4-2-10. - Fire alarm wires; notice. 
    Whenever any such moving building or structure approaches any fire alarm wire or pole which shall be endangered by the moving of such building or structure, it shall be the duty of the mover to notify the fire chief at least six (6) hours before reaching such wire or pole so that they may be removed or protected by the city authorities. 
Cross reference- Fire lanes and streets, § 8-1-24. 
4-2-11. - Moving regulations, general. 
(a)  All moving operations shall be performed in a workmanlike manner and with the least amount of noise possible. 
    In addition to other safety requirements specified in this chapter, it shall be the duty of all persons working at or responsible for such moving operations to see that all persons and vehicles are warned and kept away from such building or structure, and at such distance as to prevent injury. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any permittee hereunder to give notice to the fire department, police department, superintendent of streets, water and sewer department and any public utilities involved, at least two (2) hours in advance of the commencement of any moving operations. 
4-2-12. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3292, § 29, 7-3-01) 
CHAPTER 3. - UNSAFE BUILDINGS 
SECTION: 

4-3-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter: 
    Director means the director of buildings and inspections of the city or his authorized agent. 
    Unsafe building shall mean any building, shed, fence, or any other structure which, because of its: 
(1)  General condition, or 
(2)  Faulty or partial construction, or 
(3)  Inadequate maintenance, or 
(4)  Dilapidation or deterioration, or 
(5)  Lack of adequate doors or windows, or 
(6)  Abandonment, or 
(7)  Partial demolition or destruction, or 
(8)  Any other cause, is determined by an authorized official of the city to be: 
(a)  Dangerous to the public health, and may cause or aid in the spread of disease or injury to the occupants thereof or of neighboring buildings; or 
(b)  Especially liable to fire, and constitutes or creates a fire hazard; or 
(c)  Especially liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or by a collapse or fall of any part of such structure, or is otherwise structurally unsafe; or 
(d)  Available to and frequented by vagrants, transients, malefactors or disorderly persons, who are not lawful occupants of such structure. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 18, 9-16-14) 
4-3-2. - Declared nuisance. 
    Any unsafe building within the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and all such buildings shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation, demolition or removal in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to declare nuisances and provide for abatement, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
4-3-3. - To allow unsafe buildings declared unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit the existence of any unsafe building within the city; and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in control of any unsafe building to permit the same to remain in an unsafe condition, or to occupy such building or permit the same to be occupied while it is or remains in an unsafe condition. 
4-3-4. - Inspection; notice to abate, notice to vacate. 
(a)  The director shall examine or cause to be examined every building or structure reported or suspected to be unsafe. 
(b)  Whenever, upon due investigation, the director shall be of the opinion that any building or structure within the city is an unsafe building, the director shall thereupon cause due notice in writing to be served upon the owner or owners of such building or structure, stating that the building has been declared to be in an unsafe condition, setting forth the causes therefor, and that such unsafe condition must be removed or remedied by repairing or altering the building or structure or by demolishing or removing the same. Such notice shall require the owner or person in control of the building or structure to commence the required repairs, improvement, demolition or removal of the building or structure, and all such work shall be completed within fifteen (15) days of the date of such notice, unless for special reasons stated a longer time is allowed, but in no case to exceed one hundred twenty (120) days. 
(c)  Should the conditions require, for reasons of public welfare and safety, such notice shall also require the building or structure to be vacated immediately and not reoccupied until the required repairs or improvements are completed, the building inspected and final approval given by the director. 
(d)  Before issuing a building permit authorizing the repair or reconstruction of any building which has for any reason suffered damage to its structural components including its roof, walls or foundation, the director may, in the director's discretion, require the applicant for the building permit or the owner of the building to secure at the expense of such applicant or owner an inspection of the building by a licensed structural engineer together with a written report by the inspecting engineer which confirms that the building if repaired or reconstructed in accordance with the application for the building permit will not constitute an unsafe building as defined by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4151, § 1, 1-7-14; Ord. No. 4187, § 19, 9-16-14) 
4-3-5. - Due notice. 
(a)  Except where otherwise provided in this chapter, "due notice" shall consist of personal service to owners of record of the real estate involved, or by certified mail sent to the last known address of such owner or owners, by posting such notice in the certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(b)  Whenever, upon diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of such owner or owners shall not be ascertainable, notice mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real estate was last assessed shall constitute sufficient notice. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 20, 9-16-14) 
State Law reference- Unsafe buildings, demolition, repair or enclosure, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1. 
4-3-6. - Public notice of unsafe building. 
(a)  Whenever any building or structure is found to be unsafe for occupancy, or detrimental to the public welfare and safety, the director shall post or cause to be posted at each entrance to such building or structure a notice to read "DO NOT ENTER, UNSAFE TO OCCUPY, BUILDING DEPARTMENT, CITY OF EAST PEORIA, ILLINOIS." 
(b)  Such notice shall remain posted until such repairs, improvements, demolition or removal has been completed, and no notice so posted shall be removed without written permission by the director or the city council and no person shall enter such building or structure, except for the purpose of making the required repairs, inspection, demolition or removal of the said building. 
4-3-7. - Failure of owner to abate. 
(a)  In the event the owner or owners of any unsafe building, after fifteen (15) days' written notice, have neglected, refused or otherwise failed to put such building in a safe condition or to demolish it, the director may make or cause to be made application to the Circuit Court of Tazewell County for an order authorizing the city to demolish or repair, or cause the demolition or repair, of dangerous and unsafe building or uncompleted and abandoned building. 
    However, such unsafe buildings must be boarded up or otherwise enclosed. 
(b)  The cost of such demolition or repair shall be recoverable from the owner or owners of such real estate and shall be a lien thereon, which lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes; provided, that within one hundred eighty (180) days after such cost and expense is incurred the city, or person performing the service by authority of the city, in his or its own name, shall file notice of lien in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; and 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and 
(3)  The date or dates when the cost or expense was incurred by the city. 
Such lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or mechanic's liens; but such suits must be commenced within three (3) years after the date of filing notice of the lien. 
(c)  It shall not be a defense to any cause of action brought pursuant to this section that the building is boarded up or otherwise enclosed, although a court may order such building boarded up or otherwise enclosed. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 21, 9-16-14) 
4-3-8. - Appeal of notice to abate. 
    Should any owner or person in control of any unsafe building or structure be aggrieved with the order of the director, he may appeal within five (5) days after service of the notice to abate, as heretofore provided, to the city council, who shall forthwith and within seven (7) days hold a hearing, make inspection of the premises and render a final decision. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 4. - DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS 
SECTION: 

4-4-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter: 
    Demolition. The removal, in whole or part, of any structure or building, the removal of demolition debris, or the installation of fill material and final grading in connection with such removal. 
    Demolition contractor. Any person or firm engaged in the business of demolition of buildings or structures by contract. 
    Director. The director of buildings and inspections for the city or his authorized agent. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 22, 9-16-14) 
4-4-2. - Powers and duties of director. 
    In addition to the other powers and duties prescribed in this chapter, the director shall have the right during reasonable hours, or at any time when an extreme danger exists, to enter any premises for which a demolition permit has been issued or applied for to determine the progress of work or to determine if a safety hazard exists. He shall have the authority to order the discontinuation or modification of any demolition work when he determines that a hazardous condition may result from continued work. He shall approve or disapprove all applications for demolition permits. He shall approve all bonds required under this chapter. He shall submit an accounting of all fees collected to the city clerk. 
4-4-3. - Regulation of demolition contractors. 
(a)  Bonding required. Prior to the issuance of any demolition permit, a demolition contractor shall provide the director with the following: 
(1)  License and permit bond. A license and permit bond specifically covering demolition work and conditioned upon compliance with the provisions of this chapter, such bond to be in the amount of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). 
4-4-4. - Regulation of property owners. 
    Owners of real property may demolish their own buildings or structures. However, the director shall not issue a demolition permit until the owner has provided the following: 
(a)  Bond. A cash bond equal to fifty cents ($.50) per one (1) square foot of ground floor area of all buildings named in the application for a demolition permit. Such bond shall be conditioned upon compliance with this chapter. Such bond shall be cancelled and all monies returned to the owner upon completion of the demolition to the reasonable satisfaction of the director. 
(b)  Entry agreement. An agreement signed by the owner granting permission to employees or agents of the city to enter the named property to complete all work required under this chapter if such work is uncompleted on the date of expiration of the demolition permit. Any expenses incurred by the city as a result of such entry and work shall be deducted from the bond. 
4-4-5. - Permits; fees. 
(a)  Permits required. It shall be unlawful for any person to demolish any building or structure, or any structural part thereof, without having first obtained a demolition permit from the director. Application for a permit shall be made on a form prescribed by the director. 
(b)  Expiration of permits. Permits for demolition shall expire thirty (30) days after issuance. The director may, upon good cause shown, extend such date of expiration for a successive fifteen-day period. 
(c)  Denial of permit. The director may refuse to issue a demolition permit when the requirements of this chapter are not met or where a permit has already been issued for a specific property and no significant progress has been made toward complete demolition. 
(d)  Drawings required. Applicants for a demolition permit shall provide drawings indicating the height and location of buildings on the site, distance from property lines and adjacent buildings, final grading, party walls, protective canopies and such other information as may be reasonably requested by the director. The director may, if he determines that the safety of persons or property will not be adversely affected, waive the requirements of this subsection (d). 
(e)  Permit fees. The director shall collect fees for all demolition permits according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Residential: 
First dwelling unit on lot ..... $50.00 
Each additional dwelling unit on lot ..... 25.00 
Each accessory building ..... 15.00 
(2)  Nonresidential: 
Up to 1,000 square feet of ground floor area of building lot ..... $50.00 
For each additional 1,000 square feet of ground floor area of building on lot ..... 10.00 
(3)  Fees for demolition work started prior to the issuance of a permit shall be doubled. 
4-4-6. - Demolition inspections. 
(a)  Inspections required The director shall cause an inspection to be made of all demolitions upon the completion of work and at such other stages of work as he may determine to be necessary. 
(b)  Notification for inspection. The person carrying out a demolition shall notify the director that the site is ready for final inspection. The director shall cause an inspection within twenty-four (24) hours of such notification, nonworking days excluded. 
(c)  Discontinuance of demolition for safety reasons. If, after inspection, the director finds continued demolition will create a hazard to the public, he shall order demolition discontinued and recommend a safer method of demolition to be used. 
4-4-7. - Demolition requirements. 
(a)  General. All demolition work shall be carried out in safe and workman-like manner to minimize hazard to adjacent property and the public. 
(b)  Subterranean walls, floors, footings. All subterranean walls, floors and footings shall be removed. 
(c)  Fill material. All depressions, cavities, cisterns or wells shall be filled with approved granular material or compacted structural clay to within six (6) inches of final grade. 
(d)  Finish grade. The final grading shall be such that no depressions or cavities exist and stormwater cannot stand on the demolition site. Six (6) inches of earth shall be installed over any depression, cavity, cistern or well filled with fill material. 
(e)  Removal of debris. All debris resulting from demolition shall be removed from the site where demolition occurs in a timely manner. In no event shall debris be used for fill material. 
(f)  Barricades, fencing and canopies. Where necessary to protect public health and safety, the director may require the erection of fencing, barricades or protective canopies around the perimeter of the demolition site. 
(g)  Working hours. No demolition work shall be conducted between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. unless previously approved by the director. 
(h)  Closing of streets. Streets, roadways and alleys adjacent to a demolition site may be closed only after approval by the director. The director shall, prior to approval of such closing, consult with the fire chief, police chief and director of city services. 
(i)  Disconnection of utilities. It is the responsibility of the owner or his agent to arrange the disconnection of all utilities to a demolition site prior to demolition. All water, sewer and gas lines shall be properly capped and sealed. Sewer lines shall be disconnected in accordance with the requirements established in title 7, chapter 4 of the city Code. 
(j)  Party walls. In the event the structure to be demolished has one (1) or more party walls, the applicant shall provide drawings sealed by a registered architect or structural engineer indicating the measures to be taken to support the adjacent structures after demolition. In the event adjacent structures do not require additional support, the architect or engineer shall provide a written statement stating such conclusion. The written consent of owners of adjacent buildings to install necessary shoring or bracing shall be provided. 
(k)  Biohazardous conditions.
