    It shall be unlawful for any person to mark, deface, scratch, climb or in any other manner injure, attempt to deface or alter the direction of any street sign or traffic-control device within the city. 
Cross reference- Interference with signs and signals, § 11-3-7. 
7-1-1.42. - Stakes on pavement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive iron or other stakes in any brick, stone, asphalt, concrete or other pavement within the city, except as otherwise expressly permitted by the director of public works or provided for by ordinance. 
7-1-1.43. - Defective or dangerous sidewalks; when nuisance. 
    Every sidewalk within the city which shall from breakage therein, natural wear or age become so worn or out of repair as to endanger the safety of persons passing over the same is hereby declared to be a nuisance; and any person who shall hereafter suffer or permit such nuisance to exist in front of or adjoining premises owned, occupied or controlled by him shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
7-1-1.44. - Abatement of dangerous sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any owner, occupant or person in control of any lot or premises abutting upon or adjacent to any sidewalk wherein exist any holes, loose planks or other defects, or when the same is deemed to be a nuisance, to repair such defects and abate such nuisance without delay. 
(b)  Whenever any owner is in default of the duty imposed by subsection (a) of this section, it shall be the duty of the director to repair such defects or abate such nuisance; and the city council may, by ordinance, provide for payment of the whole or any part thereof, and defray the cost thereof by special taxation of the lots or parcels of land adjoining such sidewalk. 
(c)  Whenever any person shall recover any judgment against the city because of injury resulting from such defects or nuisance, the owner, occupant or person in control of the abutting premises where such injury was sustained shall be liable to the city for the full amount of the damages and costs so recovered against the city. 
State Law reference- Construction and repair of sidewalks, 65 ILCS 5/11-84-1 et seq. 
7-1-1.45. - Penalty, generally. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, when no specific penalty is provided therefor, any persons violating such provision shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 46, 7-3-01) 
7-1-1.46. - Continuing violation. 
    Whenever any person shall be subject to a penalty as provided for in section 7-1-1.45, he may, in addition, be subject to a further penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) for every two (2) hours that he shall permit such violation to continue after being notified in writing to discontinue the same by the director of public works or any member of the police department. 
7-1-2. - USE OF SPACE UNDER STREETS 
7-1-2.1. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any space beneath the surface of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground within the city, or to construct or maintain any structure thereunder, without having first obtained a permit therefor from the director of public works. No such permit shall be issued except as provided in this section. 
7-1-2.2. - Permit application. 
    Application for the permit required by the preceding section shall be in writing to the director, and shall state specifically the location of the space desired, its length, breadth and depth, the use intended to be made thereof, and the structure to be built therein. 
7-1-2.3. - Bond required; when liability shall cease. 
(a)  Every applicant for the permit required in section 7-1-2.1 of this chapter shall file therewith his certificate of bond, in the sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), with sureties to be approved by the commissioner of accounts and finances. The bond shall be conditioned that the applicant, his heirs, successors and assigns, will indemnify, save and keep free and harmless the city, its officers and agents from any and all loss or damage or claim of damage arising from or out of the use of the space or structure therein mentioned, and for the maintenance of the street, alley, sidewalk or public way shall, at all times after such structure is completed or such space is covered, be safe for public use, and for the full and complete protection of the city against any and all litigation growing out of the granting of such permit, or anything done under such permit, during his ownership of the property, so long as the permit shall be outstanding, and for the faithful performance and observance of all the terms and conditions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any owner to whom a permit shall have been granted, who shall convey in fee the property to which the permit applied, may notify the director of public works, in writing, of the same, and shall furnish the director, in writing, the name and address of the purchaser thereof. Upon the giving of such notice in writing and furnishing the name and address of the purchaser, all liability under the bond theretofore given by such owner shall cease and determine, except as to acts happening or causes of action occurring prior to the giving of such notice. 
7-1-2.4. - When new bond may be required. 
    If, in the opinion of the city council, the sureties of any bonds given for any permit issued under this section have become insufficient, a new bond for such permit shall thereupon be filed with sureties to be approved by the council. 
7-1-2.5. - Transfer or assignment. 
    No permit issued under the provisions of this section shall be transferred or assigned, nor shall any right or privilege thereunder be transferred or assigned, without the written consent of the director of public works. 
7-1-2.6. - Revocation of permit. 
    If any person obtaining the permit required by section 7-1-2.1 shall at any time fail or neglect to comply with the provisions of this chapter, then such permit may be revoked by the director. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall preclude the city from revoking any permit issued under this section when the space described in such permit is needed for public use. 
7-1-2.7. - Special permit required where work interferes with pipes; deposit required; restoration of surface. 
(a)  The space so permitted to be used by virtue of any permit hereunder shall not be used in such a manner as to interfere with any sewer or water pipe or any other such improvement lawfully in the street, alley or public way, unless by the written permission of the director, especially granted therefor, and no such permit shall ever be granted until the applicant therefor has deposited with the director a sum of money sufficient in said director's judgment to defray the cost and expense of rebuilding or relaying such sewer or water pipe or public improvement, and making the necessary connections therewith. 
(b)  Every permittee disturbing any such sewer or water pipe, etc. shall, within ten (10) days after such disturbance, restore the same to such condition as will meet the approval of the director. When such sewer or water pipe, etc. is so restored by the applicant, the sum so paid to the director shall be refunded to such permittee. 
(c)  If the permittee shall fail to so restore such sewer or water pipe, etc. within ten (10) days after disturbing the same, then the director shall cause the same to be restored, and the cost thereof shall be paid out of the sum deposited by the permittee, 
7-1-2.8. - Spaces under sidewalks to be kept in good repair; free of snow, ice. 
    Every person using the space under any sidewalk in the city shall at all times keep such sidewalk in good condition and repair, clear and free from all snow, ice, dirt, filth or other constructions or encumbrances. 
7-1-3. - POLES, WIRES AND CONDUCTORS 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate and prevent the use of telegraph and telephone poles, the Telegraph Act (220 ILCS 55/4); authority to regulate small wireless facilities, poles, and accessories, the Small Wireless Facilities Deployment Act (Public Act 100-585). 
(Ord. No. 4397 , § 1, 6-19-18) 
7-1-3.1. - Permit to erect, maintain required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, maintain or use any pole, or to hang any line, wire or electric conductor of any description whatsoever thereon, within the city, without having first obtained a permit therefor, under a valid and existing ordinance of the city, from the director of public works, which permit shall be countersigned by the electrical inspector. 
    Small wireless facility poles and accessories or existing poles or structures, are governed by title 4, chapter 16.1 of this Code, including erecting and maintaining poles and accessories on those poles. Applications and issuance of permits for small wireless facility poles and accessories are governed by title 4, chapter 16.1 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4397 , § 2, 6-19-18) 
7-1-3.2. - Privileges granted to city. 
    All applications for permits to erect poles in the streets and alleys of the city shall provide that the city may use the poles to be so erected and may attach thereto such necessary crossarms, wires or other electrical service of the city, and no permit shall be issued by the director for the erection of such poles in which the application and permit does not provide for the privileges required by the city as herein contained. 
7-1-3.3. - Permit fees. 
    An annual fee of two dollars ($2.00) shall be charged for each pole issued hereunder for the erection of any poles, hanging of any lines, wires or electric conductors of any description whatsoever thereon, or for any laying of any underground electrical conduits or the placing of conductors therein. 
    Such fees shall be demanded by the director before he countersigns any such permit, and shall be paid to the city clerk. 
    Permit fees for small wireless facility poles and accessories are governed by title 4, chapter 16.1 of this Code, including erecting and maintaining poles and accessories on those poles. 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate use of space over streets, etc., and to require compensation therefor, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-8; authority to regulate small wireless facilities, poles, and accessories, the Small Wireless Facilities Deployment Act (Public Act 100-0585). 
(Ord. No. 4397 , § 3, 6-19-18) 
7-1-3.4. - Plans and specifications to be filed. 
    Every application for a permit to erect a pole within the city shall include therewith complete plans and specifications setting forth the location of the pole, purpose for which same is to be used, and the materials to be used in the construction thereof. 
    Applications and the issuance of permits for the erection of small wireless facility poles and accessories are governed by title 4, chapter 16.1 of this Code, including erecting and maintaining poles and accessories on those poles. 
(Ord. No. 4397 , § 4, 6-19-18) 
7-1-3.5. - Bond required. 
    Every applicant for a permit to erect, etc. any pole, etc. shall also file with the city clerk his certificate of bond in the penal sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), with sureties to be approved by the commissioner of accounts and finances, conditioned that the applicant, his successors, grantees, assigns or lessees will pay any and all rentals provided for by this section, or which may hereafter be assessed by the city council, for the use of any public space so occupied, and to indemnify, keep and save the city, its officers and agents free and harmless and to reimburse it or them on account of any and all damages of any kind or character arising from the construction, maintenance or operation of such pole, wire or conductor, and to further indemnify and reimburse all persons damaged or injured by reason of the acts of the applicant, his successors, grantees, assigns and lessees in the exercise of the rights and privileges granted under this section. 
7-1-3.6. - Supervision of construction. 
    Upon approval of the application and bond required herein by the city council, the applicant shall have the right, permission and authority to erect, maintain, etc. the pole, conductor, etc. according to the plans and specifications filed therewith, under the supervision of the city engineer, director of public works and director of city inspections, subject, however, to all provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city pertaining thereto. 
7-1-3.7. - Right of city to remove. 
    No permission or authority shall be given to any person to erect any poles for telegraph, telephone or utility purposes, or for the purpose of stringing thereon wires, cables or conveyors for the transmission of sound or signal or of heat, light or power, upon or along any street, alley or public way within the city except upon the expressed provision that such poles and conductors are to be and will be removed forthwith whenever the city council shall order such removal. 
7-1-3.8. - Right of city to order change. 
    The city reserves the right that, in the event that said city shall change the width or grade of any street, sidewalk or alley where such poles are placed, or when for any other reason the council shall deem it necessary or expedient that the location or erection of such poles, etc. shall be changed, or that the height of the wires should be changed or altered, it shall first notify the owner or lessee of such pole, etc. of their intention to require such change, and after allowing said owner or lessee an opportunity to be heard in regard to such change or alteration, shall then order and direct such alteration or change as it shall see fit. 
7-1-3.9. - Location and height of wires. 
(a)  Wires or conductors shall in no case be placed at a greater distance from the curb separating sidewalks from roadways than four (4) feet, except where crossing streets running transverse to the direction of the lines, when such crossing shall be made in the shortest straight line, or where making necessary connections with buildings and stations. 
(b)  In no case shall any wire or conductor be placed or hung at a height of less than eighteen (18) feet from the surface of any sidewalk or like public way, or less than twenty (20) feet from the surface of any street or alley. 
7-1-3.10. - Conductors to be laid so as not to impede traffic or passage upon sidewalks. 
    The method employed in laying conductors shall be such that it will at no time be necessary to remove so much of the pavement or to make such excavation as to materially impede traffic or passage upon any sidewalk or street during the operation of laying or repairing such conductors, except when crossing streets transversely, where it shall be permitted to remove the pavement for a width not exceeding two (2) feet, and in the nearest straight line from corner to corner. In no case during the general hours of passage and traffic shall passage be interrupted thereby for a longer period than one hour. 
7-1-3.11. - Supervision of laying of wires; maximum space for placing wires. 
(a)  The work of removal and replacement of the pavements in any street, alley or other public place in and through which the wire of any company shall be laid, shall be subject to like control and supervision. 
(b)  The space selected for placing such wires, in every case being limited as to direction and general position by the provisions of this section, shall not exceed two (2) feet in width by two (2) feet in depth. 
7-1-3.12. - Maintenance of poles. 
    Every pole in any public street, alley or sidewalk of the city used for the support of telegraph, electric light, telephone or other wires shall be kept and maintained in a sound and safe condition by the person using the same. 
7-1-3.13. - Weak, defective poles. 
    When any pole to which this section applies is found to be weak, decayed or unsafe for the purpose for which used, the director of public works shall notify the person owning or using such pole to forthwith remove such pole from the public streets and alleys. Any person who shall thereafter fail to remove such pole within five (5) days of said notice, unless otherwise expressly stated, shall be deemed to be in violation hereof, subject to the penalties provided in section 7-1-1.45 for each offense; and a like offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which such violation continues. For the purposes of this section, every such pole maintained in such condition shall be deemed to constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
7-1-4. - BRIDGES AND COVERED PASSAGEWAYS 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate use of space over streets, etc., and to require compensation therefor, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-8. 
7-1-4.1. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build or construct any bridge or covered passageway over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public property within the city without having first obtained permission from the city council in the manner provided in this section, and without complying with all provisions of this chapter. 
7-1-4.2. - Petition, plans, specifications to be filed. 
    Any person requesting the permit required by the preceding section shall file with the director of public works a petition together with complete plans and specifications, setting forth the location of the bridge or covered passageway, the purpose for which same is to be used, the materials to be used in the construction and the buildings or premises to be connected thereby. 
7-1-4.3. - Bond required. 
    The petitioner shall also file his certificate of bond in the sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) with securities to be approved by the city council, conditioned that the permittee, his successors, grantees, assigns or lessees will pay any and all rentals provided for under this section, or which may hereafter be assessed by the city, for the use of the space so occupied, and to indemnify, save and keep the city, its officers and agents harmless and to reimburse it or them on account of any and all damages of any kind or character arising from the construction, maintenance or operation of such bridge or covered passageway, and to further indemnify and reimburse all persons damaged or injured by reason of the acts of the permittee, his successors, grantees, assigns and lessees in the exercise of the rights and privileges granted by virtue of this section. 
7-1-4.4. - Supervision of construction. 
    Upon the approval by the city council of the petition and bond required hereunder, the petitioner shall have the right, permission and authority to construct the bridge or covered passageway, according to the plans and specifications filed with the petition, under the supervision of the city engineer, director of public works, and director of city inspections; subject, however, to all rules, regulations and ordinances now or hereafter in force in the city pertaining thereto. 
7-1-4.5. - Expenses of construction to be borne by permittee; location. 
    Any bridge or covered passageway constructed by authority of this section shall be constructed and maintained at the sole expense of the permittee, and shall be constructed not less than twenty (20) feet from the surface of the street, alley, sidewalk or other public property over which the same is built. 
7-1-4.6. - Annual rental fee. 
    For the use of the space so occupied by bridges and covered passageways constructed and maintained by virtue of this section, the permittee or owner thereof shall pay to the city clerk annually in advance the sum of ten (10) cents per square foot, for each and every floor or story constructed; provided, however, that such rentals shall not be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) annually, payable as hereinabove set forth. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 2. - EXCAVATIONS 
SECTION: 
DIVISION I. - IN GENERAL 

7-2-1. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation or opening in any street, alley, sidewalk, curb or other public place within the city without having first obtained a written permit therefor from the director of public works; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to persons making an excavation for the purpose of connecting any private drain or sewer with any public sewer, under a written permit from the director. 
7-2-2. - Deposit required. 
    Before any permit required by the preceding section shall be issued, the applicant therefor shall deposit with the city clerk a sum of money with respect to the type of pavement to be excavated, determined in accordance with the following schedule: 
Concrete pavement, 5 to 7 inches ..... $20.00 per sq. yd. Concrete pavement, 7 to 10 inches ..... 30.00 per sq. yd. Brick on concrete base ..... 36.00 per sq. yd. Brick on earth ..... 20.00 per sq. yd. Asphalt on concrete base ..... 30.00 per sq. yd. Asphalt or brick on concrete base ..... 30.00 per sq. yd. Six inches by twelve inches (6? × 12?) concrete curb ..... 10.00 per lin. ft.  
7-2-3. - Permit fee. 
    Before any permit required by section 7-2-1 of this chapter shall be issued, the applicant therefor shall deposit with the city clerk a permit and inspection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each permit requested. 
7-2-4. - Bond required. 
    No permit as provided for in section 7-2-1 of this chapter shall be issued until the applicant shall execute to the city and deliver to the city clerk his certificate of bond, as provided for in sections 7-1-2.3 and 7-1-2.4 of this Code. 
7-2-5. - Repair of excavation; how, when, default. 
(a)  Any person making or causing to be made any excavation or opening for any purpose in any street, alley or sidewalk or any curbing within the city, shall cause the same to be repaired. 
(b)  Such repairs shall be done as follows: The excavated material shall be replaced with trench backfill; the sub-base material shall be replaced in kind and thickness as existing and the surface replaced with high-early-strength Portland Cement pavement eight (8) inches thick having a minimum compressive strength of not less than thirty five hundred (3500) pounds per square inch and a minimum modulus rupture of not less than six hundred fifty (650) pounds per square inch at the age of three (3) days. 
(c)  Such repairs are to be completed within three (3) days after completion of the work for which the excavation was made, and shall be subject to the supervision and approval of the city engineer. 
(d)  Whosoever shall neglect or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall be deemed to be in violation thereof, subject to a penalty as provided in sections 7-1-1.45 and 7-1-1.46 of this Code; which penalty shall not be decreased or in any way affected by any sum of money deposited as required under section 7-2-2 of this chapter. 
(e)  In the event of such default, the director of public works may forthwith cause such repairs to be made and completed, the cost and expense thereof to be applied against the sum deposited as required under section 7-2-2 of this chapter. 
7-2-6. - Return of deposit. 
    Upon written certification by the director of public works that the excavation permitted under this chapter has been completed and the street, alley, sidewalk or curbing repaired to his satisfaction, the city clerk shall refund to the permittee the full sum of his deposit required under section 7-2-2 of this chapter; provided, however, that such permittee shall not be entitled to recover any amounts corresponding to costs and expenses incurred by the director under subsection (e) of section 7-2-5 hereof. 
7-2-7. - Liability of permittee. 
(a)  All persons permitted hereunder to make any excavation or opening in any street, alley, sidewalk, curbing or any other public place within the city and who, under the provisions of section 7-2-5 of this chapter are required to repair the pavement or curb thereafter, shall maintain all such excavations or openings in a safe condition from the time the permittee makes the openings until the permittee shall repair the pavement or curb, and the permittee shall be liable and responsible for any and all accidents or damages of any nature occasioned by any such excavation or opening until the same is repaired and the written approval of the director of public works is obtained. 
(b)  All such repairs shall be of such character that the pavement will be and remain in good repair and condition for a period of one year from and after the completion thereof. In case any sign of disintegration appears or any defects or depression occur within such period, except such as are without the fault of the permittee or his agents, such permittee shall be liable for and responsible to repair such defects and to put the pavement in a smooth, satisfactory and good condition. 
7-2-8. - Excavations left open; barriers, lights required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any contractor for public work, any officer or employee of the city or any other person making an excavation or placing any obstruction in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground or upon any lot or premises adjoining or bounded by any street, alley or sidewalk within the city to leave the same open and unprotected by barriers and lights as hereinafter provided, adequate to protect the safety of persons, vehicles or animals passing upon such public ways. 
(b)  All railings, fences or other barriers erected pursuant to this section shall in each case be erected and maintained subject to the satisfaction of the director of public works. 
(c)  Every such excavation shall be provided with a red light or lantern or other adequate warning signal at each approach to said excavation or obstruction, which can be easily seen from each direction. Such lights shall be of a type and in locations approved by the director, and shall be maintained in continuous operation at all times when said excavation is open or said obstruction present. 
7-2-9. - Removing earth without permission. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, remove or carry away, for private purpose, any earth, gravel, rock or sod from any street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground without the express permission of the city council, under a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each and every load so removed or carried away; and any officer of the city who shall use, sell or dispose of any such earth, etc. from any street, etc. for his own private gain or benefit shall be subject to a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 47, 7-3-01) 
DIVISION II. - DRIVEWAYS 

7-2-10. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
(a)  Driveway approach means any place improved for vehicular or pedestrian traffic on street rights-of-way which connects the traveled portion of the street with a driveway or pedestrian walkway. 
(b)  Driveway; nonresidential means any passageway for vehicle ingress or egress to private property, used in whole or in part for other than residence or dwelling house purposes. 
(c)  Driveway; residential means any passageway for vehicle ingress or egress to private property, used exclusively for residence or dwelling house purposes. 
(d)  Sidewalk means that portion of the street right-of-way between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians and generally separated from the curb or roadway surface by a utility strip or grassplot. 
7-2-11. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, build, erect, establish or maintain any driveway over, across or upon any public curbing, sidewalk or parkway within the city without having first obtained a permit therefor authorized by the director of public works. 
7-2-12. - Residential driveway; application for permit, fee, specifications, deposit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct, build, establish or maintain a residential driveway in the city shall make application to the director for a permit. Such application shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the location and dimensions of the proposed driveway, and whether, in the building thereof, it will be necessary to cut down or alter a street or curb or elevate or depress the existing grade of the walk or parkway. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued hereunder until the applicant therefor shall have paid to the city clerk the fee required under section 7-2-3 of this chapter, and in addition such deposit as may be required under section 7-2-2 of this chapter. 
(c)  No permit shall be authorized by the director unless the proposed driveway is to be constructed in conformance with the following limitations and all other applicable requirements of this chapter: 
(1)  Driveway widths measured at any point on the property line shall not exceed twelve (12) feet for a single driveway, or twenty (20) feet for a double or joint driveway. In the event the sidewalk is not separated from the curb by a utility strip or grassplot, then the point at which the above measurement is made will be determined by the director in accord with good engineering practices. 
(2)  A circular return connecting the driveway approach and the street may be used, except where the driveway crosses a curb line sidewalk. The minimum radius of return, when used, shall be three (3) feet and the maximum shall be seven (7) feet. No portion of the approach shall be constructed within six (6) feet of the property line extended. The director may waive this requirement but such waiver shall not permit the removal of curbing in front of adjoining property. 
(3)  The sidewalk portion of the driveway shall be of Portland cement concrete with a minimum thickness of six (6) inches. 
(4)  The approach shall be either six (6) inches of rock base with a one and one-half (11/2) bituminous surface, or a six (6) inches thickness of Portland cement concrete. 
7-2-13. - Nonresidential driveway; application for permit, fee, deposit, specifications. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct, build, establish or maintain a nonresidential driveway in the city shall make application to the director of public works for a permit. Such application shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the location and dimensions of the proposed driveway, and whether, in the building thereof, it will be necessary to cut down or alter a street or curb or elevate or depress the existing grade of the walk or parkway. 
    No permit shall be issued for any work to be done in or about the construction of driveways until plans and specifications therefor have been submitted to and approved by the director, who shall at all times keep on file in his office a copy of such plans and specifications. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued hereunder until the applicant therefor shall have paid to the city clerk the fee required under section 7-2-3 of this chapter and in addition such deposit as may be required under section 7-2-2 of this chapter. 
(c)  No permit shall be authorized by the director of streets unless the proposed driveway is constructed in conformance with the following limitations and all other applicable requirements of this chapter: 
(1)  Driveway widths measured at any point on the property line shall not exceed thirty (30) feet, with the following exceptions: 
a.  Where the distance from curblines to property line is less than seven (7) feet, the driveway width may be thirty five (35) feet at the property line and no return will be required. 
b.  Driveways designed for one-way operation to or from parking areas shall not exceed thirteen (13) feet in width at the property line. 
(2)  A circular return connecting the driveway approach and the street may be used for all driveways, except those across curb line sidewalks. The maximum radius of return, when used, shall be seven (7) feet. When constructing a depressed curb, the amount of curb opening allowed shall be computed, using the allowable return radius. 
(3)  No portion of a driveway approach shall be constructed within five (5) feet of the property line extended. The director may, upon due consideration for pedestrian safety and where unusual conditions prevail, waive or alter this requirement; provided, however, this shall not permit the removal of curbing in front of adjoining property. 
(4)  Where more than one driveway approach is to serve a single parcel of land, there shall be an island between the driveway approaches of at least ten (10) feet along the sidewalk. 
(5)  Where more than one driveway approach serves a single parcel of land, there may be no more than one such approach for every sixty five (65) feet or any fraction thereof, of frontage along the right-of-way line. 
(6)  The approach shall be of Portland cement concrete of a minimum depth of six (6) inches and where it adjoins the gutter line, shall be faced with a raised vertical lip of not less than one and five-eighths (1 5/8 ) inches, which shall be rounded off in finishing. 
(7)  The sidewalk portion of the driveway shall be of Portland cement concrete with a minimum thickness of six (6) inches. 
(8)  The right-of-way area adjacent to and between the driveway approaches shall not be surfaced with asphalt, concrete, bituminous cement binder pavement or gravel, unless the permittee shall construct a sidewalk in accordance with the provisions of sections 7-1-1.5 et seq. of this Code. 
(9)  To prevent any part of any vehicle using any parking area from projecting over or crossing the public sidewalk, except at points designated, there shall be installed on the property inside the property line a curb or other suitable barrier to be approved by the director. 
7-2-14. - Permit to increase width of approaches and cuts. 
    Any person desiring a driveway approach or curb cut of a greater width than provided for in this division, may apply for permission from the city council. 
7-2-15. - Certain restrictions; ramps, driveway approaches, drainage water. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any property to erect, or permit to be erected, any wooden or metal ramp from the gutter line to the top of the curb. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place dirt, ashes, drain pipes or other material in the gutter for the purposes of building up an approach for a driveway. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful, in the case of nonresidential driveways, to permit surface or roof drainage water to flow over that portion of the driveway that is on the public right-of-way. 
Cross reference- Drains across sidewalks prohibited, § 7-1-1.33. 
7-2-16. - Nonconformance to curb cut provisions. 
    In any case of nonconformance with the curb cut provisions of this chapter, where construction work such as widening, resurfacing or other substantial alterations or extensions are to be made, the improvements shall be designed so as to comply with these limitations. 
(1970 Code) 
7-2-17. - Locations where driveway approaches and driveways are prohibited. 
    No driveway approach nor any driveway, either residential or nonresidential, shall be located on or enter the public right-of-way from any of the following locations: 
(a)  Along the south side of Eckley Avenue beginning at the most westerly point of Outlot A of Ville Lumiere Subdivision as shown on a plat recorded in the office of the Tazewell County Recorder of Deeds at Book JJ, pages 145 and 146 and continuing thence along the south side of Eckley Avenue in a westerly direction to the intersection of Eckley Avenue with Fondulac Drive. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any public right-of-way by motor vehicle from any location where the location of driveways or driveway approaches is prohibited by this section. 
(Ord. No. 2706, § 1, 2-1-94) 
CHAPTER 3. - TREES AND SHRUBS 
SECTION: 
DIVISION I. - IN GENERAL 

7-3-1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Public street or public highway or public place or public park shall include, but is not limited to, any land which lies between the curbline of any street or highway and the lot line of the abutting premises, and which land is not actually in use for street or sidewalk purposes. 
7-3-2. - General authority of mayor. 
    The mayor or his authorized representative is hereby empowered to superintend, regulate and encourage the preservation, culture and planting of shade trees, plants and shrubs upon public highways and public parks in the city, and to direct the method and time of trimming the same; to advise, without charge, owners and occupants of lots regarding the kind of trees, plants and shrubs, and the method of planting best adapted to and most desirable on particular streets and public highways; and to take such measures as may be deemed necessary for the control and extermination of insects, pests and plant diseases which may injuriously affect trees, plants and shrubs that are now growing or hereafter may be growing on the public highways and parks of the city. 
State Law reference- Power of city to plant trees upon public property, 65 ILCS 5/11-72-1. 
7-3-3. - Planting in public parks; general requirements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to plant any shade or ornamental tree, plant or shrub in any public highway or park until the mayor shall have approved the kind, size and variety of the same and designated the location for planting the same. The mayor shall not approve the planting of, and no person shall plant, any tree upon any street or highway, except under the following conditions: 
(a)  That such tree is one (1) of the following varieties: green ash, althea, American elm, hackberry, Norway maple, sugar maple, Schwedler maple, mountain ash, column Norway maple, column linden, sycamore maple, hornbean, black maple, sweet gum, oak, flowering crab apple or ginkgo; 
(b)  That such tree is not less than forty-five (45) feet from every other tree, unless it is an American elm which shall be not less than sixty-five (65) feet from every other tree; 
(c)  That such tree is free from infectious disease; and 
(d)  That such tree, when planted, has a diameter of at least one (1) inch at a distance of one (1) foot above the ground level. 
7-3-4. - Required distance from public ways. 
    No person shall plant any tree on any premises abutting any alley, street, public way or highway unless the distance from the center of the trunk of such tree to the inside edge of the sidewalk is not less than six (6) feet. Trees covered under this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-5. - Required distance from sewer connections. 
    No person shall plant any tree other than one (1) of the varieties enumerated in subsection (a) of section 7-3-3 of this chapter within twenty (20) feet of any sewer connection. Trees covered under this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-6. - Trees obstructing public lamps and public utility lines; notice to owner. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, lessee or person in possession, charge or control of any premises upon which any tree is growing to permit the same to grow in such a manner as to obstruct or prevent in any way the light from any public lamp from falling upon any alley, street, public way or highway, or to obstruct or interfere with any public utility line, and it shall be the duty of the director of public works to notify such owner, lessee or person to forthwith trim such tree in such a manner as to prevent such obstruction. Trees covered under this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-7. - Minimum height of tree branches over streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall maintain upon any lot of which he is an owner or person in control any tree which is so located as to extend its branches over any alley, street, public way or highway, unless the same shall be kept so trimmed that there shall be a clear height of not less than twelve (12) feet above vehicular traffic and not less than nine (9) feet above all sidewalks, unobstructed by branches; and every such person shall remove all dead branches or stubs on such trees which are or may become a menace to persons or vehicles upon said public ways. Trees covered under this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-8. - Maximum height of hedges, bushes and shrubs. 
(a)  No person shall maintain any hedge, bush or shrub, or permit the same to grow or remain, along the sidewalk abutting his premises or within forty (40) feet of the nearest right-of-way line of any intersecting alley, street, public way or highway at a height greater than three (3) feet. Bushes covered under this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  No person shall maintain any hedge, bush or shrub, or permit the same to grow or remain, anywhere upon his premises which interferes with the clear view of traffic by drivers approaching the intersection. Bushes covered under this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-9. - Failure to trim or remove trees; notice; failure to obey notice; penalty. 
(a)  Whenever any person whose duty it is to trim or remove any tree, hedge, bush or shrub as provided in this chapter shall fail to do so, the city shall cause to be served upon such person notice requiring the same to be done forthwith; and if such person shall fail to cause such trees, etc., to be trimmed or removed within ten (10) days after the service of such notice, he shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense; and each day following the tenth day after service of such notice during which such person shall fail to trim or remove said trees, etc., shall be deemed to be a separate offense. 
(b)  Such notice may be served by delivering the same, or a copy thereof, to such owner or occupant, or by leaving the same at his usual place of business or abode; and in case such owner is a nonresident of the city, by mailing notice to his last known address and by posting a copy of the same in a conspicuous place upon the lot on or in front of which such trees, etc., may be located. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 48, 7-3-01; Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-10. - Trimming by the city; lien and personal judgment. 
(a)  In the event of the failure of an owner or person in control to trim or remove, any trees, hedges, bushes or shrubs as provided in this chapter within the time provided by notice served pursuant to the preceding section, such trees, etc., may be trimmed or removed by the city. 
(b)  The cost of trimming or removing the tree, hedge, bush or shrub shall be recoverable from the owner or person in control of the real estate and is a lien thereon. The lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes; provided, however, that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred the city shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by the city in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County. Upon payment of the cost of trimming or removing the tree, hedge, bush or shrub after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the city. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose. 
(c)  If the city's costs for trimming or removing the tree, hedge, bush or shrub are not paid, the director of planning and development may commence proceedings in the circuit court seeking a personal judgment from the owner or person in control of the subject property. The action authorized by this section shall be in addition to, and without waiver of any other remedies. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prevent and remove obstructions on streets and sidewalks, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-2. 
7-3-11. - WEEDS, ANNUAL PLANTS AND GRASSES 
7-3-11.1. - Permitting growth of weeds, annual plants or grasses over ten inches unlawful. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in control of any parcel of land to permit thereon the presence of weeds, annual plants, or grasses over ten (10) inches in length or height; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit the presence of trees, shrubs, cultivated vegetable plants or cultivated flower plants. 
(b)  The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day that a violation of this section shall continue. 
(Ord. 2401, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 2754, § 2, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 3292, § 49, 7-3-01) 
7-3-11.2. - Notice to abate weeds from lots with occupied structures. 
(a)  Whenever the owner or person in control of a parcel of land with an occupied structure fails to cut or destroy any weeds, annual plants or grasses over ten (10) inches in height or length, the director of buildings and inspections may cause the service, upon such owner or person, of a notice to abate a violation of weeds, annual plants or grasses. 
(b)  Notice to abate shall be given to the property owner or legal occupant by personal service, by certified mail, or by posting the notice in a conspicuous location on the property. The text of the notice shall contain a reference to the provision of the city Code alleged to have been violated, and may contain such other information with respect to the nature of the violation as the director deems advisable. 
(1)  Personal service may be obtained through delivery of the notice by a city employee or any person authorized by law to make personal service; 
(2)  Service may be obtained by certified mail addressed to the residence or usual place of business of the owner or person in control of the property; or 
(3)  Service by posting may be obtained by posting a sign in a conspicuous place near the main entrance of a structure on the property. The posted sign shall be at least fourteen (14) inches in height and eight (8) inches in width and at the top thereof in large letters shall state the words "notice to abate." It shall be unlawful for anyone to deface, tamper with or remove the "notice to abate" sign from the property where it is posted unless authorized by the director of buildings and inspections. 
(c)  If seven (7) days have passed since the personal service, mailing, or posting of the notice, and the owner or legal occupant of the property fails to remove the weeds, plants or grasses and bring the property into compliance with this section, a summons shall be issued to such individuals to appear before an administrative hearing officer, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 11 of title 1 of this Code. Service of summons shall be by: (1) personal service; or (2) certified mail and posting the summons in a conspicuous place on the property. 
(d)  The director of buildings and inspections may cause the cutting or destruction of such weeds, annual plants or grasses upon issuance of a ruling by the administrative hearing officer, pursuant to a written finding, decision, and order finding the owner or legal occupant of the property in violation of this section. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, whenever the owner or legal occupant of any parcel of land permits the presence thereon of weeds, annual plants or grasses over ten (10) inches in length or height after having previously been found in violation of this section by an administrative hearing officer within the same calendar year, no seven-day notice will be issued for subsequent violations prior to the issuance of a summons to appear before the administrative hearing officer. 
(Ord. 2601, 8-4-92; Ord. No. 2754, § 2, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 4187, § 30, 9-16-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2754, § 2, adopted March 19, 1996, deleted the provisions of former § 7-3-11.2, pertaining to settlement option and renumbered the remaining "7-11-3" designations. The provisions of former § 7-3-11.2 derived from Ord. No. 2601, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 1992. 
7-3-11.3. - Notice to abate weeds on vacant lots and on lots with unoccupied structures. 
(a)  The city shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city limits once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in March, April, or May of each year a notice informing all owners and persons in control of any vacant lot or any lot with an unoccupied structure that the growth of weeds, annual plants or grasses on any such lot is contrary to the ordinances of the city. The notice shall further inform the public that should the weeds, annual plants or grasses ever grow to more than ten (10) inches in length or height, the city may cut the weeds, annual plants or grasses, and the owner or legal occupant shall be liable to the city for its costs. This notice shall be a display advertisement. 
(b)  Should weeds, annual plants or grasses on any vacant lot or on any lot with an unoccupied structure ever grow to more than ten (10) inches in length or height, the director of buildings and inspections shall give notice of the violation by first class mail to the owner or last known taxpayer of the property, or by posting notice on the property in the manner provided for in section 7-3-11.2 above. If the weeds, annual plants or grasses are not removed or cut within seven (7) days of the mailing or posting of the notice, the director may cause the cutting or destruction of such weeds, annual plants or grasses without further notice. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 2, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 4187, § 31, 9-16-14) 
7-3-11.4. - Lien and personal judgment. 
(a)  The cost of cutting the weeds, annual plants or grasses from private property shall be recoverable from the owner or person in control of the real estate and is a lien thereon. The lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes, provided, however, that within one (1) year after such cost and expense is incurred the city shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by the city in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County. Upon payment of the cost of cutting the weeds, annual plants and grasses after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the city. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose. 
(b)  If the city's costs for cutting weeds, annual plants or grasses are not paid, the director of buildings and inspections may commence proceedings in the circuit court seeking a personal judgment from the owner or person in control of the subject property. The action authorized by this section shall be in addition to, and without waiver of any other remedies. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 2, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 4187, § 31, 9-16-14) 
7-3-11.5. - Combining notice. 
    The notice required by this section, whether it is given by personal service, certified mail, posting or publishing, may be combined with a notice to abate refuse. 
(Ord. 2401, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 2754, § 2, 3-19-96) 
7-3-12. - Removal, destruction of trees, shrubs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, cut down, break, deface, trim or in any way injure any tree, shrub, hedge, fruit, flower, plant, vegetable or anything which may be thereon for ornament or utility, standing in any street, alley or public place within the city except by written permission of the city council or the director of public works, or upon any private premises except with the written consent of the owner. 
(b)  Permits granted by the city shall state the work to be done and the time within which it is to be done. 
(c)  No person shall remove, destroy, etc., any such trees, etc., under any permit unless proper precautions approved by the director of public works are taken to insure the safety of the public while such work is being done. 
7-3-13. - Climbing trees. 
    No person shall climb any tree growing in any highway or park in the city, or walk upon the branches thereof, while wearing spurs unless such person is in the act of removing such tree. 
7-3-14. - Safeguarding of trees during construction. 
    In the erection, alteration, repair or removal of any building or structure, the owner thereof shall place or cause to be placed such guards around all nearby trees on the public highway as will effectually prevent injury to such trees. 
7-3-15. - Connecting wires to trees. 
    No person shall attach or connect any electric or other wire to any tree on a highway or park within the city, or permit any such wire to come in contact with any such tree. 
7-3-16. - Attaching signs to trees. 
    No person shall attach any sign, placard or poster to any tree growing in any public street or park. 
7-3-17. - Depositing stone, cement near tree. 
    No person without a written permit from the mayor shall place or maintain upon the ground in any street, park or parkway in the city any stone, cement or other material which shall impede free passage of water and air to the roots of any tree, without leaving an open space of ground not less than two (2) feet in width all around the trunk of such tree. Wherever there is no such open space about any tree in any street, park or parkway in the city, the director of public works may make such open space or cause the same to be made. 
7-3-18. - Poison ivy, etc. 
(a)  No owner, lessee or occupant, or agent, servant or employee of such owner, lessee or occupant, being in control of any lot, piece or parcel of land within the city shall knowingly allow, permit or maintain on any such lot, piece or parcel of land any growth of poison ivy or other noxious weed or plant, whereby the health of the public or of any person lawfully upon or passing by such lot, piece or parcel of land may be endangered, under a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day such poison ivy or other noxious weed aforesaid shall be allowed or permitted to be or remain growing upon any such lot, piece or parcel of land after notice by the health officer to such owner, lessee or occupant, or to such agent, servant or employee to remove, eradicate or destroy the same. 
(b)  Whenever the owner or person in control of any such premises fails to remove or destroy such poison ivy, etc., within a period of five (5) days after receipt of notice to so remove, the health officer shall cause such poison ivy, etc., to be destroyed, and any expense incurred by the city in so doing, in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per hour, shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 50, 7-3-01) 
State Law reference- Power of city to remove weeds at expense of owner of premises, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-6 and 5/11-20-7. 
7-3-19. - Permitting growth of barberis vulgaris. 
(a)  It is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to plant or permit the growth of, upon any premises, the bush of the species of tall, common or European Barberry, further known as Barberis Vulgaris, and its horticultural varieties within the city. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the department of health to cause to be served a notice in writing upon the owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, charge or control of any lot, building or premises in or upon which this bush may be found, requiring them or either of them to remove, destroy and carry the same away and off such premises within two (2) days. 
(c)  If the person so notified shall refuse or neglect to comply with such order within the time and in the manner specified, the department of health shall cause the abatement of such nuisance at the expense of the party responsible for or permitting the same. 
DIVISION II. - DUTCH ELM DISEASE AND EMERALD ASH BORER[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to control and eradicate Dutch Elm Disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-11. 

7-3-20. - Infected trees declared nuisances. 
    Trees of all species and varieties of elm, zelkova and planera affected with the fungus Ceratostomella ulmi, and ash trees infected with the emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis Fairmaire), as determined by laboratory analysis or a certified arborist of the Illinois Arborist Association, are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-21. - Trees suitable for beetle breeding; places declared nuisances. 
    Trees or parts thereof of elm, zelkova or planera in a dead or dying condition that may serve as breeding places for the European elm bark beetle, scolytus multistriatus, are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 3-4-08) 
7-3-22. - Keeping infected trees prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning property whereon any tree such as is mentioned in the two (2) preceding sections is situated, to possess, keep or preserve such tree. 
7-3-23. - Notice to remove; removal by city; lien upon property. 
    The mayor or his representative shall give to the owner of premises where a public nuisance described in sections 7-3-20 or 7-3-21 is found, written notice of the existence of such nuisance, requiring the removal and burning of the same within thirty (30) days following such notice, such removal and burning to be done under the direction and supervision of the mayor or his representative. Such notice shall also notify the owner that unless such nuisance is removed and burned in compliance with the terms thereon within such thirty-day period, the city will proceed with the removal and burning of such nuisance, and any expense incurred by the city in so doing shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens. 
State Law reference- Power of city to remove infected tree at expense of owner of premises, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-12; power to abate plant nuisance at expense of owner of premises, 505 ILCS 100/10. 
7-3-24. - Notice to remove; manner of service, substance. 
    The notice provided for in the preceding section shall be personally served upon or sent by registered mail to the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes for the last preceding year on the property, such notice to be delivered or sent not less than thirty (30) days prior to the removal of the tree or trees affected. The notice shall contain the substance of the provisions of this chapter, and identify the property, by common description and the tree or trees affected. 
7-3-25. - Duty to remove; nuisance after notice. 
    Upon service of notice pursuant to the preceding section, it shall become the duty of the person so served within thirty (30) days from such service to cause such tree or breeding place to be removed and burned under the direction and supervision of the mayor or his representative. 
7-3-26. - Option to request city action. 
    In lieu of removing and burning a nuisance pursuant to the preceding section, the person charged with such removal and burning may request that the same be done by the mayor or his representative. 
7-3-27. - Nuisances on public property. 
    Trees growing upon public property constituting nuisances under this chapter, shall be removed at the expense of the city. 
7-3-28. - Enforcement of division. 
    The city council or the mayor may appoint any officer or other person to carry out the intent or purpose of this chapter, who shall act under their specific direction or as he may be instructed thereto by the mayor, and the mayor is hereby empowered to carry out and execute the terms of this chapter, and to aid him in fulfilling the same he may require members of the police or fire department to assist therein. 
7-3-29. - Right of entry. 
    In the enforcement of this chapter, the mayor or his representative may enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for purposes of inspecting any trees, shrubs, weeds or plants thereon, and may remove such specimens as are required for purposes of analysis to determine whether or not the same are infected or noxious. 
7-3-30. - Hindering enforcement officers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the mayor or his representative from entering upon private property for the purposes of performing his duties under this chapter, or to otherwise interfere with the mayor or his representative in the lawful performance of his duties under the provisions of this chapter. 
DIVISION III. - PENALTIES 

7-3-31. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or opposes the enforcement of, any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and for each subsequent offense such person shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 51, 7-3-01) 
7-3-32. - Separability of penalties. 
    The penalty provided in section 7-3-31 shall not be construed as precluding any other penalty or costs provided elsewhere in this chapter. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 4. - SEWER REGULATIONS 
SECTION: 

7-4-1. - IN GENERAL 
7-4-1.1. - Policy and purpose. 
    This chapter contemplates the regulation and supervision of the construction, installation, alteration and repair of sewers, house sanitary connections and house storm drains; the regulation of the character of discharge into and use of sewers and appurtenances; the prohibition of acts relating to sewers, cesspools, septic tanks and the like which tend to contaminate any water supply or any watercourse or tending to injure or damage the sewer system within the city or which tend to be prejudicial or detrimental to the health of the residents of this city. 
7-4-1.2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
(a)  Person shall mean any and all persons, natural or artificial including any individual, firm, company, municipal, or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity. 
(b)  Sewage or Wastewater shall mean the spent water of a community. From this standpoint of course, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and storm water that may be present. 
(c)  Industrial wastes shall mean any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
(d)  Stormwater means that portion of rain, snow or sleet which flows off over the surface of the ground, streets and structures into sewers and drainage channels or into low points. 
(e)  Domestic sewage or sanitary sewage means the waste or discharge from toilet or other household plumbing fixtures, wash water and dish water, interior basement drainage, and other dirty water from place of human residence, but not including industrial wastes, or wastes from business or commercial buildings or institutions (such as laundromats, gas stations, restaurants, hospitals, etc.). 
Domestic sewage is considered to have a BOD concentration less than two hundred twenty five (225) mg/l and a suspended solids concentration less than two hundred seventy five (275) mg/l. 
(f)  Groundwater means water which is contained in or flows through the ground. 
(g)  Solid wastes included garbage, ashes, rags, manure waste, household food, offal and other solids. The term "ashes" as herein employed shall include coal, coke, wood and the residium resulting from the combustion of any material or substance, and includes soot, cinders, slag and charcoal. 
(h)  Sewer means any outside conduit, pipe or structure, designed to serve two (2) or more properties within the city, used for conveying sewage of any kind, and shall include all manholes, intercepting chambers, pumping plants and other appurtenances thereto within the city. 
(i)  Separate sanitary sewer or sanitary sewer means a sewer intended to carry domestic sewage and such industrial wastes as may be permitted, without the admixture of stormwater. 
(j)  Storm sewer means a sewer which is intended to carry storm and surface water, but no domestic or sanitary sewage, or industrial wastes. 
(k)  City sewer or sewer of the city means any sewer constructed, under construction or maintained within the city and shall include all manholes, intercepting chambers, pumping plants or other appurtenances, thereto. 
(l)  Combined sewer shall mean a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, storm, surface and groundwater drainage. 
(m)  Sewerage (noun) means the works comprising the complete system of sewers, connections and drains within the city, including pumping stations, manholes and appurtenances thereof necessary to the collection, treatment or disposal of sewage, including the sewage treatment plant. 
Sewerage (adjective) means having to do with the collection, treatment or disposal of sewage. 
(n)  House sanitary connection or house connection or building sewer means the conduit or pipe for conveying domestic sewage from residences, human habitations, institutions, stables, garages, business buildings or industries to the connection to a sewer. 
(o)  House storm drain or house drain or building drain means a pipe or conduit which is used to conduct surface, storm, ground, roof and yard drainage away from any building. 
(p)  Definitions related to federal government: 
Federal act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of Amendments of 1972 (Pub. L. 92-500) and (Pub. L. 93-243). 
Administrator means the Administrator of the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
Federal grant shall mean the U.S. Government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by Title II Grants for Construction of Treatment Works of the Act and implementing regulations. 
(q)  Definitions related to state government: 
State act means the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970. 
Director means the Director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
State grant shall mean the State of Illinois participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act and for making such grants as filed with the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois. 
(r)  Definitions related to local government: 
Ordinance means this ordinance. 
City means the City of East Peoria. 
Approving authority means the Superintendent of the Wastewater Treatment Division, Department of Public Works, City of East Peoria. 
Superintendent shall mean superintendent of the wastewater treatment division. 
(s)  NPDES permit means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the administrator, or, where appropriated by the director, after enactment of the Federal Water Pollution Control Amendments of 1972, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to Section 402 of the Federal Act. 
(t)  Clarification of word usage: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissible. 
(u)  Definitions related to wastewater and its characteristics: 
Effluent criteria are defined in any applicable "NPDES permit." 
Water quality standards are defined in the Water Pollution Regulations of Illinois. 
Unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
PPM shall mean parts per million by weight. 
Milligrams per liter shall mean a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 g of the constituent in 1,000 ml of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
Suspended solids shall mean solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial wastes, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in "Standard Methods." 
BOD (denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at 20°C, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
pH shall mean the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in "Standard Methods." 
Standard methods shall mean the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
Floatable oil is oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
Population equivalent, as defined in section 7-4-6.2(b), is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. 
Slug shall mean any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
Major contributing industry shall mean an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: 
(1)  Has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average workday; or 
(2)  Has a flow greater than ten (10) percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; or 
(3)  Has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307 (a) of the Federal Act; or 
(4)  Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
(v)  Definitions on treatment: 
Pretreatment shall mean the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
Wastewater treatment works shall mean an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant." 
(w)  Wastewater facilities shall mean the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse. 
(x)  Definitions on user class and user classification: 
User shall mean any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group that discharges sewage to the wastewater treatment works of East Peoria. 
User class or user classification shall mean the type of user as defined herein and as described in section 7-4-6. 
Residential user shall mean any user of the treatment works not classified as an industrial user or excluded as an industrial user as provided for in this section. 
Industrial user shall mean any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions: 
(1)  Division A-Agriculture, Forestry, and Fishing. 
(2)  Division B-Mining. 
(3)  Division D-Manufacturing. 
(4)  Division E-Transportation, Communications, Electric, Gas and Sanitary Services. 
(5)  Division I-Services (such as laundromats, car washes, restaurants, hospitals, gas stations, etc.). 
A user in the divisions listed may be excluded if it is determined by the superintendent that it will introduce primarily segregated domestic waste or wastes from sanitary conveniences. 
Control manhole shall mean a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a "control manhole" is to provide access for the city representative and/or representatives of the Federal and State Environmental Protection Agencies to sample and/or measure discharges. 
(y)  Definitions related to types of charges: 
Wastewater service charge shall be the charge per quarter levied on all users of the wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in section 7-4-6 and shall consist of the total or the basic user charge, a minimum charge, the debt service charge and a surcharge, if applicable. 
User charge shall mean a charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of operation and maintenance. 
Basic user charge shall mean the basic assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system. 
Minimum charge shall mean the minimum assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system. 
Debt service charge shall be the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding and shall be computed as described in section 7-4-6. 
Surcharge shall mean the assessment in addition to the basic user charge minimum charge and debt service charge which is levied on those persons whose wastes are greater in strength than the concentration values established in section 7-4-6. 
Replacement shall mean expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
Useful life shall mean the estimated period during which the collection system and/or treatment works will be operated and shall be twenty (20) years from the date of start-up of any wastewater facilities constructed with a state grant. 
Sewerage fund or water and sewerage account are the principal accounting designations for all revenues received in the operation of the sewerage system and shall have the same meaning in this chapter. 
(z)  Miscellaneous definitions: 
Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
Watercourse shall mean a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
7-4-1.3. - Wastewater treatment division created. 
    There is hereby established a department of the city which shall be known as the wastewater treatment division. 
7-4-1.4. - Superintendent of wastewater treatment division; office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of superintendent of the wastewater treatment division. The superintendent of the wastewater treatment division shall at all times act under the direct control of the director of public works. Such superintendent shall be the head of the wastewater treatment division and shall have charge of all property and equipment pertaining thereto, and supervision over all officers and employees therein. 
7-4-1.5. - Superintendent's powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of the wastewater treatment division: 
(a)  To conduct tests thereon; 
(b)  To keep records of actions taken and examinations, inspections and tests made; 
(c)  To make a monthly report of his acts and doing to the city council; 
(d)  To advise the public, when requested, in the matter of the regulations relating to the sewerage system; and 
(e)  To enforce all provisions of this chapter. 
7-4-1.6. - Revocation of permit or registration. 
(a)  The registration of any sewer contractor or the permit to perform any sewer construction work, as required in this chapter, shall become void whenever the registrant or permittee shall refuse or neglect within ten-days' time after written notice thereof to make such necessary corrections to the sewer work, either in workmanship or material, as shall have been ordered by the director of public works. This time period may be extended by the director upon a proper showing of adequate cause by the builder. 
(b)  Such permit or registration shall become void if such permittee or registrant shall permit the use of his name by another person or persons for the purpose of obtaining a permit or registration to perform any sewer work. 
7-4-1.7. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or opposes the enforcement of, any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and for each subsequent offense such person shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 52, 7-3-01) 
7-4-1.8. - Separability of penalties. 
    The penalties provided in sections 7-4-1.6 and 7-4-1.7 of this chapter shall not be construed as precluding each other or any other penalties and costs provided elsewhere in this chapter. 
7-4-2. - CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS, GENERALLY 
7-4-2.1. - Sewer contractors; registration, bond, fee.
