(a)  Any person who desires to engage in or who shall hereafter at any time engage in the business of the construction, alteration or repair of any sewer, sanitary connection or storm drain within the city shall, before commencing such work, make application to the city clerk for registration as a sewer contractor, and shall deliver to the clerk his certificate of bond, with two (2) sureties to be approved by the council in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), payable to the city, conditioned that such person shall indemnify and save harmless the City of East Peoria, its officers and employees, of and from all liability for damages to persons or property by reason of or resulting directly or indirectly from the construction, alteration, maintenance or repair by such person of any sewer, sanitary connection or storm drain, or any work or act of omission or commission incidental thereto, or in connection therewith; conditioned further upon the conformance by such person with all provisions of this Code with respect to such work; and conditioned further upon the restoration by such applicant of any street, alley, sidewalk or pavement disturbed by him, so as to leave the same in as good condition as before the work was commenced; provided, however, that any owner or occupant of a single-family residence or duplex dwelling shall not be considered a sewer contractor for the purposes of this section. 
(b)  Upon approval of the said bond by the council, the clerk shall forthwith issue to such applicant a certificate of registration to operate as a sewer contractor within the city. No registration shall be complete until the applicant shall pay to the clerk an annual registration fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00). 
    Registration shall be valid until the first April 30 immediately following issuance of the certificate. 
(1970 Code; Ord. 1945, 7-19-83) 
7-4-2.2. - Construction of sewer, house sanitary connection, house storm drain; permit required, application. 
(a)  No sewer of any kind, public or private, house sanitary connection nor house storm drain shall be constructed, altered or repaired, nor shall any connection of any sewer, house sanitary connection or house storm drain to any sewer, public or private, be constructed, altered or repaired without first having obtained from the city clerk a permit therefor. 
(b)  There shall be three (3) classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service, 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes, and 
(3)  For private sewage disposal. 
In any case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city, (reference appendix 1). The permit application shall be signed by the owner of the premises on which the proposed work is to be done and shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. A permit fee and connection charge of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a residential or commercial building construction sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. A permit fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for an alteration or repair sewer permit shall be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed, if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. 
(d)  All details concerning the construction of any sewer, house sanitary connection or house storm drain, or appurtenances thereto, shall be subject to the approval of the said superintendent. 
(e)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(f)  Application forms:

(1970 Code; Ord. 1945, 7-19-83; Ord. No. 3228, § 1, 5-16-00; Ord. No. 3639, § 1, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 3901, § 10, 5-13-10) 
7-4-2.3. - Bond. 
    Every applicant shall be required to post bond with the city clerk as provided in section 7-4-2.1 of this chapter; provided, however, that if the application specifies that the work therein described is to be performed by a person registered in the city as a sewer contractor under the provisions of section 7-4-2.1, the bond hereinabove required for such permit shall not be required as a condition to the issuance of such permit. 
7-4-2.4. - Change in plans. 
    Any changes or modifications in the proposed work shall be considered as new work and no such changes or modifications shall be installed or made without a supplementary permit issued therefor, subject to the same terms and conditions as hereinabove required. The fee for such supplementary permit shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
7-4-2.5. - Workmanship. 
    All workmanship in connection with the construction of any sewer, house sanitary connection or house storm drain or in connection with the capping of a lateral during demolition shall be of such character as to fully secure the results sought to be obtained by all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 2, 7-17-01) 
7-4-2.6. - Discontinuance of work. 
    Any person to whom a permit shall have been issued and who shall neglect, refuse or fail to make good any defect or fault in any work done or materials used thereunder, within ten (10) days after written notice thereof from the superintendent, shall not be permitted to do any further or additional work of constructing any sewer, connection, drain or appurtenances, or capping any sewer during demolition until such defect or fault has been corrected to the satisfaction of the superintendent of the wastewater treatment division. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 3, 7-17-01) 
7-4-2.7. - Expiration of permit. 
    Whenever any work for which a permit has been issued hereunder is not commenced within six (6) months after the issuance of said permit, or if the work is not satisfactorily prosecuted after its commencement, such permit shall be considered as having expired and shall be null and void. 
7-4-2.8. - Capping of lateral sewers during demolition. 
    Any lateral sewer serving any structure being demolished within the city shall be capped in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Any person performing such a demolition must obtain a permit from the superintendent which authorizes the capping of the lateral and also provide a bond in the manner and amount provided in this chapter. Application for a permit shall be made on a form prescribed by the superintendent. A permit fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be payable upon application. 
(2)  The lateral shall be capped as close to the main as is possible without disturbing any sidewalk or pavement located above the lateral. 
(3)  All capped laterals must be inspected by the superintendent prior to back filling. If the owner or a contractor acting on behalf of the owner back fills an excavation which contains a capped lateral before the completion of an inspection by the superintendent, then the owner and the contractor shall be jointly responsible to remove back filled material in order to permit an inspection. The cost of removing back fill to permit an inspection shall be borne by the owner and the contractor employed by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 3303, § 4, 7-17-01) 
7-4-3. - SEWER CONNECTIONS 
7-4-3.1. - Notice. 
(a)  In every case of a proposed sewer connection, notice shall be given to the superintendent specifying the time and place where the work is to commence. Such notice shall be in writing and given at least one (1) full day prior to the commencement of the work. 
(b)  All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the Federal Act and more stringent state and local standards. 
(c)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
7-4-3.2. - Sewer connections. 
(a)  All connections with any sewer fifteen (15) inches or smaller shall be made by means of a "Y" or "T" branch or other special fitting provided in such sewer for that purpose. 
If a connection to a sewer must be made at any place where a "Y" or "T" branch has not been placed, where feasible, a "Y" fitting shall be placed in the main sewer in the following manner: A section of sewer pipe shall be removed from the main sewer by breaking it into pieces, care being taken not to break, disturb or injure the adjacent pipe. The "Y" fitting shall then be inserted without chipping or breaking the pipe or branch where possible; where not possible, the upper half (when in position) of the bell on the run of the "Y" branch to be inserted and the upper half of the nearest adjacent bell on the existing pipe in the trench shall then be carefully removed and the "Y" branch inserted wrongside up and revolved to bring the branch to the side it is intended for, with the broken part of the bell up. The joint shall then be cemented in the proper manner, the broken parts of the bells being well rounded over with a liberal amount of cement mortar or other approved material. 
(b)  Connections to a sewer may also be made by inserting in the sewer a standard saddle fitting. Such a fitting shall be one designed for that purpose and shall not be improvised from the bell end of a straight length of pipe. Before cutting the hole in the sewer for the saddle fitting, the sides and bottom of the length of pipe in which the hole is to be cut shall be strengthened by a layer of concrete not less than three (3) inches in thickness at any point. The hole in the pipe shall be carefully marked and chipped or pinched out; the saddle placed so that no part projects into the pipe and carefully mortared into position. Sections of pipe shall then be fitted into the saddle to form a riser and all such pieces of pipe which are vertically over the sewer shall be encased in a shaft of concrete having a thickness about the pipe of not less than three (3) inches. The shaft shall firmly rest on the block of concrete encasing the sewer pipe in which the connection was made. The concrete shaft shall be poured into a form of light sheet metal or stove pipe which form shall be left in place as the trench is backfilled. The earth backfill brought up uniformly on all sides to prevent lateral loads upon and the possible breaking of the shaft. 
7-4-3.3. - Quality of materials. 
    All materials used in any sewer, house sanitary connection or house storm drain, or part thereof, shall be free from defects. 
(1)  PVC gravity sewer pipe. All PVC sewer pipe shall conform to the standard specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials (ASTM) and unless otherwise indicated, shall have a standard dimension ratio (SDR) of 26. PVC sewer pipe shall have a bell and spigot joint with rubber gaskets. 
(2)  Cast iron pipe. All cast iron pipe and fittings used for sewers, house connections or drains shall be coated with asphaltum or coal-tar pitch and shall conform to the standard specifications for extra heavy cast iron soil pipe and fittings of the American Society for Testing Materials, or shall conform to the latest standard specifications for cast iron water pipe of the American Water Works Association. 
(3)  Prohibited materials. Not permitted for use in any sewer connection or construction are pipes known as composition, "slip seal" or fiber type. 
(Ord. No. 3228, § 2, 5-16-00) 
7-4-3.4. - Joints and connections. 
    All joints shall be made with rubber gaskets which are free from defects and installed in a workman-like manner. 
(Ord. No. 3228, § 3, 5-16-01) 
7-4-4. - HOUSE SANITARY CONNECTIONS AND HOUSE STORM DRAINS 
7-4-4.1. - Function of house connections and drains. 
    The domestic sewage from residences, human habitations, institutions, stables, garages, business buildings and industries shall be conveyed from said structures in a conduit or pipe herein termed a "house sanitary connection." The connection shall extend to a public separate sanitary sewer, if such a sewer serves the property. No storm, surface or groundwater shall be permitted to enter this house sanitary connection. 
7-4-4.2. - Independent connections and drains. 
    Each residence, institution or business building shall have its own separate house sanitary connection. A house sanitary connection shall not be permitted to serve two (2) such adjacent residences or other units except under abnormal circumstances, and then only with the written permission of the superintendent. 
7-4-4.3. - Materials and connections. 
(a)  The house sanitary connection shall be of six-inch PVC pipe or six-inch cast iron pipe; except that within five (5) feet of the exterior wall of a building it shall be of cast iron pipe, schedule 40 pipe or schedule 80 pipe. 
(b)  All underground pipes, when within four (4) feet or less of the surface of the ground under a driveway shall be of cast iron pipe, or of PVC pipe having an envelope of concrete of a mix of 1:2:4 or better and at least three (3) inches in thickness. 
(c)  Where a connection or drain is laid at less than five (5) feet from the exterior wall of a building, or in the ground where it will be subjected to vibration or settlement, cast iron pipe, schedule 40 pipe or schedule 80 pipe shall be used. Where the ground is of sufficient solidity for a proper foundation or where special supports or a secure foundation are provided, PVC pipe or cast iron pipe may be used. 
(d)  Each new building sewer shall include a clean out pipe. The clean out pipe shall be located on the exterior of the structure served by the building sewer as close as practicable to the point where the building sewer passes under or through the foundation of the structure served by that building sewer. The clean out pipe shall be constructed of the same material as the building sewer at the point where the clean out pipe intersects the building sewer and shall have a diameter of six (6) inches. Each clean out pipe shall extend to a point not less than six (6) inches, nor more than eighteen (18) inches above the surrounding finished grade and shall be equipped with a cap sufficient to prevent access by children or animals. 
(e)  Any existing building sewer which is repaired through excavation of access to the building sewer and which is not already equipped with a clean out pipe shall as part of the repair be equipped with a clean out pipe. The clean out pipe shall be located on that part of the building sewer exposed by excavation as close as practicable to the point on the exterior of the structure served by the building sewer where the building sewer passes under or through the foundation of the structure. The clean out pipe shall be constructed of the same material as the building sewer at the point where the clean out pipe intersects the building sewer and shall have a diameter of six (6) inches. Each clean out pipe shall extend to a point not less than six (6) inches and not more than eighteen (18) inches above the surrounding finished grade and shall be equipped with a cap sufficient to prevent access by children or animals. 
(Ord. No. 3228, § 4, 5-16-00; Ord. No. 3633, § 1, 8-2-05) 
7-4-4.4. - Laying. 
(a)  No house sanitary connection shall be laid parallel to or within three (3) feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. The house sanitary connection shall be laid at a sufficient depth to protect it from frost. 
(b)  All sewer and drain pipes shall be laid carefully in the trench in a straight line and on a straight grade. Where deviation from a straight run is necessary, it shall be made with a curve or other acceptable fitting. 
(c)  In the bottom of the trench a groove shall be cut for each hub, in order to give the pipe a solid bearing for its entire length, and the soil backfill shall be well rammed on either side of the pipe. 
(d)  The sanitary connection to buildings, other than those built on a slab, shall enter the building through the basement wall. Gravity connections are acceptable for fixtures only on floors which are entirely above finished grade. Any fixture connected below grade shall be connected to a pumping system which is both approved by the director of public works and designed for use in building sanitary systems. 
(Ord. No. 3228, § 5, 5-16-00) 
7-4-4.5. - Pipes to be closed. 
    The ends of all pipes not to be immediately connected shall be securely stopped by a cap or plug specifically designed for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 3228, § 6, 5-16-00) 
7-4-4.6. - Backwater. 
    Where the plumbing system of a building may be subjected to backflow of sewage or water, suitable provision shall be made to prevent overflow into the building by the installation of satisfactory backwater valves or other satisfactory means. 
7-4-4.7. - Protection of ditches or trenches. 
    All ditches or trenches shall be protected in a manner which complies with all applicable state and Federal regulations including, without limitations, those promulgated by OSHA. 
(Ord. No. 3228, § 7, 5-16-00) 
7-4-5. - INSPECTIONS AND TESTS 
7-4-5.1. - Inspections. 
(a)  All piping and appurtenances of any sewer or house sanitary connection shall be inspected by the superintendent of the wastewater treatment division to insure compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and that the installation and construction of the system are in accordance with the approved plans and specifications. 
(b)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The superintendent or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processed, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway of facilities for waste treatment. 
(c)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in section 7-4-5.1(b), above, the superintendent or duly authorized employees of the city, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in section 7-4-7.3(h). 
7-4-5.2. - Notification. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner or his agent to notify the superintendent of the wastewater treatment division orally, by telephone or in writing, not less than eight (8) working hours before the work is to be inspected and to have a time set for inspection. 
(b)  If the superintendent finds on inspection that the work or materials are not satisfactory, the owner or his agent shall remedy said defect and then renotify as above and arrange for a reinspection. 
(c)  If the superintendent or his authorized representative fails to appear within twenty four (24) hours of the time set for an inspection, the inspection shall be deemed to have been made. 
7-4-5.3. - Condemned materials. 
(a)  The presence of any material, other than that approved, near the site of the work shall be sufficient cause for condemning part or all of the work. 
(b)  Whenever inspection discloses material which does not conform to the requirements of this chapter, such material shall be condemned and the owner or his agent shall proceed no further with the use of such material. 
(c)  Condemned materials not yet installed shall be removed forthwith from the site of the work and materials already installed shall be removed within ten (10) days following the condemnation thereof, or as the superintendent may direct; and the work shall be reinspected. 
7-4-5.4. - Defective work. 
    Whenever inspection discloses work which does not conform to the requirements of this chapter, such defective work shall be corrected within ten (10) days following such inspection, or as the Superintendent may direct; and the work shall be reinspected. 
7-4-5.5. - Certificate of approval; fees. 
(a)  Whenever any sewer construction work is approved by the superintendent, the director of public works shall issue a certificate of approval, but no certificate shall be issued unless all sewer construction is in strict conformity with the rules and regulations of this chapter. 
(b)  Before any certificate of approval shall be issued, all fees, including an inspection fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per construction inspection and fifteen dollars ($15.00) per alteration or repair inspection due the city under the provisions of this chapter shall be paid to the city. 
(Ord. 1347, 1-3-78; Ord. 1945, 7-19-83; Ord. No. 3228, § 8, 5-16-00) 
7-4-5.6. - Unapproved use of sewers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make use of any new, reconstructed or repaired sewer work, or any part thereof, for which a certificate of approval has not been issued by the director of public works. In addition, the superintendent shall proceed forthwith to disconnect such newly constructed, reconstructed or repaired sewer work in operation, but for which no certificate of approval has been issued, and he may enter upon any public or private property for the purpose of such disconnection. 
7-4-6. - WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES AND INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY 
7-4-6.1. - Wastewater service charges. 
(a)  Sewer rates established. There shall be and there are hereby established quarterly rates and/or charges for the use and service of the sewage system of the city as described herein. 
(b)  User classification. There is hereby established the following user classification schedule: 
Class 
Designation Description I Those users who generate domestic waste as defined in section 7-4-1.2(e) and 7-4-6.1(g) and who are regular metered water customers of the city. II Those users who generate domestic sewage as defined in section 7-4-1.2(e) and 7-4-6.1(g) and who are not regular metered water customers of the city but are regular metered water customers of another water district. III Those users who generate domestic sewage as defined in section 7-4-1.2(e) and 7-4-6.1(g) and who are not regular metered water customers of the city or another water district; i.e., they use their own water source. IV Those users who generate wastewater that possesses strength characteristics (as measured by BOD and SS) that are in excess of that defined herein and who are not required to pretreat their wastes before discharging into the city's sewer system. V Those users who generate wastewater that possesses strength characteristics (as measured by BOD and SS) that are in excess of that defined and who are required to pretreat their wastes before discharging into the city's sewer system.  
(c)  Basis for wastewater service charges. The wastewater service charge for the use of and for services supplied by the wastewater facilities of the city shall consist of a basic user charge for operation and maintenance plus replacement, a debt service charge, a minimum charge, and a surcharge, if applicable. 
    The debt service charge shall be computed as described in (1) below. 
    The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters for wastes having the following normal concentrations: 
(1)  A five (5) day, twenty (20) degree centigrade biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of two hundred twenty five (225) mg/l or less. 
(2)  A suspended solids (SS) content of two hundred seventy five (275) mg/l or less. 
It shall consist of operation and maintenance costs plus replacement and shall be computed as follows: 
a.  Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the wastewater facilities including a replacement fund for the year, for all works categories. 
b.  Estimate wastewater volume. 
c.  Compute cost per one thousand (1,000) gallons for normal sewage strength. 
A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed the normal concentrations for BOD (less than two hundred twenty five (225] mg/l) and SS (less than two hundred seventy five mg/l). The surcharge will be based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters for all wastes which exceed the two hundred twenty five (225) mg/l and two hundred seventy five (275) mg/l concentration for BOD and SS, respectively and shall be computed as follows: 
(3)  Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the wastewater facilities including a replacement fund for the year, for all work categories. 
(4)  Proportion the estimated costs for all facilities categories by volume, suspended solids, and BOD if possible. 
(5)  Compute cost per one thousand (1,000) gallons allocable to BOD and SS removal. 
(6)  Compute surcharge costs per one thousand (1,000) gallons for wastewaters in excess of normal sewage strength for BOD and SS. 
The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be reviewed annually by certified public accountants for the city in their annual audit report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in debt service or a change in operation and maintenance costs including replacement costs. 
(d)  Measurement of flow. The volume of flow used for computing basic sewer user charges and surcharges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of one thousand (1,000) gallons; provided, however, that the volume of flow passing through an auxiliary meter installed as hereinafter set forth in this section shall be subtracted from the metered water consumption for the purpose of determining basic sewer user charges. 
(1)  Those users who are classified as class II or III may install and maintain, at their expense, water meters of a type approved by the superintendent of the wastewater treatment division for purposes of determining the volume of water obtained from other sources. If such a meter is already installed, then bimonthly water consumption figures to the nearest one thousand (1,000) gallons shall be provided by the user to the city or should be made readily accessible to the city by the utility providing the water. 
(2)  Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharge may be required by the superintendent if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records. 
(3)  Metering devices for determining the volume of waste which are installed shall be installed, owned, and maintained by the person making the installation. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is cancelled, without the consent of the superintendent. 
(4)  For the purpose of determining the amount of water purchased by a customer which does not pass into the sanitary sewer system, an auxiliary water meter may be installed. An auxiliary meter shall be installed in such a fashion that in the opinion of the superintendent, water flowing through such meter is not likely to pass into the sanitary sewer system. Auxiliary meters shall be purchased, installed and maintained at the sole expense of the customer. Auxiliary meters shall be equipped with a remote register mounted in a location accessible to meter readers. Prior to use for billing purposes, an auxiliary meter installation must be inspected and approved by a representative of the water department. In order to defray the additional cost of administration, there shall be in addition to all other charges, a bimonthly administration fee of four dollars ($4.00) with respect to such auxiliary meter. Persons taking a credit against metered water consumption for water passing through an auxiliary meter shall not be entitled to a credit against their sewer use charges as elsewhere provided in this chapter for those persons having swimming pools. 
(e)  Debt service charge. A debt service charge, CD, of $0.00 (zero) per one thousand (1,000) gallons to each user of the wastewater facility of the city is hereby established. The parameter CD is determined as described in subsection 7-4-6.1(i). 
(f)  Basic user rate schedule: 
(1)  There shall be and there is hereby established a minimum charge for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the city. Until August 1, 2017, a minimum bimonthly charge of seventeen dollars and twenty-eight cents ($17.28) shall be applied to all users whose water consumption or wastewater generation does not exceed three thousand (3,000) gallons per two-month period. On August 1, 2017, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to twenty (20.0) percent of such bimonthly charge. On August 1, 2018, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to fifteen (15.0) percent of such bimonthly charge. On August 1, 2019, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to eleven (11.0) percent of such bimonthly charge. On August 1, 2020, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to ten (10.0) percent of such bimonthly charge. On August 1, 2021, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to ten (10.0) percent of such bimonthly charge. On August 1, 2022 and on each August 1 thereafter through August 1, 2043, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of such bimonthly charge. On August 1, 2044, the city clerk shall lower the minimum bimonthly charge to forty-five dollars and twenty-eight cents ($45.28). On August 1, 2045 and on each August 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust the minimum bimonthly charge by adding to the bimonthly charge in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of such bimonthly charge. 
Rate Schedule 
The following rate schedule shall be applied to users in class designations I, II, Ill, IV and V whose bimonthly water consumption or wastewater generation exceeds three thousand (3,000) gallons. 
a.  Until August 1, 2017, the rate, CU, shall be five dollars and seventy-six cents ($5.76) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used as measured by the city, plus the debt service charge, CD. On August 1, 2017, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to twenty (20.0) percent of such rate, CU. On August 1, 2018, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to fifteen (15.0) percent of such rate, CU. On August 1, 2019, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to eleven (11.0) percent of such rate, CU. On August 1, 2020, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to ten (10.0) percent of such rate, CU. On August 1, 2021, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to ten (10.0) percent of such rate, CU. On August 1, 2022 and on each August 1 thereafter through August 1, 2043, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of such rate, CU. On August 1, 2044, the city clerk shall lower the rate, CU, to fifteen dollars and nine cents ($15.09). On August 1, 2045 and on each August 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust the rate, CU, by adding to the rate, CU, in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of such rate, CU. 
b.  A flat rate charge for nonmetered users will be established based on an assumed consumption of fifteen thousand (15,000) gallons of water bimonthly; such charge will be computed at the same rate as established in paragraph (a) of this section. 
c.  A flat rate charge for nonmetered users who are sixty-two (62) years of age or who are married couples in which one (1) spouse is sixty-two (62) years of age or older will be established based on an assumed consumption of six thousand two hundred sixty-five (6,265) gallons of water bimonthly; such charge will be computed at the same rate as established in paragraph (a) of this section. 
Editor's note- Subsection (f) was amend by Ord. No. 4323 that states an effective date of July 31, 2017.

7-4-6.2. - Industrial cost recovery. 
(a)  Industrial cost recovery required. Each industrial user shall pay that portion of any state grant which has been obtained by the city for the financing of the construction of wastewater treatment works allocable to the treatment of the wastewater from such user. 
(b)  Determination of industrial population equivalent. An industrial user's portion of any state grant shall be based on the population equivalents attributable to wastewater of such user tributary to the wastewater treatment works of the city. 
    The population equivalents shall be determined as follows:

BOD;sub \sub; = 
Average 12 month prior year's wastewater BOD concentration from user i in mg/l. 
BOD = 
Average prior 12 month wastewater 5-day BOD concentration of treatment works influent, in mg/l and 
bod = 
5 day per capita BOD, in lbs. BOD/capita/day. 
(3)  SS population equivalent: PE SS 
N I PE SS = ( M SS;sub \sub; × Q;sub \sub;) × 8.34 + (ss × 10 6 ) i = 1  
N I ss = [(SS × Q) - M SS;sub \sub; × Q;sub \sub;] × 8.34 + (DP × 10 6 ) i = 1  
Where N I , Q;sub \sub;, Q and DP are defined as in (1) above, 
SS;sub \sub; = 
Average 12 month prior year's wastewater SS concentration from user i in mg/l, 
SS = 
Average prior 12 month wastewater SS concentration of treatment works influent in mg/l, and 
ss = 
Per capita SS, in lbs. SS/capita/day. 
(4)  If the information necessary to compute the per capita parameters q, bod and ss is not available, the following values may be used unless otherwise specified by the superintendent. 
q = 
100 gallon/capita/day, 
bod = 
0.17 lb. BOD/capita/day, and 
ss = 
0.20 lb. SS/capita/day. 
(c)  Cost per capita. The dollar cost per capita, CSTPC, shall be determined as follows: 
CSTPC = Cost/[DP+1/3 (PE BOD + PE SS + PE Q )] 
where cost = 
Portion of any state obtained for financing of construction of wastewater treatment works allocable to treatment of industrial wastes, 
DP = 
Design year domestic population, 
PE BOD  = 
Design year industrial population equivalent based on 5-day BOD, 
PE SS  = 
Design year industrial population equivalent based on SS, and 
PE Q  = 
Design year industrial population equivalent based on volume. 
(d)  Cost for industrial user. The cost to be recovered from an industrial user, COST;sub ..... sub;, shall be determined as follows: 
COST;sub \sub; = CSTPC × 1/3 × (PE BOD i + PE SS i + PE Q i 
where PE BOD i  = 
Population equivalent based on user i's 5-day BOD, 
PE SS i  = 
Population equivalent based on user i's suspended solids, and 
PE Q i  = 
Population equivalent based on user i's wastewater volume. 
(e)  Charge for industrial cost recovery. Each year during the industrial cost recovery period, each industrial user of the treatment works shall pay the cost recovery amount determined as above in (d) for such industry, divided by the recovery period. Where an industry is connected to a public sewer after the start-up of the facilities constructed under a state grant, such industry shall only pay its portion of the state grant for each quarter remaining in the recovery period. Such industry will not be required to pay for those quarters of the recovery period prior to connection to a public sewer. 
(f)  Length of industrial cost recovery period. The industrial cost recovery period shall be equal to the useful life of the treatment works which shall be thirty (30) years from year of construction. 
(g)  Payments and billing periods for industrial cost recovery. For the purpose of industrial cost recovery, the year shall be divided into quarterly periods, said periods to begin on the first day of July, October, January, and March, and all industrial users of the city shall pay the cost as determined in (d) above for industrial cost recovery and billing shall be made quarterly on the fifteenth day of the month immediately following the expiration of the quarterly period, for which service has been supplied, and such charge shall be payable within thirty (30) days after rendition thereof, and in the event such bills are not paid within said thirty (30) days, a service charge of five (5) percent shall be added thereto. 
(h)  Delinquency and termination of service. In the event the charges for industrial cost recovery are not paid within thirty (30) days after the rendition of that bill, then such service charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter such delinquent charge shall constitute a lien upon the real estate for which such sewer services were supplied. The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed each quarter to file sworn statements showing such delinquencies in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County, Illinois, and the filing of such statements shall be deemed notice of a lien for the payment of such charges for sewer service. If the delinquency in the payment of the recovery cost continues for a period of more than thirty (30) days, the sewer service shall be discontinued. 
(i)  Time of first payment. The initial payment made by an industrial user which is connected to a public sewer after the start-up of the treatment works constructed with a state grant shall be made by the next regular due date as defined above in subsection (g) and shall be equal to one quarter of the amount as determined as described in subsections (d) and (e) above. 
(j)  Adjustment of charge due to strength of volume changes. If there is a change in the strength and/or volume introduced into the treatment works by an industrial user as determined by the previous year's records, the city may adjust the users portion of any state grant accordingly. 
(k)  Adjustment of charge due to plant improvement utilizing state grant funds. If there is any expansion of upgrading of the treatment works utilizing a state grant, each existing industrial user's share shall be adjusted accordingly. 
(l)  No charge for unused or unreserved capacity. Any industrial user's portion of any state grant shall not include any portion of the grant amount allocable to unused or reserved capacity. 
(m)  Commitment for increased use. An industrial user's portion of any state grant shall include allowance for the cost of any firm commitment to the city for any increased use by such user. 
(n)  Payment to the State of Illinois required. The city shall retain fifty (50) percent of the amounts recovered from industrial users. The remainder, together with any interest earned thereon, shall be returned to the State of Illinois Anti-Pollution Fund on an annual basis. 
(o)  Disposition of retained amounts. Eighty (80) percent of the retained amounts, together with interest earned thereon, shall be used solely for the eligible costs of the expansion or reconstruction of treatment works associated with the project and necessary to meet the requirements of the Federal Act and the State of Illinois. The city prior to commitment of the retained amounts shall obtain written approval of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency for any expansion or reconstruction. The remainder of the retained amounts may be used for such expenditures as the city deems appropriate. 
(p)  Investment of retained amounts required. Pending use, the grantee shall invest the retained amounts for reconstruction and expansion in: 
(1)  Obligations of the U. S. Government; or 
(2)  Obligations guaranteed as to principal and interest by the U.S Government or any agency thereof; or 
(3)  Shall deposit such amounts in accounts fully collateralized by obligations of the U.S. Government or by obligations fully guaranteed as to principal and interest by the U.S. Government or any agency thereof. 
(q)  City Clerk of East Peoria responsibility. The Clerk of East Peoria shall maintain the necessary records for determination of user share of the cost and shall provide the billing and collection services as required by subsection (h) above. 
(r)  City of East Peoria Treasurer responsibility. City of East Peoria Treasurer shall be responsible for the investment and expenditure of all monies collected for industrial cost recovery in accordance with subsections (n), (o), and (p) above. 
(s)  Monitoring required. The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of water and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special conditions for discharge established by the city or regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge. 
    The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the city but no less than once per year the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the Federal, state, and local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the city at such times and in such manner as prescribed by the city. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analyses and reporting required by the city. At such times as deemed necessary the city reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service. 
(Ord. 1347, 1-3-78) 
7-4-6.3. - Deposit required. 
    Deposits for sewer service shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of section 7-5-4.3 of the City Code. Deposits collected as provided in said section 7-5-4.3 shall be used when necessary to pay delinquent wastewater treatment charges due under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2260, 4-19-88) 
7-4-6.4. - Liability of owner, occupant and user. 
    The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the sewer services of the city shall be jointly and severally liable for the payment of the sewer service on such premises, and the sewer service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the sewer services are jointly and severally liable therefor to the city. 
(Ord. 1347, 1-3-78) 
7-4-6.5. - Wastewater facilities assessments. 
    Certain persons applying to tap-in or make any connection with the mains of the wastewater system shall be subject to a wastewater facilities assessment representing payment by the applicant for a share of the capital cost of the wastewater system constructed over the years with revenues collected from users. The imposition and amount of wastewater facilities assessments shall be determined by this section 7-4-6.5. 
(a)  Certain subdivisions with four or more lots. Except as otherwise provided in this section 7-4-6.5, the owner of any property which: 
(1)  Is subdivided after November 15, 1988, in accordance with the provisions of the East Peoria Subdivision Code; and 
(2)  Is subdivided into four (4) or more lots, any of which are to be served by wastewater main extensions to be constructed at the expense of the subdivider; and 
(3)  Has not been previously subject to an assessment under the provisions of Article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code for the installation of wastewater mains or other components of the wastewater system; 
shall be subject to a wastewater facilities assessment in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each acre of land represented on the plat of subdivision. Payment of any such assessment shall be made prior to the execution and delivery of the plat of the subdivision. 
(b)  Certain individual lots. Except as otherwise provided in this section 7-4-6.5, upon application for a new wastewater service connection for a building or property, the applicant and/or the owner of any of the following classes of property shall pay to the city a wastewater facilities assessment in the amount of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00) per connection. The classes of property subject to such assessment are as follows: 
(1)  Any lot created by subdivision after November 15, 1988, of any parcel, which subdivision creates three (3) or fewer lots; or 
(2)  Any lot created by the subdivision of any parcel completed after November 15, 1988, which subdivision, regardless of the number of lots created, is served entirely by wastewater mains installed by someone other than the subdivider; or 
(3)  Any lot annexed to the city after November 15, 1988; or 
(4)  Any lot which, regardless of when created or annexed, will be served by connection to a wastewater main installed by: 
a.  Any private person other than the owner of the lot or a predecessor in interest to the owner of the lot; or 
b.  The city's wastewater department; or 
c.  Special assessment under Article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code which assessment was not levied against the lot in question; or 
(5)  Any other lot which has not through special assessment under Article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code or through prior payment of consideration to the city or through installation of wastewater mains or other appurtenances directly contributed to the provision of wastewater mains capable of serving the parcel in question. 
(c)  Proof of prior payment. Any person asserting exemption from wastewater facilities assessments because of prior payments of special assessments under Article 9 of the Municipal Code or because of installation of wastewater mains at the expense of the applicant or a predecessor in interest or for any other reason shall have the burden of producing written receipts or other documentary evidence demonstrating to the sole satisfaction of the city that such exemption is justified. 
(d)  Installment payment of assessments. Provided that the city in its sole discretion determines that the security is adequate, a wastewater facilities assessment due under the terms of this section 7-4-6.5, may be paid in not more than five (5) equal annual installments of principal, the first of which is due no later than six (6) months following the date of application for service together with interest on the principal balance remaining unpaid from time to time at a rate of not less than nine (9) percent per annum. Accrued interest shall be payable on the date of each payment of principal. Installment obligations shall be evidenced by promissory not secured by a mortgage on the premises served by the new wastewater service. The city may in its discretion permit the subordination of any such mortgage to one or more other mortgages on the premises served by the new wastewater service. 
(e)  Discretionary waiver of assessments. The city may in its sole discretion reduce or waive a wastewater facilities assessment under the following circumstances: 
(1)  As an inducement to business enterprises considering a location in East Peoria; provided, however, that no wastewater facilities assessment shall be reduced under the provisions of this subsection to a level less than fifty (50) percent of that otherwise applicable and then only under circumstances where the proposed facility is reasonably anticipated to create at least ten (10) permanent, full-time jobs within eighteen (18) months of the date of application; or 
(2)  Under circumstances where the imposition of a mandated wastewater facilities assessment would be manifestly unjust. 
(f)  Costs of extension and other charges. The provisions of this section contemplate the tap-in to existing mains without the necessity of any extension by the city. In the event any main is extended for the benefit of one or more parcels of real property, the foregoing provisions of this section shall not prohibit the assessment of additional charges representing the cost of extending any such main for the benefit of such parcel or parcels, as such cost is determined by the director of public works. 
(g)  Equitable sharing of costs by owners of benefitted properties. Under certain conditions, the owner or owners of property may bear the entire cost of extending sanitary sewer mains to serve property being developed by such owner or owners under conditions where such extension may secondarily benefit other property which has not yet been developed. Under such conditions, the city council may as a condition precedent to permitting connections from the secondarily benefitted property to such mains require the owner(s) of the secondarily benefitted property to directly or indirectly pay a fee to the person or persons who constructed the main. The fee paid shall equal the benefit received by the secondarily benefitted property as determined by the director of public works. 
(Ord. 2304, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 2908, § 2, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3639, § 2, 10-18-05) 
7-4-6.6. - Delinquent charges; lien. 
(a)  Whenever the charges for sewer service or other charges assessed pursuant to this chapter are not paid by the due date, such charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter the city shall have a continuing lien upon the premises and real estate upon or for which sewer service is provided. 
(b)  Every such lien shall, upon compliance with the conditions hereinafter set forth, become and be prior and superior to the rights and interest of creditors, encumbrances, purchasers and other parties in interest in the premises and real estate. 
(c)  A ten (10) percent charge per month shall be added to all delinquent charges for sewer service. 
(Ord. 2581, 5-5-92) 
7-4-6.7. - Affidavit; recording. 
(a)  Whenever a bill for sewer use charges, benefits or other charges provided for in this chapter remains unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been rendered, the city clerk shall file with the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County, State of Illinois, a statement of lien claim verified by the affidavit of himself or other officer of the city having knowledge of the facts. The statement shall contain a sufficiently correct description of the lot, lots or tracts of land to identify the same, the balance due after allowing all credits, the date upon which such amount became delinquent and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount, as well as for all charges for sewer service or other services in connection therewith supplied subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(b)  No such lien shall be defeated to the proper amount thereof because of an error or overcharge on the part of the city, nor shall any such lien be defeated upon proof that such sewer service was provided to or contracted for by a tenant of the premises or occupant thereof other than the owner. 
(c)  The failure of the clerk to record such lien claim, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid sewer charges, as provided in this chapter. 
7-4-6.8. - Enforcement. 
(a)  If payment shall not be made as provided in this chapter, any amount due for sewer service, benefits, or other charges provided for in this chapter when the same becomes due, the city may file or cause to be filed a complaint in the Circuit Court of Tazewell County for a foreclosure of such lien, or, upon becoming a defendant in any pending suit affecting the premises or real estate, an answer to the complaint in the nature of an intervening petition or a cross-complaint, and the city may proceed in its corporate name to foreclose such lien in like manner and with like effect as provided by statutes of the State of Illinois in foreclosure of mortgages on real estate. Any decree rendered in the court may be enforced and collected as other decrees or judgments in the same court. 
(b)  The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the city, in the Circuit Court of Tazewell County or in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which a bill for sewer use charges has remained unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been rendered. 
(c)  The remedy provided in this section for the collection of delinquent sewer use, charges or benefits shall not be construed to abridge or in any manner interfere with the right and power of the city to enforce a collection thereof by any other action or as otherwise provided in this chapter, but the remedy herein provided shall be taken and held as an additional means to enforce payment of such delinquent water rates, charges or benefits. 
(d)  Expenses incurred by the city for the purpose of collecting delinquent service charges, delinquent facilities assessments or other delinquent fees payable pursuant to this chapter shall be assessed as a supplemental service charge. All owners, occupants and users of the premises provided with service with respect to which such a delinquency exists shall be jointly and severally liable for the payment of expenses of collection. Expenses of collection to be assessed as a supplemental service charge under authority of this subsection include, without limitation, attorneys fees incurred by the city for the purpose of collecting any delinquent amounts. 
(Ord. No. 3474, § 1, 9-3-03) 
7-4-6.9. - Disconnection of sewer service. 
(a)  Whenever any of the following charges or assessments are not paid when due, to wit: 
(1)  Wastewater service charge imposed under the provisions of this chapter; or 
(2)  Wastewater facilities assessment imposed under the provisions of this chapter; or 
(3)  Assessment for the improvement or extension of any sewer which assessment has been imposed under the provisions of Article 9 of Illinois Municipal Code; or 
(4)  Any other charges imposed or provided for in this chapter; 
then any building sewer originating on property from which the charges were generated or which is subject to such assessments may be disconnected from the city's wastewater facilities in manner hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  Whenever any of the aforementioned charges or assessments are not paid by the due date therefor, the city clerk, director of public works or the wastewater superintendent shall issue written notification that all delinquent charges or assessments are due within twenty (20) days of the date of such notification and, further, if such delinquent charges or assessments are not paid within such twenty (20) day period, the city shall forthwith disconnect such service in the manner provided by law. If such delinquent charges or assessments are not paid within the aforesaid twenty (20) day period, then the city clerk, director of public works or the wastewater superintendent shall issue a second written notification that sewer service will be disconnected ten (10) working days after the issuance of the aforesaid second notice unless payment has been made within such ten (10) day period. If at the conclusion of the ten (10) day period following the issuance of the second notice the delinquent charges or assessments have not been paid, then the city shall forthwith disconnect such sewer service at a convenient location near the point where such service connects to the city's sewer main. All notifications required in this section shall be in writing and shall be served on the person who applied for water service at the location in question or in the event water service is not supplied by the city at that location, then to the last known occupant of the premises and, in addition, said notification shall be served on the person paying real estate taxes on the property in question in the last preceding year in which real estate taxes were paid. Such notices may be served in the following manner: 
(1)  By personal service; or 
(2)  With respect to the applicant for water service or the occupant of the premises, in the event water service is not supplied by the city, by regular mail addressed to such applicant or occupant at the address last known to the city clerk; or 
(3)  With respect to the person paying real estate taxes in the last preceding year, by regular mail at the address at which the bill for such taxes was mailed. 
(c)  Sewer service which has been disconnected for nonpayment shall not be restored until: 
(1)  All delinquent charges or assessments are paid in full. 
(2)  The cost to the city of disconnecting the sewer service is reimbursed to the city. 
(3)  A sewer connection permit is duly issued by the department of public works to a duly licensed contractor of the city in the manner prescribed in this chapter. 
Service shall be restored by the owner, occupant or other interested person at the sole cost and expense of such person. 
(d)  Upon the disconnection of sewer service, the department of public works shall notify the Tazewell County Health Department and the Department of Planning and Development of the aforesaid disconnection. 
(Ord. 1966, 2-7-84; Ord. No. 2698, § 1, 2-1-94) 
7-4-6.10. - Access to records. 
    The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized representatives shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the city which are applicable to the city system of user charges or industrial cost recovery for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to insure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state grant. 
7-4-6.11. - Notice of rates; effective date of rates. 
(a)  Notice of rates. A copy of this chapter properly certified by the city treasurer, shall be filed in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of the charges of the sewerage system of said city on their properties. However, failure to file a copy of the ordinance codified in this section, as herein authorized shall not affect the validity of any rate or other charge established from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  Effective date of rates. The rates and service charges established for user charges in section 7-4-6.1 and for industrial cost recovery established in section 7-4-6.2 shall be effective as determined from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2908, § 3, 7-2-96) 
7-4-6.12. - Revenues. 
    All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewerage account of the sewerage fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the city treasurer separate and apart from his private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the city and all of said sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the city treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the City Council of East Peoria. 
    The city treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in the account of the fund designated as the sewerage fund of the city. Said treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by statute of the Revised Cities and Villages Act, effective January 1942. 
7-4-6.13. - Accounts. 
    The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the sewerage system. 
    In addition to the customary operation statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater facilities, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service charges under the waste cost recovery system and capital amounts required to be recovered under the industrial cost recovery system do in fact meet these regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following: 
(1)  Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for current fiscal year. 
(2)  Billing data to show total number of gallons billed. 
(3)  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year. 
(4)  Number of users connected to the system. 
(5)  Number of nonmetered users. 
(6)  A list of users discharging nondomestic wastes (industrial users) and volume of waste discharged. 
7-4-6.14. - Recovery of the cost of certain improvements through the imposition of supplemental user fees. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, a "neighborhood improvement" is an improvement to the wastewater system made by the city for the purpose of facilitating the treatment of wastewater generated primarily by a specific user or group of users or primarily within a confined geographic area. 
(b)  Whenever it becomes necessary for the city to construct a neighborhood improvement, the city may in its discretion require the payment of a one-time supplemental user fee to cover all or a portion of the cost of such improvement in the manner provided by this section. 
(c)  If the director of public works concludes that a supplemental user fee should be charged for the purpose of paying all or any portion of the cost of a neighborhood improvement, the director shall provide written notice of the supplemental user fee directed to the person, if any, billed for wastewater service provided to each benefited premises at the address for such person shown on billing records maintained by the city and to the address at which real estate taxes for each benefited premises were most recently mailed. Such notice shall disclose the total amount of the supplemental user fee and the distribution of that fee against each benefited user or owner. 
(d)  Any person receiving notice of the imposition of a supplemental user fee may appeal the determination to impose the fee. Any such appeal shall be submitted in writing, shall explain the basis for the appeal and shall be delivered to the director of public works within fifteen (15) days after notice of the imposition of the fee was mailed to the person submitting the appeal. Any such appeal shall be adjudicated by the commissioner having supervisory authority over the combined water and sewer system in accordance with the procedure established at section 7-5-4.16 of this title. 
(e)  Each supplemental user fee imposed under authority of this section shall be due and payable upon the first to occur of the following events: 
(1)  A benefited user utilizes that portion of the wastewater system which includes the neighborhood improvement; or 
(2)  A building permit is issued for the construction of improvements on a benefited parcel which will include a connection to the wastewater system; or 
(3)  Fee simple title to a benefited parcel is conveyed subsequent to imposition of the supplemental user charge. 
If a supplemental user fee imposed under authority of this section is not paid when due, the remedies for delinquent user fees established elsewhere in this chapter shall apply. In addition, no new connection to the wastewater system will be permitted from a benefited parcel with respect to which a supplemental user fee has been imposed until the fee has been paid in full. 
(f)  The director of public works shall cause notice of the final amount of any unpaid supplemental user fee to be recorded in the Office of the Tazewell County Recorder of Deeds and indexed against each parcel benefited by the neighborhood improvement. 
(g)  As provided by section 7-4-6.5 of this title, the owner of the benefited premises, the occupant thereof and the user of sewer services are jointly and severally liable for any supplemental user fee imposed under authority of this section. 
(Ord. No. 3899, § 1, 2-16-10) 
7-4-7. - USE AND PROTECTION OF THE SEWER SYSTEM 
7-4-7.1. - Purpose of sanitary sewer system. 
    The separate sanitary sewer system of the city has been designed and built to carry away domestic sewage and the industrial and commercial wastes as permitted and has not been designed to carry stormwater, surface water or groundwater and any act which shall cause any storm or surface water or groundwater to be conveyed to the sanitary sewers shall be directly contrary to the provisions of this chapter, and is strictly prohibited. 
7-4-7.2. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  All property owners within the City of East Peoria, Tazewell County, Illinois, are required to attach any operating human waste disposal systems on their property to available lateral sanitary sewer mains, in such a manner that no sewage is discharged except into said mains. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, "available lateral sanitary sewer mains" shall mean lateral sanitary sewer mains located within two hundred (200) feet of any property line describing the lot or tract in question and which empty into a disposal plant approved by the State of Illinois. Property subject to an easement which permits or provides access to such a lot or tract shall be considered to be part of the lot or tract for purposes of identifying the property lines of the lot or tract. Where a lateral sanitary sewer main lies within two hundred (200) feet of any property line describing the lot or tract in question but the building to be served lies more than two hundred (200) feet from the lateral sanitary sewer main, then such lateral sanitary sewer main shall not be considered an available lateral sanitary sewer main within the meaning of this section if the city council determines by resolution that all of the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  The building will be connected to an alternative sewage disposal system which is constructed and operated in accordance with regulations adopted from time to time by the Tazewell County Health Department; and 
(2)  The proposed alternative sewage disposal system will not in the opinion of the city engineer adversely affect public health; and 
(3)  The estimated cost of attaching the building to be served to the closest lateral sanitary sewer main exceeds the cost of an alternative sewage disposal system by a factor of more than two (2). 
Any such resolution which is adopted by the city council may impose such conditions as the city council deems necessary for the protection of the public. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to persons who bring their property into compliance with the requirements of this section within eleven (11) months of the passage of this chapter, and maintain said property in compliance with said requirements thereafter. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to persons who bring their property into compliance with the requirements of this section within twelve (12) months after the date of completion of available lateral sewer mains, if there are no available lateral sanitary sewer mains for the property in question at the time of passage of this section, provided that said property is maintained in compliance with said requirements thereafter. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section "date of completion of available lateral sanitary sewer mains" shall mean the date upon which the City Council of the City of East Peoria certifies that said mains are completed and ready for use. 
(f)  Notwithstanding subsections (c) and (d) of this section, discharge of human waste at any time in such a manner or location so as to create a health hazard shall be a violation of this section, said violation to be subject to the penalties of this section. 
(g)  The discharge of sewage in violation of any of the provisions of this section shall constitute and is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance. 
(h)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(i)  No septic tank or cesspool now existing or hereafter constructed shall be connected in any way, directly or indirectly, to the public sewer system. 
(j)  No building permit for the construction of any new dwelling house or commercial building within the city shall be granted until the owner applying for such construction permit shall furnish the director of public works with plans and specifications conforming to the provisions of this chapter, such that the domestic sewage therefrom shall be discharged into the said sanitary sewer system in the manner and by the means herein specified. 
(k)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(l)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter. 
(m)  It shall be unlawful to discharge any wastewater, sanitary sewage or industrial wastes into any storm sewer within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 1347, 1-3-78; Ord. 2059, 2-26-85; Ord. No. 2967, § 1, 4-29-97; Ord. No. 3245, § 1, 8-29-00; Ord. No. 3292, § 53, 7-3-01) 
7-4-7.3. - Further provisions for discharge of waste and sewage. 
(a)  No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specially designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five and five-tenths (5.5) or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc. either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(d)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the superintendent that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit, (sixty-five (65) degrees C). 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit), (zero (0) and sixty-five (65) degrees C). 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirements, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the superintendent for such materials. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the superintendent as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(8)  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5. 
(9)  Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.005 mg/l as Hg at any time except as permitted by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(10)  Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/l at any time except as permitted by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(11)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions); 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works; 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined herein. 
(12)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(e)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in subsection (d) of this section, and/or which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in chapter 1, EPA Rules and Regulations, subchapter D, Water Programs Part 128-Pretreatment Standards, Federal Register Volume 38, No. 215, Thursday, November 8, 1973, and any amendments thereto, and which in the judgment of the superintendent may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or; 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions of section 7-4-6.2. 
If the superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plant and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(f)  Grease, oil and sand interceptor shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(g)  Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(h)  Each new industry shall be required to install a control manhole and, when required by the superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent.
