The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(i)  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest editions of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from a twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples). 
(j)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength of character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefore, in accordance with section 7-4-6.1 hereof, by the industrial concern. 
(k)  Each industry shall be required to notify the superintendent when changes in industry's processing might effect the characteristics of wastewater being treated by the city. 
7-4-7.4. - Industrial wastes and sewage. 
    No person shall discharge or cause or permit to be discharged into any sewer system, which directly or indirectly discharges into the sewer system of the city, any industrial wastes which are not first approved by the superintendent. 
7-4-7.5. - Protection of sanitary sewer system. 
(a)  The separate sanitary sewer system of the city has been built to carry away the domestic or sanitary sewage, the commercial sewage, and as may be permitted, the industrial wastes of the city. It is not designed to carry any stormwater, water from air conditioning units, cooling systems, surface water or groundwater. Any act which shall cause any stormwater, water from air conditioning units, cooling systems, surface water or groundwater to be conveyed to and into the sanitary sewers is strictly prohibited, directly contrary to the provisions of this chapter, and shall be subject to the penalties herein provided. 
(b)  The sanitary or domestic sewage from all buildings shall be conveyed in house sanitary connections to the public system of sanitary sewers. Sanitary or domestic sewage may be taken to include basement floor drainage; however, this shall not include any storm or groundwater intentionally conveyed to the basement floor, and from said basement floor, to and into the sanitary sewer system. 
(c)  If the superintendent finds that any stormwater, condensate from air conditioning or cooling systems, surface water or groundwater is discharged into the sanitary sewer system from any house connection or building sewer, the user of the house connection or building sewer from which the discharge is made shall be notified in writing that such discharge must be terminated and that the means of making the discharge must be permanently disconnected within thirty (30) days from the date of the written notice. Should the user fail to terminate the discharge and/or permanently disconnect the means of making the discharge within that thirty-day period, the superintendent may notify the user in writing that the house connection or building sewer from which the discharge is made will be disconnected from the sanitary sewer system no sooner than ten (10) working days after the issuance of the aforesaid second notice. If the user fails to terminate the discharge and/or permanently disconnect the means of making the discharge within ten (10) working days after the date of such notice, the city shall disconnect such house connection or building sewer line at a convenient location near the point where such house connection or building sewer connects to the city sewer. A house connection or building sewer which has been disconnected shall not be reconnected until: 
(1)  All house drains, building drains or other similar facilities have been connected to a storm sewer or other acceptable out fall if no storm sewer is provided. 
(2)  The cost to the city of disconnecting the house connection or building sewer is reimbursed to the city. 
(3)  A sewer connection permit is duly issued by the department of public works in the manner prescribed in this chapter to a contractor duly licensed by the city. 
(4)  Service shall be restored by the user, owner, occupant or other interested person at the sole cost and expense of such person. 
(d)  Upon the disconnection of any house connection or building sewer, the department of public works shall notify the Tazewell County Health Department and the department of planning and development of the aforesaid disconnection. 
(Ord. No. 3439, § 1, 5-6-03) 
7-4-7.6. - Sewage treatment required. 
(a)  Where liquid wastes from any source are not discharged into a public sewer, such wastes shall be treated or disposed of so as not to endanger or contaminate any water supply that is or may be used for drinking or domestic purposes, or for bathing, or so as not to create any nuisance or unsanitary condition which shall be considered by the board of health of the city as a menace to the public health and safety. 
(b)  Where a public sanitary (or combined) sewer is not available under the provisions of section 7-4-7.2, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section 7-4-7.6. 
(c)  The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the State of Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code and with the State of Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than _____ square feet (_____ square meters). No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(d)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 7-4-7.2, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter, and any septic tanks and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(e)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the city. 
(f)  No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the East Peoria Board of Health. 
(g)  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to said sewer within sixty (60) days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bankrun gravel or dirt. 
7-4-7.7. - Gasoline and oil traps required. 
    A gasoline and oil trap shall be provided for the waste from all garages, automobile wash floors, cleaning establishments from which gasoline, benzine or other similar substances may be discharged. Said trap shall be installed on the waste pipe above its junction with any other pipe or receptacle containing sewage. The passing of human or animal excrement through such a trap is prohibited. 
7-4-7.8. - Sumps and receiving tanks. 
(a)  In any building in which the whole or part of the plumbing system lies below the house connection to the public sewer, the outlet from said plumbing system, or part thereof, shall discharge into a sump or receiving tank from which the sewage shall be pumped through a pipe to the house connection or to the public sewer. 
(b)  The said sump or receiving tank shall be adequate in capacity. It shall be discharged not less frequently than once each hour. It shall be constructed in a watertight and substantial manner of masonry, vitrified clay or metal. It shall be provided with an airtight cover. Any pipe discharging into the sump or receiving tank shall not be submerged. No storm, surface or ground water shall be conducted to a sump or tank receiving domestic sewage. Such water may be conducted to a separate sump for the purpose of pumping it to the surface of the ground or to a storm sewer if such exists. 
7-4-7.9. - Drainage of roofs and outside areas. 
    No roofs and outside areas of any kind shall be drained into the house sanitary connection or the separate sanitary sewer system. No roof downspouts or conductors shall in any manner be connected to discharge directly or indirectly into the house sanitary connection or the separate sanitary sewer system. 
7-4-7.10. - Foundation and floor drains. 
    Whenever drains are placed under the cellar floor or used to encircle the outer walls of a building for the removal of ground, surface or storm water, they shall not in any case be connected directly or indirectly to the house sanitary connection or the separate sanitary sewer systems. 
7-4-7.11. - Entering, injuring, interfering with sewer system. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than an authorized city employee to enter any public sewer, manhole, catch basin or other part of the public sewer system without written permission from the superintendent of the wastewater treatment division. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, maliciously or negligently break, deface, destroy or injure any public sewer or appurtenance thereto. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, molest, uncover, take off covers from manholes or lampholes, or disturb any portion of the public sewer system or appurtenances thereto. 
7-4-7.12. - Inspection; entry powers. 
    In order that the public sewer system may be fully protected against improper use and injury, the superintendent shall have free and unobstructed access to any part of any premises where house sanitary connections to be connected directly or indirectly to the public sewer system or house storm drains have been constructed, for the purpose of examining the construction, condition and usage of the same, at any reasonable hour, during construction or any time thereafter, and any owner, occupant or other person refusing to allow said superintendent or his agent access to the premises for such purpose, shall be guilty of violation of this section and shall be subject to the penalties provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1347, 1-3-78) 
7-4-7.13. - Wastewater service outside of the corporate limits. 
(a)  Limitation on wastewater service outside the city. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this section 7-4-7.13, no building sewer which is designed to serve any structure or property located outside the corporate limits of the city shall be connected directly or indirectly to any sewer which is operated or maintained by the city. 
(b)  Exception where public interest is served. This section shall not prevent the discharge of sewage generated at commercial or industrial locations outside the city into a sewer of the city under circumstances where the city council has by agreement or ordinance determined that the public health, safety and welfare will best be served by the treatment of such sewage. 
(c)  Detachment from sewer upon disconnection from the city. In the event that the owner or owners of any parcel disconnect or cause the disconnection of their property from the city, such owner or owners shall detach any building sewer serving the disconnected property or any structure located thereon from any sewer owned, operated or maintained by the city. The detachment of such building sewer shall be completed within thirty (30) days from the date upon which any order of disconnection is entered by any court of competent jurisdiction or within thirty (30) days from the date on which an ordinance authorizing disconnection is enacted by the city council. In the event that the owner or owners of the disconnected territory fail to detach any building sewer serving the disconnected territory within the time herein above provided, the department of public works shall forthwith detach the building sewer from the sewer operated or maintained by the city. 
(d)  Collection of costs of disconnection. In the event that the city detaches a building sewer serving property which has been disconnected from the city after failure of the owner or owners thereof to so detach the said building sewer, then the cost of such detachment incurred by the city shall be paid by the owner or owners of the disconnected property and shall be collected and serve as a lien on such disconnected property in the same fashion as any other delinquent charge imposed under this chapter. 
(Ord. 2426, 5-1-90) 
7-4-8. - CESSPOOLS, PRIVIES, PRIVY VAULTS 
7-4-8.1. - Construction and rebuilding prohibited. 
    No vault, privy, catch basin or cesspool shall hereafter be constructed or rebuilt in the city. 
7-4-8.2. - Maintenance of privy near other buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful and it is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to maintain any privy within forty (40) feet of any street, dwelling, shop, school, factory, church or public hall, or within one hundred (100) feet of any well, unless the same has been furnished with a substantial vault, six (6) feet deep, and made tight so that the contents cannot escape therefrom, and is sufficiently secured and enclosed. 
7-4-8.3. - Privies in places of human habitation. 
    It shall be unlawful to have the general privy accommodations of any place of human habitation within any such place of habitation, or under any sidewalk adjacent thereto. 
7-4-8.4. - Watertight cesspool required. 
    All cesspools shall be watertight. 
7-4-8.5. - Contents not to become offensive. 
    The contents of any tub, or of any receptacle, cesspool, privy, catch basin, vault, sink, water closet, cistern or anything in any room, excavation, vat, building, premises or place shall not be allowed to become a nuisance or offensive, so as to be dangerous or prejudicial to health. 
7-4-8.6. - Abatement of offensive contents. 
    All privies or catch basins, any part of the contents of which are above the surface or within two (2) feet of the surface of the earth, and all other privies or catch basins that are foul, omitting smells and odors that are prejudicial to the public health, are hereby declared nuisances, and the city health officer shall have the power to abate the same as provided in sections 9-7-16 through 9-7-21 of this Code. 
7-4-8.7. - Overflowing of offensive contents. 
    No person shall draw off or allow to run off onto any ground, street or place of the city the contents, or any part thereof, of any vault, cistern, cesspool or catch basin; nor shall any owner, tenant or occupant of any building to which any vault, catch basin, privy or cesspool shall appertain or be attached permit the contents, or any part thereof, to flow therefrom or to rise within two (2) feet of any part of the top, or such contents to become offensive; nor shall any privy or any other structure mentioned in this section be filled with or covered with dirt, until its filthy contents shall be emptied. 
7-4-8.8. - Removal; permit required. 
    The owner, tenant or occupant of any building or premises within the city shall not cause or permit any part of the contents of any privy, vault, catch basin or cesspool over which he has control to be removed, except according to a permit issued by the health officer and subject to any rules of the board of health for removing the same. 
7-4-8.9. - Disinfection. 
    All privies, catch basins, vaults and cesspools, when cleaned, shall be disinfected with freshly burned lime, and the work of such disinfection shall be done by the person removing such contents. 
7-4-8.10. - Depositing garbage in privies. 
    No person shall throw into or deposit in any vault, sink, privy, catch basin or cesspool any offal, ashes, meat, fish, garbage or other substance, nor shall any slops or kitchen wastes be allowed to run into any privy. 
7-4-8.11. - Wells and cisterns to be adequately covered. 
    The owner or occupant of any dwelling, building or other structure within the city is hereby required to place and maintain suitable coverings over all wells or cisterns outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling or structure that is accessible to children. 
7-4-8.12. - Cistern overflow pipes. 
    No cistern used for the collection and storage of rainwater from roofs shall have its overflow pipes directly connected with any sewer. Wherever an overflow pipe is provided for such cistern, such pipe shall lead to an area or gutter and shall have its outlet protected with a suitable metal screen. 
(Ord. 1347, 1-3-78) 
CHAPTER 5. - WATER REGULATIONS 
SECTION: 

7-5-1. - IN GENERAL 
7-5-1.1. - Water department created. 
    There is hereby established a department of the city which shall be known as the water department. Said department shall be a subordinate department of the department of streets and public improvements. 
7-5-1.2. - Superintendent of water; office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of superintendent of water. The superintendent of water shall at all times act under the direct control of the director of public works. The superintendent shall be the head of the water department and shall have charge of all property and equipment pertaining thereto, and supervision over all officers and employees thereof. 
7-5-1.3. - Superintendent's powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of water: 
(a)  To supervise and cause to be inspected all connections made with the public waterworks system of the city; 
(b)  To have charge of the water pumping stations of the city and to be responsible for their efficient operation and management; 
(c)  To have supervision over the making of any extensions to the waterworks system of the city; 
(d)  To enforce all laws and ordinances relating to the entire waterworks system of the city; 
(e)  To keep adequate records showing the accomplishments and expenditures of his department, and to make such reports as the council may require; 
(f)  To perform such other duties as may be required of him by the commissioner of streets and public improvements; 
(g)  To manage and supervise the water department of the city and any and all property pertaining thereto; and it shall be his duty to protect the same from unnecessary damage or loss and keep the water department in good running order and repair; and he shall superintend and direct all work pertaining to the future extension of the water department, and all repairs upon the same, of every kind and nature; he shall make a monthly report to the council, or more often if required, of all his acts and doings in and about the same. Such report shall show the kind and amount of materials used, the cost thereof and all expenses attending the works; he shall keep a correct map or profile of all the water mains now or hereafter laid in the city on file in his office, with their dimensions, location and connections, hydrants and cut-offs; he shall keep just, true and correct books of account, in such a manner as at all times to show the true condition and state of business of his office. Such books shall at all times be subject to inspection by the council. He shall deliver such books of account to his successor in office, and he shall also perform such other duties as shall be incumbent upon him; 
(h)  Not to contract for water pipes, hydrants, fixtures or material of any kind, or for construction or extension of such waterworks or water system, without first being authorized and directed to do so by the council; but said superintendent may make or cause to be made, with approval of the commissioner of streets and public improvements, all repairs that may become necessary and may employ competent labor for such work. Such repairs shall thereupon be reported to the council at its next regular meeting. 
7-5-1.4. - Consumers subject to rules and regulations. 
    The rules, regulations and water rates hereinafter established shall be considered a part of the contract with every person who is supplied with water or sewer service by the city; and such person having applied for and accepted either water service or sewer service shall be considered and held to have consented to be bound thereby and shall be subject and governed by said rules, regulations and rates. Any user of water or sewer service shall be further taken to have agreed to the amendment of these regulations from time to time in such manner as the city council in its discretion deems appropriate and shall be considered to have consented to all such amendments. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 2, 2-1-94) 
7-5-1.5. - Inspection; entry powers. 
    The superintendent of water or any officer or his authorized representative shall be permitted at any reasonable hour to enter the premises of consumers to examine the water pipes, fixtures and the manner in which the water is used in order to insure compliance with all provisions of this chapter. The fact that the owner or occupant of such premises accepts and uses water supplied by the city shall constitute consent to the making of such inspection. No person shall refuse to admit authorized representatives of the city to any premises for such purpose. Whenever any authorized representative is refused admittance, or is in any way hindered in making the necessary inspection or examination, the water may be turned off from such premises after twenty four (24) hour's written notice, served either personally or by first class mail upon the owner or occupant thereof. 
7-5-1.6. - Discontinuing water supply. 
    The city shall notify water consumers at any time it becomes necessary to shut off the city water supply, but in case of emergency the city reserves the right at any time, without notice, to shut off the water supply for repairs, extensions, nonpayment of rents or rates or for any other reason, and the city shall not be responsible for any damage, such as bursting of boilers supplied by direct pressure, the breaking of any pipes or fixtures, stoppages or interruption of water supply, or any other damage resulting from the shutting off of the city water supply. 
7-5-1.7. - Turning on water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an authorized employee or representative of the water department, to turn on the city water supply to any premises. 
7-5-1.8. - Injuring or tampering with mains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the proper authorities to tamper with, alter, injure or molest any part of the city waterworks or supply system or appurtenances thereto or any meter. Such person, in addition to being subject to penalties hereinafter provided, shall be responsible to the water department for any and all such damages and shall bear all expenses of such replacement or repair made necessary thereby, and shall also be responsible for damage to surrounding properties on account of the damage to water mains. 
7-5-1.9. - Obstructing access to certain installations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to in any manner cover, conceal, or obstruct the access to any stopcock, hydrant, water meter, meter pit, dial, valve or other device connected with any water pipes within the city by means of any lumber, brick, building material, landscaping material, paving material, fuel or any other article, thing or hindrance, particularly the obstruction of meters that will interfere with the ready access to meters at any and all times. Upon neglect to comply with this provision by the owner or occupant of any parcel served by the water system, the city water supply will be turned off at the street, after notice served, until the obstruction shall have been removed. 
(b)  Any contractor paving any street or highway within the city which contains any water valve box, curb stop, meter or other device connected to the water system shall advise the water department within forty-eight (48) hours prior to the commencement of paving. 
(c)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each device covered, concealed or obstructed in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 3324, § 2, 1-8-02) 
7-5-1.10. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  All fire hydrants installed in the city for the purpose of extinguishing fires within the city other than private hydrants as hereinafter defined are hereby declared to be public hydrants and no person other than the members of the fire department, for the uses and purposes of that department, and those specially authorized by the superintendent of water, shall open any hydrant or attempt to draw water from the same, or in any manner interfere with or injure any hydrant. The maximum interval between fire hydrants placed on any water main installed in the city shall be three hundred (300) feet; provided, however, that the director of public works may authorize a greater interval within areas utilized for industrial purposes when the director, after consulting with the fire chief, concludes that a greater interval will not compromise public safety. All hydrants shall be Mueller A-423 three-way with a five and one-fourth (51/4) inch main valve and an MJ shoe. 
(b)  A "private hydrant" is a fire hydrant situated on private property and maintained by the owner or occupant of such property for the purpose of providing water for firefighting purposes with restrictions on its use and accessibility to the public. The owner or other person in control of a private hydrant shall at the expense of such person annually maintain and test the hydrant to insure that the hydrant is in good working order. Any person responsible for the maintenance and testing of a private hydrant shall at the request of the superintendent of water provide documentary evidence acceptable to the superintendent that annual maintenance and testing has been completed. A private hydrant shall not be located within the limits of public right-of-way without the prior written consent of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 3324, § 1, 1-8-02; Ord. No. 3952, § 1, 12-21-10) 
7-5-1.11. - Leaks and waste. 
    It shall be the duty of all consumers of city water at all times to exercise due diligence to prevent waste of the water supply, and to this end shall stop all leaks on their premises. The city water supply will be shut off from any premises until any violation of this section is corrected. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-1.12. - Bulk sales; resale or redistribution of city water. 
(a)  Until August 1, 2013, there is hereby established a rate of nine dollars and seventy-eight cents ($9.78) per one thousand (1,000) gallons for all water drawn from the city's water system for bulk sales or for the purpose of resale or distribution to any premises other than that for which application has been made and the water service installed. From August 1, 2013, until August 1, 2014, the rate per one thousand (1,000) gallons charged for bulk sales of water or water drawn for resale or redistribution shall be ten dollars and thirty-seven cents ($10.37). On August 1, 2014 and on each August 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust the rate established in this section by adding to the rate in effect on the date of adjustment an amount equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of such rate. 
(b)  Should a water shortage occur or a ban be placed upon excess water, as provided under the provisions of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any recipient of city water to resell or distribute the same to any premises other than that for which application has been made and the water service installed. 
(c)  A special use permit shall be required for any premises to be used for the purpose of engaging in the business of reselling city water. 
(d)  Only the occupant of the premises engaged in the business of reselling water shall withdraw water from the city water system for the purpose of resale or distribution. Such resale or distribution shall only be made to the end user and such water shall not be supplied to any other person or business engaged in the sale of water. 
(e)  The rates and provisions of this section shall not apply to any person engaged in the business of reprocessing, purifying and bottling water for resale from a facility located within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 2302, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 2614, § 2, 10-6-92; Ord. No. 2908, § 4, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3638, § 2, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 4060, § 2, 8-7-12) 
7-5-1.13. - Obstructing or polluting watercourses. 
    It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the city. 
7-5-1.14. - Suspending water supply. 
    For a violation of any provision of this chapter, or of any of the rules and regulations made pursuant thereto, the commissioner of streets and public improvements is hereby authorized and empowered to shut off, or cause to be shut off, the supply of water to such violator. No person shall turn on, or cause to be turned on, the water to his premises after the same has been shut off without first obtaining written permission from the commissioner. 
7-5-1.15. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or opposes the enforcement of any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and for each subsequent offense such person shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 54, 7-3-01) 
7-5-1.16. - Separability of penalties. 
    The penalties hereinabove set forth shall not be construed as precluding each other or any other penalties and costs provided elsewhere in this chapter. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-1.17. - Restrictions on use of water during water shortages. 
    The city council, the director of public works or the superintendent of water may declare restrictions on the use of water supplied by the East Peoria Municipal Water System. Such restrictions may be declared at any time when, in the opinion of the city council, the director of public works or the superintendent of water, a water shortage occurs or appears eminent as a result of conditions of drought, mechanical breakdown or for any other reason. Restrictions on water usage during an actual or anticipated shortage shall be governed by the following: 
(1)  The city council may establish restrictions on the use of water supplied by the East Peoria Municipal Water System for any period deemed necessary by the city council, including a period of undetermined length not expiring until further notice by the city council. The director of public works or the superintendent of water may declare such restrictions only for a specific period of time not exceeding ten (10) days in length. 
(2)  Upon a determination that restrictions on water usage are necessary, a notice shall be posted in the East Peoria Municipal Building. Such notice shall remain posted until the termination of the restrictions therein set forth. The aforesaid notice shall: 
a.  State that restrictions on the use of water drawn from the East Peoria Municipal Water System have been imposed; 
b.  Set forth the restrictions which have been imposed; 
c.  State the period during which the restrictions will be effective or, where appropriate, that the restrictions will be effective until further notice; 
d.  Contain the date and time when the notice was posted; 
e.  Contain the signature of the director of public works, the superintendent of water or any member of the city council. 
(3)  In the event that restrictions imposed under authority of this section 7-5-1.17 are to be effective for a period in excess of five (5) days, notice of such restrictions containing substantially the same information as that required by subsection (2) immediately above shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. Failure to publish the foregoing notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city shall not affect the validity of any restriction declared under the provisions of this section 7-5-1.17; provided, however, that in the event no published notice is required hereunder or in the event that notice called for hereunder is not published, no prosecution for a violation of any such restriction shall be commenced unless the violator has failed to comply with a prior oral or written notice to the violator that his conduct violates restrictions imposed under authority of this section. 
(4)  Any use which may be made of water from the East Peoria Municipal Water System may be restricted, including but not limited to the following: 
a.  The sprinkling, watering or irrigating of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, gardens, vegetables, flowers or any other vegetation. 
b.  The washing of sidewalks, driveways, porches, buildings or other outdoor surfaces. 
c.  The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers or any other equipment or machinery. 
d.  The washing of any business or industrial equipment or machinery. 
e.  The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure. 
f.  The filling of swimming and/or wading pools. 
g.  The escape of water through defective plumbing systems. 
h.  The resale or redistribution of water drawn from the East Peoria Municipal Water System. 
(5)  Restrictions imposed under authority of this section 7-5-1.17 may be limited to certain areas of the city or may include or exclude certain classes of users, including, but not limited to, residential users, commercial users, industrial users or public entities. Use of water may also be limited to certain hours of the day or days of the week. 
(6)  It is unlawful for any person to use water drawn from the East Peoria Municipal Water System in violation of any restriction established under authority of this section 7-5-1.17. Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists or opposes the enforcement of any restriction on the use of water declared under the provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply with such restrictions shall continue. 
(7)  The superintendent of water may immediately disconnect or cause the disconnection of the water service of any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with any restriction on the use of water declared under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 2333, 5-9-89; Ord. No. 3292, § 55, 7-3-01) 
7-5-2. - SERVICE INSTALLATIONS AND CONNECTIONS 
7-5-2.1. - Application for water service. 
    No person shall be permitted to tap or to make any connection with the distribution pipes of the water department without prior written approval of the director of public works. Persons desiring water service must make application therefor to the director of public works. The director of public works shall receive all applications for installations of water service and shall keep a complete record of all applications received. No application for service through either a new or an existing connection shall be approved where the applicant or any other primary consumer of water from that connection will be a person owing any delinquent charges to the city for water or wastewater service. The director of public works or the director's designee shall have the authority to require the submission of rent receipts, signed leases or other evidence which identifies the intended consumers of the water to be supplied to the location identified in the application. The director of public works or the director's designee shall have the authority to reject any application upon a determination by such person that the applicant or any other primary consumer of water from that connection owes any delinquent charges to the city for water or wastewater service. 
(Ord. 2302, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 2666, § 1, 8-31-93) 
7-5-2.2. - Tapping and installation. 
    The water department shall tap all mains or supply pipes and furnish the necessary pipe connections to the curbline of each street. The entire expense of connecting service pipes from the curbline shall be upon the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. The city is hereby prohibited from assuming any responsibility for said cost. But all work done and all materials furnished shall be approved and inspected by the superintendent of water or his authorized representative. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-2.3. - Water tap-in charges. 
(a)  There is hereby fixed a service connection charge of: 
1" service connection ..... $3,000.00 
New service connections having a diameter of less than one (1) inch may not be installed. Fees charged for service connections having a diameter in excess of one (1) inch shall equal the cost of labor and materials incurred by the city in the installation of the service connection as determined by the director of public works. Each such service connection charge, shall be paid upon application for connection. 
(b)  The city shall tap all mains for the purpose of extending branch water mains from existing water mains. The city shall charge a fee for any such tap in accordance with the following schedule:

Excavation necessary to expose the main, trucking services, backfill, removal and replacement of pavement, seeding and related restoration and all other charges related to the tap in shall be provided by the person who requested the tap in. The main tap in fee shall be paid upon application for the tap in. On August 1, 2006 and on each August 1 thereafter the director of public works shall adjust each of the aforementioned main tap in fees by adding to the tap in fee in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three and one-half (31/2) percent of such fee. 
(Ord. 1965, 2-7-84; Ord. No. 2908, § 5, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3536, § 1, 6-29-04; Ord. No. 3639, § 3, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 4378 , § 1, 3-6-18) 
7-5-2.4. - Temporary businesses; installation charges. 
    Any person conducting a business of a temporary nature and desiring a water connection shall first pay to the city clerk the entire expense of making said tap-in to the main, together with any tap-in charges which may be provided now or hereafter by any ordinance of the city, and further shall pay the entire costs for any materials used in making said connection. 
7-5-2.5. - Water main connection; bond required, permit issued. 
(a)  No person shall do any business with, make any connections to, or in any manner perform any work upon any of the mains, connections or appliances pertaining to the waterworks of the city until he shall have filed a certificate of bond with the city clerk in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with sureties to be approved by the council indemnifying and saving harmless the City of East Peoria of and from all liability for damages to persons or property by reason of or resulting directly or indirectly from the construction, alteration or repair on account of any negligence or want of due care on his part in doing any work in and about said water mains, connections or appliances pertaining to the city waterworks, and further conditioned that he shall in all respects in doing such work be governed strictly by the rules and regulations now in force or hereinafter adopted by the city governing water main connections; provided, however, that any applicant hereunder, who is currently bonded as a registered plumbing contractor under the provisions of section 4-5-4 of this Code shall be required to furnish an additional five thousand dollar ($5,000.00) bond only. 
(b)  Upon approval of said bond by the council, the clerk shall issue a permit authorizing water main connections by the applicant, which permit shall be co-signed by the director of public works. 
(c)  No permittee hereunder shall, either directly or indirectly, allow any other person, other than his own employees under his supervision, to perform any work upon said water mains by virtue of such permit. 
(d)  Permits issued hereunder shall be valid only until April 30 of the year issued, and a new bond must be filed with the application for every new permit. 
(e)  The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall have the authority to order the revocation or suspension of any permit hereunder for the noncompliance with any provisions of this chapter or rules of the water department, and said revocation or suspension of such permit shall take effect immediately and shall remain in full force until changed by the council. Such revocation or suspension shall be reported to the council at its first regular meeting thereafter. 
Cross reference- Plumbing contractors; registration, bond required, § 4-5-4. 
7-5-2.6. - Water main connection; rules generally. 
(a)  No alterations, additions or disconnections in and about any water main, service connection or appliances thereto shall be made by any permittee hereunder that will in any way affect the measurements thereof without written permission therefor by the director of public works. 
(b)  Every permittee hereunder who shall install any pipe or fixtures for persons desiring to take water of the city, or who shall make repairs upon or additions or extensions to pipes or fixtures already installed, shall, within twenty-four (24) hours after the same is completed, file with the clerk, upon blanks to be furnished for that purpose, a full report thereof, stating the ordinary and special uses for which water is to be supplied. 
(c)  Permittees are required in all cases to comply with all rules governing consumers in the location and placing of the stop boxes and shut-offs. 
(d)  In case of leaks or other accidents to pipes or other apparatus connected with the city waterworks, permittees may shut off the water at the stopcock or main to make such necessary repairs. In all cases where permittees shall make such repairs to pipes or fixtures on any premises, they shall leave the water turned either on or off, as they found it to be when they entered the premises to make such repairs. 
(e)  In no case shall any permittee, after the completion and trial of any connection work, leave the water turned on the premises, but shall in all cases close the stopcock on the sidewalk. 
(f)  Permittees must not extend pipes from one street number to another without special permission from the director of public works, to be approved by the council. 
(g)  Whenever meters are placed on pipes connected by boilers or other hot water apparatus, a back flow prevention device installed in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code must be placed between said meter and such boiler or other hot water apparatus to protect such meter from back pressure of steam or hot water. 
(h)  The opening of stop boxes by permittees by any means other than a proper wrench is strictly prohibited. All permittees must have a stop box wrench attached to their keys for opening and closing stops. Any permittee breaking stop box covers or bolts shall be required to pay for the same. 
(i)  No permittee shall be permitted to furnish, set or repair any meters. No person not an employee of the water department shall be permitted to install or repair the same. 
(j)  In excavating for service connections, the street must be opened in such a manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the public, and a free passage of water into the gutter provided therefor. Whenever any excavation in any street or public place is left open overnight, the public shall be protected by proper guards and lights. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 3324, § 3, 1-8-02) 
7-5-2.6.5. - Water mains; specifications and manner of installation. 
(a)  Plastic pipe shall be C900. Ductile iron pipe shall be class 50 thru 53 and conform to AWWA standards. HDPE pipe will be considered, depending upon the location and application. A continuous 12-gauge insulated, stranded locating wire shall be taped to the top of all pipe, regardless of pipe material and shall extend out of all valve boxes. 
(b)  Restrained joint (retainer gland or "mega-lug") accessories shall be used on all fittings. In unstable soils, such as near the river, restrained joint gaskets (i.e.-"US Pipe Field Lock 350") shall be used in all push joints. 
(c)  Water main shall be laid to form a "loop" or to tie into the grid of piping at both ends. Valves shall be installed at all tie in points with adjustable valve boxes brought to grade level. Mains or fire protection services shall not form "dead ends", whether located on city right-of-way or on private property. 
(d)  All water mains shall be bedded in granular fill and be covered with the same to one (1) foot above the pipe. Below streets and other structures, the entire trench must be filled with granular fill and compacted in six-inch lifts. Mains shall be installed with a minimum of four and one-half (41/2) feet of cover. 
(e)  Water mains shall be pressure tested at one and one-half (1.5) times the operating pressure before being placed in service. Testing pressure must hold for two (2) hours and shall not decline more than five (5) psi during the test period. Bacteriological testing shall provide two (2) consecutive zero count samples. 
(Ord. No. 3324, § 4, 1-8-02) 
7-5-2.7. - Service pipes; specifications, and manner of installation. 
(a)  All service pipes placed in connection with the city water mains shall be of type K copper or cast iron pipe for water mains which conforms with specifications of the American Water Works Association or the American Standards Association or the Federal Specifications WWP-421 as contained in their specific publications. The house service pipe as laid out and extended by the plumber shall be of not less than the size of pipe as laid by the city in the street. All service pipes shall be marked with #12 insulated tracing wire or any alternate material approved by the superintendent. The service installation and connections shall not be covered or the trenches filled until after the water has been turned on into such pipes and the same shall have been tested and found to be watertight and the same inspected by an agent of the water department. 
(b)  When a developer is constructing a subdivision, the services shall be type K copper run in accordance with specifications of the American Water Works Association or the American Standards Association. Services shall be run to the edge of each lot, terminated with a Mueller curb stop valve and box and a loop of copper pipe brought to the surface. The curb stop valve and box shall be set at the edge of the right-of-way and be adjusted to finished grade. The water department must be called to inspect and approve the first service before the developer covers the work or proceeds with any installation. All installations must be watertight. Further inspections will be at the discretion of the water department. 
(c)  Connections to the main shall be permanent and not cause stress on the main. PVC pipe may not be drilled and tapped. A saddle must be used in all cases to connect a service pipe to the main. All service piping shall be placed at least four and one-half (41/2) feet below the finished grade. 
(d)  Meter pits shall be installed by the water department in the right-of-way near the property line of the lot being served. Meter pits shall be installed between the curb stop and the property being served. Service piping on the property being served must terminate near the curb stop serving that property and must include a minimum ten (10) feet of service piping coiled above grade. The water department must make all connections between the service piping and the meter pit and/or curb stop. 
(Ord. 1965, 2-7-84; Ord. No. 3324, § 5, 1-8-02; Ord. No. 3901, § 11, 5-13-10) 
7-5-2.8. - Service pipe repairs. 
    All repairs for service pipes and plumbing systems of buildings shall be made by and at the expense of the owner of the premises served. The city may in case of an emergency repair any service pipes, and whenever this is done, the cost of such repair work shall be repaid to the city by the owner or occupant of the premises served. 
7-5-2.9. - Service pipe excavations. 
    Any excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the same shall be made in compliance with the provisions of chapter 2 of this title. 
7-5-2.10. - Water facilities assessments. 
    Certain persons applying to make an initial tap-in or connection with the distribution pipes of the water department shall be subject to a water facilities assessment representing payment by the applicant for a share of the capital cost of the water system constructed over the years with revenues collected from users. The imposition and amount of water facilities assessments shall be determined by this section 7-5-2.10. 
(1)  Certain subdivisions with four (4) or more lots. Except as otherwise provided in this section, the owner of any property which: 
a.  Is subdivided after November 15, 1988, in accordance with the provisions of the East Peoria Subdivision Code; and 
b.  Is subdivided into four (4) or more lots, any of which are to be served by water main extensions to be constructed at the expense of the subdivider; and 
c.  Has not been previously subject to an assessment under the provisions of article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code for the installation of water lines or other components of the water system. 
shall be subject to a water facilities assessment in the amount of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for each acre of land represented on the plat of subdivision. Payment of any such assessment shall be made prior to the execution and delivery of the plat of the subdivision. 
(2)  Certain individual lots. Except as otherwise provided in this section, upon application for a new water service connection for a building or property, the applicant and/or the owner of any of the following classes of property shall pay to the city a water facilities assessment in the amount of one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00) per connection. The classes of property subject to such assessment are as follows: 
a.  Any lot created by subdivision after November 15, 1988, of any parcel, which subdivision creates three (3) or fewer lots; or 
b.  Any lot created by the subdivision of any parcel completed after November 15, 1988, which subdivision, regardless of the number of lots created, is served entirely by water mains installed by someone other than the subdivider; or 
c.  Any lot annexed to the city after November 15, 1988; or 
d.  Any lot which, regardless of when created or annexed, will be served by connection to a water main installed by: 
1.  Any private person other than the owner of the lot or a predecessor in interest to the owner of the lot; or 
2.  The city's water department; or 
3.  Special assessment under article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code which assessment was not levied against the lot in question; or 
e.  Any other lot which has not through special assessment under article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code or through prior payment of consideration to the city or through installation of mains other appurtenances directly contributed to the provision of water capable of serving the parcel in question. 
(3)  Proof of prior payment. Any person asserting exemption from water facilities assessments because of prior payments of special assessments under article 9 of the Municipal Code or because of installation of water mains at the expense of the applicant or a predecessor in interest or for any other reason shall have the burden of producing written receipts or other documentary evidence demonstrating to the sole satisfaction of the city that such exemption is justified. 
(4)  Installment payment of assessments. Provided that the city in its sole discretion determines that the security is adequate, a water facilities assessment due under the terms of this section, may be paid in not more than five (5) equal annual installments of principal, the first of which is due no later than six (6) months following the date of application for service together with interest on the principal balance remaining unpaid, from time to time, at a rate of not less than nine (9) percent per annum. Accrued interest shall be payable on the date of each payment of principal. Installment obligations shall be evidenced by promissory note secured by a mortgage on the premises served by the new water service. The city may in its discretion permit the subordination of any such mortgage to one (1) or more other mortgages on the premises served by the new water service. 
(5)  Discretionary waiver of assessments. The city may in its sole discretion reduce or waive a water facilities assessment under the following circumstances: 
a.  As an inducement to business enterprises considering a location in East Peoria; provided, however, that no water facilities assessment shall be reduced under the provisions of this subsection to a level less than fifty (50) percent of that otherwise applicable and then only under circumstances where the proposed facility is reasonably anticipated to create at least ten (10) permanent, full-time jobs within eighteen (18) months of the date of application; or 
b.  Under circumstances where the imposition of a mandated water facilities assessment would be manifestly unjust. 
(6)  Costs of extension and other charges. The provisions of this section contemplate the tap-in to existing mains without the necessity of any extension by the city. In the event any main is extended for the benefit of one (1) or more parcels of real property, the foregoing provisions of this section shall not prohibit the assessment of additional charges representing cost of extending any such main for the benefit of such parcel or parcels, as such cost is determined by the director of public works. 
(7)  Equitable sharing of costs by owners of benefitted properties. Under certain conditions, the owner or owners of property may bear the entire cost of extending water mains to serve property being developed by such owner or owners under conditions where such extension may secondarily benefit other property which has not yet been developed. Under such conditions, the city council may as a condition precedent to permitting connections from the secondarily benefitted property to such mains require the owner(s) of the secondarily benefitted property to directly or indirectly pay a fee to the person or persons who constructed the main. The fee paid shall equal the benefit received by the secondarily benefitted property as determined by the director of public works. 
(Ord. 2302, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 2908, § 6, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3639, § 4, 10-18-05) 
7-5-2.11. - Connections to serve commercial, industrial or multifamily residential structures. 
(a)  No connection of any commercial, industrial or multifamily residential structure may be made to the water system unless the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The flow of water through the most proximate watermain is sufficient to permit the fire department to promptly suppress any fire which may occur in the structure. 
(2)  A fire hydrant is located within three hundred (300) feet of the site of the structure or proposed structure. 
(3)  A loop connection shall be made to any other water main within three hundred (300) feet of the main servicing the structure where such a loop does not already exist. 
(b)  The owner of the site and the applicant for the building permit, if different that the owner, shall bear the cost of making any improvements to the water system which are necessary to comply with the requirements imposed by this section; provided, however, that no such connection shall be made without a permit from the water superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 3264, § 3, 12-5-00) 
7-5-2.12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3800, § 1, adopted June 3, 2008, repealed § 7-5-2.12, which pertained to annual inspection of backflow prevention devices and derived from Ord. No. 3324, § 6, adopted Jan. 8, 2002. 
7-5-3. - METERS 
7-5-3.1. - Meter required; application, city property. 
(a)  All premises using the city water supply must be equipped with an adequate water meter of suitable size. 
(b)  Upon proper application to the city clerk on forms to be provided, the city shall furnish every consumer a water meter, which shall always remain the property of the city. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-3.2. - Separate metered service required. 
    Each dwelling house, building or place of business having water service shall have a separate metered service installed therein. "Separate metered service" shall mean an independent service pipe extended from the building to the city water main for which an application has been made or required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1965, 2-7-84) 
7-5-3.3. - Consumer responsible for damage, breaking seal, tampering. 
    All consumers of city water shall at all times be responsible for any damage to a water meter on their premises. No person shall break the seal of any meter or in any way tamper with the same. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-3.4. - Repairs to meters. 
(a)  The water department reserves the right at any time to enter any premises supplied by city water and to exchange any meter, for repairs or otherwise, as may be deemed necessary by the department. 
(b)  Except with respect to auxiliary meters installed to monitor use of water not passing into the sanitary sewer system, all meters installed shall be maintained and repaired by the water department when rendered unserviceable through reasonable wear and tear; provided, however, that where replacements, repairs or adjustments of any meters are rendered necessary by any act, neglect or carelessness of the owner or occupant of any premises, or where meters are damaged by freezing, hot water, etc., any expense caused the water department thereby shall be charged against and be collected from the owner or occupant of the premises. 
(c)  In case of breakage, stoppage or any other irregularity in the meter, the owner or occupant is to notify the water department immediately, and any necessary repairs will be made by the department, as hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. 1965, 2-7-84) 
7-5-3.5. - Water to pass through meter. 
(a)  Whenever the accuracy of a water meter is questioned, it shall be removed at the consumer's or owner's request and shall be tested, in his presence if so desired, in the shops of the water department by means of the apparatus there provided, and a report thereof duly made. Both parties to the test shall accept the findings so made. 
(b)  The fee for such test shall be five dollars ($5.00). If the test discloses an error against the consumer of more than three (3) percent in the meter's registry, the excess of the consumption on the current bimonthly bill shall be adjusted and the entire expense of the test will be borne by the water department and the fee required shall be returned. 
(c)  Hydrant rental per year. The rate for hydrant rental in the city shall be sixteen dollars ($16.00) per year, per hydrant. 
(Ord. 2194, 6-30-87, Ord. No. 2614, § 3, 10-6-92) 
7-5-3.6. - Testing. 
    (Material Missing) 
7-5-3.7. - Defective meters; leakage. 
(a)  Whenever any meter, at any time, fails to accurately register the quantity of water consumed, the same shall be determined and charges made based on the average quantity registered during the four (4) quarters prior to the date of failure. 
(b)  No deduction shall be made on account of leakage after the water has passed through and has been registered by the meter. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-3.8. - Meter readings. 
(a)  Upon the request of the owner or occupant water meters will be re-read for a first time at no charge. 
(b)  Water meters will not be re-read for a second time in a twelve-month period unless the reading is thought to be over thirty (30) percent in error. If a second re-read is requested and usage is found to be less than thirty (30) percent in error, in the opinion of the water superintendent, a ten dollar ($10.00) service charge will be added to that account. 
7-5-4. - REVENUES AND RATES 
7-5-4.1. - Water rates established. 
    There shall be and there are hereby established bimonthly water rates and/or charges for the use of service supplied by the waterworks system of the city based upon the following schedules: 
(1)  Water service for domestic and industrial users: 
a.  For water service billed until August 1, 2013: 
First 150,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... $5.12 
150,001 - 300,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 4.41 
Over 300,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 4.12 
b.  For water service billed from August 1, 2013, until August 1, 2014: 
First 150,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... $5.43 
Over 150,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 4.67 
c.  On August 1, 2014 and on each August 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust each of the rates initially established in subsection (1)b. immediately above, by adding to each such rate in effect on the date of adjustment an amount equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of each such rate. 
(2)  Water service for senior citizens: The bimonthly charge for water to each residential water service utilized exclusively by persons sixty-two (62) years of age or over, or exclusively by married couples in which one (1) spouse is sixty-two (62) years of age or older shall be computed as follows: 
a.  For water service billed until August 1, 2013: 
First 6,000 gallons or less (no charge) ..... $0.00 
6,001 - 150,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 5.12 
150,000 - 300,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 4.41 
Over 300,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 4.12 
b.  For water service billed from August 1, 2013, until August 1, 2014: 
First 6,000 gallons or less (no charge) ..... $0.00 
6,001 - 150,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons ..... 5.43 
Over 150,000, per 1,000 gallons ..... 4.67 
c.  On August 1, 2014 and on each August 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust each of the rates initially established in subsection (2)b. immediately above, by adding to each such rate in effect on the date of adjustment, a sum equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of each such rate. 
d.  The city clerk may require reasonable proof of age of persons utilizing a water service before computing charges at rates for senior citizens. 
e.  The rates for senior citizens hereinabove established shall not apply to water service to units owned by senior citizens but rented by persons who are not senior citizens as hereinabove defined. 
(3)  Bimonthly water rates for nonmetered users: Until August 1, 2013, all water users in the city who do not have water meters shall pay a flat rate of sixty-one dollars and forty-four cents ($61.44) bimonthly. For water service billed from August 1, 2013, until August 1, 2014, such nonmetered users shall pay a flat rate of sixty-five dollars and thirteen cents ($65.13) bimonthly. On August 1, 2014 and on each August 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust the bimonthly rate for nonmetered users by adding to the bimonthly rate in effect on the date of adjustment, a sum equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of such bimonthly rate. 
(4)  Annual review: The adequacy of the water rates and other charges for use of the city's water system shall be reviewed at least annually by certified public accountants for the city. The water rates and other charges for use of the city's water system shall be revised periodically to reflect changes in local capital costs and in operations, maintenance and recovery costs. 
(Ord. 2194, 6-30-87, eff. 9-1-87; Ord. No. 2614, § 4, 10-6-92; Ord. No. 2615, § 1, 10-6-92; Ord. No. 2908, § 7, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3109, § 1, 12-1-98; Ord. No. 3638, § 3, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 4060, § 3, 8-7-12) 
7-5-4.2. - Water service outside of the corporate limits. 
(a)  Limitation on water service outside the city. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this section 7-5-4.2, no water service line which is designed to serve any structure or property located outside the corporate limits of the city shall be connected directly or indirectly to any water main which is operated or maintained by the city. 
(b)  Detachment from water main upon disconnection from the city. In the event that the owner or owners of any parcel disconnect or cause the disconnection of their property from the city, such owner or owners shall detach any water service line serving the disconnected property or any structure located thereon from any water main owned, operated or maintained by the city. The detachment of such water service line shall be completed within thirty (30) days from the date upon which any order of disconnection is entered by any court of competent jurisdiction or within thirty (30) days from the date on which an ordinance authorizing disconnection is enacted by the city council. In the event that the owner or owners of the disconnected territory fail to detach any water service line serving the disconnected territory within the time hereinabove provided, the department of public works shall forthwith detach the water service line from the water main operated or maintained by the city. 
(c)  Collection of costs of disconnection. In the event that the city detaches a water service line serving property which has been disconnected from the city after failure of the owner or owners thereof to so detach the said water service line, then the cost of such detachment incurred by the city shall be paid by the owner or owners of the disconnected property and shall be collected and serve as a lien on such disconnected property in the same fashion as any other delinquent charge imposed under this chapter. 
(Ord. 2426, 5-1-90) 
7-5-4.3. - Deposit required. 
(a)  At the time of application for water or sewer service, each applicant shall deposit with the city clerk a sum of money as determined in accordance with the provisions of this section. Such deposit may be used to pay any delinquent water or sewer charges subsequently incurred by the applicant or with respect to the applicant's property. The city clerk may waive the payment of a deposit when the clerk in the clerk's sole discretion determines that a default in payment is unlikely or that adequate alternate security exists. 
(b)  Deposits for single-family residential property and for each unit of a duplex or apartment building containing a separate metered service shall be determined in accordance with the following schedule: 
For each residential unit ..... $100.00 
(c)  Deposits for multifamily residential dwellings without a separate metered service for each residential unit and for all business, commercial and industrial properties shall be determined in accordance with the following schedule: 
For each metered service ..... $100.00 
(d)  The department of public works may in its discretion recommend a reduced deposit where the property served is provided with only water service or with only sewer service. 
(e)  All deposits made under rate schedules previously in effect shall remain unchanged unless the user specifically requests a re-evaluation of his deposit under the schedules hereinabove established. 
(Ord. 2260, 4-19-88; Ord. No. 3719, § 1, 12-5-06) 
7-5-4.4. - Liability of owner, occupant and consumer. 
    The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the consumer of the water services of the city shall be jointly and severally liable for payment of the water service on such premises, and the water service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the water service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the city. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-4.5. - Meter readings. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of water to seal and examine each meter, and to read and record each meter bimonthly or to cause the same to be done by an employee of the water department as often as is deemed necessary by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 1965, 2-7-84) 
7-5-4.6. - Nonpayment; shutting off water. 
(a)  The water supply may be shut off to any premises for which the water bill or sewer user charge remains unpaid for a period of ten (10) days after the due date. 
(b)  The water supply may also be shut off to any premises for which any of the following charges remain unpaid for a period of ten (10) days after the due date therefore: 
(1)  Water facilities assessment imposed against the premises under the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Wastewater facilities assessment imposed against the premises under the provisions of this title. 
(3)  Assessment for the improvement or extension of any water or sewer mains or other facilities related to the provision of water or wastewater service which assessment has been imposed against the premises under the provisions of Article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(c)  The water supply shall not be restored until all back water bills, sewer user charges, water facilities assessments, wastewater facilities assessments, special assessments, any costs incurred by the city and an additional delinquency charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) have been paid 
(Ord. 2581, 5-5-92; Ord. No. 2698, § 3, 2-1-94) 
7-5-4.7. - Delinquent charges; lien. 
(a)  Whenever the charges for water service or other charges assessed pursuant to this chapter are not paid by the due date, such charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter the city shall have a continuing lien upon the premises and real estate upon or for which water is used or supplied. 
(b)  A penalty of ten (10) percent per month shall be added to all delinquent charges for water service. 
(c)  Every such lien shall, upon compliance with the conditions hereinafter set forth, become and be prior and superior to the rights and interest of creditors, encumbrances, purchasers and other parties in interest in the premises and real estate. 
(Ord. 2581, 5-5-92) 
7-5-4.8. - Affidavit; recording. 
(a)  Whenever a bill for water rates, benefits or other changes provided for in this chapter remains unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been rendered, the city clerk shall file with the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County, State of Illinois, a statement of lien claim verified by the affidavit of himself or other officer of the city having knowledge of the facts. The statement shall contain a sufficiently correct description of the lot, lots or tracts of land to identify the same, the balance due after allowing all credits, the date upon which such amount became delinquent and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount, as well as for all charges for water or other services in connection therewith supplied subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(b)  No such lien shall be defeated to the proper amount thereof because of an error or overcharge on the part of the city, nor shall any such lien be defeated upon proof that such water was consumed or contracted for by a tenant of the premises or occupant thereof other than the owner. 
(c)  The failure of the clerk to record such lien claim, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water bills, as provided in this chapter. 
7-5-4.9. - Enforcement. 
(a)  If payment shall not be made as provided in this chapter, any amount due for water service, benefits, or other charges provided for in this chapter when the same becomes due, the city may file or cause to be filed a complaint in the Circuit Court of Tazewell County for a foreclosure of such lien or, upon becoming a defendant in any pending suit affecting the premises or real estate, an answer to the complaint in the nature of an intervening petition or a cross-complaint, and the city may proceed in its corporate name to foreclose such lien in like manner and with like effect as provided by the statutes of the state in foreclosure of mortgages on real estate. Any decree rendered in the court may be enforced and collected as other decrees or judgments in the same court. 
(b)  The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the city, in the Circuit Court of Tazewell County or in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which water bill has remained unpaid thirty (30) days after it has been rendered. 
(c)  The remedy provided in this section for the collection of delinquent water rates, charges or benefits shall not be construed to abridge or in any manner interfere with the right and power of the city to enforce a collection thereof by any other action or as otherwise provided in this chapter, but the remedy herein provided shall be taken and held as an additional means to enforce payment of such delinquent water rates, charges or benefits. 
(d)  Expenses incurred by the city for the purpose of collecting delinquent service charges, delinquent facilities assessments or other delinquent fees payable pursuant to this chapter shall be assessed as a supplemental service charge. All owners, occupants and users of the premises provided with service with respect to which such a delinquency exists shall be jointly and severally liable for the payment of expenses of collection. Expenses of collection to be assessed as a supplemental service charge under authority of this subsection include, without limitation, attorneys fees incurred by the city for the purpose of collecting any delinquent amounts. 
(Ord. 1965, 2-7-84; Ord. No. 3474, § 2, 9-3-03) 
7-5-4.10. - Purchasers of property required to notify water department. 
    It shall be the duty of any person about to purchase any premises within the city, or of any mortgagee, trustee or lien claimant holding any mortgage, trust deed or lien against any premises within the city, to first ascertain from the office of the city clerk as to any delinquent water bill, tax, rate, rent or service that may have accrued or be against the premises, before purchasing the premises or instituting proceedings foreclosing the mortgage, trust deed or lien, and to notify the clerk in writing as to his intention to purchase such property, or to foreclose such mortgage, trust deed or lien. Twenty four (24) hours' notice shall be deemed sufficient notice under this section. 
7-5-4.11. - Separate fund. 
(a)  All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the city water and sewerage services shall be transferred to the city treasurer not more than ten (10) days after the receipt of the same, or at such frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the city council. 
(b)  The treasurer shall receive all revenues from the city water and sewerage services and all other funds and moneys incident to the operation of such services as the same may be transferred to him, and deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the Waterworks and Sewerage Fund and the treasurer shall administer the fund in every respect in the manner provided by state law. 
(1970 Code) 
7-5-4.12. - Returned checks. 
    In the event that the owner or occupant of property receiving water service in the City of East Peoria issues a check in payment for any water and/or sewage charges which is returned by a bank by reason of insufficient funds, a closed account, or any other reason except an error by the bank, a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) service charge will be added to the account. 
(Ord. 2408, 3-27-90; Ord. No. 2908, § 8, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3638, § 4, 10-18-05) 
7-5-4.13. - Recovery of the cost of certain improvements through the imposition of supplemental user fees. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, a "neighborhood improvement" is an improvement to the water system made by the city for the purpose of facilitating the delivery of water service primarily to a specific user or group of users or primarily within a confined geographic area. 
(b)  Whenever it becomes necessary for the city to construct a neighborhood improvement, the city may in its discretion require the payment of a one-time supplemental user fee to cover all or a portion of the cost of such improvement in the manner provided by this section. 
(c)  If the director of public works concludes that a supplemental user fee should be charged for the purpose of paying all or any portion of the cost of a neighborhood improvement, the director shall provide written notice of the supplemental user fee directed to the person, if any, billed for water service provided to each benefited premises at the address for such person shown on billing records maintained by the city and to the address at which real estate taxes for each benefited premises were most recently mailed. Such notice shall disclose the total amount of the supplemental user fee and the distribution of that fee against each benefited user or owner. 
(d)  Any person receiving notice of the imposition of a supplemental user fee may appeal the determination to impose the fee. Any such appeal shall be submitted in writing, shall explain the basis for the appeal and shall be delivered to the director of public works within fifteen (15) days after notice of the imposition of the fee was mailed to the person submitting the appeal. Any such appeal shall be adjudicated by the commissioner having supervisory authority over the combined water and sewer system in accordance with the procedure established at section 7-5-4.16 of this title. 
(e)  Each supplemental user fee imposed under authority of this section shall be due and payable upon the first to occur of the following events: 
(1)  A benefited user utilizes that portion of the water system which includes the neighborhood improvement; or 
(2)  A building permit is issued for the construction of improvements on a benefited parcel which will include a connection to the water system; or 
(3)  Fee simple title to a benefited parcel is conveyed subsequent to imposition of the supplemental user charge. 
If a supplemental user fee imposed under authority of this section is not paid when due, the remedies for delinquent user fees established elsewhere in this chapter shall apply. In addition, no new connection to the water system will be permitted from a benefited parcel with respect to which a supplemental user fee has been imposed until the fee has been paid in full.
