(f)  The director of public works shall cause notice of the final amount of any unpaid supplemental user fee to be recorded in the Office of the Tazewell County Recorder of Deeds and indexed against each parcel benefited by the neighborhood improvement. 
(g)  As provided by section 7-5-4.6 of this title, the owner of the benefited premises, the occupant thereof and the consumer of water services are jointly and severally liable for any supplemental user fee imposed under authority of this section. 
(Ord. No. 3899, § 2, 2-16-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2908, § 9, adopted July 2, 1996, deleted the provisions of former § 7-5-4.13, which pertained to bimonthly water rates for nonmetered users, as derived from Ord. 2194, adopted June 30, 1987 and Ord. No. 2614, § 5, adopted Oct. 6, 1992. 
7-5-4.14. - Transfer of delinquent accounts. 
    If at any time water or wastewater service is terminated at any location in the city, any delinquency on the terminated account may at the option of the superintendent or any subordinate of the superintendent be transferred to any other water or wastewater account maintained by the city which other account is in the name of any owner or occupant who is responsible for payment of the delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 2698, § 4, 2-1-94) 
7-5-4.15. - Access for purposes of monitoring compliance with state or federal grants and loans. 
    Authorized representatives of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and/or the United States Environmental Protection Agency shall have access to the books, documents, papers and records relative to the city's system of rates and/or other charges for use of its water system for the purpose of insuring compliance with the terms and conditions of any grant or loan from either agency. 
(Ord. No. 3109, § 2, 12-1-98) 
7-5-4.16. - Appeal of disputed charges. 
    Any person who disagrees with the amount of any charge made for any service provided in connection with the city's combined water and sewer system may submit a written appeal of that charge at any time before the due date of that charge. No appeal shall be accepted after the due date of the contested charge. All such appeals shall be determined by the commissioner having supervisory authority over the water department. The commissioner shall conduct such investigation of the appeal as the commissioner deems appropriate and thereafter render a written determination of the appeal. The decision of the commissioner shall be final. Unless otherwise ordered by the commissioner, submission of an appeal shall not excuse the timely payment of the disputed bill. However, should the commissioner determine that the appealing customer was billed more than the amount authorized by law, any payment in excess of the correct amount shall be refunded to the customer. 
(Ord. No. 3109, § 3, 12-1-98) 
7-5-5. - USE OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE WATER SUPPLIES 
7-5-5.1. - Use of publicly regulated water system required. 
(a)  No person owning or occupying any property within the city shall utilize any source of water for human consumption or for household, commercial or industrial purposes other than an available publicly regulated water system. 
    For purposes of this section, an "available publicly regulated water system" shall mean, with respect to a given parcel, any water main located within two hundred (200) feet of any property line describing a lot or tract, which water main delivers water supplied by the municipal water system operated by the city or any other municipality, water supplied by any public water district, or water supplied by any community well existing as of July 1, 1999, which well is both subject to the jurisdiction of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and operated in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated or enforced by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
7-5-5.2. - Limitations on construction of private water wells. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall drill, dig, drive, or otherwise construct any private water well of any nature whatsoever in that area within the corporate limits of the city which is serviced by the municipal water system operated by the city and which is situated within Sections 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, and 34 of Township 26 North, Range 4 West (Fondulac Township) in Tazewell County, Illinois. For purposes of this section, a "private water well" shall mean any water well constructed by any person or entity other than the city. 
(Ord. No. 3331, § 1, 7-2-02) 
7-5-5.3. - Variances authorizing the construction of private water wells. 
    Where no available publicly regulated water system exists, the city council may, by resolution, authorize the construction of a private water well, but only if all of the following conditions have been met: 
(a)  The site of the private water well does not lie within one thousand (1,000) feet of any potential source of contamination by any hazardous or special waste; and 
(b)  The private water well is constructed in accordance with all applicable laws or regulations, including, without limitation, the following, as they now exist or may from time to time be amended: 
1.  The Illinois Water Well Construction Code, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 415, Section 30; and 
2.  The Illinois Water Well Pump Installation Code, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 416, Section 35; and 
3.  The Illinois Water Well and Pump Installation Contractor's License Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 225, Section 345; and 
4.  Environmental Protection Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 415, Section 5; and 
5.  Illinois Administrative Code, Title 77: Public Health, Chapter I; Department of Public Health, Subchapter r: Water and Sewage, Parts 920 (Illinois Water Well Construction Code) and 925 (Illinois Water Well Pump Installation Code) (77 Ill. Adm. Code 920.10 et seq., and 77 Ill. Adm. Code 925.10 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 3159, §2, 7-6-99) 
7-5-6. - CONTROL OF CROSS-CONNECTIONS 
7-5-6.1. - General policy. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of the rules and regulations set forth in this section 6, is: 
(1)  To protect the public water supply system from contamination or pollution by isolating within the consumer's water system contaminants or pollutants which could backflow through the service connection into the public water supply system; 
(2)  To promote the elimination or control of existing cross-connections, actual or potential, between the public water supply system and those portions of a consumer's water system which carry nonpotable water and sources or systems containing substances of unknown or questionable safety; 
(3)  To provide for a continuing program of inspection and maintenance of controls over cross-connections in order to prevent the contamination or pollution of the public water supply system and/or consumer's water systems. 
(b)  Application. The rules and regulations set forth in this section 6, shall apply to all premises served by the public water supply system. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.2. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section which regulates cross-connections: 
    Agency means the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Auxiliary water system means any water source or system on, or available to a premises other than the public water supply system. Auxiliary water may include water from another water purveyor's public water system; or water from a source such as wells, lakes, or streams, or process fluids; or used water. These waters may be polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or system over which the water purveyor does not have control. 
    Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the intended source of the potable water supply. 
    Backflow prevention device means any approved device, method or type of construction intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All devices used for backflow prevention in the city must meet the standards of the agency and the plumbing code and must, in addition, be approved by the Research Foundation for Cross-Connection Control of the University of Southern California, American Water Works Associations American Society of Sanitary Engineering, or American Nations Standards Institute or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation to be in compliance with applicable industry specifications. 
    Certified inspector means a cross-connection control device inspector certified by the agency and approved by the city. 
    Consumer or customer means the owner, lessee, occupant, official custodian and/or any other person in control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to the public water supply system. 
    Consumer's water system means any water system located on the consumer's premises. A building plumbing system is considered to be a consumer's water system. 
    Contamination means an impairment of the quality of water by entrance of any substance to a degree which could create a health hazard. 
    Cross-connection means any physical connection or arrangement between two (2) otherwise separate piping systems, one (1) of which contains potable water and the other of which contains a substance of unknown or questionable safety or quality, whereby there may be a flow from one (1) system into the other. 
    Direct cross-connection means a cross connection formed when a water system is physically jointed to a source containing an unknown or unsafe substance. 
    Double check valve assembly means an assembly composed of single, independently acting check valves approved under ASSE Standard 1015. A double check valve assembly must include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing the watertightness of each check valve. 
    Fixed proper air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the receptacle. 
    Health hazard means any condition, device or practice in a water system or its operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well-being of consumers. The word "severe" as used to qualify "health hazard" means a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in death or significant reduction in the quality of life. 
    Indirect cross-connection means a cross-connection through which an unknown substance can be forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe potable water system. 
    Inspection means a careful and critical examination of all materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of a plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the plumbing code or the regulations set forth in this section 6, for the control of cross-connections. 
    Nonpotable water means water not safe for drinking, personal or culinary use as determined by the requirements of 35 Ill. Adm. Code 604, as amended or replaced from time to time. 
    Plumbing means all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including without limitation lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to, within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live; work or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping, from discharge or pumping units to and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a building drain and a sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system five (5) feet beyond the foundation walls. 
    Plumbing code means the code regulating the installation, maintenance and repair of plumbing within the City of East Peoria found at title 4, chapter 5 of the East Peoria City Code. 
    Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a health hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
    Potable water means water which meets the requirements of 35 Ill. Adm. Code 604, as amended or replaced from time to time, for drinking, culinary and domestic purposes. 
    Potential cross-connection means a fixture or appurtenance with threaded hose connection, tapered spout, or other connection which would facilitate extension of the water supply line beyond its legal termination point. 
    Process fluid(s) means any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, pollutional or system hazard if introduced into the public water supply system or a consumer's water system. This includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Polluted or contaminated waters; 
(2)  Process waters; 
(3)  Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; 
(4)  Cooling waters; 
(5)  Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams or irrigation systems; 
(6)  Chemicals in solution or suspension; 
(7)  Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other processes, or for fire fighting purposes. 
    Public water supply system means all mains, pipes and structures through which water is obtained and distributed to the public through the water supply system operated by the City of East Peoria, including wells and well structures, intakes and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally. 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device means a device containing a minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves together with an automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the two (2) check valves and approved under ASSE Standard 1013. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks shall be less than the supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks. 
    Service connection means the opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at the water main through which water is supplied from the public water supply system to the consumer. 
    Superintendent of water means the Superintendent of Water for the City of East Peoria and any person authorized by the superintendent to act on behalf of the superintendent including, without limitation, any employee or contractor of the city or any certified inspector. 
    Survey means the collection of information pertaining to a consumer's water system. 
    System hazard means a condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply system or a consumer's water system. 
    Used water means any water supplied by the public water supply system to a consumer's water system after it has passed through the service connection and is no longer under the control of the superintendent of water. 
    Water purveyor means the owner or official custodian of a public water system other than that operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.3. - Cross-connections prohibited. 
    Connections between the public water supply system or between any portion of a consumer's water system intended to carry potable water and other systems or equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable quality are prohibited except when and where authorized by the superintendent of water pursuant to the plumbing code and the regulations set forth in this section 6, and except when fitted with backflow prevention devices or methods as set forth in this section 6. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.4. - Survey and inspections. 
(a)  The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the superintendent of water for a survey or inspection to determine the presence or absence of cross-connections within the consumer's premises, to verify compliance with all applicable regulations including the plumbing code and for testing, repair and maintenance of back flow prevention devices within the consumer's premises. 
(b)  On request by the superintendent of water, the consumer shall furnish information to the superintendent of water regarding the plumbing system within the consumer's premises. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.5. - Backflow prevention required. 
(a)  A backflow prevention device whenever required shall be installed at the point of connection to the public water supply system or as otherwise required by applicable regulations including, without limitation, the plumbing code and the regulations set forth in this section 6. 
(b)  A backflow prevention device shall be installed at the sole cost and expense of the consumer on each service line to a consumer's water system serving premises where the following conditions exist: 
(1)  Any premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary supply is accepted as an additional source by the superintendent of water and the source is approved by the agency; 
(2)  Any premises on which any substance is handled which can create an actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system. This shall include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters originating from the public water supply system which are no longer under the sanitary control of the superintendent of water; 
(3)  Any premises having internal cross-connections that, in the judgment of the superintendent of water, are not correctable or intricate plumbing arrangements which make it impractical to determine whether or not any cross-connection exists; 
(4)  Premises where, because of security requirements or other prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a complete cross-connection survey; 
(5)  Premises having a repeated history of cross-connections being established or re-established. 
(6)  Whenever in the judgment of the superintendent of water, actual or potential hazards to the public water supply system exist. 
(c)  A backflow prevention device shall be installed at the sole cost and expense of the consumer on each service line to a consumer's water system servicing the following facilities unless the superintendent of water determines that no actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system exists: 
(1)  Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, nursing homes; 
(2)  Laboratories; 
(3)  Piers, docks, waterfront facilities; 
(4)  Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or stormwater pumping stations; 
(5)  Food or beverage processing plants; 
(6)  Chemical plants; 
(7)  Metal plating industries; 
(8)  Petroleum processing or storage plants; 
(9)  Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors; 
(10)  Car washes; 
(11)  Pesticide, or herbicide or extermination plants and trucks; 
(12)  Farm service and fertilizer plants and trucks. 
(d)  Backflow prevention devices shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Maintenance as recommended by the manufacturer of the device shall be performed. The manufacturer's maintenance manual shall at all times be readily available on the site where the backflow prevention device is installed. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.6. - Type of protection required. 
(a)  The type of backflow prevention device installed shall be determined by the superintendent of water based upon the degree of hazard which exists. In determining the type of device required, the following considerations shall apply: 
(1)  An approved, fixed proper air gap separation shall be installed where the public water supply system may be contaminated with substances that could cause a severe health hazard. 
(2)  An approved, fixed proper air gap separation or an approved, reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the public water supply system may be contaminated with a substance that could cause a system hazard or health hazard. 
(3)  An approved, fixed proper air gap separation or an approved, reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device or a double check valve assembly shall be installed where the public water supply system may be polluted with substances that could cause a pollution hazard not dangerous to health. 
(b)  Where a public water supply or an auxiliary water supply is used for a fire protection system, reduced pressure principle backflow prevention devices shall be installed on fire safety systems when: 
(1)  The fire safety system contains antifreeze, fire retardant or other chemicals; 
(2)  Water is pumped into the system from another source; or 
(3)  Water flows by gravity from a nonpotable source; or water can be pumped into the fire safety system. 
(c)  All other fire safety systems connected to the potable water supply shall be protected by a double check valve assembly on unmetered service lines. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.7. - Inspection, maintenance, testing and recordkeeping. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the consumer at any premises on which any backflow prevention device is installed or are required to be installed to inspect, test, maintain and repair such device in accordance with the following schedule or more often where inspections indicate a need or are specified in manufacturer's instructions: 
(1)  Fixed, proper air gap separations shall be inspected to document that a proper vertical distance is maintained between the discharge point of the service line and the flood level rim of the receptacle at the time of installation and at least annually thereafter on the anniversary of such installation. Corrections to improper or by passed air gaps shall be made within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(2)  Double check valve assemblies shall be inspected and tested at time of installation and at least annually thereafter on the anniversary of such installation. Required service shall be performed within five (5) days after any defect occurs. 
(3)  Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention devices shall be inspected and tested at the time of installation and at least annually on the anniversary of such installation or more frequently if recommended by the manufacturer. Required service must be performed within five (5) days after any defect occurs. 
(b)  All inspection and testing shall be completed by a certified inspector at the expense of the consumer. 
(c)  Each backflow prevention device shall have a tag attached, listing the date of the most recent test or inspection, name of the certified inspector who conducted the test and inspection, and type and date of repairs. 
(d)  The consumer at the sole cost and expense of the consumer shall retain a maintenance log for each backflow prevention device on the premises where the device is located which shall include: 
(1)  Date of each test or visual inspection; 
(2)  Name and approval number of the certified inspector performing the test or visual inspection; 
(3)  Test results; 
(4)  A description of repairs or servicing required; 
(5)  The date repairs or servicing is completed. 
(e)  The maintenance log shall include all required information pertaining to the backflow prevention device for the previous five (5) years. 
(f)  The consumer acting through a certified inspector shall at the sole cost and expense of the consumer file with the superintendent of water a report of each inspection or test of each backflow prevention device. 
(g)  All records pertaining to backflow prevention devices filed with the superintendent of water shall be available for inspection by the agency as provided by law. 
(h)  Backflow prevention devices shall not be bypassed, made inoperative, removed or otherwise made ineffective without specific written authorization from the superintendent of water. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.8. - Booster pumps. 
(a)  Where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or within any premises, such pump shall be equipped with a low-pressure cut-off device designed to shut off the booster pump when the pressure in the service line on the suction side of the pump drops to twenty (20) psi or less. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the consumer to maintain the low-pressure cut-off device in proper working order. A low-pressure cut-off device shall be treated as a backflow prevention device for purposes of section 7-5-6.7, which requires inspection, maintenance, testing and recordkeeping pertaining to such devices. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.9. - Violations. 
(a)  The superintendent of water shall deny or discontinue, after reasonable notice to the consumer, the water service to any premises wherein any backflow prevention device required by these regulations is not installed, tested, maintained or repaired in accordance with this section 6, or other applicable regulations, or if it is found that the backflow prevention device has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross-connection exists on the premises, or if a low-pressure cut-off required by these regulations is not installed and maintained in working order or if evidence of inspection, maintenance or testing has not been filed with the superintendent of water. No notice of a discontinuation of water service is required should the superintendent of water conclude that immediate disconnection is necessary in order to prevent a health hazard. 
(b)  Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the consumer has corrected or eliminated such conditions or defects in conformance with applicable regulations and to the satisfaction of the superintendent of water. 
(c)  The city, the superintendent of water, and its other officers, employees and agents shall not be liable to any consumer or any other person for any injury, damages or lost revenues which may result from termination of a consumer's water supply in accordance with the terms of this chapter, whether or not said termination of the water supply was with or without notice. 
(d)  The consumer responsible for back-siphoned material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the public water supply system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired backflow prevention device, or a device which has been bypassed, shall bear the cost of cleaning the public water supply system. 
(e)  Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any provisions of this section 6, pertaining to the control of cross-connections shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
7-5-6.10. - Administration. 
    The superintendent of water may establish and maintain administrative procedures which shall be utilized to administer this section 6, as necessary to insure safe, adequate and clean water. 
(Ord. No. 3800, § 2, 6-3-08) 
TITLE 8 - FIRE REGULATIONS 
CHAPTER 1. - FIRE PREVENTION 
SECTION: 

8-1-1. - Adoption of International Fire Code, 2012 Edition. 
(a)  "The International Fire Code, 2012 Edition" (the "IFC" or "Fire Prevention Code") as published by the International Code Council, Inc., is hereby adopted and made applicable within the City of East Peoria, in the State of Illinois. 
(b)  The following sections of the IFC are hereby completed as follows: 
(1)  Section 101.1 insert: "City of East Peoria". 
(2)  At Section 109.4 insert: "misdemeanor violation of the East Peoria City Code punishable in accordance with the general penalty provisions of the East Peoria City Code" in place of the bracketed material "[SPECIFY OFFENSE]". Also delete "punishable by a fine of not more than [AMOUNT] dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding [NUMBER OF DAYS] or both such fine and imprisonment." 
(3)  Section 111.4 is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following is substituted in lieu thereof: "Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition shall be subject to penalties as provided by Section 109.4 of this code." 
(4)  Section 5704.2.9.6.1 is hereby completed to read as follows: "in all territory within the corporate limits of the City of East Peoria, Illinois other than those areas of the City assigned to the "M2 Manufacturing District, General' zoning classification." 
(5)  Section 5706.2.4.4 is hereby completed to read as follows: "in all territory within the corporate limits of the City of East Peoria, Illinois other than those areas of the City assigned to the 'M2 Manufacturing District, General' zoning classification." 
(6)  Section 5806.2 is hereby completed to read as follows: "in all territory within the corporate limits of the City of East Peoria, Illinois other than those areas of the City assigned to the 'M2 Manufacturing District, General' zoning classification." 
(7)  Section 6104.2 is hereby completed to read as follows: "in all territory within the corporate limits of the City of East Peoria, Illinois other than those areas of the City assigned to the "M2 Manufacturing District, General zoning classification." 
(8)  Appendices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H and I of the Fire Prevention Code are hereby adopted. Appendix J is not adopted. 
(c)  The "NFPA 101 Life Safety Code, 2012 Edition" as published by the National Fire Protection Association is hereby adopted and made applicable within the City of East Peoria in the State of Illinois. 
(1)  Section 24.3.5.1 pertaining to automatic sprinkler systems in new one- and two-family dwellings is hereby deleted. 
(d)  In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of the IFC, the Life Safety Code or any other provisions of the city Code, including other codes adopted or incorporated by reference by the city Code, the terms of the more stringent code as determined by the fire chief in consultation with the director of the department of buildings and inspections of the city shall apply. 
(e)  All fire department connections on either sprinklers or standpipes shall meet both of the following specifications: 
(1)  A five-inch locking Storz connection. 
All connections shall be equipped with listed plugs or caps. In the event of a conflict between this subsection (e) and any provision of any other ordinance or code applicable in the city including, without limitation, the IFC or the Building Code, then the provisions of this subsection (e) shall govern. 
(Ord. 1709, 8-26-80; Ord. No. 3076, § 1, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 3107, § 1, 11-17-98; Ord. No. 3504, § 1, 1-4-05; Ord. No. 3596, § 1, 3-15-05; Ord. No. 3758, § 3, 10-16-07; Ord. No. 4161, § 6, 6-17-14; Ord. No. 4187, § 32, 9-16-14) 
8-1-2. - Bureau of fire prevention; establishment, composition. 
(a)  A bureau of fire prevention and fire inspection is hereby established for the city, which bureau shall enforce all provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The chief or an assistant chief of the fire department may designate and detail such number of men from the uniformed force of the fire department as from time to time are deemed necessary to carry out the duties and functions of the said bureau. 
8-1-3. - Inspections and investigations; entry powers. 
    The fire chief or any member of the fire department whom he may designate shall have the right and authority to enter any building, structure or premises within the city at any reasonable hour, upon proper identification, for the purpose of making inspections or investigations with respect to enforcement of the provisions of this Title. 
8-1-4. - Elimination of hazards; order, service, review. 
(a)  Whenever any member of the fire department shall find in any building or upon any premises or other place a dangerous accumulation of combustible or explosive materials or highly flammable substances likely to burn, so situated as to endanger persons or property, or shall find junk, junk cars or other obstacles in or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors, windows or any other place likely to interfere with the operations of the fire department, or the egress of the occupants in case of fire, or shall find any violations of this chapter, he shall in writing, order that the same be remedied or removed within a specified time. 
    This order shall be served upon and complied with by the owner, occupant or person in control of such premises. 
(b)  Upon request by such owner, occupant or person in control, said order shall be reviewed by the fire chief, within such specified time limit. Said order shall remain in force and be complied with unless such order is revoked or modified by the fire chief within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of the request for such review. 
(c)  An order of any member of the fire department may be served upon the person to whom directed either by delivering a copy of the same to such person personally, or by delivering the same to and leaving it with any other person in control of the premises in question, or by sending such persons a copy of said order by registered mail to the last known post office address of such person. 
8-1-5. - Investigation of fires. 
    The fire chief or any member of his department whom he may designate shall investigate promptly the cause, origin and circumstances of each fire occurring within the city by which a person has been injured or property destroyed or damaged. If it appears to the officer making the investigation that such fire is of suspicious origin, he shall then immediately take charge of any physical evidence thereof or seal the premises and notify the proper authorities designated to make the investigation of such matter. 
8-1-6. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or opposes the enforcement of any provision of this title shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); and for each subsequent offense such person shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply with the provisions of this title shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 56, 7-3-01) 
8-1-7. - Separability of penalties. 
    The above penalty shall not be construed as precluding any other penalty and costs provided elsewhere in this title. 
(1970 Code) 
8-1-8. - Outdoor fires and open burning. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall set fire to or cause or permit to be burned in any yard, lot, street or alley, any rubbish, garbage, paper or other combustible material unless such material is confined during combustion to an approved incinerator. For purposes of this subsection an "approved incinerator" is one which prevents the escape of soot, cinders, fumes, gases and smoke. No fire may be set or caused or allowed to burn in or on any public right-of-way. 
(b)  The burning of leaves and other landscape waste material only is allowed during the period beginning on October 15 and ending on November 30 of each year and during the period beginning on April 1 and ending on April 30 of each year. However, the above indicated time spans may be expanded, shortened or completely abolished on a seasonal basis in the following manner: 
(1)  If the fire chief in his discretion determines that conditions will not permit the safe and proper burning of leaves and other landscape waste material, he may, by written notice posted in the East Peoria Municipal Building and distributed through such media as the fire chief in his discretion deems appropriate, entirely prohibit the burning of leaves and other landscape waste material during all or a portion of the period when such burning would otherwise be authorized by this subsection (b). 
(2)  In any event, no person shall burn leaves or other landscape waste material if, in the judgment of the fire chief or his designee, the burning of such material creates a general health hazard, creates a special health hazard for any nearby person who encounters or may encounter the products of combustion or endangers any adjoining building, structure or other property by the communication of smoke or fire. 
(3)  If the fire chief in his discretion determines that due to unusual seasonal conditions it would be appropriate to allow the burning of leaves and other landscape waste material at times other than those specified in this subsection (b), he may, by written notice posted in the East Peoria Municipal Building and distributed through such media as the fire chief in his discretion deems appropriate, extend the above specified time periods for the burning of leaves and other landscape waste material for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days prior to or subsequent to the times specified in this subsection (b). 
For purposes of this subsection, the term "landscape waste material" is defined as dry leaves, the dry trimmings or fallen pieces of trees or bushes not more than two (2) inches in diameter, and other dry vegetative matter as is ordinarily produced by any yard, garden or lot. "Dry" material includes only material which is not damp or wet as a result of rainfall, frost, dew or other external sources of moisture and is also seasoned by the evaporation of internal moisture commonly found in material recently cut from living plants. No landscape waste material may be burned that is transported from another yard, garden, lot or place except as is blown by the wind. 
(c)  The fire chief may in his discretion authorize the burning of any combustible material within the city, including, but not limited to, trees and brush being cleared from a lot, scrap building materials and vacant houses scheduled for demolition; provided, however, that leaves and other landscape waste material shall not be burned except pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. No person shall be authorized to burn any material or structure under the provisions of this subsection unless he has been issued a written permit by the fire chief or, in his absence, the assistant chief. The fire chief shall charge a fee for such permit in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). In addition, no building or structure shall be burned without first having secured a demolition permit in the manner provided by title 4, chapter 4 of this Code. Local, state and federal public bodies planning to engage in open burning within the city must notify the fire chief or, in his absence the assistant chief, of the location, nature and purpose of the planned burning at least two (2) hours prior thereto, but need not acquire a permit. With the sole exception of fires set and utilized by a professionally recognized fire department or brigade for training purposes, in no event shall any person burn any tires, rubber, plastic or any other material which when burned produces any toxic or noxious smoke, gases, odors or ash. 
(d)  The burning of material as authorized under subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section may occur only under the following conditions: 
(1)  Such burning may occur only between sunrise and sunset. Any fires shall be extinguished at sunset. 
(2)  Burning may be conducted only on days when the wind will not carry smoke or other products of combustion in the direction of structures or persons on nearby parcels. 
(3)  Fires shall be small and capable of being readily controlled or extinguished in the event that a change in wind direction or other factors would result in a violation of the regulations established in this section. 
(4)  A responsible person of not less than eighteen (18) years of age shall be present at the site of the fire at all times to observe and control the fire. 
(5)  Water shall be available by way of a hose connected to an operational water source which hose shall have a sufficient length and capacity to promptly extinguish the fire. 
(6)  Fires shall be completely extinguished and not allowed to smolder after substantial completion of the combustion. 
(e)  Any other provision of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, it shall be lawful for any person to burn combustible material for recreational purposes in a fire pit, but only under the following conditions: 
(1)  No combustible material may be burned in a fire pit located on any type of combustible decking. 
(2)  No combustible material may be burned in a fire pit if the fire pit is located inside of or within twenty-five (25) feet of any combustible structure or surface. 
(3)  Only dry, seasoned fire wood or charcoal briquettes may be burned in a fire pit. 
(4)  No flammable liquid other than commercially produced charcoal lighter fluid may be utilized to start a fire within a fire pit. 
(5)  A fire within a fire pit shall not be left unattended at any time. 
(6)  Any fire in a fire pit must be completely extinguished before the fire pit is left unattended. 
(7)  No combustible material may be burned in a fire pit unless an extinguishing agent such as a water hose, fire extinguisher or bucket of sand is immediately available and capable of extinguishing the fire in the event of an emergency. 
For purposes of this subsection, the term "fire pit" means any portable or permanent chiminea, fire pit, stove or other similar structure designed to contain outdoor fires. 
(f)  Any other provision of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, it shall be lawful for any person as a means of cooking food to burn combustible material ordinarily used for the purpose of cooking food outdoors in any permanent or temporary outdoor fireplace, grill or barbecue pit. Provided, however, that any such fire must be kept under competent and continuous supervision and must be kept a sufficient distance from any building, structure or other material so as not to constitute a fire hazard. 
(g)  If the fire chief or any officer of the fire department concludes that material is being burned in violation of any provision of this section or any other provision of the City Code, then the fire chief or any officer of the fire department may in his or her sole discretion order corrective measures including, without limitation, that the fire be immediately extinguished. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the orders of the fire chief or any officer of the fire department regarding any fire, including without imitation fires burning leaves and other landscape waste material pursuant to subsection (b) and fires authorized by the fire chief pursuant to subsection (c). 
(h)  Any person convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 2227, 2-16-88; Ord. 2569, 3-10-92; Ord. No. 3217, § 1, 6-20-00; Ord. No. 3292, § 57, 7-3-01; Ord. No. 3338, § 1, 3-26-02; Ord. No. 3890, § 1, 11-17-09) 
8-1-9. - Containers for combustible rubbish. 
    No person owning, occupying or in control of any building, lot or premises shall allow any combustible rubbish or other combustible material to accumulate or remain about such building, lot or premises unless such rubbish or other combustible material is placed and kept in a covered garbage receptacle of adequate size; provided, however, that such receptacle shall be constructed either of metal throughout, with a lining of metal, or of other approved material. Such container shall be equipped also with a self-closing top. 
8-1-10. - Storage of oily rags, etc. 
    Greasy, oily or paint soaked rags, waste or other combustible material of like character shall be stored in a self-closing metallic receptacle having metallic legs at least three (3) inches in height and securely braced. Such receptacles shall be kept safely clear of all combustible surroundings and their contents shall be cleared daily. 
8-1-11. - Ashes. 
    Ashes from the combustion of solid fuel shall be placed in incombustible metallic containers and no excessive accumulations of such ashes shall be permitted in any building. 
8-1-12. - Accumulations of waste materials. 
    Accumulations of waste paper, hay, grass, straw, weeds, litter or other combustible waste or rubbish of any kind shall not be permitted to remain in any yard, vacant lot or open space. All weeds, grass, vines or other growth, when such endangers property or is liable to be fired, shall be cut down and removed by the owner or occupant of such premises. 
8-1-13. - Storage and display of Christmas trees. 
(a)  Christmas trees stored or displayed for sale shall be kept outside of buildings at a distance of at least ten (10) feet from any building or structure, except that such trees may be stored closer to a blank masonry wall with the permission of the owner of such wall. 
(b)  No Christmas trees may be stored or displayed within thirty-five (35) feet of any gasoline pump. 
(c)  Trees remaining on hand after December 25 of any year shall be removed from the premises not later than December 31 of the same year. 
8-1-14. - Flammable apparel and toys. 
    No person shall manufacture, give away, offer for sale or sell within the city any article of wearing apparel or any toy which is of a material that may be hazardous to any person wearing, using or playing with such article by reason of high combustibility, flash fire characteristics or flaming up of such article of wearing apparel or toy when exposed to fire, flame or heat. 
8-1-15. - Vacant buildings. 
    No owner, lessee or other person in effective charge of any building shall permit it to remain vacant or unoccupied unless all doors, windows and other means of entry are effectively closed or locked or otherwise secured so as to prevent unauthorized persons from gaining access thereto. 
8-1-16. - General housekeeping; storage of stock. 
(a)  Broken windows, broken plastering, holes in floors, ceilings or combustible hollow partitions or sheathing and furring in any building shall be repaired without delay using an appropriate material of equal fire resistance. 
(b)  Stock and other stored materials shall be kept at least eighteen (18) inches below all ceilings and shall be piled so as not to interfere with the operation of fire doors and so as to maintain adequate aisles. 
(c)  In buildings equipped with automatic sprinklers, stock and other stored materials shall be kept at least eighteen (18) inches below the sprinkler heads. Where any stock or stored materials are piled over twelve (12) feet high, the clearance shall be thirty-six (36) inches. 
(d)  All stock and other stored material shall be kept in a neat, orderly and compact manner. 
(e)  When stock is dispensed directly from a shipping container and combustible material is used as protective packing, such packing material shall be removed from the container and disposed of in accordance with section 8-1-9 of this chapter. 
8-1-17. - Smoking regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, match or cigarette lighter: 
(a)  In any retail store where there are sold dry goods, clothing for men, women or children, floor coverings, curtains, upholstery or drapery material, bedding, paper products, pyroxylin plastics, paints, oils or similarly flammable material or products; provided, however, that smoking may be permitted in designated smoking areas approved by the fire chief; 
(b)  In any place where moving picture films are kept or stored; 
(c)  In public garages and livery stables; 
(d)  In any place where volatile flammable liquids are handled or hazardous processes exist; 
(e)  In any elevator used by the public; 
(f)  In any theater, church, school auditorium or gymnasium while occupied, except in rooms designated and approved as smoking rooms by the fire chief or his representative; 
(g)  In any building or premises used for public assembly where the combustible nature and quantity of the contents are such that, in the opinion of the fire chief, smoking would constitute a hazard to life or property; or 
(h)  In bed in any dormitory, rooming house, hotel, lodging house, hospital, convalescent home, home for the aged, apartment or private dwelling. 
    The owner or person in control of any place wherein smoking is prohibited shall cause to be conspicuously displayed notices or signs reading: "NO SMOKING". It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, cover up, deface, injure or disturb any such sign. 
8-1-18. - Exits and fire escapes. 
(a)  Every school, theater, apartment building, rooming house, hotel, restaurant, church and retail store shall have at least two (2) exits that can be opened from the inside, separated by at least twenty (20) feet. 
(b)  The fire escape regulations of the State of Illinois shall be the rule applied in requiring fire escapes, their maintenance, care and type of construction thereof, except as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  Every building used as a theater, hospital, school, rooming house, apartment house, lodging house, hotel, home for the aged, nursing home, convalescent home, factory or mill or for offices, workshops or public assemblage for entertainment above the first story not having proper and sufficient exits or facilities for escape in the case of fire, shall be equipped with fire escapes combined with suitable balconies, platforms, railings and stairways firmly anchored to the outer walls and arranged to take as many approved openings of each story as may be necessary to make them accessible, safe and adequate for the escape of the occupants in case of fire. 
State Law reference- Fire Escape Act, 425 ILCS 15/1 et seq. 
8-1-19. - Exit and fire escape signs. 
(a)  Each such exit shall be designated by a suitable sign "EXIT" or "FIRE ESCAPE" located over or immediately adjoining every such doorway or opening through which one must pass to reach such exit or fire escape. 
(b)  Every "EXIT" or "FIRE ESCAPE" sign shall have letters not less than five (5) inches high, and shall be illuminated by external or internal illumination so as to be clearly visible to the public at all times. 
(c)  Directional signs shall be provided in premises requiring such designation where the path of travel or the location of the exit or fire escape is not clear and unmistakable due to intersections or hallways, turns or corridors or other intervening partitions. Such directional signs shall bear the words "TO EXIT" or "TO FIRE ESCAPE". Such directional signs shall be illuminated when necessary so as to be clearly visible to the public at all times. 
(d)  All illuminated exit, fire escape and directional signs shall be maintained on a separate electrical circuit. 
8-1-20. - Exit doors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lock or fasten any door or other means of exit from any floor of any building or premises where persons are gathered for business, employment, worship, conference, instruction or entertainment or where persons are lodged or housed, during the time such buildings or premises are so occupied, in any manner that will not permit the easy and immediate opening of such door or other means of exit from within, without any special knowledge and without the use of a key. 
8-1-21. - Storage of combustible materials under stairways, in elevator shafts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, store or keep, or permit to be placed, stored or kept, under or at the bottom of any stairway, or inside or outside any elevator or other shaft in any building, any combustible or flammable materials, fluids or compounds; nor shall such combustible or flammable materials be placed, stored or kept in any place where fire or burning would obstruct or render hazardous egress from a building. 
8-1-22. - Aisles. 
(a)  All aisles, passageways, corridors and exits of all such places named in section 8-1-20 hereof, shall be kept free from stools, chairs, sofas, draperies, stock and other obstructions, and no person shall be allowed to stand in or occupy such aisles, passageways, corridors or exits. 
(b)  No obstruction of any kind that will hinder or block access or egress of occupants or would interfere with the operation of the fire department will be permitted on any fire escape, in any hallway, passageway, stairway, window, driveway, alley or doorway in or upon any premises within the city. 
8-1-23. - Fire extinguishers. 
(a)  Every public building, apartment house, rooming house, hotel, motor court, school or any place storing or using flammable liquids shall have a suitable type of fire extinguisher approved by Underwriters Laboratory, Incorporated or the Factory Mutuals Engineering Corporation. 
(b)  There shall be at least one (1) fire extinguisher on each floor, including the basement, of every such building named above, and at least one (1) extinguisher shall be provided at each entrance to every room or area where flammable liquids are stored or used. 
(c)  The fire chief or any member of the fire department as he may designate shall have authority to approve the proper type, size and location of each fire extinguisher and the installation of the same. 
(d)  Every fire extinguisher shall be kept in proper working order and must be kept filled with the proper extinguishing agent at all times. 
(e)  Every fire extinguisher in use shall be inspected or tested at least once every year by the fire chief or some member of the department designated by him or some other person approved to make such inspection or test. Each such fire extinguisher shall have attached thereto an identification tag showing the date when recharged or tested and signed by the person making such test. Every person testing or recharging fire extinguishers shall report to the fire department, within ten (10) days, the location and identification of the extinguishers, the date when tested or recharged, results of such test and the chemical being used. 
8-1-24. - Fire lanes and streets. 
    No person, contractor or street or highway department shall close any street, alley or fire lane for repair or construction purposes or obstruct the same in any manner, at any time, without notifying the fire department at least two (2) hours before closing or obstructing the same. 
(1970 Code) 
Cross reference- Fire alarm wires, notice, § 4-2-10. 
8-1-25. - Fees for services. 
(a)  Vehicle fires. When emergency response services are rendered by the East Peoria Fire Department for a fire in a vehicle owned by any person, business or other entity who is not a resident of the City of East Peoria, Illinois, there shall be a charge for fire protection services to the owner of the vehicle of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(b)  Extrication from vehicles. When emergency response services are rendered by the East Peoria Fire Department for extrication of any person who is not a resident of the City of East Peoria, Illinois, from any vehicle and the owner of the vehicle is a person, business or other entity who is not a resident of the City of East Peoria, Illinois, there shall be a charge for extrication services of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The person extricated and the owner of the vehicle shall be jointly liable for the amount due. 
(Ord. No. 3622, § 1, 6-2-05) 
CHAPTER 4. - FIREWORKS 
SECTION: 

8-4-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Consumer fireworks. Any explosive composition or substance or combination of substances prepared for the purpose of producing an audible or visible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation that must comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations of the U.S. Consumer Products Safety Commission and classified as fireworks by regulations of the United States Department of Transportation, as these regulations are amended from time to time. It shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which required fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, sky rockets, roman candles, bombs or other fireworks of similar construction or any other tablets and devices containing any explosive substance, compound or mixture; provided, however, that the term "consumer fireworks" shall not include snake or glow worm pellets; smoke devices; sparklers (which shall include only such a device that is a stick or wire coated with pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 100 grams and produces a shower of sparks upon ignition); trick noise makers known as "party poppers", "booby traps", "snappers", "trick matches", "cigarette loads" and "auto burglar alarms"; toy pistols, toy guns or other devices in which paper caps are used; provided further, that such paper caps contain twenty-five one-hundredths grains or less explosive compound and that they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic caps that contain less than twenty hundredths grains of explosive mixture; the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
    Display fireworks. Any substance or item classified as a Division 1.3G explosive or firework that is used for professional outdoor displays, as defined under the Pyrotechnic Use Act (425 ILCS 35/0.01 et seq.) and the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act (225 ILCS 227/1 et seq.). 
    Lead pyrotechnic operator. An individual who is responsible for the safety, set up, and discharge of the pyrotechnic display and who is licensed with the state pursuant to the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act (225 ILCS 227/1 et seq.). 
    Pyrotechnic display. The detonation, ignition, or deflagration of display fireworks or flame effects to produce visual and audible effects of an exhibitional nature before the public, invitees, or licensees, regardless of whether admission is charged. 
    Pyrotechnic distributor. Any individual, firm, corporation, or other entity as provided under the Pyrotechnic Use Act (425 ILCS 35/0.01 et seq.) who distributes display fireworks for sale in the State of Illinois, provides display fireworks as part of a pyrotechnic display service in the State of Illinois, or provides only pyrotechnic services and who is licensed with the state pursuant to the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act (225 ILCS 227/1 et seq.). 
    Pyrotechnic production company. Any individual, firm, corporation, or other entity as provided under the Pyrotechnic Use Act (425 ILCS 35/0.01 et seq.) who provides pyrotechnic services or pyrotechnic display services as part of a film, digital and video media, television, commercial, music, or theatrical production and who is licensed with the state pursuant to the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act (225 ILCS 227/1 et seq.). 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 2755, § 1, 1-3-95; Ord. No. 4386 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
8-4-2. - Possession, sale, use or storage. 
    No person shall possess, sell, offer for sale, expose for sale, loan, give away, store or have in possession with intent to sell, or to use, discharge or cause to be discharged, fire or otherwise set in action within the city any fireworks, including any display or consumer fireworks as herein defined; provided, however, that public exhibition of display fireworks and pyrotechnics may be given if a permit for such display is granted by the city as provided herein. 
(Ord. 2571, 4-21-92; Ord. No. 2755, § 2, 1-3-95; Ord. No. 4386 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
8-4-3. - Seizure authorized. 
    The fire chief with approval of the city council shall seize, take, remove or cause to be removed, at the expense of the owner, all stocks of fireworks, including consumer fireworks and display fireworks, offered or exposed for sale, stored, or held in violation of this chapter. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 4386 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
8-4-4. - Fireworks displays and exhibitions. 
(a)  A permit for a professional pyrotechnic display (exhibition of fireworks) may be issued pursuant to chapter 4 of title 3 of the city Code only when the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The pyrotechnic display will be set up and performed by a pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor licensed by the State of Illinois; and 
(2)  The pyrotechnic display will be set up and performed by a lead pyrotechnic operator licensed by the State of Illinois who is employed by a pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor licensed by the State of Illinois; and 
(3)  The name of the lead pyrotechnic operator, along with proof of the license held by the lead pyrotechnic operator and proof of the license held by the pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor seeking the exhibition of fireworks permit, shall be provided with the permit application materials; and 
(4)  Proof of insurance by providing a certificate of insurance demonstrating liability insurance coverage meeting the requirements of section 1-8-4.13 of the city Code that covers the pyrotechnic display event and all periods of time when pyrotechnic or explosive materials are in the actual or constructive possession of the pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor, including when these materials are being stored, transported, handled, use, discharged, and displayed in relation to the permitted event; furthermore, the proof of insurance must also demonstrate that the certificate holder has additional insurance coverage as follows: (i) general aggregate liability coverage of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00), (ii) excess liability coverage of four million dollars ($4,000,000.00) per occurrence, and (iii) a minimum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident in workers compensation insurance coverage; and 
(5)  The insurance coverage carried by the pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor shall be carried with an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Illinois; and 
(6)  The city shall be listed as an additional insured under the insurance policy carried by the pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor, which shall be shown on the certificate of insurance provided with the permit application materials; and 
(7)  Certification that any employee or assistant working for the pyrotechnic production company or pyrotechnic distributor putting on the pyrotechnic display is at least eighteen (18) years of age, and if the employee or assistant is possessing, using, purchasing, or transferring any explosives for the setting up or performing of the pyrotechnic display, the individual is at least twenty-one (21) years of age; and 
(8)  The application for the permit for the exhibition of fireworks has been submitted to the city not less than twenty-five (25) days prior to the pyrotechnic display event. 
(b)  The requirements of this section are in addition to any requirements established under chapter 4 of title 3 of the city Code for the issuance of a permit for the exhibition of fireworks. However, despite any provision in chapter 4 of title 3 of the city Code to the contrary, the issuance of a permit for the exhibition of fireworks must be approved by the city council before the city clerk may issue such permit. 
(c)  The fire chief, or his designee, must be permitted to inspect and must approve the display site for any pyrotechnic display before the permit for the exhibition of fireworks is issued and the pyrotechnic display is performed. No pyrotechnic display shall be performed until this inspection has been completed and approval has been given by the fire chief or his designee. The fire chief, or his designee, has the authority and discretion to immediately stop any pyrotechnic display at any time to ensure the safety of the display site and the safety of the viewing public. 
(d)  The exhibition of fireworks may only be performed at the pyrotechnic display event set forth in the permit, and the possession, use, and distribution of fireworks will only be permissible for the permitted event. A permit for the exhibition of fireworks is non-transferrable. 
(e)  A display or exhibition of consumer fireworks is prohibited in the city. 
(Ord. No. 4386 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
8-4-5. - Exceptions to chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: 
(a)  The use of fireworks by railroads or other transportation agencies for signal or illumination purposes; provided, however, that such used articles will be disposed of by burying the same in the ground or immersing the same in water; or 
(b)  The use of blank cartridges for signal or ceremonial purposes in athletics or sports contests; or 
(c)  Use by the Armed Forces of the United States or the State of Illinois. 
(1970 Code; Ord. No. 4386 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
Editor's note- Formerly codified as § 8-4-4 which was renumbered by Ord. No. 4386 . 
CHAPTER 5. - LOCK BOX SYSTEM REQUIRED 
SECTION 

8-5-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall have the indicated meanings: 
(a)  Lock box means a key lock box manufactured by the Knox Company of Irvine, California, or any successor company which manufactures a compatible system. 
(b)  Commercial building means any building in the city used or designed for commercial, industrial or multi-family purposes except as follows: 
(1)  Any such building protected and/or patrolled at all times by security guards. 
(2)  Multi-family residential complexes which do not have locked doors or gates which protect a common corridor or other means of providing access to the living units. 
(3)  Nursing homes. 
4)  Buildings owned or occupied by any local, state or federal unit of government. 
(5)  Buildings that are open for business twenty-four (24) hours per day. 
(c)  Owner means the owner of record, tenant, lessee or other person having a possessory or proprietary interest in a commercial building. 
(d)  Existing commercial building means a commercial building which has been completed and lawfully occupied before June 15, 1998. 
(e)  New commercial building means a newly constructed commercial building completed on or after June 15, 1998 or an existing commercial building which has been remodeled pursuant to a building permit which authorizes improvements having a value in excess of twenty thousand ($20,000.00) which improvements are to be completed on or after June 15, 1998. 
8-5-2. - Applicability to new buildings. 
    The owner of each new commercial building shall install a lock box near the main entrance of the building at such specific location as the fire chief deems appropriate before occupying the building. No occupancy permit shall be issued for a new commercial building until a lock box has been installed as required by this chapter. 
8-5-3. - Applicability to existing commercial buildings. 
    The owner of each existing commercial building shall install a lock box near the main entrance of the building at such specific location as the fire chief deems appropriate by June 15, 2000. 
8-5-4. - Contents of lock box. 
    Each lock box on each commercial building shall contain a properly labelled key or keys which will allow access by the fire department to the building in the event of an emergency call to that building. 
8-5-5. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 3075, § 1, 6-23-98; Ord. No. 3292, § 59, 7-3-01) 
TITLE 9 - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL HEALTH AND SANITATION REGULATIONS 
SECTION: 

9-1-1. - Policy and purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to regulate and control all persons under its jurisdiction insofar as reasonably necessary for the purposes of public health as provided in this Title. Whenever any ambiguity or uncertainty exists, the provisions of this Title shall be interpreted, if possible, to effectuate the above declaration of policy. 
9-1-2. - Health officer to record births, deaths. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to collect and keep records pertaining to miscarriages, stillbirths, births, illnesses, accidents and deaths occurring within the city and at appropriate times to compile statistics in regard to such and prepare indices therefrom as are useful in determining the health status of the city. 
    This section shall become effective at such times as the city council shall, by resolution, deem it possible to carry out its provisions. 
9-1-3. - Doctor, etc. to report births, deaths. 
    It shall be the duty of the doctor or attendant at any birth, stillbirth or death to file a proper record of the same on proper forms provided by the city health officer in the office of said health officer. 
    This section shall become effective at such time as the city council shall, by resolution, deem it possible to carry out its provisions. 
9-1-4. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or opposes the enforcement of any of the provisions of this Title shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and for each subsequent offense such person shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which said violation, neglect or refusal to comply with the provisions of this Title shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 60, 7-3-01) 
9-1-5. - Separability of penalties. 
    The penalty provided in the preceding section shall not be construed as precluding any other penalty or costs provided elsewhere in this Title. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 2. - FOOD AND BEVERAGES 
SECTION: 

9-2-1. - Wholesome food, etc. required. 
    All food, drink and raw material used in the preparation thereof shall be fresh, sound, wholesome and safe for human consumption. Food in the process of decomposition, adulterated or otherwise unwholesome shall not be served, offered for sale or sold. 
State Law reference- Pure food regulations, 410 ILCS 620/9. 
9-2-2. - Confiscation of unwholesome food. 
    No person shall bring or cause to be brought into the city, or shall keep, store, sell or offer for sale for human consumption, any decayed or unwholesome vegetables or fruits or any diseased, tainted, impure or otherwise unwholesome meat, fish, bird or fowl. The health board shall forthwith cause seizure and destruction of all such meat and provisions. 
9-2-3. - Unwholesome or condemned food. 
    Food or drink which has become unfit for human consumption shall be kept separate and apart from other food which is held and offered for sale, and it shall be properly denatured, marked "CONDEMNED" and removed daily, and no accumulation of condemned food, rubbish or offensive material shall be permitted in any room or place where food or drink is prepared, exposed, handled, stored, offered for sale or sold, except in suitable receptacles made of metal for holding without leakage all garbage, waste, rubbish or offensive material which may accumulate during twenty four (24) consecutive hours, which receptacles shall be provided upon every licensed premises. Every such receptacle shall be substantially airtight and watertight shall be fitted with a tight cover, and shall be kept covered except when being filled or emptied. 
9-2-4. - Adulterated or misbranded food. 
    No person shall have, sell or offer for sale in the city any food which is adulterated or misbranded. 
(a)  Food shall be deemed adulterated: 
(1)  If any substance has been mixed with it so as to reduce, lower or injuriously affect its quality or strength; or 
(2)  If any inferior or cheaper substance has been substituted wholly or in part therefor; or 
(3)  If any valuable constituent of the article has been wholly or in part abstracted; or 
(4)  If it consists wholly or in part of diseased, decomposed, putrid or rotten animal or vegetable substance, or any portion of any animal unfit for food, or if it is a product of a diseased animal or one that has died otherwise than by slaughter; or 
(5)  If it is colored, coated, polished or powdered, whereby damage is concealed, or it is made to appear better than it actually is; or 
(6)  If it contains any added poisonous ingredient or any ingredient which may render it injurious to health; or, if it contains any antiseptic or preservative not evident and not made known to the purchaser or consumer by some means reasonably calculated to convey this information; or 
(7)  If, in the case of a confectionery, it contains terra alba, barytes, talc, chrome yellow or other mineral substance or poisonous coloring matter, or flavor, or other ingredients deleterious or detrimental to health, or any vinous, malt or spirituous liquor or compound, or narcotic drug; or 
(8)  If, in the case of spirituous, fermented and malt liquors, it contains any substance or ingredient which is not normally present in such liquors, or which may be deleterious or detrimental to health when such liquors are used as beverages. 
(b)  Food shall be deemed as misbranded: 
(1)  If it is an imitation, or is offered for sale under the distinctive name of another article; or 
(2)  If it is labeled or branded so as to deceive or mislead the purchaser, or if the contents of the package as originally put up shall have been removed in whole, or in part, and other contents shall have been placed in such package; or 
(3)  If the package or its label shall bear any statement, design or device regarding the ingredients or the substances contained therein, which statement, design or device shall be false or misleading in any particular; or 
(4)  If it is other than it is represented to be. 
(c)  Sausage and sausage meat shall be deemed to be adulterated: 
(1)  lf it contains cereal vegetable starch, vegetable flour, milk or its derivatives, or analogous substances in excess of the limits prescribed under the regulations of the board; or 
(2)  If it contains any added coloring matter; or 
(3)  If it contains added water or moisture in excess of limits prescribed under the regulations of the board; or 
(4)  If it contains any substance or ingredients which render such meat or meat food products unsound, unhealthful unwholesome or unfit for human food; or 
(5)  If it contains any dye, preservative or added chemical except common salt, sugar, wood smoke, cider vinegar, wine vinegar, malt vinegar, sugar vinegar, glucose vinegar, spirit vinegar, pure spices, saltpeter or nitrate of soda. 
State Law reference- Adulterated or misbranded food, 410 ILCS 620/3.9. 
9-2-5. - Storage, transportation and display of foods for sale, generally. 
    All food stored or transported shall be protected from dust, dirt, flies and other contamination, and no food shall be deposited or allowed to remain nearer than two (2) feet above the surface of any sidewalk, street, alley or other public place, or the floor of any building where stored or exhibited, unless the same shall be contained in boxes or other receptacles so as to be protected from dogs and other animals and their excretions. No candy, bread, pastry or other bakery products for sale, shall be displayed in any open window or doorway of a building or other public place, unless such candy, bread, pastry or other bakery product is separately wrapped in paper or contained in a dustproof and flyproof wrapper or container. 
9-2-6. - Display of food. 
    All food or drink not protected by flyproof and dustproof wrappers must be covered in cases of glass, metal or other material so as to reasonably prevent contamination from dust, dirt, flies and other sources, and all show or display cases, windows, counters or shelves used in handling, keeping and displaying food and drink shall be kept clean and sanitary, free from such contaminating agents or material, and in good repair. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the necessary exposure of food during the immediate process of serving in a food dealer where food is served for immediate consumption on the premises. 
9-2-7. - Refrigeration of food, generally. 
    All perishable food or drink shall be stored and kept refrigerated in a properly constructed refrigerator, the temperature of which shall not exceed fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit at any time. All refrigerators, iceboxes and appurtenances thereof used for the storage of food or drink shall be kept clean and sanitary, and in good repair, and any compartment used for the storage of ice shall be lined in such a manner as to be watertight. Waste water from refrigerators, iceboxes, refrigerated display cases, windows, counters, vats or tanks or other containers used in refrigerating and storing food and drink shall discharge into properly trapped sewer connections. 
    All bakeries or other food dealers manufacturing foods containing custard cream filling consisting essentially of milk, cream, butter, eggs, sugar or cornstarch and flavor shall provide adequate refrigeration for the storage of such bakery goods at a temperature of not more than fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit. Immediately after cooling, all such custard or cream-filled bakery goods shall be placed in such refrigerator and kept there until sold. 
9-2-8. - Sale of food on pushcarts. 
    Where not otherwise prohibited by this Code, no food or drink shall be sold, offered for sale or dispensed upon any stand, pushcart, wagon or other licensed vehicle, or in any street or other public place, except that food or drink may be dispensed on such vehicles or in such places if kept in closed bottles, packages or containers until the time of sale, and then served only in single-service containers that are destroyed after being used once. 
Cross reference- See § 3-9-1 et seq. of this Code for provisions relating to peddlers, itinerant merchants, etc. 
9-2-9. - Utensils. 
(a)  Use and care, generally. All utensils, apparatus and appurtenances thereof used in the preparation and handling of food or drink shall be so constructed and placed that they can be thoroughly cleansed, and they shall be kept clean and sanitary, and in good repair.
