The use of any utensil in the preparation, service and sale of food or drink which is worn, rusted, corroded or in such condition that it cannot be rendered clean and sanitary by washing is prohibited. 
(b)  Cleaning. Every food dealer where food or drink is served or consumed on the premises, or served from the premises to be consumed elsewhere, shall be provided with ample facilities for the washing and proper cleansing of utensils with hot and cold water. All utensils shall be properly cleansed after being used and no utensil shall under any circumstances be used a second time, unless it shall have been properly cleansed after a previous use thereof. In such cleansing the use of water which has become insanitary by previous use is prohibited. 
    No utensil will be deemed to have been properly cleansed, unless after each use of such utensil it shall have been cleansed by any one of the following methods: 
(1)  By mechanical dish-washing machines which have a direct connection to a hot water supply and which subject all surfaces of the utensils, either in washing or rinsing, to a temperature of not less than one hundred eighty (180) degrees Fahrenheit for not less than one minute. 
(2)  By hand washing in warm water containing soap or other effective cleansing agent, followed by complete immersion of all utensils in clean water to a temperature of not less than one hundred eighty (180) degrees Fahrenheit for not less than one minute. 
(3)  By a combined cleansing and disinfecting method in which the utensils are washed in clean water containing an organic compound in such quantity as to yield not less than two hundred (200) parts per million of available chlorine when first added and at no time thereafter less than sixty (60) parts per million. 
The wash water used in this method must be changed whenever the cleansing properties of the solution are so reduced that the utensils are not thoroughly cleansed of visible matter. 
(4)  By a chlorine rinse method in which the utensils are washed in water containing soap or other effective cleansing agent; then rinsed in clean water to remove the soap, and again immersed for at least two (2) minutes in a second rinse of clean water containing a disinfectant in such quantity as to yield not less than one hundred (100) parts per million of available chlorine when first added, and not less than sixty (60) parts per million of available chlorine at any time thereafter. The chlorine solution must be in a container which does not absorb or react with chlorine. In using this method, the first rinse water shall not be permitted to become soapy, and three (3) compartment vats must be used, the first compartment for washing, the second for rinsing and the third for chlorine immersion. 
Sterilization by any of the above prescribed methods shall not apply to single-service containers, either utensils or straws, made of paper or wood or similar materials that are used but once and then destroyed. All such single-service containers shall be protected from dust, flies and contamination until used. 
The use of any article, polish or substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poison is prohibited for the cleansing or polishing of copper, nickel, silver, silverplated ware, appliances or utensils in any food dealer. 
(c)  Storage. All utensils after having been cleansed and sterilized must be stored, kept and handled in a manner reasonably calculated to prevent contamination from dust, flies or other sources. 
9-2-10. - Stoves, ovens. 
    All stoves, ovens and ash pits shall be provided with ventilating hoods and pipes, or with other mechanical means to so ventilate them as to render harmless to persons working therein or nearby any steam, gases, vapors, excessive heat or impurities that may be generated or released, and all stoves and ovens shall be kept clean and sanitary, and in good repair. 
9-2-11. - Preparation of food for sale in living quarters. 
    No food or drink intended for public sale shall be prepared or processed in a room which is used for sleeping quarters or for human habitation. 
State Law reference- Sleeping in rooms where food is prepared for sale, 410 ILCS 650/9. 
9-2-12. - Animals in food establishments. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, or any person having the care or custody of a dog, cat or other animal to permit such animal to enter any food establishment; provided, however, that the person owning or operating such premises may permit a watchdog to remain therein if held or restrained in such a way that such dog cannot injure or come in contact with any food. 
9-2-13. - Ventilation; screens and doors. 
    All kitchens shall be provided with mechanical means of ventilation. Every water closet or urinal compartment in any food dealer, except when provided with mechanical means of ventilation, shall have a window at least one foot by three feet (1'×3') opening to the external air, with an increase of seventy two (72) square inches in the size of the window for each additional water closet. The entire window shall be made so as to readily open. The door shall be self-closing where the compartment opens into the room where food or drink is prepared, exposed, handled, stored, offered for sale or sold; and, if required by the board of health, a suitable and properly lighted vestibule shall be provided, and the door of such vestibule shall be self-closing. All water closet compartments and vestibules shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, and in good repair. 
    All doors, windows and other openings shall be properly screened from the first day of May to the first day of November of every year, and all screen doors shall be provided with self-closing devices. 
State Law reference- Doors and screens in food establishments, 410 ILCS 650/4. 
9-2-14. - Food dispensers and employees; infectious or venereal disease. 
    No person who has any infectious or venereal disease in any infectious stage shall be permitted to work as a food dispenser. The board of health, or any person delegated by it, shall be empowered to make such examinations of food dispensers as may be deemed necessary to determine the presence of such infectious or venereal disease and any food dispensers and persons seeking employment as food dispensers shall submit to such physical examinations, either by a physician of the board, or otherwise, as the board deems necessary for the preservation of public health. The board shall have the power to prohibit the employment of any food dispenser or prospective food dispenser who is suffering from any disease detrimental to public health or who shall refuse to submit to such examinations as the health officer may deem necessary to determine the presence of such disease. It shall be the duty of the proprietor of any food dispensary to require such examinations as the health officer may require before accepting any person for employment as a food dispenser. The board shall have the power to require examinations of food dispensers at such intervals of time as may be deemed necessary. 
State Law reference- Permitting persons afflicted with contagious or venereal diseases to work in food establishments, 410 ILCS 650/10. 
9-2-15. - Food dispensers and employees; toilets and washrooms. 
    A sufficient number of water closets, conveniently located, shall be provided for all employees engaged in the preparation or handling of food or drink, and such water closets shall be kept clean and sanitary, and in good repair. A washroom conveniently located shall be provided and furnished with soap, running water and fresh, clean, individual towels daily. A notice shall be conspicuously posted in the water closet compartment or washroom directing all employees to cleanse their hands on leaving the toilet and immediately before commencing work. The use of the public toilet towel is prohibited. 
State Law reference- Toilet rooms and lavatories in food establishments, 410 ILCS 650/5. 
9-2-16. - Food dispensers and employees; personal cleanliness. 
    All food dispensers shall wear clean garments, shall be clean in their habits, shall thoroughly wash their hands before beginning work, shall keep them clean while working and shall wash their hands immediately after visiting the toilet. 
State Law reference- Clothing of operators or employees of food establishments, 410 ILCS 650/2. 
9-2-17. - Evidence of intent to use food for human consumption. 
    The presence of any food, drink or raw food material in any part of a food dealer's premises shall be deemed prima facie evidence of its intent to be used for purposes of human consumption. 
9-2-18. - Disposition of funds received. 
    The city treasurer shall credit all sums received by virtue of this chapter to the public health board fund of the city, to be used by such Board to defray the cost of enforcement of this chapter. 
9-2-19. - Vermin, etc.; walls, ceilings and floors. 
    The places where food and food products are stored, manufactured, processed, served or offered for sale shall be free from flies, rats and vermin; and the walls and ceilings shall be constructed of a smooth, hard material and must be kept clean and sanitary, and in good repair. The floors shall be smooth and watertight and must be kept clean and sanitary, and in good repair, and shall be scrubbed or flushed with water daily. 
State Law reference- Walls, ceilings and floors in food establishments, 410 ILCS 650/3. 
9-2-20. - Lighting. 
    All rooms or places in which food or drink is prepared, exposed, handled, stored, offered for sale or sold shall be properly and adequately lighted. 
9-2-21. - Retail food establishments; inspection, generally. 
    Every keeper of a meat market or dealer in meats or every grocer or milk dealer shall allow any duly authorized agent of the public health board to freely and fully inspect any milk, meat, fish or vegetables or other foodstuffs kept, offered or intended for sale thereby, and shall answer all reasonable and proper questions asked by such agent relative to the condition thereof and to the places such articles may be. 
9-2-22. - Cleanliness of storage places. 
    Every person being the owner, lessee or occupant of any room, stall or place where any meat, fish or vegetables designed or held for human food shall be stored or kept, or shall be held or offered for sale, shall put and keep such room, stall or place and its appurtenances in a clean and wholesome condition. 
9-2-23. - Storage of food, generally. 
    Every person being the owner, lessee or occupant of any room, stall freight house, cold storage house or other place, other than a private dwelling, where any meat, fish, poultry, game, vegetables, fruit or other perishable articles adapted or designed to be used for human food shall be stored or be kept, whether temporarily or otherwise, and every person having charge of or being interested or engaged in the care, custody or sale of any such article of food shall put, preserve and keep such article of food in a clean and wholesome condition, and shall not allow the same, nor any part thereof, to become putrid, decayed, poisoned, infected or in any manner rendered or made unsafe or unwholesome for human food. 
9-2-24. - Frozen meat thawed; label required. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale for human consumption any meat, poultry or fish which has been frozen and later thawed, unless such meat, poultry or fish is plainly labeled to indicate this, and such labels shall be on the display counter or table where such meat is offered, and also on each package in which such meat, poultry or fish is wrapped when sold or delivered. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 3. - DISEASE CONTROLS[1] 
SECTION: 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Special duties of license (mobile home parks), § 3-16-23. 

DIVISION I. - IN GENERAL 

9-3-1. - Spitting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit or expectorate upon the floor or against the wall, steps, entrance or any other part of any church, schoolhouse, passenger depot, courthouse or other public building; nor of any store, office, shop, dwelling or room of any private building frequented by the public or to which the public is invited; nor in any taxicab or other vehicle accommodating the public. 
9-3-2. - Common drinking cups. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup or cups, dipper or other similar utensil for the use of more than one person in any park, playground, school theater, store, hotel or other place frequented by the public. 
9-3-3. - Common towels. 
    No owner, lessee, tenant, manager or other person in charge or control of the management of any hotel, cafe, rooming house, factory, office building, boarding house, restaurant, mill, workshop, bakery, laundry, store, lavatory or other place wherein guests are entertained or laborers or employees or persons are accommodated, for compensation or without compensation, where any washroom, toilet room or other room is furnished, kept or supplied shall furnish for the use therein of its guests, employees or patrons any towel for the use of more than one person, unless it be a so-called continuous towel; and all towels furnished for the use of patrons or other persons in any of the places mentioned in this section shall be adapted only for the use of a single person, unless the so-called continuous towels are furnished. 
9-3-4. - Towels; sufficient supply. 
    Every owner, lessee, tenant, manager or other person in charge or control of the management of any of the places mentioned in section 9-3-3 furnishing towels for the use of guests, employees, patrons or other persons shall furnish or cause to be furnished daily a supply sufficient for all such persons entitled to use the same; and whenever so-called continuous towels are furnished, they shall be furnished in sufficient numbers or shall be changed often enough so that a clean portion of the same shall always be available for use. 
9-3-5. - Sale of secondhand clothing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, expose or offer for sale any article of secondhand clothing or wearing apparel by means of which disease may be conveyed, unless such articles have been thoroughly disinfected by means approved by the health officer. 
9-3-6. - Impure ice. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer or expose for sale or deliver within the city any impure ice or ice containing any filth, or other matter deleterious to health. 
9-3-7. - Depositing garbage, dead animals, filth. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place, deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any garbage, dead animal, animal matter, filth or other refuse upon any street, alley or other place, private or public, within the city, except in places that may be designated as dumping grounds by the board of health, or as elsewhere provided. 
9-3-8. - Accumulation of garbage, manure, etc.; removal. 
    It shall be unlawful to accumulate or permit to remain any pile or deposit of manure, garbage or any other offensive or nauseous substances within the city. Any such substances must be removed to such places as may be designated as dumping grounds by the board of health, or as elsewhere provided. 
9-3-9. - Stagnant pools of water. 
    Any stagnant pool of water in the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his control. 
9-3-10. - Condition of premises. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any building, structure or place to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous or detrimental to the public health in any way. Any such structure, building or place is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
9-3-11. - Minimum heating of apartments, offices, stores. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person who shall lease by oral or written agreement any apartment, office or store and who has undertaken by said agreement to furnish heat for the tenant or occupant therein to provide heat to such rooms, apartments, offices or stores from September 15 of each year to June 15 of the succeeding year. 
(b)  The minimum temperature that shall be maintained in apartments or rooms of lodging is sixty eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit from seven thirty o'clock (7:30) A.M. to ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. and sixty five (65) degrees Fahrenheit from ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. to seven thirty o'clock (7:30) A.M. 
(c)  The minimum temperature that shall be maintained in offices and stores is sixty eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. until closing time and a minimum of sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit from closing time in the evening until eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. 
(d)  Provided, however, that failure to furnish the heat required shall not constitute an offense hereunder where it is due to a breakdown of the heating plant if diligence is used to have such plant repaired, nor where it is due to strikes, to a general shortage of fuel, to any act of the tenant making the complaint, or to any cause beyond the owner's control. 
9-3-12. - Diseases transmissible to man from animals. 
    It shall be the duty of any owner or possessor of any animal to report to the health officer the existence with respect to such animal of any disease which is transmissible to human beings. 
DIVISION II. - CONTAGIOUS DISEASES 

9-3-13. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
(a)  Carrier means any person who, without symptoms of communicable disease, harbors and disseminates the specific micro-organism. 
(b)  Fumigation means a process by which the destruction of bacteria, insects, lice and animals is accomplished by the employment of gaseous agents. 
(c)  Isolation means the separating of a person suffering from a communicable disease, a carrier of the infecting organism, or a person suspected of having such a disease or of being a carrier thereof from other persons, in such places and under such conditions as will prevent the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent. 
(d)  Quarantine means the limitations of freedom of movement of any person who is sick with or who has been exposed to a communicable disease. 
9-3-14. - Diseases dangerous to public health to be reported. 
    It shall be the duty of every physician, attendant, laboratory technician, parent, householder, principal, teacher or any other person having knowledge of a known or suspected case of contagious, infectious or communicable disease or any other disease dangerous to the public health to report the same immediately to the health officer. 
9-3-15. - Enforcement of state law. 
    The health officer shall enforce the state statutes and the rules and regulations of the State Department of Public Health relative to the control of communicable disease. 
9-3-16. - Investigation by health officer. 
    The health officer or his duly authorized representative shall make such investigation as in his judgment may be necessary to determine the presence or absence of any communicable disease. 
9-3-17. - Quarantine. 
    The health officer, in such cases as may be reasonably necessary, may establish a quarantine and direct that no person shall enter or depart from such premises except physicians, nurses or necessary attendants who have had special training in the control of communicable disease. Said officer shall establish and enforce reasonable quarantine rules; and he shall determine the time when the quarantine shall end. 
9-3-18. - Removing quarantine placards; violating quarantine. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully tear down, cover or deface any placard put upon quarantined premises under the direction of the health officer. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any quarantine established or rules pursuant thereto. 
9-3-19. - Delivery of food, etc. to quarantined premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the delivery of food or drink intended for human consumption to enter any premises which are quarantined because of the existence of a contagious disease. No containers or bottles shall be removed from such premises until the termination of the quarantine; and no such containers which have been left at the premises during the quarantine shall be placed in use for the carrying of food or drink until they have been thoroughly sterilized. 
9-3-20. - Fumigation of quarantined premises. 
    Premises which have been quarantined shall be thoroughly fumigated or otherwise freed from all risk of contagious disease under the supervision of the health officer before the quarantine shall end. 
9-3-21. - Spreading contagion. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or carelessly spread or cause the spread of any contagious disease. 
9-3-22. - Isolation of carriers. 
    The health officer or his representative may isolate or restrict the movement of carriers of contagious diseases until such carriers are shown by laboratory tests to be free from the organisms of the disease. 
9-3-23. - Securing material for laboratory analysis. 
    The health officer or his representative shall secure such material for laboratory analysis as is necessary in determining the diagnosis of illness or the existence of the carrier state in any person; and any such person, upon request, shall provide such material or permit such material to be taken by said officer. 
9-3-24. - Clothing worn by attending persons. 
    Every physician, nurse or attendant waiting upon a person having smallpox or similar contagious or infectious disease shall change or thoroughly disinfect his clothing before going upon any street or into any public place. 
9-3-25. - Vaccination against smallpox. 
    In case of an epidemic of smallpox or whenever it reasonably appears necessary to prevent the contagion of smallpox, the health officer or his representative may require a person to be vaccinated. It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully refuse to be so vaccinated. In case such person is unable to pay for such vaccination, the health officer shall provide the same free of charge. 
9-3-26. - Community education programs. 
    The health officer shall carry out programs of community education relating to those illnesses for which effective artificial immunity can be induced, to the end that such a number of inhabitants will cause themselves to be immunized as to prevent the entrance of such preventable illness into the city or to minimize the possibility of an epidemic. 
9-3-27. - Deaths to be reported. 
    It shall be the duty of every physician within the city to report in writing to the health officer the death of any of his patients who shall have died in the city of a contagious or communicable disease within twelve (12) hours thereafter, and to state in such report the specific name and type of such disease. 
9-3-28. - Supplementary regulations; authorization to commissioner of public health and safety. 
    The commissioner of public health and safety shall make all necessary rules and regulations supplementary to those contained in this chapter for the public health and welfare of the city as he may deem from time to time essential and necessary. 
DIVISION III. - VENEREAL DISEASE 

9-3-29. - Diseases enumerated; declared dangerous to public health. 
    The following diseases-syphilis, gonorrhea and chancroid-are hereinafter designated "venereal diseases." The same are hereby recognized and declared to be contagious, infectious, communicable and dangerous to the public health. 
9-3-30. - Report of infections required; information to be shown. 
    It shall be the duty of every physician, nurse, superintendent or manager of a hospital or dispensary, and of every person who makes a diagnosis or gives treatment for a venereal disease, to report to the city health officer, on a card supplied by the health officer, the name, age, sex, color, marital status and occupation of such diseased person; the nature and previous duration of such disease; and the probable source of infection. Such report shall be mailed within three (3) days after the first examination of such person. 
9-3-31. - Reports of venereal disease to be kept confidential. 
    All reports made pursuant to section 9-3-30 concerning persons infected with venereal disease shall be kept confidential and inaccessible to the public. 
9-3-32. - Preventing spread of infection. 
    Upon the receipt of a report of venereal disease, it shall be the duty of the health officer to institute such measures as will protect other persons from infection by such venereally-diseased person. Such measures include all those heretofore provided to prevent the communication of other contagious, communicable or infectious diseases. 
9-3-33. - Investigation of suspected cases. 
    In all suspected cases of venereal diseases in the infectious stages, the health officer shall immediately use every available means of ascertaining whether the person so suspected of being infected is suffering from the disease; and if so, such officer shall whenever possible ascertain the sources of infection. In such investigation the health officer is hereby vested with full powers of inspection, examination and isolation as in his judgment may be reasonably necessary. 
9-3-34. - Duties and powers of health officer. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer and he is hereby directed and empowered: 
(a)  To make any examination necessary of persons reasonably suspected of having syphilis in the infectious stages, gonococcus infection or chancroid. Because of the prevalence of such venereal diseases among prostitutes, procurers, persons guilty of lewd and lascivious conduct, and persons who associate with prostitutes, all such persons shall be considered within the above class; 
(b)  In examining or inspecting women pursuant to subsection (A) above, to appoint women physicians for such purposes whenever the services of a woman physician are requested or demanded by the person examined; 
(c)  To quarantine or isolate persons infected with any venereal disease whenever such quarantine or isolation is reasonably necessary to protect the public health. In establishing quarantine or isolation, the health officer shall define the limits or area in which the person reasonably suspected or known to have venereal disease and his immediate attendant are to remain. No persons other than the attending physician shall enter or leave such area without permission of such officer. In cases of quarantine or isolation such officer shall not terminate such quarantine or isolation until the cases have become noninfectious. 
9-3-35. - Infecting other persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to infect any other person with any venereal disease. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to perform or commit any act which exposes any other person to infection with any venereal disease. 
9-3-36. - Sales of drugs to be recorded. 
    Any druggist or other person who sells any drug, compound or preparation of any kind used, advertised, labelled or reasonably intended to be for the cure of any venereal disease, shall keep a record of the name, address and sex of any person making such purchase. 
    A copy of such record shall be mailed immediately to the city health officer. 
9-3-37. - Effective date of Division III. 
    This Division III shall become effective at such time as the city council, by resolution, shall deem it necessary to carry out its provisions. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 4. - AIR POLLUTION CONTROL 
SECTION: 

9-4-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be known and cited as the East Peoria Air Pollution Control Code. 
9-4-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
(a)  Air contaminant means particulate matter, dust, fumes, gas, mist, smoke or vapor or any combination thereof. 
(b)  Air contaminant source means any and all sources of emission of air contaminance, whether privately or publicly owned or operated. Without limiting the foregoing, this definition includes all types of business, commercial and industrial plants, works, shops and stores; heating power plants and stations; buildings and other structures of all types, including single and multiple family residences, apartments, houses, office buildings, hotels, restaurants, schools, hospitals, churches and other institutional buildings; automobiles, trucks, tractors, buses and other motor vehicles; garages and vending and service locations; and stations, railroad locomotives, ships, boats and other water-borne craft; portable fuel burning equipment, incinerators of all types, indoor and outdoor, refuse dumps and piles, and all stack and other chimney outlets from any of the foregoing. 
(c)  Air pollution means presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one or more air contaminants in sufficient quantities and of such characteristics and duration as to be injurious to human, plant or animal life or to property, or which unreasonably interferes with the enjoyment of life and property. 
(d)  Commission means the air pollution control commission of the city. 
Cross reference- Air pollution control commission, Title 2, ch. 12. 
9-4-3. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
    The intent and purpose of this chapter is to maintain the purity of the air resources of the city consistent with the protection of the normal health, general welfare and physical property of the people, maximum employment and the full industrial development of the city. The commission shall seek the accomplishments of these objectives through the prevention, abatement and control of air pollution by all practical and economically feasible methods. 
9-4-4. - Air pollution prohibited. 
    The discharge into the outdoor atmosphere of an air contaminant so as to cause air pollution and create a public nuisance is contrary to the public policy of the city and is hereby declared unlawful and a violation of this chapter. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 5. - SANITATION OF BUILDINGS AND PREMISES 
SECTION: 

9-5-1. - Health nuisance defined. 
    Any building or part thereof which, by reason of its unsanitary condition or of its being infected with disease, is unfit for human habitation or which from any other cause is a source of sickness among the inhabitants of the city or which otherwise endangers the public health is hereby deemed a public nuisance. 
9-5-2. - Use of premises. 
    No person owning, occupying or in control of any building or premises shall use or permit the use of the same for the existence or performance of any thing or act dangerous or prejudicial to the public health. 
9-5-3. - Unsanitary or unhealthy buildings not to be leased. 
    No owner, agent, lessee or person in possession, charge or control of any building, or any part thereof, shall lease or let the same, or any portion thereof, or allow the same to be occupied by any person as a dwelling or lodging house unless such premises are in a clean, wholesome and sanitary condition and fully comply with all provisions of the minimum housing regulations of this Code. 
Cross reference- Minimum housing regulations, Title 4, ch. 8. 
9-5-4. - Duty of persons vacating premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person occupying any building or premises, or portion thereof, not to remove or cause to be removed therefrom, before vacating the same, all garbage, ashes, rubbish, refuse or miscellaneous waste, or to leave such building or premises in any condition detrimental or dangerous to health. 
9-5-5. - Overcrowding premises. 
    No owner, lessee or keeper of any apartment house, rooming house, boarding house, hotel or dormitory shall cause or allow the same to be overcrowded or so great a number of persons to dwell, remain or sleep in any such house, or any portion thereof, as to cause any danger or detriment to health. 
9-5-6. - Inspection powers. 
    The health officer is hereby authorized and empowered to cause a sanitary inspection to be made of any and all buildings or premises within the city at any reasonable hour. 
9-5-7. - Notice of nuisance. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to cause an examination to be made of any building or premises alleged to be a public nuisance. If the health officer shall find that a public nuisance exists, as defined in this chapter, he shall serve written notice upon the owner or person in control of the building or premises, or his agent, directing such person to abate such nuisance and within forty eight (48) hours to place such building or premises in a condition which shall not endanger the public health. 
9-5-8. - Abatement by city; costs. 
    Upon failure of an owner or person in control to place any building or premises in a sanitary condition within forty eight (48) hours of the notice required by the preceding section, the health officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance. Such officer shall keep an account of the costs and expenses of placing such premises in a sanitary condition, and upon completion of the same shall certify such costs to the city clerk. The clerk shall bill the owner or the person in control of the premises for such costs and expenses incurred by the city. 
(1970 Code) 
CHAPTER 6. - GARBAGE AND RUBBISH 
SECTION: 

9-6-1. - Construction. 
    In construction of this code, the definitions hereunder shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(a)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular number shall include the plural number; and the plural number shall include the singular number. 
(b)  The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
(c)  The word "may" is permissive or discretionary. 
(d)  Words not defined shall be interpreted in accordance with definitions contained in the latest edition of Webster's New Collegiate Dictionary. 
9-6-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Code, the words and phrases listed hereunder have the meanings designated herein, except when a particular context clearly requires a different meaning: 
    Ashes. Includes residue from fires used for cooking or heating buildings. 
    Brush. Includes trimmings from shrubs, trees or other woody plants. 
    Bulky wastes. Includes auto parts, tires, wheels, mechanical equipment, television sets, stoves, refrigerators, appliances, furniture pieces, rubbish, construction or demolition wastes, or trees, branches, stumps, bushes, root systems or trimmings not constituting brush. 
    City. The City of East Peoria, Illinois. 
    Construction and demolition waste. Includes lumber, plywood, paneling, plastic board, roofing scraps, plastic, glass, concrete, rubble, conduit, pipe, wire or other wastes generated from the construction, remodeling, repair or demolition of a building, dwelling, structure or portion thereof. 
    Garbage. Includes wastes resulting from the handling, packaging, preparation, cooking or consumption of food. 
    Other wastes. Includes any item not specifically enumerated and defined in this section. 
    Refuse. Includes garbage, rubbish, ashes, bulky wastes, brush, construction and demolition wastes. 
    Rubbish. Includes combustibles, such as paper, cardboard, cartons, wood, boxes, excelsior, plastic, rags, cloth, bedding, leather, rubber, grass, leaves, yard trimmings and garden wastes, or noncombustibles such as metal, tin cans, metal foil, dirt, stone, bricks, ceramics, crockery, glass or bottles, or combustibles thereof weighing fifty (50) pounds or less. 
    Solid waste driver. Includes a city employee under the direction and supervision of the director of city services, or a person, firm or corporation licensed as a refuse collector by the City of East Peoria. 
(Ord. 1947, 8-2-83) 
    Waterway. Includes any creek, ravine, ditch, culvert or other structure, channel or depression, whether natural or man-made, which regularly or intermittently conveys water from one location to another. 
(Ord. 2449, 8-7-90) 
9-6-3. - Department of solid waste created. 
    There is hereby established a department of the city which shall be known as the department of solid waste. Said department shall be a subordinate department of the department of streets and public improvements. 
9-6-4. - Superintendent of department of solid waste; office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of superintendent of solid waste. The superintendent of solid waste shall at all times act under the direct control of the director of city services. Such superintendent shall be the head of department of solid waste, and shall have charge of all property and equipment pertaining thereto and supervision over all officers and employees therein. 
9-6-5. - Powers and duties of superintendent. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of solid waste: 
(a)  To advise the public, when requested, in the matter of regulations pertaining to the sanitation system of the city; 
(b)  To conduct examinations and make inspections pursuant to the provisions herein; 
(c)  To enforce the provisions of this chapter; 
(d)  To keep records of actions taken, examinations, inspections and tests made, accomplishments and expenditures of his department, and such other records as the council may require; 
(e)  To perform such other duties as may be required of him by the commissioner of streets and public improvements; and 
(f)  To make a monthly report of his acts and doings to the city council. 
9-6-6. - Rules and regulations. 
    The commissioner of streets and public improvements shall have the authority and power to make rules and regulations from time to time for the collection of garbage, and shall give public notice of such rules and regulations. 
9-6-7. - CITY SERVICE 
9-6-7.1. - Service provided. 
    The city shall provide by its agents, contractors or employees a refuse collection and disposal service to persons owning or residing in one- and two-family dwellings within the city in the manner and to the extent provided in this chapter. The city shall not provide such service to any commercial, manufacturing, industrial, business enterprise, persons residing in residential buildings containing more than two (2) dwelling units, or within any mobile home park. 
9-6-7.2. - Director's authority. 
    The director of the city services is hereby authorized to publish schedules for the collection of refuse by the city and to establish and promulgate rules and regulations governing the actions of city refuse collectors. 
9-6-8. - REQUIREMENTS FOR UTILIZATION OF CITY COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE 
9-6-8.1. - Preparation of solid waste material. 
    All owners and occupants of dwelling units in one- or two-family dwellings utilizing the city's refuse collection and disposal service shall prepare all solid waste materials as follows: 
(a)  All garbage shall be thoroughly drained of all liquid. Liquids shall be separated from the regular waste and placed in a visible manner. 
(b)  All rubbish containing sharp objects shall be securely wrapped in paper. 
(c)  Ashes shall be extinguished so that no fire remains. 
(d)  No ashes shall be mixed with garbage, rubbish or brush. 
(e)  Brush shall not exceed four (4) feet in length or four (4) inches in diameter. Brush will only be picked up by the city during semi-annual clean up week. 
(f)  Appliances, "white goods," water heaters and other bulky wastes shall not be collected. 
(g)  Construction and demolition waste shall not be collected. 
(h)  Carpeting and padding will only be picked up by the city during semi-annual clean up week. 
(Ord. No. 2933, § 1, 10-1-96; Ord. No. 4106, § 1, 10-15-13) 
9-6-8.2. - Receptacles. 
    All owners and occupants of dwelling units in one- or two-family dwellings utilizing the city's refuse collection and disposal service shall comply with the following: 
(a)  Standards. Except as provided in section 9-6-8.3 and after being prepared in the manner required by section 9-6-8.1, all garbage, rubbish and ashes shall be placed for collection at the time and location provided in subsection 9-6-8.3(a) or be placed in a refuse receptacle in compliance with the following specifications: 
(1)  Approved receptacles. Until March 1, 2014 receptacles shall be constructed of galvanized metal, aluminum, plastic (plastic cans will be the owner's responsibility in freezing temperatures. The cans become brittle in these circumstances) or other water and weatherproof material. They shall taper from top to bottom, be fitted with handles or bales and be equipped with a cover or lid. Plastic bags of at least one and five-tenths (1 5/10 ) mil thickness, ties at the top, may be used, providing they carry the seal of the National Sanitation Foundation. Total capacity of any receptacle shall not exceed thirty-two (32) gallons and a total weight of the receptacle and contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds, including the weight of the receptacle. From and after March 1, 2014, receptacles shall be ninety-five-, sixty-five- or thirty-five-gallon toters that may be purchased from the City of East Peoria or leased or purchased through Waste Management or any other entity provided such toter has all of the following features: 
a.  0.175" minimum wall thickness. 
b.  One-piece injection molded high density polyethylene (HDPE) construction. 
c.  Extra wall thickness in bar area with rotating steel bar. 
d.  Non-slip, textured finish on outside corners with all other surfaces smooth inside and out with no protrusions. 
e.  Ergonomic handles. 
f.  Heavy duty integrated lid hinges. 
g.  In-molded bar supports. 
h.  In-molded, reinforced sleeve for bar-locking lifter or in-molded, reinforced frontal rim for comb lifters. 
i.  In-molded support ribs for reinforcement. 
j.  Seven-eighths-inch solid steel axles with wheels. 
k.  Three-eighths-inch bottom wear strip. 
l.  Sealed overlapping lid which opens to two hundred seventy (270) degrees. 
m.  In-molded integral hand grips for pushing/pulling the cart. 
n.  Lift bars must be between seventeen (17) and eighteen (18) inches above ground level. 
o.  All models must meet criteria for use with standard bar lock lifters or automated grabbers (bar must be metal) and must also be suitable for use with comb lifters or automated grabbers. 
(2)  Prohibited receptacles. Receptacles prohibited by the city shall include, but not be limited to, metal drums, fiber or paperboard drums, wire trash burners, barrels, paper shopping bags, cardboard boxes, receptacles without lids, open plastic bags or receptacles having sharp or jagged exposures. From and after March 1, 2014 galvanized metal, aluminum and plastic garbage cans and plastic garbage bags are prohibited. 
(b)  Responsibility for maintenance. It is the joint obligation of the owners and occupants of all dwelling units in one- or two-family dwellings utilizing the city's refuse collection and disposal service to provide approved refuse containers and to keep them in good repair. Whenever any receptacle shall become defective, it is the responsibility of the owner or occupant to repair or replace it. 
(c)  Procedure for disposal of defective receptacles. The city shall have the right to condemn defective receptacles by placing thereon a red tag or sticker which shall be notice to the owner or occupant of its defective nature. The owner of said receptacle shall replace or repair the same before it is used again. The city shall have the right to dispose of the defective receptacle during any subsequent collection. 
(d)  Delay or suspension of standards. The city council may by resolution partially or wholly delay or suspend the standards imposed by this section. 
(Ord. No. 2933, § 2, 10-1-96; Ord. No. 4106, § 2, 10-15-13) 
9-6-8.3. - Receptacle placement; collection requirements. 
(a)  Owners, operators or occupants utilizing the city's collection service shall place or cause to be placed, not later than five o'clock (5:00) a.m. of the day of collection and not earlier than six o'clock (6:00) p.m. of the day preceding collection, receptacles, rubbish, and brush on the curb line behind the curb, or within thirty (30) inches of the street surface where no curb exists, so placed that the contents will not be scattered by the wind or animals. Receptacles shall be returned to the premises within twelve (12) hours after having been emptied. 
(b)  Quantities. The city's weekly refuse collection and disposal service shall include the collection of: 
(1)  Not more than three (3) toters or mandatory receptacles meeting the requirements of subsection 9-6-8.2(a): 
(2)  An unlimited number of empty cardboard boxes, which, before collection shall be broken down by the owner or occupant utilizing the city's refuse collection and disposal service. 
(Ord. No. 4106, § 3, 10-15-13) 
9-6-9. - REQUIREMENTS FOR REFUSE RECEPTACLES 
9-6-9.1. - Owner's obligations and specifications. 
    The owners of business, commercial, manufacturing, industrial, mobile home parks or residential structures other than one- or two-family dwellings in which refuse is accumulated for disposal shall provide or cause to be provided refuse receptacles meeting the following requirements and shall further provide for private refuse collection of the contents thereof: 
(a)  Dumpsters. Covered metal attachable containers commonly known and referred to herein as "dumpsters" securely fastened with safety chains to permanently fixed objects or other safety device, so as to prevent them from tipping over. 
(b)  Roll-off boxes. Open metal attachable containers commonly known and referred to herein as "roll-off boxes." Said roll-off boxes shall not be used for the storage or disposal of garbage, rubbish or other refuse, if said use in such an open container would constitute a nuisance, cause an offensive or objectionable odor, or would be difficult because the contents would be scattered by the wind or animals. 
(c)  Exceptions. When the use of a dumpster or roll-off box would otherwise be required and where conditions exist which would make the use of such a device impossible or impractical, the director of city services may permit the use of other receptacles. Any person desiring to utilize a receptacle other than a dumpster or roll-off box, where the use of one would otherwise be required, shall submit a written application to the director of public works specifying the nature of the impossibility or impracticality and describing the proposed type of receptacle. The director may condition his approval in writing as necessary to provide a safe and sanitary refuse disposal procedure. 
9-6-9.2. - Location. 
(a)  One- and two-family dwellings: 
(1)  Except when lawfully set out for collection, no accumulated refuse or refuse container shall be stored in the front yard or in the front or side yard of any corner lot. 
(2)  Refuse not in receptacles shall be neatly stacked and screened from view until lawfully set out for collection. 
(b)  Other uses or occupancies: 
(1)  Dumpsters. Dumpsters shall not be permitted in the front yard or in the front or side yard on corner lots. Dumpsters located within twenty-five (25) feet of a dedicated public street shall be screened from view at all times. 
(2)  Roll-off boxes. Roll-off boxes shall not be permitted in a front or side yard or on a dedicated street right-of-way, unless the director of city services gives temporary permission for a roll-off box to be located on the public right-of-way or in a front or side yard. Dumpsters shall be located on a concrete or asphalt pad. 
(3)  Other receptacles. Other receptacles shall be placed and stored as specified in the permit received from the director of public works. 
(4)  Exceptions. Any person desiring to locate a dumpster or roll-off box on the dedicated public right-of-way in a yard where the placement of such a receptacle would otherwise be prohibited, other than temporarily, may submit a request to the director of city services specifying the proposed location, justifying the location, and explaining the receptacle's screening so as to shelter and protect surrounding properties to the same or a greater extent than if the receptacle was located in a yard where it would otherwise be permitted. 
9-6-10. - DEPOSIT AND STORAGE OF REFUSE 
9-6-10.1. - Depositing refuse; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, bury, throw, place or cause to be deposited, buried, thrown, or placed any refuse within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 61, 7-3-01) 
9-6-10.2. - Permitting refuse to remain, penalty and settlement options. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in control of property, whether occupied, unoccupied or vacant, to permit any refuse deposited, buried, placed or accumulated thereon, to remain, regardless of whether said owner or person in control permitted the refuse to be deposited, buried, placed or accumulated on the property. 
(b)  The penalty for a violation of this section shall be a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day that any violation of this section shall continue. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 3, 3-19-96) 
9-6-10.3. - Notice to abate refuse from lots with occupied structures. 
(a)  Whenever the owner or person in control of a parcel of land with an occupied structure permits any refuse to be placed, deposited, buried, thrown or to accumulate or remain thereon, the director of planning and zoning may cause the service, upon such owner or person, of an administrative ticket as provided in section 14(b) of chapter 1 of title 1 of this Code or a notice to abate a violation of refuse. 
(b)  An administrative ticket or a notice to abate shall be given by personal service, by certified mail or by posting a sign regarding the violation on the premises of the property in violation. 
(1)  Personal service may be obtained through delivery of the administrative ticket or the notice by a city employee or any person authorized by law to make personal service; 
(2)  Service may be obtained by certified mail addressed to the residence or usual place of business of the owner or person in control of the property; or 
(3)  Service by posting may be obtained by posting a sign in a conspicuous place near the main entrance of a structure on the property. If the city official issues a notice to abate, the posted sign shall be at least fourteen (14) inches in height and eight (8) inches in width and at the top thereof in large letters shall state the words: notice to abate. The text of the notice shall contain a reference to the provision of the City Code violated and may contain such other information respecting the nature of the violation as the department of planning and zoning deems advisable. It shall be unlawful for anyone to deface, tamper with or remove the "notice to abate" sign from the property where it is posted unless authorized by the director of planning and zoning. 
(c)  Upon the failure of the owner or persons in control to comply with the administrative ticket or notice to remove refuse from lots with occupied structures within seven (7) days from the date of the service of the administrative ticket or notice to abate by personal service, certified mail or posting, the director of planning and zoning may cause the removal of such refuse. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 4, 3-19-96) 
9-6-10.4. - Notice to abate refuse on vacant lots and on lots with unoccupied structures. 
(a)  The city shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city limits once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks during the spring and summer months of each year a notice informing all owners and persons in control of any vacant lot or any lot with an unoccupied structure that the existence of refuse on any such lot is contrary to the ordinances of the city. The notice shall further inform the public that should refuse ever accumulate, the city may remove the refuse without further notice and the owner or person in control shall be liable to the city for its costs. This notice shall be a display advertisement. 
(b)  Should refuse ever be deposited, buried, thrown, placed or accumulated or remain on any lot with an unoccupied structure, the director of planning and development may cause the removal of such refuse. 
9-6-10.5. - Lien and personal judgment. 
(a)  The cost of removing the refuse from private property may be recoverable from the owner or person in control of the real estate and is a lien thereon. The lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes, provided, however, that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred the city shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by the city in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Tazewell County. Upon payment of the cost of removing the refuse, the lien shall be released by the city. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose. 
(b)  If the city's costs for removing the refuse are not paid, the director of planning and development may commence proceedings in the circuit court seeking a personal judgment from the owner or person in control of the subject property. The action authorized by this section shall be in addition to, and without waiver of any other remedies. 
9-6-10.6. - Combining notice. 
    The notice required by this section, whether it is given by personal service, certified mail, posting or publishing, may be combined with a notice to abate a violation of weeds, annual plants or grasses. 
9-6-10.7. - Storage or disposal of refuse. 
(a)  Burning prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or set fire to or cause to be burned or cause to set fire to any refuse within the city unless such material shall be burned in an incinerator or furnace properly constructed for such purpose and approved by the Environmental Protection Agency. 
(b)  Exception. The burning of leaves shall be permitted as provided in this Code. 
(c)  Requirements as to the storage of food. It shall be unlawful for any person to store human or animal food or feed within the city limits in other than a rat-free and rat-proof container, compartment, room or building. 
9-6-10.8. - Disturbing refuse of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than a refuse collector employed or licensed by the city to remove, disturb or damage any refuse or refuse receptacle properly set out for collection, provided, however, any person may remove refuse set out for collection from property owned, rented or leased in which such person otherwise has a legal interest. 
9-6-11. - Penalty. 
    Except as provided in section 9-6-10, whenever, in this chapter, any act is prohibited or whenever the failure to comply with any action is declared to be unlawful, any person violating such provision shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be regarded as committed each day upon which a person shall continue the violation of a provision or permit any violation to exist. 
(Ord. 2400, 2-20-90; Ord. No. 3292, § 62, 7-3-01) 
9-6-12. - Severability clause. 
    If any provisions of this chapter or the application thereof is held to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such ruling shall not affect any other provisions of this Code not specifically included in such ruling or which can be given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or application; and to this end, the provisions of this Code are declared severable. 
(Ord. 1947, 8-2-83) 
CHAPTER 7. - NUISANCES[2] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances (licenses and permits), § 3-2-13. 

9-7-1. - Nuisances declared unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to wilfully or negligently create, erect, maintain or permit a nuisance to exist anywhere within the city. 
State Law reference- Power of city to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
9-7-2. - Penalty. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a nuisance, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, when no specific penalty is provided therefor, any person violating such provision shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 3292, § 63, 7-3-01) 
9-7-3. - Nuisances defined, generally. 
    Any thing, act, omission, occupation or condition which shall exist or continue for such a length of time as to: 
(a)  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the health, safety, peace or welfare of the public; or 
(b)  In any way render the public insecure in life or property; or 
(c)  Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or 
(d)  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, sidewalk, alley, navigable body or other public way or place; is hereby declared a nuisance. 
9-7-4. - Nuisances defined, general enforcement. 
    Any nuisance declared by statute, this chapter or other provisions of this Code or ordinances of the city shall be enforceable under the provisions of this chapter as if enumerated specifically herein. 
9-7-5. - Enumeration not exclusive. 
    Nuisances enumerated in this chapter shall not be deemed exclusive, but are in addition to and to be construed in conjunction with any other nuisances enumerated in statutes or other provisions of this Code or ordinances of the city. 
9-7-6. - Duty of city officers to investigate; power of entry. 
(a)  For the purpose of discovering nuisances, it shall be the duty of the police, fire, health and building officers and inspectors to investigate, confirm and report any nuisances coming to their attention. 
(b)  In order to investigate, confirm and report nuisances, said officers and inspectors shall, upon proper identification, be permitted at any reasonable hour and in a reasonable manner, to visit and enter into or upon any premises or property within the city to make an examination thereof, if they shall have reasonable grounds to believe that a nuisance exists. 
9-7-7. - Notice to proper officials. 
    Whenever any nuisance shall be reported to or investigated and determined by the police, fire, health or building officers or inspectors, notice shall be given to the owner or person in control of the property or premises involved, and to the appropriate city officials whose functions include the abatement of such nuisances. 
9-7-8. - Foul odors, filth. 
    It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the health, safety, welfare, peace and comfort of the city and its residents for any person. 
(a)  Businesses. To conduct any business or to use any premises so as to create an offensive or foul odor which taints the air and renders it nauseous to persons in the vicinity; or 
(b)  Animals. To keep or maintain any animals in an unclean or filthy manner or surroundings, or to keep or maintain any animals from which emit any particularly foul or offensive odors; or 
(c)  Animal carcasses, etc. To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon any premises or place any animal carcass or any offal, filth, excretion or other noisome or noxious animal matter of any kind which is, or is likely to become putrid, foul or offensive; or 
(c)  Vegetable matter. To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon any premises or place any slop or other vegetable matter of any kind which is or is likely to become putrid, foul or offensive; or 
(e)  Cellars, vaults, privies, etc. To cause or permit any cellar, vault, cistern, drain, privy, yard or other premises whatsoever to become, from any cause, foul or offensive or injurious to the public health; or 
(f)  Stagnant water. To permit to be collected or to stand upon any premises any foul or stagnant water of any kind; or 
(g)  Stables and pigsties. To locate or maintain, or permit to exist or remain anywhere within the city any stable or pigsty; or 
(h)  Foul or noxious substances. To use, deposit or keep any property, substance or thing emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous or noxious odor, effluvia or stench particularly repulsive to the physical senses and which annoys, discomforts or endangers the welfare, health or safety of any person. 
(Ord. 2336, 5-16-89) 
State Law reference- Power of city to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
9-7-9. - Rubbish, dry grass. 
    It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and health and a nuisance for any person to cause or permit: 
(a)  Rubbish, rags, etc. The deposit or accumulation of any refuse, oily rags, rubbish or other materials or substances of any kind, so as to constitute a fire hazard; 
(b)  Dry grass, vegetation, etc. The deposit, accumulation, existence or growth upon any property of any dry or dead weeds, grass, vegetation or other like substances of any kind, so as to constitute a fire hazard; or 
(c)  The deposit, accumulation or existence of any refuse, including rubbish, garbage, bulky wastes or brush or other materials or substances in any waterway. 
(Ord. 2449, 8-7-90) 
9-7-10. - Petroleum products, explosives. 
    It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any person to cause or permit: 
(a)  Petroleum products. The accumulation or storage of any petroleum, naphtha, benzine, coal oil, gasoline, kerosene, turpentine or other petroleum products or inflammable fluids of any kind, in quantities greater than ten (10) gallons on the interior of or within fifty (50) feet of any building exclusively occupied as a residence; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to licensed gasoline service stations or to fuel used for heating the nearest adjacent residence. 
(b)  Explosives. The deposit, accumulation, storage or presence, within one hundred (100) yards of any building occupied as a residence or business, of any powder magazine, nitroglycerine, dynamite or other explosive substance of any kind. 
(Ord. 2336, 5-16-89) 
9-7-11. - Unsafe buildings. 
    It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any person to cause or permit the existence of any unsafe, dilapidated or otherwise insecure building, wall, stack, chimney, cornice, sign, awning or other like structure of any kind which, from manner of construction, age, condition or other circumstances, is or may become a menace to the safety of persons or property. 
Editor's note- For definition of "unsafe building" see § 4-3-1 of this Code. 
State Law reference- Power of city to define and demolish unsafe buildings. 
9-7-12. - Abandoned refrigerators. 
    It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any person to cause or permit the existence or storage in any place accessible to children of any abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox, ice chest, deep freeze or other airtight appliance or container of any kind, of a capacity of one and one-half (11/2) cubic feet or more, from which the lids, doors or other covers have not been removed, or which cannot be easily opened by a child, by means of pushing only, from the inside thereof. 
(1970 Code) 
State Law reference- Abandonment of refrigerators or iceboxes in places accessible to children, 720 ILCS 505/1. 
9-7-13. - Inoperable and unused motor vehicles. 
(a)  It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any person to cause, permit or allow the existence of any inoperable motor vehicle, any motor vehicle not regularly used, or any parts of a motor vehicle to exist or be stored upon any public or private property in view of the general public; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall apply to any motor vehicle or part thereof which is kept in a building, or to a motor vehicle or parts thereof completely on the premises of a duly licensed junkyard. 
(b)  "Inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle; (1) from which, for a period of at least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels, or other parts have been removed; or (2) on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, altered, damaged or otherwise treated so that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. Inoperable motor vehicle shall not include any motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. However, a motor vehicle upon which repairs or services are not concluded within seven (7) days from the date of the notice specified in subsection (c) shall not be deemed to be "rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations" and shall be construed to be an inoperable motor vehicle. 
(c)  "Motor vehicle not regularly used" means any motor vehicle which; (1) has not been driven off the premises where it is parked or stored under its own motor power for a period longer than four (4) months; (2) is not registered, licensed, or properly displaying registration plates or stickers as required under Article IV of Chapter 3 of the Illinois Vehicle Code; or (3) exhibits damaged parts or parts in disrepair, including, but not limited to, broken and missing windows, body panels with holes, and fluid leaks, which pose an open threat of injury or contamination for a period longer than fourteen (14) days. 
(d)  Whenever any police officer determines that a nuisance as declared in this section exists, the police officer shall cause a written notice to abate to be served upon the person who is causing, permitting or allowing the nuisance to exist. Said notice shall describe the inoperable motor vehicle, motor vehicle not regularly used, or motor vehicle parts and give the person served seven (7) days from the date of service of the notice to either abate the nuisance, or if an inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used, to request a hearing on the question of whether or not the described motor vehicle is an inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used, as the case may be, within the meaning of this section. Such notice shall be by means of personal service or by certified or registered mail. Personal service shall be by any police officer of the East Peoria Police Department or any person authorized by law to make personal service. If the person served with the written notice to abate fails to request a hearing within the seven-day period, it shall be presumed that the motor vehicle is an inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle not regularly used, as the case may be, and authorized officials of the city may proceed to abate the nuisance in the manner provided in this section. If the person served with the written notice to abate requests a hearing within the seven-day period, the director of planning and community development shall act as a hearing officer and shall schedule and conduct a hearing within thirty (30) days after receipt of the request for a hearing. Reasonable notice of the hearing shall be given to the person requesting the hearing. During any such hearing, any person interested in the described inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle not regularly used, and any representative of the city, may call witnesses and present evidence concerning the motor vehicle. Any party to the hearing may be represented by legal counsel at the expense of such party. The hearing officer shall within seven (7) days following the hearing make written findings of fact regarding the motor vehicle and determine whether or not the motor vehicle constitutes an inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle not regularly used within the meaning of this section. Such findings of fact and determination shall be served in the same manner as prescribed in this section for service of a notice to abate. If the hearing officer determines that the vehicle is an inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle not regularly used, then the notice to abate shall become effective from and after the date such determination is served on the person who requested the hearing. 
(e)  Any person who shall cause, permit or allow such a nuisance to continue or exist after the expiration of seven (7) days from the date of the notice to abate shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense. Each day that such nuisance continues or exists after the expiration of the aforesaid seven (7) days shall be deemed to be a separate offense. Further, each such inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used shall constitute a separate offense. 
(f)  Whenever any person causes, permits or allows such a nuisance to continue or exist after the expiration of seven (7) days from the service of the notice to abate, or effective date of the notice to abate if a hearing has been conducted as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the city may, at its option, cause the abatement of the nuisance specified in this section by the same method of disposal of abandoned vehicles provided in sections 11-5-14(C); 11-5-14(D); 11-5-15; 11-5-16; 11-5-17; 11-5-18; 11-5-19 and 11-5-20 herein. However, if the nuisance is located on property other than the public right-of-way or property in the possession or control of the city, the city shall, before abating the nuisance, obtain the consent of the person served with the notice to abate or an order from the Tazewell County Circuit Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction authorizing the abatement of the nuisance. Nothing in this section shall be construed as imposing upon the city a duty to abate the nuisance specified in this section. The action authorized by this section shall be in addition to and without waiver of any other remedies. 
(g)  A person shall fall within that class of persons who shall be deemed to cause, permit or allow such a nuisance to exist if such person: 
(1)  Has an ownership interest in or is in control of the inoperable motor vehicle; 
(2)  Causes the inoperable motor vehicle to be deposited at the site in question; 
(3)  Has an ownership interest in the real estate upon which the inoperable motor vehicle is located; 
(4)  Has an ownership interest in or operates a business which causes, permits or allows such a nuisance to exist on the real estate upon which the business is operated or on adjacent real estate which is under the control of the business owner or operator; or 
(5)  Has an ownership interest in real estate upon which a business is being operated and the operator or owner of said business causes, permits or allows such a nuisance to exist on the real estate upon which the business is being operated or on adjacent real estate which is under the control of the person having an ownership interest in real estate upon which said business is being operated. 
(Ord. 2243, 5-31-88; Ord. No. 3290, § 2, 6-5-01; Ord. No. 3690, § 1, 5-2-06; Ord. No. 3735, § 1, 3-20-07) 
State Law reference- Power of city to declare inoperative motor vehicle a nuisance, 65 ILCS 5/11-40-3; power of city to define, prevent, and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; and power of city to promote health or suppress disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5. 
9-7-14. - Dust, cinders. 
(a)  It is hereby declared a menace to the public health and a nuisance for any person to cause or permit any dirt, sand, gravel, cinders, ashes, earth or other similar materials to be hauled, moved, rolled, compacted, scraped, dragged or otherwise disturbed, including, but not limited to, causing or permitting such materials to be disturbed through the operation of a motor vehicle, so as to cause or permit dust to be raised, blown or stirred through the operation of machinery or otherwise, to the detriment of any person or property. 
(b)  Every person engaged in the hauling of any sand, dirt, cinders, ashes, earth or other similar materials or substances, or engaged in the moving, rolling, compacting, scraping, dragging or other disturbance of soil, and the like, shall make adequate provision as often as is required to arrest and prevent such dust through the use of salts, oil, chemicals and other materials used and recommended for retarding or eliminating such dust, subject to the supervision and approval of the director of public works. 
(c)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first offense, five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second offense, and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each additional offense. Each separate occurrence shall be deemed a new offense. 
(Ord. No. 3481, § 2, 1-2-04) 
State Law reference- Power of city to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
9-7-15. - Scaffolding, ladders. 
    It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any person: 
(a)  To erect or use, or to cause or permit to be erected or used, any insecure or unsafe scaffold or ladder whereby the safety of persons working thereon or passing thereunder may in any way be endangered. 
(b)  To place or leave, or to cause or permit to be placed or left, any tools or articles on any such scaffold or ladder in such manner that the same may fall into any street, sidewalk or other public way, whereby the safety of persons passing thereunder may in any way be endangered. 
9-7-16. - Notice to abate nuisance. 
(a)  Whenever any health or building official or inspector, or any police or fire officer, determines that a nuisance exists on any private property or premises, the proper city official shall cause an administrative ticket as provided in subsection 1-1-14(b) of this Code or a written notice to be served personally upon the owner or person in control of the property or premises who is causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance which administrative ticket or notice shall give the person served seven (7) days from the date of service of the administrative ticket or notice to abate the nuisance. Such service of an administrative ticket shall be deemed the equivalent of a notice to abate as described in this section. Such notice shall be by means of personal service of a copy of the complaint or by certified or registered mail of a copy of the complaint. Personal service shall be by any authorized inspector from the department of inspections or by any police officer of the police department or any person authorized by law to make personal service. 
(b)  Such notice shall fairly apprise such person of the nature of the nuisance, his duty to abate or remove the nuisance within the time provided therein, the penalty for the nuisance and failure to abate the same, and shall state that, if said nuisance is abated by the city, liability for the necessary expenses so incurred shall accrue as provided for in section 9-7-18 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 5, 3-19-96) 
State Law reference- Power of city to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
9-7-17. - Duty to abate; time limits. 
    It is hereby declared the duty of any person determined to have created, caused, erected, maintained or permitted a nuisance to exist within the city to discontinue and abate such nuisance within seven (7) days, or such other time period as may be specified in the administrative ticket or the notice, from the date the notice or ticket is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 6, 3-19-96) 
9-7-18. - Failure to abate; separate and recurring offense; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to neglect, refuse or otherwise fail to remove or abate any nuisance after expiration of the seven (7) days or other specified time period provided by notice thereof; and each twenty-four (24) hours, or fraction thereof, during which such nuisance continues or exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall cause, permit or allow a nuisance to continue or exist as provided for in subsection (a) above shall be subject to a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such offense. 
(Ord. No. 2754, § 7, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 3292, § 64, 7-3-01) 
9-7-19. - Abatement by city. 
    Whenever any nuisance is not abated by the owner, lessee or person in control of the premises or property affected within the time provided by notice, the proper city officer shall cause the abatement or removal of such nuisance. 
9-7-20. - Summary abatement by city when emergency or on public property. 
    Whenever any nuisance: (a) constitutes or is deemed to be an imminent or immediate danger to public health or safety; or (b) exists on public property, the proper city officer shall cause such nuisance to be summarily and immediately abated and removed, regardless of any five (5) day or other time period specified by notice to the person responsible therefor; provided, however, that in situation (a) above, such officer shall have first applied for and obtained the written permission of the mayor for such summary abatement. 
9-7-21. - Costs of abatement; debt of owner. 
(a)  Any costs or expenses of abatement reasonably incurred by the city pursuant to the provisions of sections 9-7-19 and 9-7-20 of this chapter, shall be deemed a debt to the city by the owner, lessee or person in control of premises upon which such nuisance existed; provided, that where specifically provided in this Code or by statute, such costs and expenses shall become a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city attorney to enforce by civil action any and all such debts or liens as provided for in subsection (a) of this section. 
(1970 Code) 
State Law reference- Power of city to control and eradicate Dutch Elm Disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-12; rat extermination, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-8; weeds 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7; power of city to demolish, repair, or enclose unsafe buildings, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1. 
9-7-22. - Nuisance property. 
(a)  It is hereby declared a menace to the public health and a nuisance and danger to the health, safety, welfare, peace and comfort of the city for any owner of real property to permit such property to become a nuisance property. 
(b)  Any owner of nuisance property shall be in violation of this chapter and subject to its remedies. 
(c)  Definitions. 
(1)  Nuisance property. Nuisance property shall be property upon which three (3) or more of the offenses listed below have occurred during any three hundred sixty-five-day period, as a result of any three (3) or more separate and distinct events: 
a.  Criminal housing management as defined in 720 ILCS 5/12-5.1 or a similar city ordinance; 
b.  Mob action as defined in 720 ILCS 5/25-1 or a similar city ordinance;
